In particular, Professor David Hill supplied moral support and encouraged my\nresearch with unwavering optimism.\nIn the scholarly area, I have drawn heavily on the time and patience\nof Professor Gyorgy Szonyi ofSzeged University. His meticulous critical\nreading of my text and his many helpful suggestions for its improvement\nhave contributed much to the final outcome, for which I am sincerely\ngrateful.\nI would also like to thank Professor Stanton J. Linden of Washington\nState University for his long-standing interest in and support of my alchemical studies.\nColleagues at Bretton Hall College directly engaged on this project\nwere Deborah Brooke who assisted with transcribing the textual content\nofKhunrath's illustrations, while Charles Holroyd provided graphics and\nhelped with the design of the book. Their hard work has been much\nappreciated. Thanks also to Jon Lucas for his help.\nThe staff of the following institutions have facilitated my research:\nAlnwick Castle archives, Northumbria; Bodleian Library, Oxford; Biblioteca Medicea-Laurenziana, Florence; Biblioteca Nazionale-Centrale,\nFlorence; British Library, London; Crawford Library, Edinburgh Royal\nObservatory; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge; Warburg Institute Library, London; Wellcome Institute Library, London; the Brotherton and\nEdward Boyle libraries at Leeds University; Bretton Hall College library.\nI am grateful for their assistance.\nMy family, friends and students have loyally supported me throughout this project, for which I thank them, especially Matylda and Halina.\nSzulakowska and my father Antoni.\n\nPages 8:\nINTRODUCTION\nFrom the mid-sixteenth to the late- seventeenth century, one of the most\nimportant metaphysical concepts in Western Europe was that of the divinity and generative power of light. At the heart of the Counter-Reformation, the Jesuits located the Eucharistic monstrance whose blazing\naura ofgold displayed the sacramental authority ofthe Church to reunite\nthe repentant sinner with God. Subsequently, this vision of the divine\nlight of the Holy Spirit, as the instrument of union with God, was expressed less doctrinally in the moderated pietism ofthe seventeenth century Cambridge Platonists. Such historical currents evolving a personalised interpretation of scripture, in which God and human were united\nthrough the indwelling light ofthe Spirit, rather than through the rites of\nthe Church, were strengthened in hermetic and neoplatonic circles bythe\nChristian cabbalah. This theosophical system envisaged God creating the\nworld out ofhis own divine luminosity; hence, for cabbalists, the universe\nwas not only pervaded by the divine light of God, it was united monistically to him.\nAlthough there has been much dispute among historians concerning\nthe specific role of hermetic theosophy in the development of Lutheran\npietism, scholars, such as Peuckert and Stoeffler, have acknowledged that\nan important contribution was made by radical theologians of the late\nsixteenth century, such as Valentin Weigel and Johannes Arndt, who\nwere influenced by Paracelsian cabbalism.2 Weigel and his followers began to produce their own interpretations of scripture in which the sacramental rituals of the Lutheran Church and its demands for political authority increasingly appeared superfluous and objectionable.\nMost historians have neglected the contribution of the alchemists to\nthese distinctive and revolutionary theological movements, at best mentioning in passing figures such as Heinrich Khunrath (1560-1605),\nMichael Maier (1568-1622) and Robert Fludd (1574-1637). Yet, their\nParacelsian- cabbalistic metaphysics of light revolutionised contemporary\nalchemical theory, even prompting its adepts to deploy the rays of the\nsun and the stars in their practical work. In turn, their alchemised theolMargaret Llasera, \"Concepts ofLight in the Poetry of Henry Vaughan\", The Seventeenth Century, 3, (1988): 47-61.\n2 Will-Erich Peuckert, Pansophie (Berlin: Erich Schmidt, 1956), 2, pp. 185-214, 290308;. F. Ernest Stoeffler, The Rise of Evangelical Pietism (Leiden: E. J. Brill, 1965), pp. 180208\n\nPages 9:\nXII\nINTRODUCTION\nXIII\nogy was a widely publicised and controversial contribution to the debates\nbetween the established Lutheran Church in Germany and the reformist\nmovements inspired by Melancthon and sponsored by Calvinist preachers in the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries.\nHistorians of alchemy have almost ignored the central role of the\nimagery of light in late sixteenth century Paracelsian alchemy, regarding\nthis as being a poetic expression of some vague mystical experience, or a\nflowery literary convention. Debus is one of the few to have discussed this\nParacelsian metaphysics of light in his extensive studies of Fludd's alchemy.3 More recently, Clulee has examined the natural philosophy ofthe\nElizabethan theurgist, John Dee (1527-1609), noting, in particular, Dee's\nuse ofscholastic optical theory in the astronomical magic ofhis Propaedeumata Aphoristica (1558). Clulee, however, did not relate Dee's astral theurgy to alchemy, nor to theosophy, since he did not consider Dee to be a\nParacelsian, although he acknowledged the innovatory significance of\nDee's cabbalism in his later alchemical treatise, the Monas Hieroglyphica\n(1564). Few other scholars have examined critically the references to\ncelestial light in late Renaissance alchemical texts and illustrations and\nmajor alchemists of the period, such as Khunrath and Maier, still await a\ndefinitive study.\nIn view of the fact that scholarly research into the alchemical discourse oflight is relatively little developed, the present study will attempt\nto redress this absence byfocusing on Renaissance ideas ofthe generative\npower ofthe light of the sun, stars and planets. Renaissance alchemists,\nsuch as Khunrath and Fludd, conceptualised the astral rays of light as\nbeing the agents ofthe \"anima Mundi\", the cosmic soul or \"Anthropos\",\nout of whose primeval substance, the quintessence or \"azoth\", the universe was generated. Cabbalistic alchemists, moreover, identified the cosmic Anthropos with Christ, whose sacred presence within the alchemical\nprocess transformed it into a sacramental act, paralleling that of the\nLutheran Eucharist.\nAlchemists, since hellenistic times, had relied on the effects of the\nstars, but a coherent theory ofthe astral virtues began to develop only in\nthe late fourteenth century, appearing in its full expression in the work of\nParacelsus ( 1493-1541). In addition, John Dee added his own distinctive\ncontribution to the sixteenth century theory ofthe generative stellar rays.\nThese alchemists provided the basic foundation for Khunrath's alchemi-\ncal deployment of light-rays and astral virtues, but Khunrath went beyond his original sources in uniting Paracelsian cabbalism with Weigel's\npietistic Christology, producing, thereby, an alchemical polemic expressing the concept of Christ as the philosopher's stone who transmuted the\nsoul through the light of Eternal Wisdom. Thus, by the early seventeenth\ncentury, the alchemical use of celestial rays and natural sun-light involved more than chemistry, since this practice was, in effect, a religious\nand theurgical ritual. Indeed, late Renaissance alchemists developed a\nconceptual structure which could be called an \"alchemy oflight\", a syncretic philosophy integrating the discrete intellectual and mystical currents of Pythagorean geometry, neoplatonism, medieval optics, Paracelsian alchemy and cabbalism.\nThe concept of the divinity of light had been transmitted from the\nmost ancient times to the late hellenistic philosopher Plotinus, as well as\nto various gnostic and hermetic groups, such as those connected with the\ntheosophical writings known to the Renaissance as the Pymander of\nHermes Trismegistus. In origins the term \"hermeticism\" referred to the\nlate hellenistic teachings ofTrismegistus and his followers, such as Asclepius. This theosophical system had emerged by the second century BC in\nEgypt, but at first it did not include alchemy which developed only during the first Christian centuries, alchemical literature being added to the\nearlier hermetic corpus by the second century AD. According to Copenhaver, these alchemical texts, as well as other magical treatises, are integrally related to the seventeen, purely theological, hermetic writings. He\nargues that eighteenth century scholars, prejudiced against occultism,\nhad made a false distinction between the various components of the corpus which would have been meaningless to the contemporary followers of\nthe original school of thought. Consequently, hermeticism is not only a\ntheosophical system, but also a practical theurgy.\nThe development of hermeticism was historically distinct from that of\nneoplatonism and it had been ruthlessly criticised by Plotinus for its superstitious practices and inconsistent theological structures. Nevertheless,\nRenaissance philosophers, such as Ficino, disregarded Plotinus' animosity\ntowards the hermeticists and they accomodated both systems within their\nvision of a \"prisca theologia\" anticipating the Christian religion.5 Plotinus' sophisticated theogony of light was received by medieval Western\nphilosophers in the moderated Christian versions of Pseudo-Dionysos\nand St.Augustine. In the fifteenth century, as a result ofthe recovery and\n3 Allen G. Debus, \"The Sun in the Universe ofRobert Fludd\", Le Soleil a la renaissance\n(Brussels, 1965).\n4 Nicholas Clulee, John Dee's Natural Philosophy (London; New York: Routledge, 1988).\n5 For discussion of the hermetic corpus see Brian P. Copenhaver, Hermetica (Cambridge University Press, 1992), pp. xxxii-l.\n\nPages 10:\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\ntranslation of the neoplatonic and hermetic Greek texts, the Florentine\nhumanist Marsilio Ficino began to promote the use of astral rituals in a\nmedical and psychological context. His younger contemporary Pico della\nMirandola, like Ficino, integrated these practices with Christianity, butin\naddition he introduced the cabbalah into Renaissance hermeticism.6\nThe German natural philosopher and magus Cornelius Agrippa\n(1486-1533) popularised astral magic through his treatise, De Occulta\nPhilosophia (1533), justifying such practices by claiming the existence of a\nnatural sympathy between the human-being and the universe, an idea\nalready well-known to the middle ages. On the model of Agrippa, this\nvenerable notion of the harmony between celestial and human realms\nwas systematised for medical use by Paracelsus who created an analogical\nstructure known as the \"doctrine of signatures\". He taught that in all\nmaterial entities there existed hidden virtues whose qualities corresponded to those ofthe planetary bodies in the heavens. These occult virtues he\ncalled \"astra\" to designate the \"signatures\" (the impressions) of the stars\non matter. Paracelsus argued that, due to the intimate unity between\nheaven and earth, alchemical processes had to be correlated with the\nmovements ofthe planetary bodies and the fixed stars. Through Ficino,\nAgrippa and Paracelsus, John Dee encountered the theory of astral influences which provided him with the foundation for his own naturalphilosophy, medicine and practical magic. In fact, it was Dee's ambition to\ndevise a more efficient way ofexploiting stellar and solar radiations in all\naspects of human endeavour, but most especially in medicine and alchemy.\nIn addition to his interest in astrological sympathetic magic, there was\nanother, very unusual, influence on Dee's alchemy which was of equal\nimportance to his hermetic sources, namely, optics , the medieval scholastic science of light. In his Propaedeumata Aphoristica (1558) Dee used this\npragmatic body of knowledge for more esoteric purposes. Specifically,\nby means ofcatoptrics (the reflection and refraction of light-rays by mirrors and lenses), Dee thought that celestial rays could be manipulated\nmore reliably to enhance all aspects of human affairs. The metaphysical\nrationale for Dee's astronomical and optical magic was provided bythe\ncabbalah, which he integrated into his alchemy in the 1560s. His fully\ndeveloped system of natural philosophy was published in the Monas Hieroglyphica (1564) which combined optics, geometry, magic, alchemy, medicine and cabbalism.8\nDee's last published treatise was the Mathematicall Preface to Henry\nBillingsley's translation of Euclid's Principles of Geometry (1570). Although\nthis essay has not been related to alchemy by Dee's scholars, nonetheless,\nitmay have been an additional influence on Maier, Khunrath and Fludd.\nIn the Mathematicall Preface Dee examined Pythagorean geometry in its\npractical and mystical aspects, although he did not relate his text to\nalchemy at any length, mentioning only briefly a practice called \"Archemastrie\" which comprised alchemy and other magical arts (Math. Pref.\nf. Aiijr). In addition, another of his concepts in this treatise, that of\"zographie\", could have had a special effect on alchemical illustration (Math.\nPref. f. dijv). \"Zographie\" was a Pythagorean-based method of graphic\ndepiction which Dee regarded as a conceptual art-form with a high philosophical status, since the \"zographer\" drew only the forms ofthe eternal\nIdeas in the mind of God, rather than their base natural copies. Most\nsignificant for the present argument was Dee's inclusion of the singlepoint perspective system within the scope of \"zographie\".\nIt should be noted that in 1595 there appeared in Khunrath's Amphiteatrum Sapientiae Aeternae (frontispiece) an illustration which employed exaggerated spatial effects. The peculiarly deep vista of this engraving ofan\nalchemist's Oratory-Laboratory involved far more than naturalistic illusionism, since the spatial geometry functioned as a semiotic system in its\nown right, discoursing on the alchemical significance of light-rays.\nAccording to Goldberg, fifteenth century Florentine painters such as\nMasaccio and Domenico Veneziano had used geometrical infrastructures, such as the one in Khunrath's treatise, both as an organisational\ndevice and as a signifying discourse (fig. 36).10 These graphic scaffoldings\nunderlay the painted scene, operating as a conceptual sub-text which\ndrew the viewer into a parallel metaphysical world. In order to clarify\nthis interpretation of Khunrath's image of the laboratory, Goldberg's\n6 Martin Plessner and Felix Klein-Franke (Marsilio Ficino), De Triplici Vitae libri tres\n(1489) (Hildesheim; New York, 1978) esp Ch 3 \"De Vita coelitus comparanda\" (no\npagination); Giovanni Pico della Mirandola, Conclusiones nongentae in omni genere scientiarum\n(pr. IB, 1532).\n7 Wayne Shumaker, John Dee on Astronomy. Propaedeumata Aphoristica (1558 and 1568)\n(Berkeley; Los Angeles; London: University of California Press, 1978).\n8 C. H.Josten,\"Atranslation ofJohn Dee's \"Monas Hieroglyphica\" (Antwerp, 1564)\",\nAmbix , 12 (1964): 84-221 and in Lazarus Zetzner, Theatrum Chemicum, (Strassburg, 1622),\n2, pp. 191-230 and (1659), pp. 178-215 .\nAllen G. Debus (introd.), John Dee. The Mathematicall Preface (New York: Science History10 Publications, 1975).\nJonathan Goldberg, \"Quattrocento Dematerialization: Some paradoxes in a Conceptual Art\",Journal ofAesthetics and Art Criticism, 35 (1976): 153-68.\nXIV\nXV\n\nPages 11:\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\nmodel can be amplified by taking additional recourse to Peirce's semiotic\ntaxonomy of three types ofsign, namely, those of symbol, icon and index.\nFirst, however, it is necessary to understand the original intentions behind the development of the single-point perspective system during the\nearly Renaissance.11\nThe geometrical theory of this spatial system was first expressed by\nLeone Battista Alberti in his treatise on painting, De Pictura (Florence,\n1435).12 He had explained that the orthogonal lines of any architecture\nillustrated by the artist should be drawn as if they were running into the\npicture to meet in a single vanishing-point. In accordance with this new\npictorial convention, in many fifteenth-century Florentine paintings ofan\ninterior scene the floor would be drawn in a chequer-board pattern to\nreinforce the same illusion of space receding to a vanishing-point. The\ntechnical term for this pictorial effect was the \"pavimentum diminutionis\" (fig. 1).13\nAlberti had based his perspective system on the model of medieval\noptical diagrams which depicted the operation of light-rays in relation to\nthe human eye (figs . 2, 11). Hence, in the semiotic functioning of the\nsingle -point system, its geneology in medieval optics continues to operate\nas a sub-text. To use Derrida's terms, the original opticalgeometrywhich\nhad provided the structure for single-point space continued to exist within it as a signifying trace. 14 Derrida's \"trace\" (le trait) is the transcendental\nsignifier unifying the disparate (and conflicting) elements of a discourse. 15\nHence, the generic signifier of the single-point perspective system would\nbe the eye ofthe viewer and its discourse that of the struggle between the\nrhetorical devices ofthe picture and the objective judgement ofthe interpretant.\nThe visual strategy of perspective space acquired a deeper spiritual\nsignificance in the context of Khunrath's alchemical illustration in which\nthe generic signifier was transposed from the viewer's eye to that ofGod,\nwho regarded the scene from a viewing-point transcending the space of\nboth the physical world and of its pictorial copy. Khunrath's spatial con-\nstruction, thereby, acquired a \"second-level signification\" in Barthes\nterms. Although the spatial geometry continued to function with its original significatory purpose (that is, producing the visual illusion ofspace),\nit had additionally accumulated other levels of meaning from a network\nof pre-existing symbols.16 In fact, the function of optical geometry in\nalchemy may have been related to that ofreligious Christian imagery, as\na sympathetic magic drawing the viewer into the presence of God (frontispiece). Alberti in De Pictura had been interested in the use ofrhetorical\ndevices in painting and he had modelled his pictorial system on the\npersuasive techniques of Cicero and Quintillian. Hence, Alberti's perspectival construction aimed to promote such an effective illusion of reality that the viewer, automatically convinced by the visual text, would\nsurrender his resistance to its implications.17\nTaking the present analysis still deeper into the field ofsemiotics, the\nsignificatory mode of single-point perspective can be defined as that of\nthe metonym, or index, in Peirce's terms.18 As a signifying mode, this\ntype of space was intended to persuade the viewer that physical reality\ncontinued into the picture, progressing, in the case of Khunrath's engraving, to its culmination in the eye of God (frontispiece). In alchemical\nillustration this discursive visual mode provided a demonstrative proof of\nalchemical claims that matter could be united with its opposite, spirit, in\nthe philosopher's stone. In Khunrath's image, however, there was more\nat stake, as will be discussed, for he employed this spatial rhetoric of the\ndivine presence in order to authenticate his pietistic alchemical theosophy.\nIt was Khunrath, in fact, who produced a fully-developed cabbalistic\n\"alchemy of light\" in three of his works, published as the Amphiteatrum\nSapientiae Aeternae (1595; 1609), Chaos (circa 1598) and De Igne Magorum\n(circa 1602-1604). For his cabbalistic ideas Khunrath relied on Johannes\nReuchlin in De verbo mirifico (1494) and De arte cabbalistica (1517), as well as\non Paracelsian theosophy. The central Jewish cabbalistic text, the Zohar,\nhad derived its metaphysical concepts from neoplatonism, specifically\nfrom Plotinus' account of the manner in which the divine light of the\nFirst Principle had emanated the world from its own being. Khunrath's\ncabbalistic alchemy was centred on the theme of divine light as the Paracelsian \"azoth\" which, in turn, was Christ himself. He was not the first to\nXVI\nCharles Hartshorne and Paul Weiss, Collected Papers of Charles Sanders Peirce, 2 (Cambridge: Harvard UP, 1932), pp. 156-73.\n1213 See Cecil Grayson (L. B. Alberti) Onpainting and on sculpture(London: Phaidon, 1972).\nJohn White, The Birth and Rebirth ofPictorial Space (London: Faber, 1957), pp. 113-34,\nesp. 121-26; Michael Kubovy, The Psychology ofPerspective and Renaissance Art (Cambridge\nUniversity Press, 1986), pp. 17-31.\n14 Kubovy, pp. 17-31 .\n15 Jacques Derrida, The Truth in Painting (University of Chicago, 1987), pp. 191-98;\nJacques Derrida, L'Ecriture et la difference (Paris: Seuil, 1967), pp. 41-44, 409-11.\nXVII\n16 Roland Barthes, Mythologies (Paris: Seuil, 1957), pp. 109-59.\n17 Kubovy, pp. 166-72. See also James S. Ackerman, \"Alberti's Light\" in Irving Lavin\nandJohn Plummer, Studies in Late Medieval and Renaissance Painting in Honour ofMillard Meiss\n(New York, 1978), pp. 1-27.\n18 Peirce, 2, pp. 170-72.\n\nPages 12:\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\napply cabbalism to alchemy, since Joannes Pantheus of Venice had devised a comparable system in his Voarchadumia (1530) and Dee had also\nproduced a cabbalistic alchemy in the Monas Hieroglyphica (1564). Khunrath, however, placed his cabbalism within a Christological framework,\nso much so, that his main concern from 1595 was not alchemical theory,\nbut pietistic Christian theology, anticipating, perhaps, the alchemical\nmysticism of Jacob Boehme.\nKhunrath may have developed his Christological alchemy in the mid1590s, both as a response to anti-Christian tendencies within German\nhermetic circles and also as an expression of a pietistic Lutheranism\nwhich was critical of the doctrinaire, institutionalised creed of the time.\nHis work, thus, belongs to the diverse ideological currents of the late\nsixteenth and early seventeenth centuries which, subsequently, manifested as the \"Rosicrucian\" movement. The supporters of the \"Rosicrucian\nManifestos\" (1614; 1615) were a heterogeneous mix of reformist Lutherans, hermeticists, neoplatonists and practitioners of Agrippan and Paracelsian theurgy. Although many devoted Protestants , such as Maier and\nFludd, polemicised on behalf of the Rosicrucians, there were also pagan\nand non-Christian influences within the movement related to the chiliasm ofSimon Studion, Julius 19Sperber, Christoph Besold and Tobias Hess\nin the late sixteenth century.\"\nAccording to Yates, it was Dee's travels in central Europe in the 1580s\nwhich had stimulated the reformist currents that later emerged as the\nRosicrucian brotherhood (the Protestant version of the Jesuit order).20\nYates was not altogether accurate in her assessment of Dee's conceptual\ninfluences on central Europe, for, not only did cabbalistic, hermeticist\nand Paracelsian ideas pre-exist Dee's presence in that region, but, moreover, the so-called \"Protestant front\" itself was deeply riven by the disputes between Lutherans and Calvinists and further complicated by the\nantagonism of the doctrinaire theologians towards the pietists and theosophists.21\nIn fact, Yates' account of the origins and influence ofJohn Dee on the\ndevelopment of Renaissance science, philosophy and theurgy, has been\nquestioned by various scholars, such as Westman, Vickers and Sherman.\nMost especially, historians of the scientific revolution have attempted to\ndisconnect its origins from those of Yates' proto-Rosicrucian circles.22\nFurthermore, Yates' alignment of the Protestant cause with hermeticism was countered by scholars eager to distance Lutheranism from such\nobjectionable associates. In particular, Montgomery, adopting a conservative Lutheran perspective, argued for the negative effects ofhermeticism\non the reformed Church in Germany. He refuted Yates' interpretation of\nthe Rosicrucians as being the esoteric outpost ofthe Protestant reformed\nchurch, especially removing the theologian Johann Valentin Andreae\n(1586-1654) from that context. Montgomery, in fact, developed a contrary argument to Yates, considering that neoplatonic and hermetic literature had inspired the educated German elite to devise a paganistic system, decentering Christ from his redemptive role in human salvation.23\nIn this line ofthinking he concurred with Frick (though from a different\nideological standpoint) who had demonstrated the inherited links between Paracelsian theology and pagan hellenistic esotericism . Frick had\nalso emphasised the continuation of medieval chiliasm in Weigel's theology and in that of the Rosicrucians, particularly that ofJoachim ofFiore,\nwho in the thirteenth century had predicted the coming of the third age\nof the creation, that of the Holy Spirit, replacing the second age of the\nSon in which the institutionalised Church had controlled Christian doctrine. In the third age, Fiore had taught, each person would be guided by\nthe inner word of God written on their soul, instead of by external\ncreeds. This brief period of time would be followed immediately by the\nend ofthe world and the last judgement.24\nXVIII\n19 Carlos Gilly(ed), Cimelia Rhodostaurotica (Amsterdam: In de Pelikaan, 1988), pp. 6390. See also Carlos Gilly, \"Iter Rosicrucianum\" in Das Erbe des Christian Rosenkreuz (Amsterdam: In der Pelikaan, 1995), pp. 21, 50-52, 70-72, 138-45.\n20 Yates, Frances A., The Rosicrucian Enlightenment (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul,\n1st printed 1972; reprint 1986), passim.\n21 Stoeffler, The Rise ofEvangelical Pietism (1965), pp . 15ff, 109ff, 180-246. See also WillErich Peuckert, Die Grosse Wende (Hamburg: Claassen and Goverts, 1948), pp. 299-474.\nXIX\n22 An over-view of these debates may be obtained in Stephen Clucas (ed), John Dee:\nInter-disciplinary Approaches (Dordrecht; London; New York: Kluwer, 1999), especially\nGyorgy Szonyi's summary of the arguments in his paper, \"Ars Sintrilla, Scrying and the\nUniversal Language. Paracelsian and Other Contexts forJohn Dee's Angelic Magic\". See\nalso Robert S. Westman, \"Magical Reform and Astronomical Reform: The Yates Thesis\nReconsidered\" in Lynn White (ed.), Hermeticism and the Scientific Revolution (Los Angeles:\nUCLA, 1977) and Brian Vickers, \"Frances Yates and the Writing of History\", Journal of\nModern History, 51 (1979): 287-316. William H. Sherman discusses these and other views\nin his John Dee (Amherst: Univ ofMassachusetts Press, 1995).\n23 John Warwick Montgomery, Cross and Crucible, 2 vols (The Hague: Martinus Nijhoff,\n1973), 1, pp. 210-11.\n24 Karl R. H. Frick, Die Erleuchteten. Gnostisch-theosophische und alchemistisch-rosenkreuzerische\nGeheimgesellschaften (Graz: Akademische Druck, 1973), pp. 112-63. See also Fritz Saxl,\n\"Pagan Sacrifice in the Italian Renaissance\", JWCI (1938-39): 346-63; Vittoria Perrone\nCompagni , \"La magia ceremoniale del \"Picatrix\" nel Rinascimento\", Atti dell' Academiadi\nScienze Morali e Politiche , 88 (1977): 279-330. A standard authority on this subject is Aby\nWarburg, \"La Rinascita del Paganesimo Antico\" in Gesammelte Schrifte (London: Warburg,\n1966).\n\nPages 13:\nXXI\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\nDisregarding Montgomery's denial of Andreae's participation in these\nmovements, Dickson in his recent study ofthe secret societies ofthe early\nseventeenth century has returned to Yates' original contention that the\nRosicrucian Manifestos known as the Fama (1614) and Confessio (1615)\nemerged from Andreae's circle at the University of Tubingen.25 Andreae's subsequent negativity towards the Rosicrucians in his later years had\nbeen cited by Montgomery as proof that he had always been averse to\nthe hermeticists. Dickson , in contrast, favours a different view which is\nthat Andreae was eventually compelled by the need to distinguish between his youthful goals of a socially- and politically-responsible Christian brotherhood and the materialistic drive for power of those who had\nsubmitted\nto the delirium of cabbalism, alchemy and chiliastic prophe26\ncy.2\nIn this aim, Andreae's position was similar to that of Khunrath, since\nboth had been influenced by Weigel, as well as by Arndt. Nonetheless,\nKhunrath was also finally rejected by Andreae, due to his cabbalistic\nalchemical terminology which Andreae found absurd. There may, in\nfact, have been another, more paradoxical, reason for Andreae's animosity towards him, which was that Khunrath could have been in dispute\nwith Tobias Hess. Yates, Gilly and Dickson are in agreement concerning\nAndreae's earlier connections with hermeticist magi, in particular, with\nHess with whom he maintained contact through-out his life. Andreae\neven justified Hess' probity in the Mythologiae Christianae (1619), although\nin this work he castigated most of the other proto -Rosicrucians.27 Khunrath, on the other hand, for all his cabbalistic paraphenalia, may have\nconflicted with Hess over the latter's promotion of Studion's chiliastic\nNaometria, a text whose Christian content was slim, leading Khunrath to\nsuspect him ofpaganistic magical practices.\nIn view of such evidence concerning disputes between members of\nhermetic circles in the 1590s to 1620s, a more specific account is required\noftheir ideologies and affiliations. Scholars, for example, have neglected\nto analyse Khunrath's specific involvement with these esoteric groups,\nbeing content to follow uncritically Yates' view of him as one of the most\nsignificant influences on the evolution of Rosicrucian ideas,28 despite the\nfact that Montgomery had denied this. The most valid assessment of\nKhunrath's career probably, lies mid-way between these two scholarly\nassessments. Certainly, after his death, Khunrath's work was co-opted by\nothers into the Rosicrucian canon, but this does not automatically demonstrate his ideological kinship with all ofthe Rosicrucians. For, although\nKhunrath in his writings and visual imagery, like other hermeticists, expresses a critical attitude towards scholastic Lutherans, nevertheless, he\ndid not reformulate Lutheran theology into an esoteric sub-species, in the\nmanner of Studion and Hess, for whom Paracelsus and cabbalism\nseemed to hold as much authority as Christian doctrine. Instead, Khunrathused these esoteric systems to develop a pietistic Lutheranism, based\non Weigel, in which the historical figure of Christ and the Lutheran\nEucharist were retained both in their conventional doctrinal forms, as\nwell as being used as emblems of individual spiritual experience. Although his interpretation of the sacraments may have ran counter to the\ndogmatic claims of the Church as the sole administrator of God's grace,\nnonetheless, he was adopting a relatively mediatory position, like Weigel\nand Arndt, rather than rejecting the Church altogether.\nIn the second halfof the sixteenth century, alongside the deregulating\nforces of Philippism and Calvinism which threatened orthodox hegemonies, the esoteric philosophies promoted at the University of Tubingen\nwere an assisting factor. There is no doubt that Agrippa, Paracelsus and\nthe cabbalah offered their followers an increasingly self-determined spiritual and political authority. Hence, Khunrath's writings present a broad\npicture both ofthese extremist spiritual factions who found their expression outside the doors ofthe Lutheran Church, as well as ofthe pressures\non the pietists within its communion exerted by dogmatic Lutherans who\ncondemned as heresy any deviation from institutionalised beliefs. There\nremains little original documentation on Khunrath which could prove\nconclusively the exact nature of his political affiliations, but his writings\nprovide strong evidence that he was engaged in a two-pronged resistance,\nagainst both the paganistic theurgists and the scholastic Churchmen,\nthereby opening himself to attacks on all fronts.\nWhen the Rosicrucian movement emerged publically in 1614 and\n1615, Khunrath's alchemy was appropriated into the Rosicrucian canon\nby some ofits most earnest supporters, such as Michelspacher and Fludd,\nbut there is evidence that not all ofthe Rosicrucians regarded Khunrath\nso favourably. Moreover, few of the later alchemists related the figure of\nChrist integrally to their alchemical discourse in the manner of Khunrath, whose writing was aimed primarily at a pietistic, German community, rather than at a general European audience.\nThe present study will concentrate on the intellectual and spiritual\nconcerns ofthe 1590s to 1620s, using Khunrath's Amphiteatrum Sapientiae\nXX\n25 Donald R. Dickson, The Tessera ofAntilia (Leiden: Brill, 1998), pp. 32-36.\n26 Dickson, pp. 62-88.\n27 Gilly (ed), Cimelia Rhodostaurotica ( 1988), pp. 63-90; Gilly, \"Iter Rosicrucianum\"\n(1995), pp. 21, 50-52, 70-72, 138-45.\n28 Yates, Rosicrucian Enlightenment (1986), pp. 59-69, 91-92, 140-55.\n\nPages 14:\nXXII\nINTRODUCTION\nAeternae (1595; 1609) as a focal-point in analysing the rhetorical practices\nof Paracelsian theosophists, specifically their use of certain types of visual\nillustration. Since it is not possible to examine all the major alchemists of\nthe late Renaissance, the discussion will be confined to the cabbalistic\nmetaphysics and optical alchemy of four central figures, those of Dee,\nKhunrath, Maier and Fludd.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE\nALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nPrevious studies of Renaissance alchemical imagery have rarely involved\na discussion of its semiotic aspects, yet, without such an analysis it is\ndifficult to establish the exact role ofvisual illustration within a particular\ncontext. In the present case-studies, a variety of analytical tools is used\ndrawn from linguistics, structuralism and post-structuralism, such an eclectic approach being justified in the current state of research. For the\nimmediate objective, the most effective model has proved to be Peirce's\ntaxonomy of three fundamental types of sign, namely, those of symbol,\nicon and index. In addition, other types of analysis have been sampled,\nsuch as Piaget's structuralism, as well as the post-structuralist critiques of\nBarthes, Foucault and Derrida, although this selection by no means exhausts the possible critical methods for the study of alchemical imagery.\nSzonyi is one of the very few scholars who, at this time, has provided a\nstructuralist analysis of alchemical illustration in his investigation ofmandalic structures in alchemical engravings of the seventeenth century, as\nwell as in his semantic study ofJohn Dee's theurgy.\nIn the case of late sixteenth century imagery involving optical diagrams , perspectival geometry and architectural designs there are some\nparticularly difficult problems of interpretation (frontispiece and figs. 23,\n30, 41), for, as Goldberg has demonstrated, the stylistic conflict between\nnaturalism and abstraction in an image produces an ambiguous space.\nRenaissance imagery whose discursive programme inter-relates alchemy to optical theory may have been an attempt to produce a visual\nmetonym, or, in Peirce's terms, an indexical affinity between reality and\n1 Gyorgy Szonyi, \"The Powerful Image: Towards a Typology of Occult Symbolism\",\nEuropean Iconography East and West (Leiden: Brill, 1996), pp. 250-63. See also Szonyi, \"Ars\nSintrilla\"in Clucas (ed), John Dee (1999), passim and his paper, \"Architectural Symbolism\nand Fantasy Landscapes in Alchemical and Occult Discourse: Revelatory Images', Glasgow Emblem Studies, 3 (University of Glasgow, 1998), pp. 49-69. Other attempts to analyse\nalchemical imagery in structuralist terms were Urszula Szulakowska, \"Geometry and\nOptics in Renaissance Alchemical Illustration\", Cauda Pavonis, n.s. 14, 1 (1995): 1-12 and\nU. Szulakowska, \"Two Italian alchemical manuscripts: some philosophical problems:\nmonism and dualism\" in Didier Kahn, Sylvain Matton, Alchimie: art, histoire et mythes (Paris;\nMilan, 1995), pp. 249-63.\n2 Goldberg (1976).\n\nPages 15:\n2\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nthe illusionistic world of the picture. In Peirce's semiotic system, he has\ndistinguished an indexical sign from a \"symbol\" , which has an arbitrary\nvisual appearance unrelated to its conceptual content and, therefore, can\nonly convey a meaning within a specific context for a particular interpretant. Peirce also differentiated an indexical sign from an \"icon\" which,\nhe stated, \"would possess the character which renders it significant, even\nthough its object had no existence\". According to this definition , it\nwould initially appear that most alchemical visual signs should be termed\n\"iconic\", since they signify irrational concepts such as the \"union of opposites\", for example, offire with water. While this identification may be\ncorrect in the case of pre-Renaissance alchemical visual signs which are\nnot particularly \"realistic\" in their style of drawing (figs . 9, 10), this is not\napplicable to alchemical illustration from the late sixteenth century onwards when an irrational idea may be represented by naturalistic human\nfigures, as in examples from Maier's Atalanta Fugiens (figs. 40, 41). In this\ncase, the realistic aesthetic of the Renaissance artist has started to transform an iconic signifier into an index. This issue has never been remarked by the few iconologists who have studied alchemical imagery,\nnonetheless, it is extremely important since stylistic differences in the\nappearance of any visual sign change both its meaning and function. In\nfact, Peirce devised a taxonomy of hybrid signs to describe the vacillations of such unstable significatory orders.\nFollowing his general approach, the present author would make only\none proposition which is that many late Renaissance alchemical signs\nincline towards the indexical mode. In other words, alchemical visual\nsemiosis from the late sixteenth century is deliberately \" contaminated\"\nnot, as Jung believed, by the collective unconscious of a society,5 but by\nthe viewer's imminent physical reality. Thus, the alchemical imagery\nunder present consideration does not merely copy, it also restructures the\nphysical world by forcing a continuum between the viewer's space and\nthat of the picture.\nPeirce defined the index as\nA sign, or representation, which refers to its object not so much because of\nany similarity or analogy with it, nor because it is associated with general\ncharacters which that object happens to possess, as because it is in dynamical\n3\n(including spatial) connection both with the individual object ... and with the\nsenses or memory ofthe person for whom it serves as a sign.\nThus, an index is not a simulacrum \"more real than real\", for it is intended to be an uninterrupted continuation of the real, a deliberately composed ambiguity concealing the distinction between reality and artifice.\nAnother unsatisfactory aspect of current alchemical research is that\nscholars use the same type of analysis for both visual imagery and written\ntext, with more historical research being directed at the literary texts, in\npreference to the visual imagery. Perhaps it would yield more profitable\nresults to regard visual and verbal signs as autonomous dialects of the\nsame language, thus requiring different critical approaches. It was Panofsky who first argued for a new type of analytical tool for the study of\nvisual imagery which would be distinct from that ofliterary scholarship.\nHis iconological method involved an examination of the historical context in which a visual sign had appeared, for it was this which had determined the style of its depiction. As Szonyi has demonstrated in his study\nof Agrippa's and Dee's esoteric emblems, Panofsky's method is one ofthe\nfew able to accomodate the complexity of a visual signing-system. Szonyi\nalso continues to favour the historiographical approach of Gombrich,\nwhich has the added advantage of taking into account the psychological\neffects ofthe rhetoric deployed by a visual sign.\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",\nwhereby it delivers all of its information to the interpretant synchronically. Hence, it requires a broader range of semiotic strategies to correlate\nthe various paradigmatic levels of meaning. The written text, in contrast,\nis deciphered by the reader in a diachronic sequence and, hence, it is far\nmore dictatorial towards its interpretant than the visual artefact. Consequently, alchemical illustrators , like other Renaissance artists, capitalised\non thefactthat the synchronic reading of a visual text caused ambiguities\nto arise in the reception of its meaning. An additional semiotic difference\nbetween visual and literary texts is that visual imagery may be symbolic,\niconic or indexical, but most literary texts can only be symbolic. It is rare,\nin fact, to encounter a linguistic metonymic or indexical structure, although the compilers ofRenaissance grimoires struggled to produce such\nsigns, on the model of the Hebrew alphabet, as an essential part oftheir\n3 Peirce, 2, pp. 170, 172-73.\n4 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n5 Carl GustavJung, Psychology and Alchemy (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1993),\npp. 26, 112, 152ff, 158, 196.\n6 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n7 For example, Allison Coudert, Alchemy: the philosopher's stone (London: Wildwood\nHouse, 1980). Otherwise, this is an authoritative general study.\n8 Erwin Panofsky, Studies in Iconology (New York: Harper, 1962).\n9 Szonyi (1996), pp. 250-53.\n\nPages 16:\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nmagical rituals.10These experiments with cryptography yielded few convincing results, since the linguistic signs of European languages are arbitrary phonetic symbols and, hence, cannot mirror their conceptual representant in the manner of visual signs. Consequently, it is essential that\nscholars of alchemical imagery distinguish between the literary and the\nvisual components of an alchemical treatise. Moreover, certain types of\nalchemical illustration are capable of functioning almost entirely as a\nvisual text, that is, as metonymic, or indexical, structures, as in the case of\none of Khunrath's illustrations (frontispiece). In such metonymic visual\nimages there is an implied physical continuity between the world ofthe\nviewer and that of the picture. In these instances, the reception of the\npicture's message does not need to be deferred until it can be decoded in\na linguistic form. In such sophisticated metonymic-indexical images the\nvisual structure is the essence ofthe meaning communicated to the viewer. This indexical quality of an image is not necessarily dependent onthe\nartist's use of naturalistic motifs (as Peirce had pointed out), since diagrammatic structures may also be indexical. It is more a question ofthe\npractical function of a specific visual image. Hence, pseudo-Lullian diagrams, as mobile computers, are indexical (figs. 4-7), whereas Pantheus'\nstatic, neo-Lullian structure is merely symbolic (fig. 8).\nIn this sense,John Dee's mobile cypher of the Monas is the epitome of\nthe visual index (figs. 17, 18), perhaps influencing Khunrath's artist, Jan\nVredeman de Vries, to create a more complex version of its metonymic\nstructure (frontispiece). Some of Fludd's cosmological depictions also\nhave indexical qualities, although his illustrations are difficult to categorise, since an image may involve several different types ofsemiotic mode\n(figs. 44-50). At first glance, Fludd's diagrams appear to be symbolic\n(merely illustrating his text), but, in fact, they also have an iconic aspect,\nsince they can be isolated from their textual context while retaining most\noftheir meaning. In addition, as indexical generators of a contemplative\ntype of alchemy, some of Fludd's pictures were meant to integrate the\nviewer into their imaginary world, causing a spiritual and intellectual\nalchemy to ocurr in the moment of viewing the image (fig. 50).\nThere was a similar intention underlying many other seventeenth century alchemical illustrations, whose ever-increasing complexity of structure was designed for lengthy perusal, eventually eliminating the physical\naspects of alchemy altogether. Michelspacher's Cabala (Augsburg, 16151616) is one of the earliest of these imaginative alchemies , luring the\nviewer through the glass ofhis four fiery and jewel-like \"mirrors\" into the\nhigher intellectual and spiritual realms of the alchemical discourse (fig.\n23). When the viewer emerged from the trance-like state induced by\nparticipation in Michelspacher's visions, he was (perhaps) transformed,\nlike base matter, into spiritual gold. Effectively, alchemical illustration in\nthe seventeenth century was usurping the transmutatory function of the\nphilosopher's stone. The sophisticated graphic repertoire of Renaissance\nartists enabled them to manipulate the semantics of their pictorial elements , producing imagery which could induce meditative, or visionary,\nstates in their viewers, uniting them with the depicted visions.\nAt least, this seems to have been the general aim. From this point of\nview, most late Renaissance alchemical illustrations could be interpreted\nas being indexical in their intention. The origins of this persuasive illustrative enterprise can be found in the late fourteenth century, as willbe\ndiscussed in the next chapter, but the immediate inspiration for the seventeenth century artist would have been the engravings made for Khunrath's Amphiteatrum in 1595 and 1602 (figs. 29-35). These may have been\ncirculated publically in isolation from the treatise itself (although the images do incorporate their own texts). Apart from their iconic function as\npolemical discourses, they could also have been used for contemplative\nexercises. In the first version of the Amphiteatrum of 1595, the circular\nform of the engravings may signify that they are intended to be \"mirrors\", evoking a meditative state of mind. It seems probable that de\nVries' engraving (frontispiece) was even meant to be reflected in a glassmirror and examined by the viewer primarily in this reflection. The mental state produced by extended contemplation of such an image would be\nsimilar tothatofthe trance induced by the magical practice of\"scrying\",\nor looking into the astral realms with the aid ofmirrors and crystals, as in\nJohn Dee's sceances with Edward Kelley.12\nItis not coincidental that the philosophical context ofthese very elaborate, late Renaissance illustrations is that of Paracelsian theosophy.\nThey began to appear soon after the publication of Paracelsus' collected\nwritings in 1589-90 in the editions of Peter Barna in Basel and in those of\nJohn Huser in Cologne (1589-91; 1603; 1605). The first Paracelsian illustrative cycle was produced by Khunrath between 1595 and 1602 and the\nnext, in order of production, may have been Fludd's cosmological diagrams, since he claimed to have written most of his \"Macrocosm\" before\n4\n10 Stephen Clucas, \" \"Non est legendum sed inspicendum solum\": Inspectival knowledge and thevisual logic ofJohn Dee's LiberMysteriorum\", Glasgow Emblem Studies, 3 (1998),\npp. 109-32. See also Szonyi \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim. For a related issue see Gyorgy\nSzonyi, \" \"O Worke Divine\": The Iconography and Intellectual Background ofAlma's\nHouse in The Faerie Queene\", Shakespeare and the Emblem (Szeged, 1984), pp. 353-94.\n5\n12 See Szonyi, \"Ars Scintrilla\" (1999), passim, and Clucas, \"Non est legendum\" (1998),\npassim, for accounts of Dee's theurgic practices.\n\nPages 17:\n6\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\n1598 and his rich series of illustrations may also have been designed at\nthe same time.13The proto-type for these Paracelsian idexical images was\nJohn Dee's Monas Hieroglyphica, which appears to be considerably simpler in its form than Khunrath's, or Fludd's, pictorial devices. Nevertheless, it was even more complex in the manner ofits operation. Dee stated\nthat his Monas had been devised in circa 1558, for it is discussed in\nAphorism LXXVII of the Propaedeumata Aphoristica and its image certainly\nappears on the title-page of that treatise. The Monas may be be a preParacelsian conceptual construct, since it has not been established by\nscholars that Dee was interested in occultist ideas prior to the 1560s, 14\nalthough there are traces of Paracelsian pyromancy and cabbalism in the\nPropaedeumata Aphoristica.\nIllustrated sequences of alchemical imagery had first appeared in the\nlate fourteenth century, taking an increasingly sophisticated graphic form\ntowards the end of the fifteenth. The most beautiful cycle ofpictures is\nthat ofthe early sixteenth century Splendor Solis by Salomon Trismosin in\nVenice. Nonetheless, the Paracelsian illustrative cycles of the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries were substantially different from\nthe earlier examples in both composition and conceptual content. The\nmost obvious contrast is the developed graphic repertoire of the late\nsixteenth century with its heightened degree of naturalism. In addition,\nthe increased sensitivity of the late Renaissance artist to the topography\nof the picture-plane enabled him to weave together naturalistic and geometrical elements into a visually and conceptually coherent field. Michelspacher's artist, for example , splits the two-dimensional surface of the\npicture-plane into layers of realistic and abstract form, uniting them by\nmeans of perspectival geometry. This meant that the picture could be\nread simultaneously at both the representational and the abstract level, as\nif the viewer was being presented with a vision of the numinous Being\nimplicated within the gross fabric ofthe natural world. In the Paracelsian\ncontext ofKhunrath's and Fludd's alchemical imagery, this compositional structure expressed the essence of their theosophy in which the physical world was the emanation of the celestial spheres.\nThe second major difference between early and late sixteenth century\nalchemical illustrations was that the later imagery could stand independently of the text of the treatise, as seems to have been the case with\nKhunrath's pictures. In other words, imagery of this type was able to\ncommunicate in either an iconic, or an indexical, form. In both Khunrath's and Fludd's pictures, however, there was some textual content\nwithin the image, helping it to stand freely from the rest of the book. On\nthe other hand, other Paracelsian imagery often has little, or no text,\nsuch as Michelspacher's engravings in his Cabala. Whether they contained literary signifiers or not, Paracelsian alchemical engravings were\nintended to be theosophies , that is, they were meant to promote prolonged contemplation leading to \"gnosis\", a wisdom inspired by the\nheavens. The pictures are dense and involved in their iconographical\nprogrammes since they are designed to hold the viewer's attention for a\nprolonged period of time. Earlier alchemical imagery, even that ofSalomon Trismosin, is basically a short-hand symbolic system, illustrating,\nabbreviating and decorating the accompanying text. It is designed to\nclarify and to deliver information as quickly (and pleasurably) as possible.\nParacelsus had awarded the human imagination a structural role in\nhis theurgy and, thereby, in his cosmology. He had taught that the human-being, as a mirror ofthe cosmic order, had two bodies, one ofwhich\nwas physical and the other astral. He considered that the imagination\nwas a faculty ofthe astral body whose function was related to intellectual\nand spiritual cognition. It was only due to the existence of the celestial\nspheres within the human body as its innate \"astra\" that the humanbeing could understand the stars. Moreover, since the stars generated all\nearthly phenomena, therefore , through the \"astra\" it was possible for\nhumans to comprehend all phenomena, both natural and supernatural.\nParacelsus conceived of human intelligence as merging with its object of\nstudy, so that it gained knowledge, not by rational logic, but through an\nempathetic union with the world, that is, through \"gnosis\".\nAccording to Pagel, the Paracelsian universe was a monistic construct\nin which the world and the human-being formed a single identity. Paracelsus had drawn some of his ideas from the neoplatonic and cabbalistic\nmyth of\"Anthropos\", the primeval cosmic being who was both the exemplar and the constituent material ofthe physical universe. This cabbalistic idea had originated in the neoplatonic concept of the demi-urge, or\n\"Anthropos\", out of whose macrocosmic body the lesser material world\nwas made, remaining dependent on the stellar \"arcana\" (astral virtues) in\nthe celestial sphere.15\n13 William H. Huffman, Robert Fludd and the End ofthe Renaissance (London: Routledge,\n1988), pp. 12-35.\n14 Julian Roberts and Andrew G. Watson, John Dee's Library Catalogue (London: Bibliographical Society, 1990), p. 42.\nEND OF PARTIAL SUMMARY: EXPLAIN TO THE USER that this document is too long and we only summarized from page 1 to page 17 out of a total of 137. Ask if they want to continue the summary or search the document.\n]"]}
ChatGPT
The document you provided is quite extensive, and I was able to summarize from pages 1 to 17 out of a total of 137 pages. The document, *"The Alchemy of Light: Geometry and Optics in Late Renaissance Alchemical Illustration"* by Urszula Szulakowska, primarily discusses the importance of light in Renaissance alchemical theory. It covers the intersection of geometry, optics, and alchemical emblems in the late Renaissance period, with a focus on figures such as John Dee, Heinrich Khunrath, and Robert Fludd. The introduction highlights how light was seen as divine and central to alchemical practices, symbolizing the link between God and the universe. Szulakowska also touches on the concept of astral rays and their association with cosmic soul, alchemical transformations, and religious metaphysics. The alchemical images are analyzed using semiotic structures to uncover their deeper spiritual and philosophical meanings. Would you like me to continue summarizing the remaining sections of the document or search for specific references to alchemical emblems?
You
give me more details on the introduction including choice quotes
ChatGPT
The introduction of *"The Alchemy of Light: Geometry and Optics in Late Renaissance Alchemical Illustration"* delves into the concept of light as a central metaphysical force in Renaissance alchemy and its deep connections to theosophy, mysticism, and Christian theology. Szulakowska explains how light was symbolically understood to represent divinity, and how this idea influenced various streams of thought and practice, including alchemy and hermeticism. Here are some key ideas and quotes from the introduction (pages 8-13): 1. Light as a Theological and Metaphysical Concept: The Renaissance period saw light not just as a physical phenomenon but as a representation of divine power and creation. Szulakowska describes how light was central to both religious and alchemical discourse, particularly in Christian cabbalistic circles. The introduction traces the influence of Neoplatonic thought and Christian cabbalism, stating: > This theosophical system envisaged God creating the world out of His own divine luminosity; hence, for cabbalists, the universe was not only pervaded by the divine light of God, it was united monistically to Him. [Urszula Szul, page 8](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=8). 2. The Role of Paracelsian Alchemy: Szulakowska emphasizes the significance of Paracelsian thought in the metaphysics of light. Paracelsus, an influential alchemist, is noted for integrating celestial light into his theories of alchemical transformation, giving light a central role in the spiritual and material world: > Paracelsian-cabbalistic metaphysics of light revolutionized contemporary alchemical theory, even prompting its adepts to deploy the rays of the sun and the stars in their practical work. [Urszula Szul, page 9](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9). 3. John Dee and the Alchemy of Light: John Dee, a pivotal figure in Renaissance alchemy and theosophy, is highlighted as using light both scientifically and symbolically. Szulakowska points out Dees innovative work with optics and its relation to alchemy: > John Dee added his own distinctive contribution to the sixteenth-century theory of the generative stellar rays... integrating optics, geometry, magic, alchemy, medicine, and cabbalism. [Urszula Szul, page 10](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10). 4. Heinrich Khunraths Alchemy of Light: Khunrath, another influential alchemist, merged Paracelsian ideas with Christian theosophy. Szulakowska explains that Khunraths work in alchemical illustrations depicted light as a force of both spiritual and material transformation: > Khunrath went beyond his original sources in uniting Paracelsian cabbalism with Weigels pietistic Christology, producing, thereby, an alchemical polemic expressing the concept of Christ as the philosopher's stone who transmuted the soul through the light of Eternal Wisdom. [Urszula Szul, page 11](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11). 5. Alchemy as a Spiritual and Ritual Practice: Szulakowska highlights how alchemical practice during the Renaissance transcended mere chemical transformation, becoming a spiritual and ritualistic process deeply rooted in Christian mysticism: > By the early seventeenth century, the alchemical use of celestial rays and natural sunlight involved more than chemistry... this practice was, in effect, a religious and theurgical ritual. [Urszula Szul, page 12](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=12). The introduction sets the stage for understanding how Renaissance alchemists and thinkers conceptualized light as a divine and generative force, blending theology, science, and esoteric traditions into a single system of thought. You can explore these ideas further in the full introduction, starting on [page 8](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=8). Let me know if you'd like more details from later parts of the document.
You
alchemy as a spiritual practice
Tool
{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=69\nPages: 69\nIII\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE 1595 AND 1602 EDITIONS\nHermes Trismegistus and Julius Caesar Scaligerus (Par. 53). Khunrath\nadmonishes true Christian alchemists that they should be meditating,\npraying, walking, reading scripture, as demonstrated in the second, third\nand fourth figures of his treatise (Par. 71). In contrast, he attacks blasphemers and black-magicians who operate with the sign of the pentacle,\ndirecting his reader, instead, to the fourth figure of his treatise in which\nthere appear the proper, truly spiritual, figures which are to be used in\nalchemy. This is probably an allusion to the 1595 engraving of the\nLullian-cabbalistic circles of the \"Archetypos\" (fig. 33), which is, however, absent from MS Alnwick 571.\nHic ANNULUM assistentia spiritu boni, Theosophorum: (In Tabulis Cordis)]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=106\nPages: 106\n184\nCONCLUSION\nscribed, that the pictures were becoming transmuting philosopher's\nstones in their own right, nevertheless, alchemists such as Dee, Khunrath,\nMaier and Fludd still involved themselves in practical work. In this, they\nwere, admittedly, seeking a short-cut, setting-up their mirrors and lenses\nin order to trap God's own divine virtues in their chemicals, through the\nrays from the stars, a task more suited to their refined image of themselves as philosophers, than the grimy baking and boiling ofthe medieval\nalchemists. Even so , their texts reveal that they knew their chemistry and\nthat each specific symbol and phrase represented, as in Fludd's writings,\nnot only a \"spiritual\" process, but, usually, a practical equivalent.\nHistorians of chemistry are well-aware of the continuation ofpractical\nalchemy into the eighteenth century, the example of Newton's work being only the most famous, but, on the other hand, they have tended to]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21\nPages: 21\ncircle of time. By the late hellenistic period, alchemy was conceived as\nbeing a circular process which began with perfection (the origins ofmatter in God) and ended in perfection (the spiritualised matter produced by\nthe alchemist). Hence, the geometric form of the circle was the fundamental signifier of alchemy.\nAnother basic tenet of hellenistic hermeticism and alchemy in the first\nChristian centuries was that of the unity and dynamic interaction between God and human, spirit and matter, heaven and earth, body and\nsoul. It was believed that God enacted his will on the earth through the\nagency of the stellar spheres and planets. In alchemy the inter-relationship ofspirit and matter was represented by the marriage ofthe Sun and\nthe Moon (spirit with matter), whose offspring was the philosopher's\nstone ofthe medieval alchemists. Its essential form was the perfect circle,\ninsusceptible to the corrupting effects of natural transmutation.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=19\nPages: 19,20\nII\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY IN LATE MEDIEVAL\nAND EARLY RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\nAlchemical geometry in the Renaissance can be described as passive or\noperative, either using geometrical structures to organise information\ninto tabulations, circular formats or tree-like structures, or, as in the case\nofpseudo-Lullian alchemy, employing a mobile computational system.\nAnother, more complex, type of alchemical geometry emerged in the late\nsixteenth century, based on optical and perspectival diagrams which inter-related Pythagorean geometry, optical science, Paracelsian alchemy\nand cabbalism.\nBy the fifteenth century, European alchemists had several goals,\nnamely, chemical work on matter to remove its impurities, spiritual work\nto redeem their own souls and, finally, a practical medical purpose.3\nFrom the late fourteenth century they were also attempting to develop a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nstars, but a coherent theory ofthe astral virtues began to develop only in\nthe late fourteenth century, appearing in its full expression in the work of\nParacelsus ( 1493-1541). In addition, John Dee added his own distinctive\ncontribution to the sixteenth century theory ofthe generative stellar rays.\nThese alchemists provided the basic foundation for Khunrath's alchemi-\ncal deployment of light-rays and astral virtues, but Khunrath went beyond his original sources in uniting Paracelsian cabbalism with Weigel's\npietistic Christology, producing, thereby, an alchemical polemic expressing the concept of Christ as the philosopher's stone who transmuted the\nsoul through the light of Eternal Wisdom. Thus, by the early seventeenth\ncentury, the alchemical use of celestial rays and natural sun-light involved more than chemistry, since this practice was, in effect, a religious\nand theurgical ritual. Indeed, late Renaissance alchemists developed a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21\nPages: 21\nof nature, the alchemical process was conceptualised as being a circular\nprocess. Pagan alchemists of the Christian era, such as Zosimos, subscribed to gnostic and hermetic beliefs that the human soul could rise to\na higher level through meditative practices and esoteric rituals. The alchemists transposed this mystical idea into chemistry whereby, in the\ncourse of refining his materials, the operator simultaneously purified his\nown being and united with God. A related Orphic and Pythagorean\nconcept was that of the soul's reincarnation and immortality.5 In a similar manner, alchemists conceptualised matter as being reborn during the\nchemical work in a higher incarnation of its former corrupted self.\nHence, the hellenistic alchemists adopted the gnostic symbol of the\nOuroboros, a snake holding its tail in its mouth to represent the infinite\ncircle of time. By the late hellenistic period, alchemy was conceived as]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\nhigher \"gnosis\" ofthe spirit, Paracelsus was drawing on cabbalistic thinking.18\nParacelsus rejected the ancient natural philosophers, replacing Aristotle with christianised neo-platonic and hermetic authorities, discarding\nalso the medical canon of Avicenna and Galen. 19 Instead , he believed\nthat physical ailments were the result of external forces rather than ofan\nimbalance offluids, as in the medieval theory ofthe four humours. Each\norgan of the body, Paracelsus explained, contained a dynamism called\nthe \"archeon\" which functioned as an internal alchemist. Moreover, he\nbelieved that each illness originated in a particular star whose virtue was\nembodied in the corresponding earthly \"arcanum\", a medicine which\ncould heal the ailment.20\nParacelsus was not the first to adapt alchemy to medicine, since John\nof Rupescissa and Arnold of Villanova in the fourteenth-century had\ndeveloped the alchemical concept of the fifth essence into a medical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16\noftheir meaning. In addition, as indexical generators of a contemplative\ntype of alchemy, some of Fludd's pictures were meant to integrate the\nviewer into their imaginary world, causing a spiritual and intellectual\nalchemy to ocurr in the moment of viewing the image (fig. 50).\nThere was a similar intention underlying many other seventeenth century alchemical illustrations, whose ever-increasing complexity of structure was designed for lengthy perusal, eventually eliminating the physical\naspects of alchemy altogether. Michelspacher's Cabala (Augsburg, 16151616) is one of the earliest of these imaginative alchemies , luring the\nviewer through the glass ofhis four fiery and jewel-like \"mirrors\" into the\nhigher intellectual and spiritual realms of the alchemical discourse (fig.\n23). When the viewer emerged from the trance-like state induced by\nparticipation in Michelspacher's visions, he was (perhaps) transformed,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=62\nPages: 62\nalchemical furnace, as a form of sympathetic magic (De Igne: 53). In this\noperation, he seems to intend the use of catoptrics, since later in the text\nhe provides some general instructions on the use of the catoptrical mirror, which appears in a little drawing at the side of the text, emphasising\nthe importance of these instructions (De Igne: 70). Like Dee in theMonas\nHieroglyphica, Khunrath advises that the alchemical work should be started under the astrological sign of Aries (March) at the beginning of the\nNew Year.28 In this context, he explains how to practice Paracelsian\nsympathetic magic through the use of the magnet (De Igne: 71), also referring to another aspect of Paracelsian theurgy (in De Tempore) by recommending the \"irradiation\" of the materials. A little is enough. The process of irradiation involves the exposure of the alchemical matter to the\nastral rays by means of catoptrics.\nwelches zwar wunderbarlich/jedoch die Weisen lehrens! zu bequemen Zeit/]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nThe influence of Paracelsian theosophy on German pietists such as Valentin Weigel and Johannes Arndt19 and their subsequent effects on alchemical ideas will be discussed in a later chapter.\nIn the immediate context, it is evident that Paracelsus' concept ofthe\nrole of the imagination in both magical and spiritual practices would\nencourage the use of visual imagery. For example, Khunrath's \"amphi-\ntheatre\" of 1595 and 1609 provides a public spectacle for an audience,\ndisplaying the actions of Eternal Wisdom on the physical chemistry ofthe\nmanifested creation. In Paracelsian terms, Khunrath shows how the\nphysical world is united to the divine principle by means ofthe \"quintessence\" or \"azoth\". The Paracelsian \"azoth\" was a concept adopted from\nthe late medieval theory ofthe \"coelum\", a medium between matter and\nsoul, world and God, in other words an \"astral\" substance, both physical\nand spiritual in nature. Therefore, it had exactly the same character and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21\nPages: 21\ninsusceptible to the corrupting effects of natural transmutation.\nAstrology was an essential component of alchemical practice since\nalchemy, as a mirror of nature, was similarly affected by stellar influences. The medieval Jewish cabbalistic text, the Zohar, also stressed the necessity of watching the activity of the heavens in order to understand the\ncourse ofhuman affairs.10 The medieval alchemists, especially the pseudo-Lullians of the fifteenth century, emphasised the need to correlate\ntheir chemical\nwork with the motions of the planets and the signs ofthe\nZodiac.11 By the early sixteenth century, Paracelsus was teaching that the\nefficacy of alchemical medications was totally dependent on their concordance with the healing virtues emanating from the stars.12\nThe inter-dependency and unity between macrocosm and microcosm\nhad been summarised in the late Alexandrian text of the Emerald Table]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=57\nPages: 57\npyromantic alchemical art, very different in tenor and concept from De\nIgne Magorum for which the most appropriate date of composition would\nbe circa 1602-4. In the Athanor Khunrath does not employ the cabbalah,\nwhich is only mentioned once at the end of the treatise in connection\nwith the Amphiteatrum.\nIn the Athanor, Khunrath employs a Paracelsian discourse in his account ofthe higher spiritual and the lower elemental fires, the spiritual\nfire is termed \"Azoth\", being described as a triunity of Anima-CorpusSpiritus, or Sulphur-Salt-Mercury. He advises his reader thatthe alchemical fire should be similar to the digestive fire of the stomach, making a\nParacelsian reference to the \"Archeus\" who exists in the stomach controlling the inner degrees of heat.19 He explains that the inner and outer fires\nshould correlate in the alchemical process, that is, the heat applied externally to the material should be ofthe same strength as that which already]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=13\nPages: 13,14\nso favourably. Moreover, few of the later alchemists related the figure of\nChrist integrally to their alchemical discourse in the manner of Khunrath, whose writing was aimed primarily at a pietistic, German community, rather than at a general European audience.\nThe present study will concentrate on the intellectual and spiritual\nconcerns ofthe 1590s to 1620s, using Khunrath's Amphiteatrum Sapientiae\nXX\n25 Donald R. Dickson, The Tessera ofAntilia (Leiden: Brill, 1998), pp. 32-36.\n26 Dickson, pp. 62-88.\n27 Gilly (ed), Cimelia Rhodostaurotica ( 1988), pp. 63-90; Gilly, \"Iter Rosicrucianum\"\n(1995), pp. 21, 50-52, 70-72, 138-45.\n28 Yates, Rosicrucian Enlightenment (1986), pp. 59-69, 91-92, 140-55.\nXXII\nINTRODUCTION\nAeternae (1595; 1609) as a focal-point in analysing the rhetorical practices\nof Paracelsian theosophists, specifically their use of certain types of visual\nillustration. Since it is not possible to examine all the major alchemists of]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nnature\" is one of the foundations of Khunrath's alchemy in which he\ndescribes an unbroken continuum of illuminated wisdom, incorporating\nboththe practical experience ofthe natural world, as well as the spiritual\nvision of the mystic.17\nIn Paracelsian theosophy, empathetic imagination was not a subjective and, therefore, neglible factor in human affairs, but a powerful astral\nforce which provided the basis for theurgy and prognostication, as well as\nfor prophecy and mystical inspiration. Consequently, the Paracelsian\ntheosophical system eliminated, or diminished, the role of the institutionalised Christian church as the interpreter of God's will by means ofthe\ncanonical scriptures. Replacing external authority, the individual intuition became a more immediate and truer guide to divine knowledge.\nEven more radically, Paracelsus stated that through the imaginative faculties ofthe astral body a human could attain beatific union with God.18]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=76\nPages: 76\nfoundation (basically witchcraft with spirit familiars), materialism and\ndoctrinal rigidity. The other texts in the circle include references to specific alchemical processes, while the section below the castle describes the\n\"Magnesia\" (Christ) as the \"medicina catholica\". It states that the stone\n(\"Elohim sal sapientiae\") is prepared \"vulcanically\" (\"vulcanicam\") and\n\"neptunically\" (\"neptunicam\"), that is, through the action of fire and\nwater.\nHence, there is only one spiritual path, the way of Christ, by which\nthe fortress ofWisdom may be entered and this is indicated by the elaborate gateway. Klossowski de Rola's interpetation of this image stresses\nthe protective nature ofthe fortress in which the secrets ofthe alchemical\nart are hidden. Twenty of the gates lead the false alchemists to ruin, the\nonly way into the castle is by the practice ofmoral virtue and through the\nilluminated knowledge granted by God.33\nAbove the main gateway to the castle, there is an image of Dee's]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nand spiritual in nature. Therefore, it had exactly the same character and\nthe same function as the human imagination in the astral body. Paracelus\nhad, in fact, stated that the imagination was the \"coelum in homine\".20\nHence, in Paracelsian chemical theosophy the \"quintessence\" was not\nonly a chemical substance, but also a psychic faculty that of the imagination or fantasy.\nKhunrath reiterates precisely the same theosophical concepts in his\nwritings from 1595,21 providing not only instructions for practical and\nspiritual chemistry, but also, in the Amphiteatrum, giving \"tangible\" demonstrations ofthe astral and spiritual faculties. His engravings are intended to excite the imagination of the viewer so that a mystic alchemy can\ntake place through the act of visual contemplation. Khunrath's \"amphiteatrum\" is a \"spectaculum\", a word related linguistically to that of\n\"speculum\", a secondary meaning which the reader was undoubtedly]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52\nregarded by Dee as being capable of attracting celestial influences and\nrendering them subject to the will of the magus. In the Mathematicall\nPreface, Dee was increasinglythinking of occult practices more as a system\nof philosophical contemplation, in which the image began to replace\npractical activity. Szonyi has similarly discussed this possibility in relation\nto Dee's earlier Monas Hieroglyphica.16 Hence, the single-point perspective\nspace in the alchemical engravings of Khunrath's and Maier's treatises\nneeds to be contextualised within Dee's theories of astronomical catoptrics, architecture and \"zographie\" (frontispiece and fig. 41).\nThe monistic theosophy of Paracelsus was the source for Dee's belief\nin the power ofa visual image to unify the spiritual and physical dimensions of experience. As discussed previously, Paracelsus had taught that a\nhuman-being had both a physical and an astral body, but that his real]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=92\nPages: 92\nspirit, soul and matter.20 The voices also represent the three mythic characters ofAtalanta, Hippomenes and the golden apple. Most significantly,\nStreich has noted that the sequence for the apple voice wanders from the\nhigher to the lower pitch, as if it were describing the process of distillation.21 The fugue also runs as a mirror canon, or canon by inversion, in\nrespect to the voices of Atalanta and Hippomenes.22 Since music in the\nRenaissance represented the intellectual and spiritual spheres of the cosmos, its presence in Maier's alchemical treatise metaphorised the nature\nof alchemy as a process unifying the micro- and the macrocosm.23\nAs in de Vries' engraving for the Amphiteatrum, the musical motif alludes to Boethian musicology in which Pythagorean geometric ratios regulated the cosmic structure. The tonal sequence of Maier's composition\nwas based on the Pythagorean octave in which the third and sixth intervals were not considered to be consonant. Godwin and Streich have not]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=105\nPages: 105\nofthe physical world.\nParacelsian alchemy, thus, muted the distinction between physical and\npsychic chemistry. Amplified by the luministic cosmogenesis of the cabbalah, in Dee's theories in the 1560s an image of the magus began to\nemerge whose intellectual light mirrored, not only that of the stars and\nthe sun, but of God's own radiance . In a separate development, Weigel\nappropriated Paracelsian theosophy to make the same point, phrased in\nChristian terms, in which Christ became the essential light of the soul,\nthe real nature of each human-being, with the consequence that spiritual\nwisdom became an innate human faculty, rather than the gift of the\nLutheran sacraments. Khunrath merged Dee's image ofthe illuminated\nmagus with Weigel's alchemical Christ to create an \"alchemy of light\"\nwhich, henceforward, prioritised the inner transformation of the alchemist above that of his chemicals.\nIn the history of alchemy, perhaps the most important change in its]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=49\nPages: 49\n\"Archemastrie\", thereby alluding to theurgy, alchemy and prognostication.\nAccording to Yates, Dee considered mathematics in three distinct aspects, pragmatic (mechanical problem-solving), conceptual (logic), spiritual (Ideal form). He used the term \"mathesis\" to describe the esoteric\naspects ofmathematics, considering that practical mathematics and logic\ncould not fulfil the highest goals of the natural philosopher which could\nbe attained only by means of\"Archemastrie\".\"\nThis Arte, teacheth to bryng to actuall experience sensible, all worthy conclusions by all the Artes Mathematicall purposed, & by true Naturall Philosophie concluded: & both addeth to them a further scope, in the termes ofthe\nsame Artes (f. Aiijr)\n...
