And though some Artes, have in them, Experiences: but neither, all, that\nthey may: nor yet sufficiently, and to the utmost, those, which they do,\nThere, then, the Archemaster steppeth in, and leadeth forth on, the Experiences,]"]}
ChatGPT
Alchemy as a spiritual practice is discussed throughout Urszula Szulakowskas text, particularly with regard to the interrelationship between physical alchemical work and the spiritual or mystical transformation of the practitioner. Here are some key points and quotes: 1. Spiritual Transformation in Alchemy: Alchemy was not only about transforming materials but also about the spiritual purification and enlightenment of the alchemist. This concept is rooted in the idea of alchemy as a circular process in which both matter and spirit are refined: > In alchemy, the inter-relationship of spirit and matter was represented by the marriage of the Sun and the Moon (spirit with matter), whose offspring was the philosophers stone of the medieval alchemists. [Urszula Szul, page 21](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21). 2. Alchemical Work as Religious and Mystical: The practice of alchemy, particularly in its later developments, involved not only chemical experimentation but also theurgical rituals aimed at uniting the alchemist with divine wisdom: > By the early seventeenth century, the alchemical use of celestial rays and natural sunlight involved more than chemistry... this practice was, in effect, a religious and theurgical ritual. [Urszula Szul, page 9](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9). 3. The Role of Imagination and Visualization: In Paracelsian alchemy, imagination and visualization played critical roles in linking the physical and spiritual realms. Visual alchemical illustrations were used to initiate a spiritual process within the viewer: > Khunrath's engravings are intended to excite the imagination of the viewer so that a mystic alchemy can take place through the act of visual contemplation. [Urszula Szul, page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18). 4. Moral and Spiritual Virtue: Moral and spiritual purity were seen as essential for alchemical success. Khunrath emphasized that alchemists should be devoted to prayer and meditation, linking physical alchemical processes with inner spiritual work: > Khunrath admonishes true Christian alchemists that they should be meditating, praying, walking, reading scripture... directing his reader... to truly spiritual figures which are to be used in alchemy. [Urszula Szul, page 69](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=69). These sections show how alchemy transcended chemistry and became a spiritual and moral pursuit, with alchemists seeking both material transformation and inner enlightenment through their work. You can explore these themes further in the full text [here](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21).
You
imagination and visualization
Tool
{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nThe influence of Paracelsian theosophy on German pietists such as Valentin Weigel and Johannes Arndt19 and their subsequent effects on alchemical ideas will be discussed in a later chapter.\nIn the immediate context, it is evident that Paracelsus' concept ofthe\nrole of the imagination in both magical and spiritual practices would\nencourage the use of visual imagery. For example, Khunrath's \"amphi-\ntheatre\" of 1595 and 1609 provides a public spectacle for an audience,\ndisplaying the actions of Eternal Wisdom on the physical chemistry ofthe\nmanifested creation. In Paracelsian terms, Khunrath shows how the\nphysical world is united to the divine principle by means ofthe \"quintessence\" or \"azoth\". The Paracelsian \"azoth\" was a concept adopted from\nthe late medieval theory ofthe \"coelum\", a medium between matter and\nsoul, world and God, in other words an \"astral\" substance, both physical\nand spiritual in nature. Therefore, it had exactly the same character and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nand spiritual in nature. Therefore, it had exactly the same character and\nthe same function as the human imagination in the astral body. Paracelus\nhad, in fact, stated that the imagination was the \"coelum in homine\".20\nHence, in Paracelsian chemical theosophy the \"quintessence\" was not\nonly a chemical substance, but also a psychic faculty that of the imagination or fantasy.\nKhunrath reiterates precisely the same theosophical concepts in his\nwritings from 1595,21 providing not only instructions for practical and\nspiritual chemistry, but also, in the Amphiteatrum, giving \"tangible\" demonstrations ofthe astral and spiritual faculties. His engravings are intended to excite the imagination of the viewer so that a mystic alchemy can\ntake place through the act of visual contemplation. Khunrath's \"amphiteatrum\" is a \"spectaculum\", a word related linguistically to that of\n\"speculum\", a secondary meaning which the reader was undoubtedly]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17\nPages: 17\nprogrammes since they are designed to hold the viewer's attention for a\nprolonged period of time. Earlier alchemical imagery, even that ofSalomon Trismosin, is basically a short-hand symbolic system, illustrating,\nabbreviating and decorating the accompanying text. It is designed to\nclarify and to deliver information as quickly (and pleasurably) as possible.\nParacelsus had awarded the human imagination a structural role in\nhis theurgy and, thereby, in his cosmology. He had taught that the human-being, as a mirror ofthe cosmic order, had two bodies, one ofwhich\nwas physical and the other astral. He considered that the imagination\nwas a faculty ofthe astral body whose function was related to intellectual\nand spiritual cognition. It was only due to the existence of the celestial\nspheres within the human body as its innate \"astra\" that the humanbeing could understand the stars. Moreover, since the stars generated all\nearthly phenomena, therefore , through the \"astra\" it was possible for]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=71\nPages: 71\nof the action. This image is based on the Paracelsian theory of the\nimagination as a means of attaining spiritual union with the celestial\nrealms. Hence, Khunrath's engravings in the Amphiteatrum are \"stagesets\" into which the consciousness of the viewer is absorbed. By imaginatively performing within these scenes, that is, by following the spiritual\ninstruction of the imagery and their texts, the viewer enters into a contemplative state leading to \"gnosis\". Subsequent to the encomium, there\nis an epigram in praise of Khunrath, written by Johannes Seussius of\nDresden to the Elector of Saxony in 1604, which similarly locates Khunrath's alchemical theory within the spectacle of a macrocosmic theatre.6\nThe rhetorical devices of Khunrath's engravings may be usefully]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=82\nPages: 82\nenhanced.53Engravings intended to be viewed by means of the \"Vue d'\nOptique\" depict a long depth-of-field, as well as strong contrasts oflight\nand shadow in the foreground. Thus, by means of catoptrics de Vries\ncould have been attempting to produce an unbroken spatial (indexical)\ncontinuum between the physical world and the illustration. For that very\npurpose Alberti in his De Pictura (1435) had originally introduced the\ndevice of single-point space into painting, in order to blur the division\nbetween imagination and reality. Alberti's spatial geometry was primarily\na rhetorical device designed to slip a message effortlessly pastthe viewer's\nobjective judgement. According to Obrist, the medieval alchemists had\nprovided visual depictions oftheir ideas with the same intention of confusing the viewer's sense of reality.54 Paracelsus had also considered the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52\nhuman-being had both a physical and an astral body, but that his real\nbody was astral. It was by means of the imagination located in the astral\nbodythat a person could attain to \"gnosis\" and, thereby, learn to control\nphysical manifestation through the \"astra\" present within all things.\nThus, for the Paracelsian magus it was sufficient to contemplate an object, instead of manipulating it physically. Visual imagery, such as talismanic cyphers or alchemical pictures, provided a stimulus to the imagination of the magus and acted as simulacra of the objects under his\ncontrol.\nDee's view of the theurgic function of Pythagorean-based drawing\nmay explain two particular alchemical images which Yates stated that she\nfound incomprehensible. The alchemical image which specifically puzzled her was Emblem VIII from Maier's Atalanta Fugiens (1617) (fig. 41).\nHer attribution of a conceptual influence on Maier from Dee in this\ncontext is accurate, but she did not connect Emblem VIII specifically to]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=82\nPages: 82,83\nhuman imagination to be an astral force, capable of theurgically manipulating the world of time and space. Hence, the prime function of de\nVries' engraving was to validate Khunrath's cabbalistic Christological\nalchemy.\nThere are two other pictures in Khunrath's iconographic repertoire\nwhich similarly provide a rhetorical defence of his position as a spiritual\nalchemist against the rising tide of objections to his theosophical Christology. These are the Magdeburg emblem of an owl and the 1602 image of\nthe \"calumniatores\".\n136\n52 Jung's drawing in Bibliotek Kopenhagen, MS GKS 1765 may be seen in thereproduction in Gilly, Cimelia Rhodostaurotica (1995), p. 14, Item 12b.\n137\n53 Henry Moore Institute, Leeds, Peter Scheemakers: \"The Famous Statuary\" (1691-1781),\n1966, exhibition catalogue, No. 6, Vue d'Optique engraving, c. 1750, with mahogany\nand glass viewing machine.\n54 Obrist, pp. 55-65, 248-49.\nCHAPTER TEN\nEPICUREANS, BLASPHEMERS, SOPHISTS AND\nBLACK-MAGICIANS: THE PERSECUTION OF]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16\noftheir meaning. In addition, as indexical generators of a contemplative\ntype of alchemy, some of Fludd's pictures were meant to integrate the\nviewer into their imaginary world, causing a spiritual and intellectual\nalchemy to ocurr in the moment of viewing the image (fig. 50).\nThere was a similar intention underlying many other seventeenth century alchemical illustrations, whose ever-increasing complexity of structure was designed for lengthy perusal, eventually eliminating the physical\naspects of alchemy altogether. Michelspacher's Cabala (Augsburg, 16151616) is one of the earliest of these imaginative alchemies , luring the\nviewer through the glass ofhis four fiery and jewel-like \"mirrors\" into the\nhigher intellectual and spiritual realms of the alchemical discourse (fig.\n23). When the viewer emerged from the trance-like state induced by\nparticipation in Michelspacher's visions, he was (perhaps) transformed,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\n\"speculum\", a secondary meaning which the reader was undoubtedly\nintended to retrieve from the original title ofthe treatise. Hence, Khunrath's theatre of images, like a mirror, catoptrically reflects the celestial\nspheres to the human mind, awakening the empathetic faculty of the\nhuman spirit which unites, through the imagination, with the heavenly\nrealms. Thus, the visual imagery of Khunrath's treatises has become the\nalchemical quintessence, the spiritualised matter of the philosopher's\nstone, transmuting both the human soul and the physical world into gold.\nIt is evident that late Renaissance alchemists were involved in a radical semiotic enterprise, intuiting the possibility of devising a visual signing-system which would resolve the dualistic conflict of the European\nlinguistic sign in which signifier and signified were arbitrarily related.22\nAccordingly, John Dee regarded his Monas Hieroglyphica as a graphic\nsystem which was also practical chemistry (figs. 17, 18), a metonymic]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nnature\" is one of the foundations of Khunrath's alchemy in which he\ndescribes an unbroken continuum of illuminated wisdom, incorporating\nboththe practical experience ofthe natural world, as well as the spiritual\nvision of the mystic.17\nIn Paracelsian theosophy, empathetic imagination was not a subjective and, therefore, neglible factor in human affairs, but a powerful astral\nforce which provided the basis for theurgy and prognostication, as well as\nfor prophecy and mystical inspiration. Consequently, the Paracelsian\ntheosophical system eliminated, or diminished, the role of the institutionalised Christian church as the interpreter of God's will by means ofthe\ncanonical scriptures. Replacing external authority, the individual intuition became a more immediate and truer guide to divine knowledge.\nEven more radically, Paracelsus stated that through the imaginative faculties ofthe astral body a human could attain beatific union with God.18]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17\nPages: 17,18\nwas made, remaining dependent on the stellar \"arcana\" (astral virtues) in\nthe celestial sphere.15\n13 William H. Huffman, Robert Fludd and the End ofthe Renaissance (London: Routledge,\n1988), pp. 12-35.\n14 Julian Roberts and Andrew G. Watson, John Dee's Library Catalogue (London: Bibliographical Society, 1990), p. 42.\n15 Walter Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" in Antoine Faivre and RolfChristian\nZimmermann (eds), Epochen der Naturmystik (Berlin: Erich Schmidt, 1979), pp. 57-58, 61,\n70, 89-99. The theological works of Paracelsus are found in Karl Sudhoff and Wilhelm\nMatthiesen (eds) Paracelsus. Samtliche Werke: Part II (Munich: O.W.Barth, 1923), 1, pp. 89110, De religione perpetua and pp. 111-32, De summo et aeterno bono.\n7\n8\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nBy means ofthe imaginative faculty residing in a human's astral body\n(the \"supercoelestis corpus\"), an empathetic union could beattained with]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=78\nPages: 78\nattack. Drawing on Gombrich's distinction between\nrevelatory and didactic images, as in Szonyi's useful argument,38 the 1595 engravings\ncould be defined as being revelatory cosmograms, while the 1602 imagery are primarily didactic narratives, although they also have a revelatory\naspect in their mystical intensity. Furthermore, the aerial view of the\nlandscape in many of the 1602 scenes, particularly in that ofthe \"Porta\nAmphiteatri Sapientiae\", not only produces a narrative, didactic sequence, it also creates an imaginative space into which the viewer seems\nto be absorbed.39 Hence, the panoramic aspect of some of the 1602\nimages in the Amphiteatrum, is an indexical device capturing the spectator\nwithin their discourse (figs. 29, 31), although the picture of the \"calumniatores\" is a purely didactic image since this was, indeed, its sole purpose\n(fig. 35).\nThe discourse of the enlightened mage, however, commences earlier]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=82\nPages: 82\nalso promote the spatial illusionism. Consequently, these various graphic\ndevices seem to indicate that the image should be viewed with the aid of\nan optical lens, such as a magnifying glass, or by means of a double\nreflection in two mirrors, or by a combination of mirrors and lenses.\nWhen it is viewed through a convex lens, the graphic exaggerations drop\nback and cease to intrude on the visual logic of the scene, for the depth\nofthe hall diminishes and the floor appears less raked. In particular, the\nspace around the table and the fire-place becomes \"real\" and the furniture stands-up, away from the background.\nBy the eighteenth-century there existed an apparatus known as the\n\"Vue d'Optique\" consisting of an arrangement of mirrors and lenses\nused to reflect the image of an engraving to a viewer, usually of an\narchitectural scene whose three- dimensional quality was thereby greatly\nenhanced.53Engravings intended to be viewed by means of the \"Vue d']","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16\nsimilar tothatofthe trance induced by the magical practice of\"scrying\",\nor looking into the astral realms with the aid ofmirrors and crystals, as in\nJohn Dee's sceances with Edward Kelley.12\nItis not coincidental that the philosophical context ofthese very elaborate, late Renaissance illustrations is that of Paracelsian theosophy.\nThey began to appear soon after the publication of Paracelsus' collected\nwritings in 1589-90 in the editions of Peter Barna in Basel and in those of\nJohn Huser in Cologne (1589-91; 1603; 1605). The first Paracelsian illustrative cycle was produced by Khunrath between 1595 and 1602 and the\nnext, in order of production, may have been Fludd's cosmological diagrams, since he claimed to have written most of his \"Macrocosm\" before\n4\n10 Stephen Clucas, \" \"Non est legendum sed inspicendum solum\": Inspectival knowledge and thevisual logic ofJohn Dee's LiberMysteriorum\", Glasgow Emblem Studies, 3 (1998),]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17\nPages: 17\nmost obvious contrast is the developed graphic repertoire of the late\nsixteenth century with its heightened degree of naturalism. In addition,\nthe increased sensitivity of the late Renaissance artist to the topography\nof the picture-plane enabled him to weave together naturalistic and geometrical elements into a visually and conceptually coherent field. Michelspacher's artist, for example , splits the two-dimensional surface of the\npicture-plane into layers of realistic and abstract form, uniting them by\nmeans of perspectival geometry. This meant that the picture could be\nread simultaneously at both the representational and the abstract level, as\nif the viewer was being presented with a vision of the numinous Being\nimplicated within the gross fabric ofthe natural world. In the Paracelsian\ncontext ofKhunrath's and Fludd's alchemical imagery, this compositional structure expressed the essence of their theosophy in which the physical world was the emanation of the celestial spheres.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=50\nPages: 50\ndi Giorgio Martini (1439-1502), in which he had related the proportions\nofthe human-body to those of the macrocosm. His ideas were probably\nthe source ofAgrippa's similar account in De Occulta Philosophia.10\nIn Renaissance art-theory, the same aesthetic system governed the\nstructure of both organic and inorganic ideal form, the depiction ofthe\nhuman-form being related to that of spatial geometry. In De pictura\n(1435), Alberti had applied the geometrical rules of optics (\"perspectiva\nnaturalis\") to the art of painting in order to produce the illusion of a\nthree-dimensional space (\"perspectiva artificialis\").\" Alberti had imagined rays oflight being projected bythe eye in the form of a pyramid (fig.\n2). He then constructed their mirror-image on the canvas in the form of\na reversed pyramid with its apex located in the middle of the painting,\nwhich was the \"vanishing point\" absorbing all the orthogonal lines ofthe\ndrawing (fig. 1).12]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=102\nPages: 102,103\nVerbum, et Apollo, quamvis sit in hac mundo, similiterque eius tabernaculum\".\n50 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1621), Tract I, p. 27: \"me solem visibilem pro ipso corpore Christi\nmystico accipere\".\n51 Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1494 ed.), pp. 95-103 andDe Arte\nCabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1517 ed.), pp. 143-55.\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nnew images is a somewhat novel and ungainly catoptrical conceit, incorporating a radiant sun, drawn with a face whose nose consists of the\nequilateral triangle of the Holy Trinity. It directs the rays of its solar\nvirtues onto a star, which reflects them to a wind-god, who, in turn,\nblows them down to the earth (Fludd, 1626: 189) (fig. 49). This picture\nmay have originated in Balthasar Schwan's engraving for Maier's Septimana Philosophica in which the rays ofthe sun are catoptrically reflected by\nthe mirror of the moon (fig. 37).]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nresults to regard visual and verbal signs as autonomous dialects of the\nsame language, thus requiring different critical approaches. It was Panofsky who first argued for a new type of analytical tool for the study of\nvisual imagery which would be distinct from that ofliterary scholarship.\nHis iconological method involved an examination of the historical context in which a visual sign had appeared, for it was this which had determined the style of its depiction. As Szonyi has demonstrated in his study\nof Agrippa's and Dee's esoteric emblems, Panofsky's method is one ofthe\nfew able to accomodate the complexity of a visual signing-system. Szonyi\nalso continues to favour the historiographical approach of Gombrich,\nwhich has the added advantage of taking into account the psychological\neffects ofthe rhetoric deployed by a visual sign.\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=97\nPages: 97,98\npresent study.\n2 Joscelyn Godwin, Robert Fludd (London: Thames and Hudson, 1979), passim.\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nimagery itself. Fludd's engravings also frequently appear in popularised\naccounts of alchemy, though Klossowski de Rola did not include them in\nhis account of seventeenth century alchemical engravings. The most\nextensive discussion of Fludd's intellectual development has been provided by Huffman, though he also disregarded Fludd's visual work. It is\nregrettable that these authorities have largely neglected Fludd's engravings, for even Godwin's admirable interpretation is directed more at an\naudience of twentieth century alchemical adepts. This disregard for the\nintellectual significance of the illustrations could lead to misinterpretations of Fludd's ideas, since, according to Yates, his visual imagery was\nintegral to his theoretical concepts. Their importance is indicated by the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16\nscholars of alchemical imagery distinguish between the literary and the\nvisual components of an alchemical treatise. Moreover, certain types of\nalchemical illustration are capable of functioning almost entirely as a\nvisual text, that is, as metonymic, or indexical, structures, as in the case of\none of Khunrath's illustrations (frontispiece). In such metonymic visual\nimages there is an implied physical continuity between the world ofthe\nviewer and that of the picture. In these instances, the reception of the\npicture's message does not need to be deferred until it can be decoded in\na linguistic form. In such sophisticated metonymic-indexical images the\nvisual structure is the essence ofthe meaning communicated to the viewer. This indexical quality of an image is not necessarily dependent onthe\nartist's use of naturalistic motifs (as Peirce had pointed out), since diagrammatic structures may also be indexical. It is more a question ofthe]"]}
ChatGPT
Imagination and visualization play crucial roles in the alchemical processes discussed in *"The Alchemy of Light"*. The influence of Paracelsian theosophy is particularly significant in shaping the understanding of imagination as a powerful astral force, used not only for spiritual practices but also for understanding the cosmos and connecting with divine realms. Here are some key points: 1. Imagination as a Link to the Celestial: Paracelsus taught that imagination was a faculty of the astral body, which allowed humans to access the celestial spheres and understand their mysteries. Imagination was seen as an astral force that could affect both the physical and spiritual worlds: > Paracelsus had awarded the human imagination a structural role in his theurgy... he considered that the imagination was a faculty of the astral body whose function was related to intellectual and spiritual cognition. [Urszula Szul, page 17](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17). 2. Visualization as Spiritual Alchemy: Alchemical illustrations were not mere decorations but were designed to engage the imagination of the viewer. Khunraths Amphiteatrum Sapientiae contains elaborate imagery intended to lead the viewer into a contemplative state, which allowed for a mystic alchemy to occur through visual contemplation: > Khunrath's engravings are intended to excite the imagination of the viewer so that a mystic alchemy can take place through the act of visual contemplation. [Urszula Szul, page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18). 3. The Function of Visual Imagery: The use of optical and visual elements in alchemical texts like Khunraths works was designed to create "stages" or visual spectacles that would guide the observers consciousness into a higher, contemplative state. These visuals were thought to help the viewer unite spiritually with the celestial realms: > Khunrath's theatre of images, like a mirror, catoptrically reflects the celestial spheres to the human mind, awakening the empathetic faculty of the human spirit. [Urszula Szul, page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18). 4. Imagination as the Quintessence: In late Renaissance alchemy, imagination was considered part of the quintessence, bridging the physical and spiritual realms. Through imagination, alchemists believed they could engage with spiritual forces and enact transformations both in themselves and in the material world: > Thus, the visual imagery of Khunrath's treatises has become the alchemical quintessence, the spiritualized matter of the philosopher's stone, transmuting both the human soul and the physical world into gold. [Urszula Szul, page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18). In summary, imagination and visualization were integral to Renaissance alchemy, functioning not only as tools for spiritual transformation but as methods to understand and manipulate the cosmos through both intellectual and mystical practices. You can explore more of these discussions in [Urszula Szul's text, page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18).
You
continue with the summary
Tool
{"result":["[Summary from page 18 to page 29 out of a total of 137:\nPages 18:\n8\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nBy means ofthe imaginative faculty residing in a human's astral body\n(the \"supercoelestis corpus\"), an empathetic union could beattained with\ncosmic Anthropos, a state of being which provided humans with true\nwisdom. Paracelsus found no contradiction between his concept of a\nknowledge intuited with the aid of the heavens and his parallel assertion\nthat it was necessary to undertake an empirical investigation of natural\nphenomena in \"das Licht der Natur\". Modernist science would find a\ndegree of conflict between these two modes of gaining knowledge, those\nofrevelation and empirical deduction. Pagel, however, has defended the\nintegrity of Paracelsus' theoretical programme, arguing that in the Paracelsian system the outward manifestations of the light of nature were\nreflected in the light of human understanding. Paracelsus believed the\nsame celestial light illuminated, created and sustained nature, as well as\nthe human-being at the core of his being.16 The concept ofthe \"light of\nnature\" is one of the foundations of Khunrath's alchemy in which he\ndescribes an unbroken continuum of illuminated wisdom, incorporating\nboththe practical experience ofthe natural world, as well as the spiritual\nvision of the mystic.17\nIn Paracelsian theosophy, empathetic imagination was not a subjective and, therefore, neglible factor in human affairs, but a powerful astral\nforce which provided the basis for theurgy and prognostication, as well as\nfor prophecy and mystical inspiration. Consequently, the Paracelsian\ntheosophical system eliminated, or diminished, the role of the institutionalised Christian church as the interpreter of God's will by means ofthe\ncanonical scriptures. Replacing external authority, the individual intuition became a more immediate and truer guide to divine knowledge.\nEven more radically, Paracelsus stated that through the imaginative faculties ofthe astral body a human could attain beatific union with God.18\nThe influence of Paracelsian theosophy on German pietists such as Valentin Weigel and Johannes Arndt19 and their subsequent effects on alchemical ideas will be discussed in a later chapter.\nIn the immediate context, it is evident that Paracelsus' concept ofthe\nrole of the imagination in both magical and spiritual practices would\nencourage the use of visual imagery. For example, Khunrath's \"amphi-\ntheatre\" of 1595 and 1609 provides a public spectacle for an audience,\ndisplaying the actions of Eternal Wisdom on the physical chemistry ofthe\nmanifested creation. In Paracelsian terms, Khunrath shows how the\nphysical world is united to the divine principle by means ofthe \"quintessence\" or \"azoth\". The Paracelsian \"azoth\" was a concept adopted from\nthe late medieval theory ofthe \"coelum\", a medium between matter and\nsoul, world and God, in other words an \"astral\" substance, both physical\nand spiritual in nature. Therefore, it had exactly the same character and\nthe same function as the human imagination in the astral body. Paracelus\nhad, in fact, stated that the imagination was the \"coelum in homine\".20\nHence, in Paracelsian chemical theosophy the \"quintessence\" was not\nonly a chemical substance, but also a psychic faculty that of the imagination or fantasy.\nKhunrath reiterates precisely the same theosophical concepts in his\nwritings from 1595,21 providing not only instructions for practical and\nspiritual chemistry, but also, in the Amphiteatrum, giving \"tangible\" demonstrations ofthe astral and spiritual faculties. His engravings are intended to excite the imagination of the viewer so that a mystic alchemy can\ntake place through the act of visual contemplation. Khunrath's \"amphiteatrum\" is a \"spectaculum\", a word related linguistically to that of\n\"speculum\", a secondary meaning which the reader was undoubtedly\nintended to retrieve from the original title ofthe treatise. Hence, Khunrath's theatre of images, like a mirror, catoptrically reflects the celestial\nspheres to the human mind, awakening the empathetic faculty of the\nhuman spirit which unites, through the imagination, with the heavenly\nrealms. Thus, the visual imagery of Khunrath's treatises has become the\nalchemical quintessence, the spiritualised matter of the philosopher's\nstone, transmuting both the human soul and the physical world into gold.\nIt is evident that late Renaissance alchemists were involved in a radical semiotic enterprise, intuiting the possibility of devising a visual signing-system which would resolve the dualistic conflict of the European\nlinguistic sign in which signifier and signified were arbitrarily related.22\nAccordingly, John Dee regarded his Monas Hieroglyphica as a graphic\nsystem which was also practical chemistry (figs. 17, 18), a metonymic\ncontinuum of physical and conceptual alchemy.\n16 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" (1979), pp. 59-60. For a different interpretation of Paracelsus' two kinds of knowledge, as interpreted by Valentin Weigel, see\nPeuckert, Pansophie (1956), 2, pp. 295-300.\n17 For example in Heinrich Khunrath, Chaos (Magdeburg: Johann Schemidt, 1616),\np. 68.\n18 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" ( 1979), pp. 60-62, 70-74.\n19 See Frick, Die Erleuchteten. Gnostische-theosophische und alchemistisch-rosenkeuzerische\nGeheimgesellschaften ( 1973), pp. 112-63.\n9\n20 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" in Epochen der Naturmystik (1979), pp. 60-62,\n91-92.\n21 For example, see Heinrich Khunrath, Chaos (Magdeburg: J. Schmeidt for Johann\nFrancken, 1616), pp. 68-72.\n22 Referto Szonyi, \"Ars Scintrilla\" (1999), passim, and his paper forthcoming in RenaissanceQuarterlyfor a discussion ofthe theurgic linguistics ofFicino, Agrippa and Paracelsus.\n\nPages 19:\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nAlchemy has always been a type of \"gnosis\", a non-rational esoteric\nphilosophy, fully explicable only by its initiates. Fundamentally an oral\nsystem of knowledge, the epistemic changes in alchemical theory cannot\nbe recovered in their entirety by contemporary historians, even from the\nconsiderable amount ofphysical evidence available to them. Problems of\ninterpretation are exacerbated by the fact that there are few immutable\nmeanings for the various symbols since they have become amplified in\nthe course of their historical use. In Barthes' terms, they should be considered as \"mythic\" secondary-level signifiers, each alchemical sign bearing with it the history of its use. Thus, although dictionaries ofalchemical\nterms, such as Dom Pernety's, are numerous, they have more value as\nhistorical artefacts in their own right, rather than as aids to the contemporary historian.23 The absence ofthe objective markers provided by oral\nwitness has occasionally produced strange results in contemporary alchemical research in which scholars may find themselves producing a\nparallel alchemical treatise to the original text, rather than an empirical\ncommentary on it. This happened in the case of Jung who produced a\nnew school ofalchemy, which was as much a continuation of the Paracelsian theosophical tradition, as a critique ofit.24\nIn the psychological approach of the Jungians and Freudians, alchemy\nis presented as a \"perennis philosophia\" of symbolic archetypes and ideas\nrepressed bythe rational mind. The misconception in these psychological\nstudies is that it is possible to \"explain\" alchemy while disregarding the\nepistomology of a particular concept. A more cautious iconographic approach may yield, at least, a partially verifiable rationale for the historical\ndevelopment of alchemical theory. For example, studies such as those of\nBarbara Obrist and Pamela Smith have demonstrated that alchemy is\nnot a transhistorical myth, but a construct which is culturallyproduced.25\nObrist's research is of particular importance to the present argument\nsince she has explained the reasons for the appearance ofelaborate cycles\nof visual illustration in the late fourteenth century.\nIt is debatable whether \"alchemy\" is an ageless \"prisca theologia\",\nalthough important elements have remained constant through-out its two\nthousand years of history. Perhaps it is more useful to view alchemy as an\nevolving language, which is both a self-contained structure, yet which\nchanges according to the dictates of its own chronological period. In\nPiaget's definition, a \"structure\" has an innate organic integrity and coherence, with a set of intrinsic laws self-regulating its dynamic transformations.26 The present study aims to demonstrate the operation ofsome\nof the geometric and optical signifiers which facilitated communication\nbetween the Renaissance alchemist and his audience.\nIO\n23 Dom Pernety, Dictionaire mytho-hermetique (Paris, 1787; Paris, 1972).\n24 For an example of a Freudian alchemical treatise see Johannes Fabricius, Alchemy\n(Copenhaven: Rosenkilde and Bagger, 1976).\n25 Barbara Obrist, Les Debuts de l'Imagerie Alchimique (XIV -XVe siecles) (Paris: Le\nSycomore, 1982). A similar study on the political context ofalchemy is Pamela H. Smith,\nThe Business ofAlchemy (Princeton UP, 1994).\n26 Jean Piaget, Structuralism (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1971), pp. 5-16.\nII\n\nPages 20:\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY IN LATE MEDIEVAL\nAND EARLY RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\nAlchemical geometry in the Renaissance can be described as passive or\noperative, either using geometrical structures to organise information\ninto tabulations, circular formats or tree-like structures, or, as in the case\nofpseudo-Lullian alchemy, employing a mobile computational system.\nAnother, more complex, type of alchemical geometry emerged in the late\nsixteenth century, based on optical and perspectival diagrams which inter-related Pythagorean geometry, optical science, Paracelsian alchemy\nand cabbalism.\nBy the fifteenth century, European alchemists had several goals,\nnamely, chemical work on matter to remove its impurities, spiritual work\nto redeem their own souls and, finally, a practical medical purpose.3\nFrom the late fourteenth century they were also attempting to develop a\nvisual signing-system which could express paradox, specifically the concept of the union of opposites. Their semiotic quest was based on a\npantheistic intuition which had accompanied alchemy from its origins in\nlate hellenistic culture. The pagan alchemists had believed that matter\nwas pervaded by spirit since the world was God's emanation in a perpetual cycle ofcreation, dissolution and re-creation. Matter and spirit, thus,\nformed one essential identity.\nIn the fourteenth century, Arnald of Villanova and John of Rupescissa\nhad also introduced a new medical purpose into the traditional alchemical theories oftransmutation. Subsequently, alchemists sought not only to\ncreate the philosopher's stone, they also ventured on another, equally\nurgent, quest which was to produce the \"universal panacea\", said to be\ncomposed ofthe\"quintessence\" which had been described byAristotle as\na mean between matter and spirit out ofwhich the heavenly spheres were\nformed. The introduction of a medical purpose into alchemy also neces1-12 Szulakowska, \"Geometry and Optics in Renaissance Alchemical Illustration\" (1995):\n2 Urszula Szulakowska, \"Material Pantheism in the Pseudo-Lullian \"S\"-Circle of the\nPowers of the Soul\", Ambix, 35 (1988): 127-54.\n3 Coudert, pp. 14-35; F. Sherwood-Taylor, The Alchemists (St. Albans: Paladin, 1976),\npp. 15-23; G. F. Hartlaub, Der Stein der Weisen (Munich, 1959), passim.\n\nPages 21:\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nsitated a more refined use of astrological data in order to correlate the\nlaboratory work with the influences ofthe stars.\nOn the model, thus, of the circulating heavens governing the seasons\nof nature, the alchemical process was conceptualised as being a circular\nprocess. Pagan alchemists of the Christian era, such as Zosimos, subscribed to gnostic and hermetic beliefs that the human soul could rise to\na higher level through meditative practices and esoteric rituals. The alchemists transposed this mystical idea into chemistry whereby, in the\ncourse of refining his materials, the operator simultaneously purified his\nown being and united with God. A related Orphic and Pythagorean\nconcept was that of the soul's reincarnation and immortality.5 In a similar manner, alchemists conceptualised matter as being reborn during the\nchemical work in a higher incarnation of its former corrupted self.\nHence, the hellenistic alchemists adopted the gnostic symbol of the\nOuroboros, a snake holding its tail in its mouth to represent the infinite\ncircle of time. By the late hellenistic period, alchemy was conceived as\nbeing a circular process which began with perfection (the origins ofmatter in God) and ended in perfection (the spiritualised matter produced by\nthe alchemist). Hence, the geometric form of the circle was the fundamental signifier of alchemy.\nAnother basic tenet of hellenistic hermeticism and alchemy in the first\nChristian centuries was that of the unity and dynamic interaction between God and human, spirit and matter, heaven and earth, body and\nsoul. It was believed that God enacted his will on the earth through the\nagency of the stellar spheres and planets. In alchemy the inter-relationship ofspirit and matter was represented by the marriage ofthe Sun and\nthe Moon (spirit with matter), whose offspring was the philosopher's\nstone ofthe medieval alchemists. Its essential form was the perfect circle,\ninsusceptible to the corrupting effects of natural transmutation.\nAstrology was an essential component of alchemical practice since\nalchemy, as a mirror of nature, was similarly affected by stellar influences. The medieval Jewish cabbalistic text, the Zohar, also stressed the necessity of watching the activity of the heavens in order to understand the\ncourse ofhuman affairs.10 The medieval alchemists, especially the pseudo-Lullians of the fifteenth century, emphasised the need to correlate\ntheir chemical\nwork with the motions of the planets and the signs ofthe\nZodiac.11 By the early sixteenth century, Paracelsus was teaching that the\nefficacy of alchemical medications was totally dependent on their concordance with the healing virtues emanating from the stars.12\nThe inter-dependency and unity between macrocosm and microcosm\nhad been summarised in the late Alexandrian text of the Emerald Table\nattributed to Hermes Trismegistus (circa second century AD) which became the iconic statement ofthe alchemists, \"That which is above is like\nto that which is below\". The subject ofthis verse is an unidentified entity,\nstated to be the child of the moon, which is carried in the womb of the\nwind. It rises to the heavens above and sinks down again to the earth,\nrepeatedly.13 The Emerald Table became an appropriate description ofthe\nalchemical process with the subsequent invention of the chemical still.\nZosimos had discovered distillation in circa 300 AD, but it was the Arabs\n14\nH. J. Sheppard, \"The Redemption Theme and Hellenistic Alchemy\", Ambix, 8\n(1960): 98-110 and also H.J. Sheppard, \"Gnosticism and Alchemy\", Ambix, 6 (1957-58):\n140-48. For a different view of the role of gnosis in hellenistic alchemy see Frick, Die\nErleuchteten (1973), pp. 77-80.\n5 This issue is discussed in Urszula Szulakowska, \"The Pseudo-Lullian Origins of\nGeorge Ripley's Maps and Routes\", Cosmos, 9 (1993): 107-26. See also Daniel Pickering\nWalker, \"Eternity and the After-Life\", JWCI(1964): 241-50.\n6 H.J. Sheppard, \"The Ouroboros and the Unity of Matter in Alchemy\", Ambix, 10\n(1962): 83 ff; Frick, Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 9-26.\n7 Marcelin P. E. Berthelot, Introduction a L'Etude de la Chimie des Anciens et de Moyen Age\n(Paris, 1889), passim; M. P. E. Berthelot, Les Origines de l'Alchimie (Paris, 1885), passim.\nFrick provides a succinct discussion of the alchemy ofthe late hellenistic period and its\ninfluence on the Arabs in Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 67-88.\n8 Andre Jean Festugiere, La Revelation d'Hermes Trismegiste, 1, L'Astrologie et les Sciences\nOccultes (Paris, 1944; Paris, 1950) and vol 2, Le Dieu Cosmique (Paris, 1949).\n15\n9 Joachim Telle, Sol und Luna (Hurtgenwald: Guido Pressler, 1980), pp. 55-64.\n10 Sherwood-Taylor (1976), pp. 21-22, 51-54. Also see Aby Warburg, Orientalisierende\nAstrologie (Leipzig, 1927). For astrology in cabbalism see Fischel Lachower and Isaiah\nTisby (eds), The Wisdom of the Zohar, 2 (Oxford U.P, 1989), pp. 662-66 and Frick, Die\nErleuchteten (1973), pp. 58-66.\nSherwood-Taylor (1976), pp. 51-54; Lynn Thorndike, History ofMagic and Experimental Science, 4 (New York: Columbia U.P, 1953), p. 36. Henceforward, this work will be\ndesignated as \"M&ES\" ; Eugenio Garin, Lo Zodiaco della Vita (Rome and Bari, 1976); Aby\nWarburg, Italienische Kunst und internazionale Astrologie (Rome, 1922), pp.180-93.\n12 Karl Sudhoff and Wilhelm Matthiesen (eds), Paracelsus. Samtliche Werke, I, vols. 1-5,\n10-14 (Munich; Berlin: R. Oldenbourg, 1928-33), for example, vol. 3, pp. 92-200, Decem\nlibriArchidoxis and vol. 12, pp. 1-444, Astronomia Magna, as well as vol. 12, pp. 503-5, Ars\nsignatoria.Another central Paracelsian text concerning the influence ofthe stars on a long\nand healthy life is De vita longa, Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 221-48 (German text), 249-92 (Latin\nversion). The standard authority on the Paracelsian system is Walter Pagel, Paracelsus\n(Basel: Karger, 1982), see pp. 64-71.\n13 E. J. Holmyard, \"The Emerald Table\", Nature (1923): 525-26; Robert Steele and\nDorothea Waley Singer, \"The Emerald Table\", Proceedings ofthe Royal Society ofMedicine, 21\n(1928): 41-57. For an account of hellenistic hermeticism and alchemy see Frick, Die\nErleuchteten (1973), pp. 72-88.\n\nPages 22:\n16\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nwho developed the full procedure in the seventh century. 14 In Arabic and\nmedieval European alchemy, the Emerald Table came to be regarded as a\nmetaphor ofthe circular process of distillation in which the volatile spirits\nwere repeatedly separated by heat from the material dregs and rewith them. When the spirits were deemed to be sufficiently purified,united\nwere conducted into a separate container, while the materials left inthey\nthe\nflask were calcinated and purified, eventually being re-united with the\nspirits . Hence, the volatile spirits left the dregs of \" dead\" matter, in the\nsame manner as the human soul left the body at death. So too,\nthey were\nreturned to the matter, just as in Christian belief the soul rejoined the\nbody at the Last Judgement. The process of distillation, thus, symbolised\nboth death and resurrection, as well as the union of macro and microcosm .\nA pantheistic current, promoting the concept of a\nbetween spirit and matter, entered medieval alchemy from the union\nmystical\nof\ndivine numbers invented by Pythagoras. He believed that thesystem\noriginal\nIdeal Numbers existed eternally in the Mind of God who created the\nworld by means of their emanation from the Monad to the Decad.\nTherefore, mathematical knowledge provided a direct link with God,\nsince the human soul was constituted from pure number. The\nsacred\nnumbers were the skeletal structure of manifestation and they could\nbe\ninterpreted as taking a corresponding geometrical form: 1 = point: 2 =\nline: 3 triangle (plane): 4 = cube (third-dimension). Pythagoras considered that the Ideal Numbers realised themselves in a material form by\nmeans of a trinitarian dialectic. In this process, the Monad produced the\nDyad, their opposition being resolved in the Ternary which producedthe\nQuaternary, the sequence continuing through the rest of the numbers to\nthe Decad. Pythagoras also developed a system of mathematical ratios to\nexplain the order of creation, obtaining these from a musical model, that\nof the monochord, which he believed to be generated by the motions of\nthe stellar spheres and planets.15\nArabian scholars translated many of the late hellenistic neoplatonic,\nneopythagorean and hermetic treatises and, through Latin\nfrom the Arabic in the late twelfth century, some ideas were translations\ntransmitted\nto the West.16 In the early medieval period, the Christian philosopher\nBoethius produced an influential doctrine based on Pythagorean geometryand arithmetic which he expounded in his De Institutione Musica andDe\nInstitutione Arithmetica.17 These works laid the foundation of medieval\nscholarship and his ideas supplied the parameters for the world-view of\nthe medieval period. Due to Boethius, Pythagorean mathematics, geometry and music were introduced into the medieval universities, becoming\nthe \"lingua franca\" of European science and art. This mystical ideology\nwas a major constituent of the liberal arts\ncurriculum, lying uneasily\nalongside Aristotelian natural philosophy.18\nHowever, it was not until the late fourteenth and early fifteenth centuries that the conceptual influence of Pythagorean geometry could be discerned in an alchemical context. It made its first appearance in a novel\ntype of alchemical imagery in the late fourteenth century, far more complex than earlier hellenistic and Arabic graphic cyphers since the new\nillustrations involved a whole sequence of pictorial imagery. In addition\nto figurative and narrative elements, the visual forms also involved geometrical schemes, though they lacked finesse in design and graphic skill.\nSuch crude geometries, accompanying equally rough symbolic figures,\nare first encountered in the untitled alchemical treatise of Gratheus and\nin another work by the alchemist Constantinus, Le livre des secrets de ma\ndame alchimie, but in these two treatises the geometrical structures are little\nmore than frames for the figurative imagery.19\nIn her investigation of the origins of alchemical illustration, Obrist\nargued that the function ofthese visual forms was rhetorical. They were\na strategy devised to counter the arguments of the scholastics who concurred with Aristotle in maintaining that a substance could not change\nspecies. In the Aristotelian definition, \"species\" constituted distinct orders\nwhich could not interchange their formal qualities. Therefore, since the\ndifferent metals belonged to different species, lead could not turn into\ngold. This scholastic argument completely invalidated the whole alchemical enterprise. In response, alchemists produced a rhetorical device, permitting them to ignore such pedestrian objections. They \"proved\" the\ntruth of alchemy by means of pictures which aimed to confuse reality\nwith its painted simulacrum. In addition, alchemical illustrators appropriated Christian iconography, deliberately conflating alchemical imagery\n14 Robert P.\n(1956): 439-46. Multhauf, \"The significance of distillation\", Bulletin ofthe History ofMedicine\n15 Peter Gorman , Pythagoras. A Life (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1979). A more\ncomplex analysis can be found in Michael\nJ. B. Allen, Plato and Nuptial Arithmetic (Univ.\nCalifornia, 1994), pp. 44-80.\n16 For a general over-view see Paul Oskar Kristeller, Renaissance Thought and Its Sources\n(New York: Columbia U.P, 1979). A more specific argument is that of Brian P.\nCopenhaver in David C. Lindberg and Robert R. Westman, Reappraisals ofthe Scientific\nRevolution (Cambridge UP, 1990), pp. 261-301.\n17 Vincent Foster Hopper, MedievalNumber Symbolism (New York: Columbia U.P, 1938).\n18 Gordon Leff, Paris and Oxford Universities in the 13th-C and 14 th-C (New York, 1968).\n19 Obrist, figs. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 11.\n17\n\nPages 23:\n18\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nwith the sacred visions of the saints. In this manner, the alchemists\nmoved their theories from the ground of scholastic debate to that ofthe\nunquestionable truths of the Christian faith.20\nAnother major development in alchemical visual imagery took place\nin the early fifteenth century when a complex geometry intended as a\npractical device was created by pseudo-Lullian alchemists. These were a\ngroup of anonymous writers working under the name of the Catalan\nmystic Ramon Lull, although he had not accepted the claims of alchemy\nand had never discussed the subject. Regardless of this fact in the late\nfourteenth century the first unillustrated text appeared under his name in\nCatalonia. Transported to Northern Italy, the older texts were translated\nfrom the vernacular into Latin and new ones were produced, with the\nfirst alchemical Lullian geometries appeaing in the 1430s to 1440s (figs.\n4-7).21 The original Lullian Art (invented in circa 1272) had been designed as a system of logic using visual computational figures.22 The\ndiagrams were intended to be cut from paper and constructed into a\nmobile calculator, fastened in the middle with string. The pseudoLullians, similarly, appropriated the Lullian tabulations which had recorded the computations of the letters of the alphabet and they also\nemployed Lullian tree diagrams. The alphabet performed a symbolic\nfunction representing the various objects of discourse, a device which\nLull had encountered in the cabbalistic alphabets of Abraham Abulafia\nin thirteenth century Spain.\nThere are three main ideas in pseudo-Lullian theory, those of circularity, motion and of the medium between opposites, all of which originate in Aristotle's theory ofthe four elements. In his text On Coming-to-be\nand Passing Away Aristotle had demonstrated that the changing nature of\nthe world was the result of the constant transmutation of the elements\ninto one other.23 Since each element had two qualities (fire had heat and\ndryness), therefore, opposites united by moving through their common\nquality, for example, fire turning into water by passing through the quality of dryness shared with earth and then through the quality of coldness\nwhich earth shared with water. In the medieval period, Aristotle's theory\nwas pictured as a square with the elements placed at the four corners, the\nopposites being laid out across the diagonals (fig. 3). Around the edges of\nthe square the mutations took place in a circular motion.24\nHence, the symbolic picture of the alchemical process was not only\nthat of a circle, but also that of the squaring of the circle. The same idea\nis subsequently encountered in George Ripley's Compound of Alchemy as\nwell as in Michael Maier's Emblem XLVI in the Atalanta Fugiens (fig. 39).\nSince this geometrical feat cannot be accomplished in Euclidean geometry, therefore, the concept of the squaring of the circle came to signify\nany process which could be accomplished only by means of divine intervention. In fact, it became a generic sign for the alchemical process itself\nand Maier produced a treatise based on this idea, De Circulo Physico,\nQuadrato (Oppenheim: Luca Jennis, 1616), which was an account ofthe\nrole of the sun in the making ofpotable gold.\nIn alchemical theory, the squaring of the circle was a monistic concept\nsince it implied that nature (signified by the square of the four elements)\nwas God (signified by the perfect circle). Perhaps unwittingly, the pseudoLullian alchemists introduced a material pantheism into their conceptual\nstructures, thereby transgressing Catholic dogma which abhorred any\nidentification ofnature with God. Lull himself had encountered the same\nheresy in the design of his original geometry in the 1270s based on the\nnumber four, causing him to produce another model in the 1290s based\non a trinitarian structure. Whichever numerology was employed in the\nLullian Art, it radically altered the metaphysical universe conceptualised\nby the system.25\nLull's numerology of three represented the conventional Christian\nimage of the Triune God (Father; Son; Holy Spirit) in his alchemical\nmirror as soul, matter, spirit, while the numerology based on four represented matter (the four elements). In the Ars Compendiosa of the 1270s the\nfirst Lullian scheme consisted of a series of diagrams based on the \"Figura Animae A\"\", representing the soul. They took the form ofa numberof\nconcentric circles, around whose circumference Lull placed the names of\nthe dignities of God such as \"Magnitudo\", or \"Bonitas\", as established by\nneoplatonic Christian doctrine (fig. 4). In the middle of each circle there\nwere located four over-lapping squares, signifying the physical elements.\nGod was then allocated sixteen dignities (4 x 4) at the edges of the circle\nto accord with the inner squares. The conceptual outcome was that God\nwas given the form of matter (fig. 5, pseudo-Lullian version).\n20 Obrist, pp. 55-65, 248-49.\n21 Michela Pereira, The Alchemical Corpus Attributed to Raymond Lull (London: Warburg\nInstitute, 1989), pp. 6-8, 12-15, 17-20, 22-28.\n22 Frances A. Yates, \"The Art of Ramon Lull\", J. W. C. I(1954): 115-73;\nF.A. Yates, \"Ramon Lull andJohn Scotus Erigena\", J. W. C. I (1960): 1-44.\n23 Aristotle, On Coming-to-be and Passing Away (Oxford: Clarendon, 1922). On pseudoLullism see Thorndike, M&ES, 4, pp.3-64, esp pp. 34-35.\n19\n24 Yates (1954): 149, fig. 2.\n25 Erardo-W Platzeck, \"Descubrimento y esencia del Arte del. Bto. Ramon Lull\",\nEstudios Lulianos, 8 (1964): 137-54.\n\nPages 24:\n20\n21\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nIt seems probable that in order to conform to Catholic orthodoxy,\nLull changed his geometrical system to one corresponding with the Augustinian theory of\"exemplarism\". In this neoplatonic system nature is a\nmirror of God and, thus, displays his trinitarian form without being any\npart of God himself. In his Ars Inventiva Veritatis (1289-90), Lull produced\na new circular diagram of the \"Figura Animae\", computed this time by\nthree triangles (3 x 3), with God being awarded nine dignities. This symbolically expressed the nature of God as pure spirit26in the three Persons\nof the Holy Trinity (fig. 6, pseudo-Lullian version).\nThe second fundamental figure ofthe Art was the circle ofthe \"Figura\nT\" which correlated the \"Figura A\" by means of a set of qualifying\ncategories. It was always provided with triangles in order to perform its\ncomputing function (fig. 7). On the inner circles were written the names\nof various aspects of the subject of investigation and a formulated set of\nquestions addressed the various issues. The over-lapping quadrangles (in\nthe first version of the Art in the 1270s), or triangles (in the second\nversion of the 1290s), computed the answers.\nThe pseudo-Lullian alchemists were little affected by Lull's theological\nproblems, since they used both of his numerological systems interchangeably, applying whichever geometry best suited their immediate purpose\n(figs. 5, 6). In fact, pseudo-Lullian alchemy, for all its heretical connotations, flourished above all other types through-out the fifteenth and into\nthe early sixteenth century. Its attraction undoubtedly lay in the possibility of building the diagrams as conceptual play-things. Pseudo-Lullian\ndiagrams appeared to rationalise alchemy, laying-open to human sight a\nmap, or vademecum, of the necessary procedures.\nLullian geometries influenced some of the engravings in Khunrath's\nAmphiteatrum Sapientiae Aeternae (fig. 33), as well as illustrations produced\nfor Oswald Croll, Johann Mylius, Jacob Boehme and other alchemists.\nAgrippa in his De Occulta Philosophia (1533) was an influential force in the\nfurther dispersal and development of Lullian ideas in the early sixteenth\ncentury27 and in the same years, Pantheus of Venice introduced cabbalism into the Lullian geometry of his Voarchadumia (1530). Using complicated Latin alphabetical systems, magical cyphers and cabbalistic Hebrew letters and names, Pantheus made a significant amendment to the\nbasic Lullian \"Figura A\" by turning it into a static diagram, more like a\nmap with four compass points, than a computational device (fig. 8).28\nJohn Dee obtained a large number of Lullian and pseudo-Lullian treatises, as well as the Voarchadumia, but he rejected this system in favour of\ncabbalism and catoptrics for his own Monas Hieroglyphica,29 although, according to Clucas, Dee employed Lullian geometry for his angelic magic.30 Dee's alchemical collaborator, Edward Kelley, was strongly influenced by the pseudo-Lullians and by their English follower, George\nRipley, whose works also appear in Dee's library.31\nIn the late fifteenth century George Ripley, canon of Bridlington (active 1450 to 1490) introduced pseudo-Lullian alchemy into England, dispersing these ideas through his Cantilena (De lapide philosophorum, seu de\nphoenice).32 In his later treatise, the Duodecim Portae (first published in England as The Compound ofAlchemy in 1591), Ripley devised an alchemical\ntopography which translated the original Lullian computational circles\ninto a geographical map. He described a castle with twelve doors which\nhad to be negotiated by a circular sea-voyage. Both the castle and the\ncircular journey represented the pseudo-Lullian alchemical circles. Ripley speaks of\"turning the wheel\" to take a course into the four corners of\nthe earth, visualising the alchemist as a helmsman on a ship and the\nalchemical process as an expedition across the oceans. His \"wheel\" signified the Aristotelian square ofthe four elements (fig. 3).33 Ripleyobtained\nhis idea ofthe rotation ofthe elements from the pseudo-Lullians, making\nstatements such as,\nBut fyrst of these Elements make thou Rotacyon,\nAnd into Water thy Erth turne fyrst of all;34\n26 This issue is discussed at length in Szulakowska (1988): 127-54.\n27 Henry Cornelius Agrippa, \"in artem brevem Raymundi Lullii Commentaria\" in\nOpera, 2 (London, 1600), pp. 449-51. See also Thorndike, M&ES, 5, pp. 127-38.\n28 Joannes Pantheus, \"Ars et Theoria\", Theatrum Chemicum, (Strassburg: Zetzner, 1659/\n61), pp. 459-549, fig. p. 460. Also Clulee, pp. 101-3.\n29 Roberts and Watson, John Dee's Library Catalogue (1990), for Lull and ps. Lull see\n1401-1424, 2278-2281, B217, B241, B224, DM8, M16, M23, M46, M66; Pantheus 1437,\nD16.\n30 Clucas (1998), pp. 109-32.\n31 Elias Ashmole, \"Sir Edward Kelley to G. S. Gent.\" in Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum\n(London, 1652; New York and London, 1967), pp. 324-33. Other texts were translated into English by Arthur E. Waite in The Alchemical Writings of Edward Kelly (London,\n1893). For Dee's Ripleian collection see Roberts and Watson, for example, DM4, DM6,\nDM91.\n32 N. L. Brann, \" George Ripleyand the Abbot Trithemius\", Ambix, 26 (1979), 212-19;\nStanton J. Linden, \"The Ripley Scrolls and The Compound ofAlchemy \", Glasgow Emblem\nStudies, 3 (1998), pp. 73-94. Professor Linden is currently preparing a critical edition of\nthe33Compound ofAlchemy.\nSzulakowska ( 1993).\n34 Ashmole, p. 133.\n\nPages 25:\n22\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\n... Altytude, Latytude, and Profundyte,\nBy whych algates turne we must our Whele;\nKnowing thy entraunce in the West shall be;\nThy passage forth into the North yf thou do well35\nOn the model ofRipley's Duodecim Portae Michael Maier described similar\nalchemical voyages around a Lullian alchemical circle in the Cantilenae\nIntelectuales (1617), Viatorium (1618) and Tripus Aureus (1618).36\nRipley's probable disciple Thomas Norton was similarly influenced by\npseudo-Lullian alchemy,37 producing one of the most important Renaissance alchemical treatises, The Ordinal ofAlchemy (begun in 1477).38 Dee\ntranscribed a copy of this text in his own hand in 1577 and had it bound\nin purple velvet (Bodleian Library MS Ashmole 57).39 According to Ashmole, Maier came to England in 1611 specifically to learn English, so\nthat he could translate Norton's treatise into Latin for his compendium of\nalchemical texts, the Tripus Aureus (Frankfurt, 1618).40 Norton also referred to the importance of geometry in his alchemical theory, but he\ndeveloped this idea much further than either the pseudo-Lullians or Ripley. In fact, although Norton's Ordinal is related conceptually to the work\nof Ripley, it is very different in tone and structure from any of Ripley's\ntexts. Norton carries the authority of a learned university scholar and his\nalchemical claims are supported by discursive comments which evidence\na much wider philosophical background. He was not the first English\nalchemist to advocate the use of geometry in alchemy since in the thirteenth century Roger Bacon in his Mirror of Alchemy had noted the applicability of geometry and mathematics to alchemy.41 Norton, however,\nwas the first to recommend taking recourse to all seven liberal arts. In\nthis his direct influence was Boethius and he mentions Pythagorean musicology, specifically the tonal structures of the \"dyapason\", \"diapente\"\nand \"diatesseron\" . Most important in the context of the present study,\nNorton advised the alchemist to use \" science perspectyfe\".\nwhen Boicius seid: Tu numeris elementa ligas.\nIoyne your elementis Musicallye,\nFor ij causis: one is for melodye\nwhiche theire accordis wil make to your mynde\nThe trewe effecte when that ye shalle fynde;\nAnd al-so for like Dyapason,\nwith diapente & withdiatesseron,\nwith ypate ypaton & lekanos Muse(d),\nwith accordis which in musike de (used),\nwith theire proporcions cawsen Armonye,\nMuch like proporcions be in Alchymye ...\nWith astrologie ioyn Elementis also,\nTo fortune theire worchingis as thei go; ...\nAnd science perspectyfe gevith grete euydence\nTo al the mynysters of this science;\n(British Library MS Add. 10, 302)42\nNorton also emphasised the importance of astrology in alchemical work.\nA copy of his Ordinal in British Library MS 10. 302 (circa 1490) includes\na diagram of astrological calculations (f. 67v).\nIn the late fourteenth century another important theoretical interrelation between astrology and alchemy was developed in the work of\nJohn ofRupescissa. In his De consideratione quinte essentie (circa 1370) Rupescissa described the properties ofan elixir oflife, a \"fiery water\" whichhe\ncalled the \"coelum\", or quintessence, a union of two antagonistic principles. He adapted Aristotelian physical theory to a medical purpose, regarding his \"coelum\" as being the universal panacea. While modern\nchemists would identify this substance as alchoholic spirits, earlier alchemists preferred to award Rupescissa's panacea a spiritual significance far\ngreater than that of a euphoric beverage. Consequently, his life-giving\nelixir was appropriated by the pseudo-Lullians to become the foundation\noftheir own alchemical practice.43\nBythe late sixteenth century the concept ofthe \"coelum\" was merging\nwith that of the Paracelsian \"flamma vitalis\", the fiery virtue in the air\nproduced bythe sun's rays. Drawing on the work ofRupescissa, Paracelsus described the fifth essence as the vital spirit of life in his De natura\nrerum, Archidoxis and De vita longa among other texts. In the Volumen medicinae paramirum (circa 1520) he defined the fiery virtue as an \"ens astrale\",\n35 Ashmole, p. 137.\n36 Szulakowska (1993).\n3738 See GarethRoberts, TheMirror ofAlchemy (London: British Library, 1994), pp.41-42.\nThe Ordinal ofAlchemy (Oxford U. P, 1975).\n39 John\nThis isReidy,Thomas\nR&W: DM96Norton.\n.\n40 Ron Heisler, \"Michael Maier and England\", The Hermetic Journal (1989): 119-25.\n+ Stanton J. Linden (ed),TheMirror ofAlchemy Composed by the Thrice- Famous and Learned\nFryer Roger Bacon (New York: Garland, 1992), p. 30: \"first learne geometry, and her\nmeasures, that so he may rightlyframe his furnaces, not passing a meane, either by excess\nor defect: and withall, he must know the quantitie ofhis fire\".\n23\n42 Reidy, pp. 53-54.\n43 Joannes de Rupescissa, La Vertu et Propriete de la Quinte Essence de Toutes Choses (Lyon:\nJean de Thoumes, 1549; Milan: Bibliotheca Hermetica, 1971). For an examination ofhis\ntheories see Thorndike, M&ES, 4, pp. 37-41; 5, pp. 630-32.\n\nPages 26:\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\noriginating in the celestial bodies, while in the Liber Azothhe spoke ofthe\nastral virtue as a fire, or a vital saltpetre, or nitre. Through pseudoLullian texts, the followers of Paracelsus related the Paracelsian stellar\nfire to that of Rupescissa's \"coelum\", specifically Blaise de Vigenere\n(1523-1596) in his Discourse ofFire and Salt (1608). Vigenere described the\nlife-giving property in air as a vital Sulphur, or fire and Salt, stating that\nthese were the basic components of saltpetre. Peter Severinus (15421602), physician to the Danish court, related the properties of the thunder to that of saltpetre. Another Paracelsian, Gerhard Dorn, borrowed\ndirectly from Rupescissa's original text for his description of the vital\nproperties of air in his Chymisticum artificii (1569). John Dee owned copies\nof Rupescissa's original treatise, in one instance bound together with\nParacelsus Wunder Artznei, and he also acquired various works by Dorn,\nincluding the Chymisticum artificii.\nAccording to Debus it was the Paracelsian chemists ofthe early seventeenth century who developed the specific theory of the vital saltpetre in\nair, withJoseph Du Chesne (Quercetanus) producing the full theory.\nBy the year 1600 it had become a basic part of the Paracelsian tradition to\nspeak ofthe vital air, or more specifically, theflamma vitalis or the vital aerial\nSulphur.44\nKhunrath integrated Rupescissa's quintessence into his own theoretical\nprogramme as the Paracelsian \"azoth\". This aetherial fire increased in\nsignificance from its first mention in his Amphiteatrum of 1595, becoming\nthe main subject of De Igne Magorum (circa 1602-1604). Khunrath also\ncommented extensively on the \"azoth\" in his second Amphiteatrum of\n1609, identifying it with the \"Magnesia\" and with Christ. He also employed Rupescissa's term for the quintessence calling it the \"caelum\",\nstating that it corresponded to the cabbalistic \"Schamaim\", the original\nsubstance used by the \"Ruah-Elohim\" (Christ as Creator God) in the\nformation of the world. Indeed, Khunrath expanded Rupescissa's astrological medicine into a Christocentric alchemical cosmogenesis.\nFifteenth and early sixteenth alchemical manuscripts and printed\nbooks, had pictured the celestial virtue as the fall of a heavenly \"dew\", or\n\"ros coeli\", onto the earth. An illustration of this process, transformed\ninto a cabbalistic symbol, is also encountered in the engraving of the\n\"Archetypos\" in Khunrath's Amphiteatrum (1595) (fig. 33). At the top of\nthe illustration, God appears in the form of his Hebrew name, the Tetragrammaton, showering his divine virtues onto the flames of aspiring\nsouls. The original concept ofthe dew of heaven had been developed and\ndispersed by an influential alchemical text ofthe late fourteenth century,\nthe Rosarium Philosophorum. This was composed of quotations from the\nmaster alchemists ofthe middle ages, organised into a sequential account\nof the alchemical process with additional commentaries. Illustrations had\nbeen added to the text by circa 1400, although it also continued to be\nissued without the pictures, the pictorial versions being known as the\n\"Rosarium cum figuris\".45 The iconographic sequence remained constant between manuscript and printed versions, of which the first appeared in Lyons in 1504. The Rosarium did not refer to Rupescissa's\n\"coelum\" since it was based on the medieval Aristotelian tradition.\nIn the Rosarium, the picture of the dew of heaven illustrates the final\nstages of the alchemical work, that of the \"ablutio vel mundificatio\", a\nseries of purifications (fig. 9). The image depicts a dead hermaphrodite,\nsignifying the incomplete philosopher's stone, being washed by a heavenly efflux. The text cites the Arabian alchemist Senior, who explains that\nthe gross residues require purification on the departure of the volatile\nspirits.46 Later on, an anonymous philosopher is made to comment on\nthe alchemical axiom, \"Wash Latona and burn your books\".47 Latona\nwas the mother ofApollo and Diana, gods of the sun and moon. Some of\nthe aphorisms in the last section of the Rosarium became the subject of\nMaier's emblems in the Atalanta Fugiens (1618), including the washing of\nLatona in Emblem XI. This provides evidence ofMaier's interest in the\nsubject of the celestial virtue and it should be noted that he also refersto\ncatoptrics in the same treatise. The text of the Rosarium states that the\n24\n44 Allen G. Debus,\"The Paracelsian Aerial Nitre\", Isis, 55 (1964): 43-61, esp 44-45,\n49ff, quotefrom p. 51. Thorndike, M&ES, 5, pp. 630-32. See also Pagel for the influence\nofRupescissa on Paracelsus, Pagel \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), pp. 91-92.\nFor Dee's collection see R&W: Rupescissa and the ps. Lullian version of his theory,\n1405,1436, 1457, M16, M46; Paracelsus on fifth essence 1496; Dorn 1447, 1512, 1517,\n1518, 1524 (Chymisticum articifici), 1525, 2227, 2236; Quercetanus 1544.\n25\n45 Thorndike,M&ES, 4, pp. 10-12. In Roberts and Watson's catalogue ofhis library,\nJohn Dee does not appear to have had a copy ofthe Rosarium, but he had copies ofallthe\nauthors who are cited in it. The authoritative edition ofthe Rosarium is Lutz Claren and\nJoachim Huber (eds), Rosarium Philosophorum, 2 vols (Weinheim: VCH, 1992), see vol 2,\nJoachim Telle, \"Bemerkungen zum \"Rosarium Philosophorum\"\", pp. 180-86.\n46 Claren and Huber, p.78: \"est res de coelo descendens, et terra cum humore suo\nsuscipit eam et retineatur aqua coeli cum aqua terrae, et aqua terrae propter servitium\nsuum et arenam suam honorat eam, et congregatur aquam in aquam ... et dealbatur ...\nSenior in Epistola Solis et Lune\".\n47 Claren and Huber, p. 79: \"Ideo dicit Philsophus: dealbate latonem et libros rumpite,\nne corda vestra rumpantur. Haec est enim compositio omnium Sapientum, et etiam tertia\npars totius operis. Iungite ergo ut dicitur in turba, siccum humido, id est terram nigram\ncum aqua sua, et coquite donec dealbatur\".\n\nPages 27:\n26\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nblack ashes should be supplied with \"humiditas\" to remove their impurities. The author identifies \"humiditas\" with the \"azoth\".48\nThe washing ofthe stone is followed by another picture, depicting the\nsoul returning from heaven to the inert body of the hermaphrodite. This\nalchemical process is described as \"Animae Iubilatio seu Ortus seu Sublimatio\". At this stage, the reader is informed, the fire should be stoked\nup and the chemicals heated, calcinated, albefied (whitened) and otherwise processed. Most notably, the Rosarium connects these events with\nAristotle's theory ofthe rotation ofthe elements which is interpreted as\nbeing a process of chemical refinement.49 The text also relates this work\nto the account in Genesis, 1, where the spirit of God is described as moving over the waters in the first days of creation. Hence, the idea being\nexpressed in this section of text is that the celestial dew contains the\nvivifying quality required to animate and perfect the philosopher's\nstone.50 The alchemist Alanus is cited on the livid, metallic, viscous qualities of this celestial fluid which, surprisingly, resembles gross chemical\nmercury.51\nIn the next section of the Rosarium, Aristotle is made to state that\n\"Nullum tingens venenum generatur absque Sole et eius umbra, id est\nuxore\" which became the subject ofMaier's Emblem XLV in the Atalanta\nFugiens (fig. 39).52 The commentary in the Rosarium explains thatthe process ofsublimation consists of removing the purest parts from the faeces of\nimpure matter so that they may attain the quintessential virtue.53 The\naccompanying illustration pictures the soul departing once again from\nthe body to allow the ashes to undergo further purification.\nThe most important illustration in the Rosarium appears near the end\nofthe treatise in a section concerning \"Illuminatio\", which could provide\nevidence for the use of solar rays in late medieval alchemy. The picture\nshows a blazing sun, either rising out of a grave, or falling into it (fig. 10).\nAlthough the accompanying text makes no clear reference to the use of\nsun-light, yet, in its discussion of the perfect nature of gold there may be\na hidden allusion to this process. The reader is required to undertake a\ngeometrical exercise involving the form of the circle which is also said to\nbe that ofthe sun, the dominating astral body.54 The sun is described as\ngiving his light to the stars, planets and moon. This solar theme continues\ninto the next stage of the process, that of \"Multiplicatio\" which is the\naugmentation of the powers of the stone. The illustration of dew falling\nonto the dead hermaphrodite re-appears (fig. 9) and Geber is quoted on\nthe multiplication ofthe \"solaris medicinae\", potable gold. The reader is\ninstructed to project the elixir of gold, or of the sun's rays perhaps,\nrepeatedly over the ashes.55 The final process in the Rosarium is that of\n\"Revificatio\" which completes the making of the philosopher's stone and\nis signified by a picture of the soul returning to the bodyfrom heaven.56\nA common factor in all these alchemical theories, those of pseudoLull, Ripley, Norton and the Rosarium, is that the celestial virtue (occasionally related to the sun's rays) is often conceptualised by geometrical\nparadigms. It may be concluded that the geometry of these alchemical\ntreatises signifies the use of astrology which is wholly dependent on mathematics and geometry. Out of this general historical context, John Dee\nwas to devise a more specific deployment ofthe astral virtues in alchemy\nby means of scholastic optical theory and astronomy and, subsequently,\nby the cabbalah.\n48 Claren and Huber, p. 81. For more information see Pagel (1982), pp. 59-61, including the well-known portrait of Paracelsus in which the word \"azoth\" is written on the\nknob\nof his walking-stick. See also Debus (1964): 43-61.\n49 Claren\nand Huber, p. 86.\n50 Claren and Huber, pp. 87-88: \"Senior... Haec aqua divina est rex de coelo\ndescendens. Idem: Ipse est reductor animae ad corpus suum, quod vivificat post mortem\nfacta\nsuam, et per eum vita est, postquam non erit mors ... Genesis ... Ex aqua omniaea\".\nsunt, et super aquam ferebatur spiritus dei, et principium generationis hominis ex\n51 Claren and Huber, pp. 88-89: \"Alanus Philosophus. Una res ex omnibus est\neligenda, quae est lividi coloris, habens speciem metallicam limpideam et liquidam, et est\nres calida et humida, aquosa et adustiva, et est oleum vivum, et tinctura viva, lapis\nmineralis et aqua vitae mirae efficacie\"..\n52 Claren and Huber, p. 89.\n53 Claren and Huber, p. 89: \"Secunda Sublimatio est extractio, quod in ipsa est de\nnatura quintae essentiae, a fecibus elementaribus separata. Dico autem quintam\nessentiam animam tingentem, ad quam necessaria est ablutio, ut per eam extrahatur\nunctuosas arsenice ... sive natura oleaginosa, purissimae unctuositas, quae ligata estcum\nfecibus suis, quae feces non permittunt ipsam sublimari\".\n27\n54 Claren and Huber, p. 121: \"Fili recipe de simplicissimo et de rotundo corpore, et\nnoli recipere de triangula vel quadrangulo sed de rotundo est propinquius simplicitati\nquem triangulus. Notandum est ergo quod corpus simplum nullum habens angulum [p..\n122] quia ipsum est primum et posterium in planetis sicut sol in stellas, quia in\nAstronomia firmamenti videmus, quod sol est dominus planetarum, et omnes planetes\negent lumine suo, quia dat lumen suum sursum usque ad lunam, deinde respicit omnia\ntam superiora quam inferiora\".\n55 Claren and Huber, p. 146: \"multiplicatio elixiris sit duobus modus, una per\nreiterarium solutionem and coagulationem lapidis, secunda per proiectionem primi\nlapidisconvertetur\nelixir superincorpus,\naut \".albeum aut rubeum tali quantitate quod idem corpus,\nmedicinam\netiam\n56 Claren and Huber, p. 156.
