{"result":["[Summary from page 30 to page 40 out of a total of 137:\nPages 30:\n32\nCHAPTER THREE\nTHE INFLUENCE OF MEDIEVAL OPTICS ON RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\ncosmogony of light and darkness. Christ was occasionally given the Mithraic title of \"Sol Invictus\".15 Similarly, contemporary late Alexandrian\nneoplatonists and hermeticists identified the sun withthe divine firstprinciple. Thus, Asclepius had regarded the sun as the transmitter of God's\nbeneficence to the earth, nullifying the effects of the negative demonic\npowers.16 Subsequently, the neoplatonist Pseudo-Dionysos the Aeropagite propagated a Christian image of the sun as representing the quality of\nGod's Divine Intelligence.17\nIn the seventh century, Isidore of Seville integrated Christian and\nneoplatonic conceptions ofthe sun with those ofnaturalphilosophyin his\nTreatise on Nature. Other sources for Isidore's imagery ofthe sun were late\nhellenistic texts which had interpreted the ancient gods as signifying different aspects of the One Divine Being, such as Cornutus in De Natura\nDeorum, or Hyginus on the stellar constellations in his Fabulae. The most\nimportant source, however, for the development ofthe subsequent identity of sun and Christ was Macrobius in the Saturnalia, who ventured to\nprove that all gods were subsumed by the Sun as the sole absolute deity.18\nIsidore christianised Macrobius' analogical interpretations and developed\nthem into a cosmogenesis. The sun became Christ's \"modus operandi\"\nwhereby he conferred life and health on the world (XV: 3).19 Thereby,\nIsidore inspired a lineage of medieval texts which implicated the sun into\nChrist's role as Creator. The lines of Isidore's account of the sun are\nfound in the French Ovide moralisee of the early fourteenth century and in\nthe fifteenth century Latin commentary, the Reductorium morale by Petrus\nBerchorius on Chapter XV ofOvid's De natura deorum. These texts provided an analogical commentary on Ovid's poem concerning the nature of\nthe pagan gods, regarding them as being various attributes of Christ.\nAnother significant influence on this medieval exegetical tradition was\nthe late antique Fulgentius whose fables of the gods became a popular\nsecular workin the fifteenth century, frequently illustrated.20\nDuring the Florentine revival of classical learning in the fifteenth century, the neoplatonic philosophers Ficino, Pico della Mirandola and, later, Campanella in the early sixteenth century engaged with hermetic\nideas of the sacred and magical attributes of the physical sun.21 Influenced by the theurgic hermeticism of Iamblichus, Psellus, Porphyry, as\nwell as by the earlier Orphic poems, Ficino in De Triplici Vitae (1489)\ndeveloped talismanic and magical rituals invoking the beneficial attributes of the sun, stars and planets. The recent research of Michael\nAllen into Ficino's Pythagorean numerology has revealed his interest in\noptical geometry as a theurgic device, enabling the spirit of the magus to\nact as a mirror of the \"idola\" flowing from animate and inanimate objects. Effectively, the mental planes of the magus, like mirror-surfaces,\nwere programmed by geometrical formulae corresponding to the various\nastral forces. Szonyi in his study of John Dee's Monas Hieroglyphica has\nconcluded that Ficino's theurgy was as significant in its influence on\nDee's magical practices as were medieval scholastic sources.22\nSince the ancient imagery ofthe sun had already acquired a Christian\nmeaning by this period, therefore, Ficino's magical operations involving\nthe solar rays had a particularly numinous potency. His method, however, was a misapplied semiotic system, that is, he reified immaterial metaphors by means of false analogies between the abstract sign and its, supposedly physical, referent. In other words, the conceptual contents ofa\n15 Franz Cumont, The Mysteries of Mithra (New York, 1956), passim.\n16 Copenhaver, Hermetica (1992), pp. 59-61.\n17 There is a full discussion of neoplatonic and hermetic solar imagery in Debus (1965).\n18 Fridericus Osannus, Lucius Annaeus Cornutus. De natura deorum (Gottingen: Johannis\nBapt. Casp. d'Ansse, 1844), pp. 194, 200, 225, 328, 372-77, 433, 516-17,\n524; H. I. Rose,\nHygini Fabulae (Brussels: A.W. Sijthoff, 1978), pp. 12, 15, 20, 22, 36, 38; Percival Vaughan\nDavies, Macrobius the Saturnalia (New York: Columbia UP, 1969), Bk I, Caps 17-23, pp.\n137-46.\n19 Jacques Fontaine (ed), Isidore de Seville, Traite de la Nature, (Bordeaux: Foret et Fils,\n1960), pp. 237- 43: \"sol Christus est, sicut in Malachia scriptum est: ... Merito autem\nChristus sol intelligitur dictus, quia ortus occidit secundum carnem, et secundum spiritum\nde occasu rursus exortus est. Item sol inluminat et exurit et opaco tempore confovet\nsanos, febricitantes vero flagrantia geminati caloris incendit. Ita est Christus credentes\nfidei spiritu vegetante inluminat, negantes se aeterni ignis ardore torrebit\".\n33\n20 Cornelis de Boer, Ovide moralisee en prose (Amsterdam: N. Holland, 1954), Bk I, Cap\nXLIV-XLVI, pp. 64-68; Bk III, Cap 1, pp. 113; Bk IX, Cap VII, p. 248. Also C. de Boer,\nOvide moralisee (Amsterdam: Johannes Muller, 1915), pp. 117-32 and Maria S. Van der\nBijl, \"Petrus Berchorius, Reductorium morale\", Vivarium, 9, 1 (1971): 25-48, esp pp. 2733. For Fulgentius see Rudolfus Helm, Fabii Planciadis Fulgenti Opera (Leipzig, 1898), BkI,\nCap XII p. 23; Bk III, Cap IX, pp. 73-77. The medieval illustrated Fulgentius is reproduced in Stanislas Klossowski de Rola, Alchemy (London: Thames and Hudson, 1973), figs\n53-62. Dee had copies ofsome ofthese works see R&W: Fulgentius M7, Macrobius 971\nand Hyginus 609.\n21 Kristeller ( 1979) & D. P. Walker(1958), passim.\n22 Michael Allen (1994), pp. 97-99; Szonyi's paper on Ficino and Dee is forthcomingin\nRenaissance Quarterly. Professor Szonyi has kindly drawn my attention to Ficino's optical\ninterests and their consequences for Dee's theories. For Ficino's magical rituals see his De\nTriplici Vitae libri tres (1978), for example, Bk III, Cap I, similitudes of the sun such as\nheliotrope, myrrh, amber, crocus. Ficino's works are found in Dee's collection see R&W:\n404, 736, 1124, 1282, B83, B120, B132, B141, B157, B177. Dee also had a copy ofFicino\nDe Triplici Vitae R&W 779, his translation ofPlotinus R&W: 108 and his Opera R&W: 204,\nas well as his Theologia Platonica R&W: 893.\n\nPages 31:\n34\nCHAPTER THREE\nsign were regarded as being a physical reality. In the same way, Fludd's\ncabbalistic alchemy and medicine in his Philosophia Sacra (1626) relied for\nits effect on the reification of a metaphorical sequence in which the sun\nwas personified as the demiurge, the eye ofgod, the altar of Christ as the\ncabbalistic Messiah, as well as the primal medicine. Fludd's sun-based\nmedicine, like Ficino's astrological talismanic magic, was based on a semiotic fallacy concerning the ontological status of similitude within a sign.\nDue to this unconscious process of reification in mystical symbols, itis\nnot surprising to find the idea ofthe divinity of light also influencing late\nmedieval experimental optics, otherwise a dour and sober science. In\nparticular, Robert Grosseteste created an optical theory which was based\nnot on the Greeks and Arabs, but on Platonic mysticism. In fact, Grosseteste's treatise De Luce, written in the fourteenth century, was modelled on\nPlato's cosmology in the Timaeus which had described a process of creation effected by means of light, fire and geometric measure. Grosseteste\ninter-related Platonic cosmology with optical theories concerning the\nemanation ofphysical light. Thus, he stated, light was the first corporeal\nform, multiplying itself from a single-point in all directions, whereby it\nformed a sphere and within it there arose matter. In the subsequent\nstages of the cosmic creation, there were a series of differentiations in\nphysical matter according to the Pythagorean mode of number, measure\nand proportion.23 Fludd mentions Grosseteste in his Utriusque Cosmi ...\nHistoria (1619) and even illustrates his cosmogenesis in a magnificent visual image (fig. 46). This engraving shows the dove of the Holy Spirit\nemerging from the primal divine Word \"FIAT\" and circling the dark\nvoid with a ring of light.24 Fludd, like Plato and Grosseteste, thought that\nmatter was condensed light and he also concurred with them in distinguishing between its material form and the incorporeal Light of Intelligence emanating directly from the Mind of God. Similarly, medieval\nopticians such as Grosseteste and Witelo influenced one of Fludd's contemporaries, Jacob Boehme ( 1575-1624), the Protestant German theosophist, who described a remarkable theogony of light in his treatise, Aurora\n(1612), in which the natural light of the sun became the body of the\nredeeming Son of God.25\n23 James McEvoy, The Philosophy of Robert Grosseteste (Clarendon Press: Oxford, 1982),\npp.\n53-54, 167-80; Alistair C. Crombie, Robert Grosseteste (Oxford, 1962); Eastwood, 9, pp.\n306-21.\n24 Robert Fludd, Utriusque Cosmi Historia , \"Macrocosm\", 1 (Oppenheim: J. T. de\nBry,25 1617), Tract I, p. 49.\nMcEvoy, p. 55; Eastwood, 9, pp. 306-21. For Boehme's concept of the sun in the\nAurora see Pierre Deghaye, \"Dieu et la Nature dans L'Aurore Naissante deJacob Boehme\"\nin Faivre and Zimmermann (eds), Epochen der Naturmystik (1979), pp. 125-56, see esp pp.\nTHE INFLUENCE OF MEDIEVAL OPTICS ON RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\n35\nJohn Dee also referred to Grossesteste's idea of the creative action of\nlight in his Propaedeumata Aphoristica,26 but he relied more onAl-kindi and\nRoger Bacon for the specifc details of his astronomy. Both French and\nClulee have argued that Dee revived the knowledge ofscholastic scientific and mathematical ideas in an age whose main intellectual interest lay\nin humanism, to the neglect of the older medieval empirical sciences.\nAgainst this argument is the case put by Mordechai Feingold which evidences the continuing strength ofthe scholastic mathematical tradition in\nEnglish Renaissance universities.27\nIn addition, Szonyi's recent examination of Ficino's influence on Dee,\nspecifically that of Ficino's astral magic and his related optical interests,\nnecessitates some modification of Clulee's claim for scholastic philosophy\nas being Dee's most important resource prior to the 1560s. Partlyfrom\nthe evidence of Dee's library, Clulee had argued that Roger Bacon (midtwelfth century) was Dee's major preceptor for his astronomical theory,\nadditional ideas being drawn from the Arabs, Grosseteste, Witelo and\nJohn Pecham.28 It may be that further investigation by Szonyi will lead to\na re-assessment of Clulee's argument.\nDee had a great interest in catoptrics, as is demonstrated in Roberts\nand Watson's catalogue of his library which contains many Arabic and\nscholastic resources. Catoptrics was a branch of the science of optics\ninitiated by the ancient Greeks and defined by Archimedes as the study\nof the refraction and reflection of light-rays by mirrors or prisms. The\nincendiary properties of parabolic mirrors, which collected and focused\nthe rays ofthe sun, had already been known in the sixth century AD by\nphilosophers such as Anthemius of Thralles.29 In the medieval period,\n129-31. For Boehme's account of Christ as the redeeming light see Will-Erich Peuckert,\nBoehme. Samtliche Schriften (Stuttgart: Frommanns Verlag, 1955), 1, \"Aurora Signatura Rerum oder Morgenrothe in Anfang\", pp. 263-84.\n26 Clulee, pp. 54-57, 67, 153, 164-65. For the large numbers of optical treatises owned\nby Dee see R&W through-out.\n27 Clulee, pp. 52-73; Peter French, John Dee (London: Routledge, 1987), pp.26-27. See\na contrasting view in Mordechai Feingold, The mathematician's apprenticeship (Cambridge\nUniversity Press, 1984), pp. 45-85.\n28 See Szonyi's paper, forthcoming in Renaissance Quarterly. Professor Szonyi is currently\npursuing further research on this issue. Clulee's argument is found in his John Dee's Natural\nPhilosophy, pp. 39-73. For the history of medieval optics see Eastwood, 10, pp. 51-55 and\nRonchi, pp. 60-76. See R&W for Dee's extensive collection ofBacon's work: M96, M17,\nM19, M20, M41, M61, M72, esp M26. Also Dee's collection of Pecham's workin R&W:\n83, 617, M38. Dee had a copy ofBacon's Liber de sigillis solis insignis secundum Hermetem with\nother texts by Bacon on sigills, R&W: M26.\n29 Smith, pp. 355-59. The various manuscripts owned by Dee are too numerous to list\nhere, see R&W, for example, M2, M109.\n\nPages 32:\n36\nCHAPTER THREE\nRoger Bacon, in particular, dispersed and popularised catoptrical science\nthrough his treatise De speculis comburentibus.30 These optical theories were\nimportant for the development of Dee's astronomy, but there was one\nparticular idea which may also have affected Dee's alchemy. Bacon had\nstated in De multiplicatione specierum (I, i) that every point on a luminous or\ncoloured body sent forth the image of its visible qualities as \"species\" in\na succession of\"multiplications\" which were transmitted through a medium such as light, or air, to the eye of the viewer.31 Another widely-read\nfourteenth century optician, John Pecham, had modelled his ideas ofthe\nemanation of \"species\" on those of Alhazen and Bacon.32\nSuch medieval optical, astronomical and theurgical resources were\ncollected together and systematised for practical application by Dee who\nwas a mathematician, technologist, educator and medical practitioner, as\nwell as a magician, alchemist and necromancer.33 In circa 1556 he began\nto engage in the study of medieval optics,34 an interest recorded in his\nlibrary catalogue which included three manuscripts of Alkindi's De radiis\nstellarum, along with the works of many other optical theorists.35 Clulee\nhas described the years 1548-1558 as being Dee's Aristotelian phase,36\nwhereas, in the later stages of his career, hermeticism, cabbalah and\nneoplatonism played a much larger role than scholasticism.37\nIt is well-known that in Dee's immediate circle there was a highly\ndeveloped astronomical interest, for example, the mathematician Thomas Digges was a friend and pupil. Another associate with an equal\ninterest in optics was the mathematician and astronomer Thomas Harriot (1560-1621), a member of the circle at Syon House of Henry Percy,\n30 Lindberg (1976), p. 108; Clulee, pp. 64-66. For Dee's holdings ofBacon's optics, see\nR&W: M17, M19, M20, esp M26, M41, M61, M72, M96.\n31 Smith, pp. 29-31; Clulee, pp. 56-57; Lindberg (1976), pp. 107-16.\n32 David C. Lindberg, John Pecham and the Science ofOptics (Madison: University ofWisconsin , 1970), passim.\n33 Clulee, pp. 203-30; R&W, pp. 3-54.\n34 Clulee, pp. 39-73, esp pp. 64-65; R&W, pp. 30-34.\n35 R&W: 307, M28, M37, pp. 30-34. He also acquired Alhazen's works, Boethius's\nArithmetica, Nicolas Oresme's Liber divinationum, Witelo's Perspectiva, Bacon's Opus Tertium,\nGrosseteste's De luce, calore etfrigide and Pecham's Perspectiva Communis. These are listed in\nR&W through-out.\n36 Clulee, pp. 40-42.\n37 Clulee, pp. 79-80. For Dee's cabbalistic texts see the comment in R&W, pp. 28-29.\nHis Hebrew, Syrian and \"Chaldean\" collection is mostly catalogued in R&W: 1558-1624.\nThere are more Syrian and Hebrew grammars through-out the rest of the R&W catalogue,\nPostel. as well as the cabbalistic treatises ofps. Lull, Pico della Mirandola, Reuchlin and\nTHE INFLUENCE OF MEDIEVAL OPTICS ON RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\n37\n52\nEarl of Northumberland.38 It has been established that Dee also gained\ninformation concerning the properties of lenses and mirrors from Gogava's edition ofAlhazen on catoptrics (included in his translation ofPtolemy\nOpus quadripartium, 1548). Gogava probably instructed Dee in the manufacture and use of astronomical and optical apparatus.39\nDee himself wrote an richly illustrated but unfinished tract on catoptrics (dated 1558) which is found in British Library MS Cotton Vitellius\nC.VII, art. 5, De Speculis comburentibus libri 5 (ff. 280r-309v) (figs. 12-15).\nFrom the internal evidence, it seems that Dee intended to prepare this\nmanuscript for publication. In the text he states briefly that his ideas were\ngathered from ancient philosophers (f. 280r). Dee's subject-matter concerns the Euclidean rules of optical conic sections (f. 309v) (fig. 15),\nas well as the angles of incidence and refraction of light by mirrors\n(f. 284r ff), illustrated by several detailed drawings of light-rays reacting\nto a parabolic surface (f. 282r) (figs. 12-14). Other similar experiments\nwith mirrors and lenses are recorded in manuscripts located in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, such as MS Sloane 3854 which contains a section\nentitled Experimenta in Speculo (ff. 76r ff), among a set of treatises concerning angelic magic. On one folio, there is a drawing of a mirror inscribed\nwith a magic pentacle which demonstrates how Dee enrolled practical\noptics into the service of his magical rituals (f. 80v).\nDee's optical and astronomical treatise, the Propaedeumata Aphoristica\nwas printed in London by Henry Sutton in 1558 and re-printed with his\nown augmentations by Reginald Wolfe in London in 1568. According to\nShumaker, in this work Dee aimed to reduce astrological practice to a set\nof comprehensible rules based on the physical properties of the planets.\"40\nDee considered that by means of optical instruments it was possible to\ncollect the occult virtues of the stellar radiations,41 particularly42recommending the use of catoptrics in the making of theurgical sigils.4\n38 On Dee and Harriot see Feingold, pp. 136-47. For an intellectual biography of\nHarriot see R. H. Kargon, Atomism in England from Harriot to Newton (Oxford U.P, 1966),\npp. 18 ff. See also John W. Shirley, Thomas Harriot Renaissance Scientist (Clarendon Press:\nOxford, 1974).\n39 Shumaker, Prop. Aph, pp. 62-64; Clulee, p. 31. In the Propaedeumata Aphoristica, Dee\nalso acknowledged the influence of Gerard Mercator, Gemma Frisius and Gaspara\nMirica.\n40 Shumaker, p. 53.\n41 Shumaker, p. 51. The provenance and form of Dee's mirror is discussed by Clulee,\np. 262: n. 120.\n42 Shumaker, p. 67.\n\nPages 33:\nAphorism LII\nIf you were skilled in \"catoptrics\" you would be able, by art, to imprint the\nrays of any star much more strongly upon any matter subjected to it than\nnature itself does. This, indeed , was by far the largest part of the natural\nphilosophy of the ancient wise men. And this secret is not of much less\nthe philosophers , called inferior,\ndignity than the very august astronomy ofcertain\nMonad 43\nwhose symbols ... [are] ... enclosed in a\nAccording to Dee, mirrors could imitate planetary influences, increasing\nand decreasing the intensity oftheir radiations catoptrically and imprinting their influences on matter and magical gems.44 In these statements,\nthere45 are traces of the talismanic magic of Ficino, Agrippa and Paracelsus.\nAphorism XXVI\nThe stars and celestial powers are like seals whose characters are imprinted\ndifferently by reason of differences in the elemental matter. In the same way,\nthe engraved forms ofour seals are imprinted more easily upon one material\nthan upon another ... You will therefore consider talismans rather attentively, and other still greater things.46\nDee also refers to the powerful esoteric practice ofpyromancy, the art of\nfire, in alchemy.\nAphorism II\nwonderful changes may be produced by us in natural things by means ofthe\nprinciples of pyronomia.47\nPyrologians (alchemists) are mentioned again in another section whose\nobstetrical character recalls Paracelsus' alchemical cosmogony in Philosophia ad Athenienses. Dee speaks of the \"four separate great wombs ofthe\nworld\" (air, fire, water, earth) which are constituted of \"three separate\nparts\", probably alluding to the Paracelsian trinity of Sulphur, Mercury\nand Salt.48 Moreover, Dee's euology of the occult properties of fire is\nsimilar to that of Paracelsus in the Archidoxa which may have influenced\nDee even at this early date.49 He also refers to the cabbalistic practice of\n\"notarikon\".\nTHE INFLUENCE OF MEDIEVAL OPTICS ON RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY 39\nAphorism XVIII\nIn the four separate great wombs of the larger world are three distinct parts;\nthese are , however, at the same time condensed, structured and regulated by\ntheir own appropriate weights and may now be called, by notariacal design,\nAOS, or OSA, or SOA (for pyrologians will understand me if I speak so) 50\nSince Khunrath admitted to an admiration for Dee's work and specifically referred to the Propaedeumata Aphoristica in his Amphiteatrum, it is probable that his own pyromantic theories were influenced by this passage in\nDee's treatise.51\nOf similar importance to Khunrath's alchemical practices were Dee's\nreferences to Bacon's theory of the \"multiplication of species\".52 Dee\nargues that everything sent forth rays as \"species\" of itself which emanated from every point of the object in a spherical fashion,53 but, whereas\nspecies in general did not require light in order to create an effect on\nanother object,\nthose ofthe celestial spheres could only operate by means\nof light- rays .54 In addition, the distance of a heavenly body from the\nearth determined the effect of the stellar species on the lower world. In\nother words, in Dee's account, the rays of the stars operate in the same\nmanner as the cones of light-rays emanating from an object to the human\neye. The crucial point is that the geometrical laws governing human\nvision are exactly the same as those determining the radiation of light\nfrom the stars.\nDee stated that the rays of the stars took a conical form, whose base\nwas located on the face ofthe star, with the apex on the earth below. The\nrays within the geometrical cone grew stronger as they approached the\ncentral ray which stood at the perpendicular within the cone ofrays.55\nHence, it was the centric ray which the theurgist had to project onto his\nmaterials.56 Therefore, according to Dee, it was necessary to perform\nmagical operations when the appropriate star stood at the perpendicular\nto the horizon ofthe earth and was nearest to the earth.57\nIn due course, these aspects ofDee's astrological theory will be considered in their influence on the alchemical illustrations of Khunrath, Maier\nand Fludd. Of specific importance to these later alchemists was Dee's\n43 Shumaker, p. 149.\n44 Shumaker, Aphorisms, LIIII, LV and LXXXIX, pp. 148-51, 174-75.\n45 See Szonyi (1999).\n46 Shumaker, pp. 134-35.\n47 Shumaker , pp. 122-23.\n48 Allen G. Debus, The Chemical Philosophy, 1 (London: Heinemann, 1977), pp. 51-76.\n49 Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 92-200 , Decem libri Archidoxis.\n50 Shumaker, pp. 128-29.\n51 Khunrath (Hanover, 1609), p. 6.\n5253 Shumaker, p. 62;. Clulee, pp. 56-57.\nShumaker , p. 63.\n54 Shumaker, p. 64.\n55 Shumaker, Aphorisms XXXII-XLVIII, pp. 136-37.\n56 Shumaker, Aphorism XXXIIII, pp. 136-38.\n57 Shumaker, Aphorism LIIII, pp. 148-51.\n38\nCHAPTER THREE\n\nPages 34:\n40\nCHAPTER THREE\nportrayal ofthe geometrical cones of astral influences and the manner in\nwhich they imprinted their qualities onto base matter. Although Clulee\nhas stated that Dee made astrology of practical use to alchemists for the\nfirst time, he was referring only to Dee's specifically alchemical treatise,\nthe Monas Hieroglyphica.58 Yet, the earlier Propaedeumata Aphoristica had an\nequal practical import for alchemists since it was offering them a shortcutto their goal oftransmutation by means ofDee's system of astronomical catoptrics. The use of his optical theory in their laboratories would\nallow alchemists to summon species from the stars to impregnate and\nthereby transmute their gross \"prima materia\" into a higher form. For\nexample, they could summon the species ofsilver from the moon, orgold\nfrom the sun.\nA substantial re-orientation of alchemical theory towards astral-magic\nhad already been initiated by the publication of Paracelsus' writings in\nthe mid-1550s, as well as by the cabbalah. As a result of such influences,\na cabbalistic theogony of light was eventually developed by Paracelsian\nalchemists such as Heinrich Khunrath, Edward Kelley, Oswald Croll,\nMichael Sendivogius and Stefan Michelspacher. Even the Jesuit encyclopaedist Athanasius Kircher, though declaring himself to be a sceptic,\nnevertheless, considered alchemical theory with deep interest in his treatises which also proudly displayed his own catoptrical apparatus (fig. 20).\nThus, from the late sixteenth century, alchemists increasingly lifted their\neyes from their furnaces to inspect the divine actions of the heavenly\nfires.\nIn his later treatise, the Monas Hieroglyphica of 1564, Dee presented a\nmore sophisticated metaphysical structure based on cabbalism to justify\nhis catoptrical alchemy. Nevertheless, in terms of effective benefit to contemporary alchemists, Dee had already provided much the same information in the Propaedeumata Aphoristica. Although Clulee does not consider\nthat alchemy was of interest to Dee in the 1550s, there are, nevertheless,\nsufficient hints within the text of the Propaedeumata Aphoristica to indicate\nthat Dee envisaged an alchemical purpose for his astral catoptrics.\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY:\nTHE \"ASTRAL VIRTUE\" AND\nTHE \"AERIAL SALTPETRE\"\nThe controversy generated by the medical theories of Paracelsus (14931541) was caused not only by his adoption of alchemical methods for\npreparing medicines and his innovatory use of inorganic substances, but\nalso by his disturbing synthesis of medicine, magic, theology and cosmology. Paracelsus' ambitiously expansive (and often self-contradictory) vision forced his educated contemporaries to re-assess both their professional activities as physicians, as well as their philosophical systems and\neven their religious beliefs.\nParacelsus' own Christian commitment cannot be doubted, for this\nwas one of his declared reasons for his attack on pre-Christian medical\ntheorists such as Galen. Nonetheless, Paracelsus developed a monistic\ntheosophical structure for his chemical universe in his account of the\nunion between the astral human faculties and the macrocosm. Similarly,\nin his cosmogenical theories, the primal four elements emerged directly\nfrom the soul of the universe. The chief adversary of Paracelsus in the\nsecond half of the sixteenth century was the Protestant theologian Thomas Erastus (1523-1583) who castigated Paracelsus for his superstitious\nmedical practices, specifically his use of astrology.2 Alchemists such as\nKhunrath and Fludd who joined the Paracelsian school had to address\nsignificant theological issues to avoid constructing a philosophical system\nequating God with nature.\nIn the Philosophia ad Athenienses, Paracelsus described a cosmos whose\nform was that of an alchemical still,4 fabricating a monistic model of the\nworld's emergence from the \"mysterium magnum\", a prime matter un-\n58 Clulee, p. 106.\n1 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" (1979), pp. 60-62, 70-74. For Erastus see\nThorndike, M&ES, 5, pp. 617-51. See also Frick, Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 112-122.\n2 Debus (1977), 1, pp. 129-34; Thorndike, M&ES, 5, pp. 652-67.\n3 Walter Pagel, \"The Prime Matter of Paracelsus\", Ambix, 9 (1961): 117 ff.\n4 Debus (1977), 1, pp. 51-61, 76, 86-87. These texts are found in Sudhoff, I, 8, Das\nBuch Paragranum, pp. 31-126, see esp pp . 31, 115, 133 and I, 9, Opus Paramirum, pp. 37-223\nand also I, 10, pp. 7-487, der Grossen Wunderarznei.\n\nPages 35:\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\nderstood to be life itself, or the soul,5 the mother of all phenomena, both\nsubstantial and insubstantial. In the primal creative act God separated\nthe elements7 from each other, acting in the manner of a chemist in his\nlaboratory. Out of insubstantial prime matter there emerged the four\nproto-elements which were the primal qualities of fieriness , airiness, wacreated the secondary material\nteriness and earthiness, which, in turn,\n8\nelements offire, water, earth and air. The chemical processes ofseparation and coagulation produced a mixture ofthe four secondary elements\nwhich Paracelsus termed the \"Ilyaster\", containing all the objects of material creation. In addition to these elements, the cosmic order rested on\nthree other principles, Mercury, Sulphur and Salt.10\nIn a variety of other texts, Paracelsus promoted the idea that the\nhuman-being was an integral unity with the macrocosm of stars and\nplanets, formulating, therefore, a series of practical techniques, such as\nastrology, astral-magic, rituals, chemical potions and talismans, whereby\nthis relationship could be exploited in medicine, as well as in prognostication. In De pestilate Paracelsus explained that a human-being consisted\nof both an animal and a sidereal body, made from fire and air.12 For\nexample, in Das Buch Paragranum Paracelsus explained that\nThe inner stars of man are, in their properties, kind, and nature, by their\ncourse and position, like his outer stars, and different only in form and in\nmaterial . Just as the sun shines through a glass as though divested of\nbody and substance-so the stars penetrate one another in the body ... For\nthe sun and the moon and all planets, as well as all the stars and thewhole\nchaos, are in man .... The body attracts heaven ... and this takes place in\naccordance with the great divine order.13\nMoreover, a human-being partook of the character of the four elements.\nMan consists of the four elements, not only as some hold-because he has\nfour tempers, but also because he partakes ofthe nature, essence and properties of these elements. In him there lies the \"young heaven\" which is their\nfather. For man was created from heaven and earth, and is therefore like\nthem.14\nSimilarly, the heavens reflected the nature of the human constitution.\nIn the heavens you can see man, each part for itself; for man is made of\nheaven. And the matter out of which man was created also indicates to you\nthe pattern after which he was formed.15\nConsequently, humanity was a mirror of the cosmic structure, reflecting\nthe cosmic body of Anthropos.\nWithin the metaphysical construction ofthe world, Paracelsus placed\nthe supreme influence of divine light which he considered to be the\nhigher intelligence in both the natural world, as well as in humans.16\nIn the Philosophia magna, Liber de nymphis, however, he distinguished\nbetween the light of nature (\"das Licht der Natur\") and that of the human spirit and intelligence.17 The idea of the light of nature was developed in mathematical terms in the Astronomia Magna (1537-8) in which\nParacelsus discussed the importance ofmathematics in the study of natural philosophy. He explained that astronomical mathematics examined\nthe manner in which the stars caused generation and creation on the\nearth, their effects being related to their height, profundity, amplitude\nand angular juxtapositions. There is a close relationship between these\nParacelsian ideas in the Astronomia Magna and Dee's theories in the Propaedeumata Aphoristica of 1558, although neither Debus, nor Clulee, have\ndiscussed this relationship. In some of his ideas concerning the essential\nrole of astronomy in developing both intellectual understanding and the\n42\n5 Sudhoff, I, 13, Philosophia ad Athenienses, pp. 389-423 . See also Walter Pagel, \"The\nPrime Matter of Paracelsus\", Ambix, 9 (1961): 117 ff.\n6 Sudhoff, I, 13, Philosophia ad Athenienses, pp. 390-92. See Pagel, \"Paracelsus als\n\"Naturmystiker\" (1979), pp. 63-67.\n7 Sudhoff, I, 13, Philosophia ad Athenienses, p. 393.\n, pp. 396-98. See also Debus, (1977), 1, pp. 5161.8 Sudhoff, I, 13, Philosophia adAthenienses\nWinder, \"The Higher\n; Walter Pagel\nand Marianne\npp. 51-61\n9 Debus,and(1977),\nElements\nPrime1,Matter\nin Renaissance\nNaturalism\nand in Paracelsus\", Ambix, 21\n(1974): 93 ff.\n10 Sudhoff, I, 13, pp. 7-123, Philosophia de generationibus etfructibus quatuorelementorum, see\nesp pp. 9-23 on the elements and the Ilyaster. These ideas are discussed in Pagel,\n\"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\"\"\" (1979), pp. 67-69.\n11 Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 92-200, Decem libri Archidoxis; I, 12, pp . 1-444, Astronomia Magna;\nI, 12, pp. 503-4; I,\nI, 12, pp. 500 ffDe probatione magiae. I, 12, pp. 502-3, De divinatione.\n. See Pagel(1982), pp. 64,\nde\ndivinis\noperibus\net\nsecretis\nnaturae\n,\npp.\n1-378,\nPhilosophia\nmagna\n14\n67.\n12 Jolande Jacobi (ed), Paracelsus Selected Writings (New York: Pantheon, 1951), p. 92\n(translation of Sudhoff, I/14, 597-98 De pestilate. Sudhoff lists this text as spurious).\n43\n13 Jacobi, pp. 160-64 (Paragranum); Pagel (1982), pp. 65-68.\n14Jacobi, pp. 160-64 (Paragranum).\n15 Jacobi, pp. 31ff(Paragranum).\n16 Jacobi, p. 117 (Sudhoff, I/9, p. 253 Opus Paramirum). The full transcription of this\nwork is found in Sudhoff, I, 9, pp. 37-229, 231-47.\n17Jacobi, pp. 115 ff, esp pp. 117-18 (Sudhoff, 1/14, pp. 115-51, Philosophia magna Liber\nde nymphis); Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), pp. 59-60.\n\nPages 36:\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\nhigher \"gnosis\" ofthe spirit, Paracelsus was drawing on cabbalistic thinking.18\nParacelsus rejected the ancient natural philosophers, replacing Aristotle with christianised neo-platonic and hermetic authorities, discarding\nalso the medical canon of Avicenna and Galen. 19 Instead , he believed\nthat physical ailments were the result of external forces rather than ofan\nimbalance offluids, as in the medieval theory ofthe four humours. Each\norgan of the body, Paracelsus explained, contained a dynamism called\nthe \"archeon\" which functioned as an internal alchemist. Moreover, he\nbelieved that each illness originated in a particular star whose virtue was\nembodied in the corresponding earthly \"arcanum\", a medicine which\ncould heal the ailment.20\nParacelsus was not the first to adapt alchemy to medicine, since John\nof Rupescissa and Arnold of Villanova in the fourteenth-century had\ndeveloped the alchemical concept of the fifth essence into a medical\ntheory. Paracelsian alchemy was not concerned with transmutation, but\nwith the preparation ofmedicines. Paracelsus departed from Arabic medicine mostly in his conviction that chemically prepared inorganic medicines were superior to the herbal preparations ofmedievalphysicians. To\nthis end, he stressed the importance of the metals, particularly mercury,\nantimony and iron salts, advocating also the medicinal use of poisons,\nsuch as arsenic, in strict dosages.22 He prepared these by means of distillation in order to purify and intensify the volatile spirits ofthe substance\nby removing the impure earths. This would introduce the hidden virtue\nof the star governing the disease and induce healing by homeopathic\nmeans.23\nAccording to the Paracelsian doctrine of signatures, the \"astra\" (stellar\nvirtues) present within all natural bodies were the foundation of practical\nmedicine, since each person had an astral body which overlay and penetrated his physical body, so that the external and imminent \"astra\" were\neffectively the same entity. Thus, Parcelsus stated, a remedy was dependant on the astrological effects of the heavens.24 In the Volumen medicinae\nparamirum (circa 1520), he urged the physician to acquire a sound knowledge ofastronomy in order to understand the effects ofthe astral emanations by means of which God had impressed earthly things with \"signatures\",25\nFor a clearer understanding of Paracelsus' theory of\"signatures\", it is\nhelpful to consider Foucault's analysis of the Renaissance concept ofthe\nworld as being constructed on the basis of similitude and difference. The\nRenaissance taxonomy of phenomena, whether spiritual, physical, aesthetic or linguistic, was based on the idea that representation (similitude)\nwas that which guaranteed their authenticity. Similitude was judged in\nthe terms of adjacency (\"convenientia\"), analogy (\"aemulatio\") and sympathy (\"concordia\"). This taxonomy was inscribed within the universe in\nthe form of signs, decipherable only by an elite of natural philosophers.\nAs Foucault points out, in the sixteenth century no distinction was made\nbetween the empirical observations ofthe natural philosophers and those\noftheologians, or occultists. All of these systems of knowledge were dependent on their ability to read the inscriptions which already pre-existed\nin the forms of the world. Foucault argues that Renaissance signs were\norganised into a conceptual structure consisting of three qualities which\nwere the marks of the sign, the things designated by those marks and the\nsimilitude between them. Since it was \"aemulatio\" which constituted\nboth the form and the content of the sign, these three elements operated\nas a single figure. Foucault's contention is that in the seventeenth century\nthis triple construction of a sign became a binary in which a signifier\n(\"significans\") was connected to a significance (\"significandum\"), abandoning the quality of similitude.26\nFoucault's argument provides one explanation for the intensity ofthe\nlate Renaissance search for the \"lingua Adamica\" through the devices of\nmagical cryptography. The issue of the Adamic language has been discussed by Szonyi in his study of the influence of Paracelsian talismanic\nlinguistics on Dee's theurgy. (Dee had certainly procured two copies of\nParacelsus Expositio magicarum figurarum). In contrast to the characterisa-\n44\n18 Pagel (1982), pp.71-76; Allen G. Debus, \"Mathematics and Nature in the Chemical\nTexts ofthe Renaissance\", Ambix (1968): 1-28; Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \"\n(1979), pp. 59, 65-66\n19 J. R. Partington, A History of Chemistry, 2 (London: Macmillan, 1961), pp. 115-51;\n(1982): 130-58.\nPagel\n20 Pagel\n(1982): 105-12; Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), p. 85 \"jede\nKrankheit ein Stern\".\n21 Thorndike, M&ES, 3, pp. 347-69; 4, pp. 37-41; F. N. L. Poynter (ed), Chemistryin the\nService ofMedicine (London, 1963), pp. 5-26, esp p. 17.\n22 Pagel (1982), pp. 133-56.\n23 Pagel (1982), p. 70; Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), p. 63.\n45\n24 Pagel (1982), pp. 67-71. Pagel gives an excellent explanation of the Paracelsian\n\"astra\" in his \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), pp. 70-74.\n25 Pagel ( 1982), pp. 59-61.\n26 Michel Foucault, The Order of Things (London; New York: Tavistock; Pantheon,\n1970), pp. 30-94. For a more specific historical account ofthe epistemologicalchanges in\nsixteenth century culture see Will-Erich Peuckert, Die Grosse Wende (Hamburg: Claassen\nand Goverts, 1948), pp. 299-474.\n\nPages 37:\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\ntion of Dee by previous historians such as Yates, Clulee and Sherman,\nSzonyi has offered a rather different interpretation of Dee's intellectual\nactivity.\nDee as a\"magus\" ... had an amazingly wide range of interests but [he] also\nincreasingly had a focusing obsession, a magical program, not necessarilyto\nimprove the sciences in order to prepare the scientific revolution, rather to\nfind an alternative system ofknowledge ... Dee clearly distinguished between\nscience after the Fall and that of primordial wisdom. His aim was to restore\nthe Adamic or Enochian wisdom of the Golden Age and that would not be\ncompatible with the methods and means of the fallen science relying on\ndiscursive logic.27\nIf it was indeed the case that late sixteenth century intellectual culture\nwas in the process of inaugurating a new episteme, that of the scientific\nrevolution and the enlightenment, then there may well have been a sense\nof existential panic, a feeling that meaning was becoming ever more\ndifficult to retrieve from the open book of nature. The interest in magical\ncyphers may have been an attempt to close the widening gap arising in\ncultural semiosis in which the signifier was slipping away from its referent.\nThe Renaissance came to a halt before the brute fact that language existed:\nin the density of the world, a graphism mingling with things or flowing\nbeneath them ... the existence oflanguage preceded, as if by a mute stubborness, what one could read in it and the words that gave it sound. From the\nseventeenth century, it is this massive and intriguing existence of language\nthat is eliminated\n... one might say that language in the Classical era does\nnot exist: it functions.28\nFor Paracelsus, the primal language of signatures was inspired by God's\nmanner of sustaining the cosmic order, inscribing the forms of all manifestation with a stellar emanation, the \"azoth\". In his Liber Azoth he had\nreferred to it as an aerial nitre, or saltpetre, transmitted by the rain to the\nearth from the spirit of the sun.29 His followers, Severinus, de Vigenere,\nSendivogius, Quercetanus and Fludd developed the full idea ofthe aerial\nsaltpetre at the end of the sixteenth and in the early years of the seventeenth centuries. Another origin for the concept of this astral virtue was\nthe use of nitrates in the manufacture of gunpowder, a major European\nindustry in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. In the industrial\nprocess, nitrate salts were exposed to the elements and the solar rays in\norder to enhance their explosive, preservative and generative properties.\nParacelsus in the Grossen Wunderarznei considered that such virtues were\nimpregnated into the salts by the aerial virtue, explaining thunder and\nlightening as being caused by a \"Saltniter-Sulphur\", while the stars themselves were composed either of sulphur, or nitre. John Dee had at least\ntwo copies ofthe Grossen Wunderarznei, as well as the work ofBodenstein,\nSuchten, Quercetanus, Severinus and Dorn.30\nQuercetanus (1544-1609) stated that Salt was the true and essential\nmedicine appearing in three forms, marine, fixed and nitrous. All ofthese\nwere related to generation, but of these three spirits of Salt, he considered that saltpetre, originating in urine, was the highest form since it\npartook ofthe three kinds of life, animal, vegetable and mineral and also\nembodied the three principles of Sulphur, Mercury and Salt. Du Chesne\nbelieved thatthe highest form of saltpetre was alchemical, rather than the\nvulgar version produced by industrial chemists and fireworks specialists.31\nDespite Du Chesne's rejection ofempirical chemistry, the Paracelsian\nalchemist Michael Sendivogius (1566-1636) referred to the industrial\nprocess of weathering nitric salts by means of the sun and the elements in\nhis Novum Lumen Chymicum ( 1604). Szydlo has argued that his chemical\nwork demonstrates that Sendivogius intuited the existence of oxygen,\neven producing this gas prior to Lavoisier.32 Andreas Orthelius wrote a\ncommentary on Sendivogius' Novum Lumen Chemicum which was published\nin Eberhard Zetzner's Theatrum Chemicum (Strassburg, 1656), accompanied by a set of engravings, one ofwhich shows an open alchemical flask\npositioned in front ofa window, while another depicts a tub of chemicals\nstanding in the open air (fig. 16).33\nParacelsus had examined the alchemical role of the sun in his Neun\nBucher Archidoxis (circa 1526-1527) in which he compared the earthly fire\n46\n27 Quote from Szonyi \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim. See also Szonyi \"O Worke Divine\"(1984), pp. 353-94. Dee's Paracelsian texts on sigils are listed in R&W: 844, 956.\n28 Foucault, p. 79. See also Brian Vickers, \"Analogy versus identity: the rejection of\noccult symbolism, 1589-1680\" in Brian Vickers (ed), Occult and Scientific Mentalities in the\nRenaissance (Cambridge UP, 1984), pp. 95-163.\n29 Debus (1964): 43-61 , esp. 44-45, 49ff.\n47\n30 Zbigniew Szydlo, Water Which Does Not Wet Hands (Warszawa: Polish Academy of\nSciences, 1994), pp. 67-92. For Paracelsus see Sudhoff, 10, pp. 7-423 der Grossen\nWunderarznei; Debus (1964): 44-47. For Dee's collection see R&W: 521, 1447, 1457, 1465,\n1526, 1544, 2227, 2236,\n31 Debus (1964): 51-54.\n32 R.J. W. Evans, RudolfII and his world(Oxford U. P, 1973), p. 211-12; Szydlo (1994).\nSendivogius appears as \"Sarmatus\" in Michael Maier, Symbola Aureae Mensae (Oppenheim:\nJ. T. de Bry), Bk XII, pp. 553-60 esp. pp. 555-58.\n33 Andreas Orthelius, \"Commentator In Novum Lumen Chymicum Sendivogii\" in\nTheatrum Chemicum, 6 (Strassburg: Zetzner, 1656), illustrations on pp. 413, 415.\n\nPages 38:\n48\nCHAPTER FOUR\nin the alchemical furnace to the sun's heat. This text was issued in many\neditions from the 1570's and it had a considerable influence on occultist\npractices. Paracelsus described the aethereal spirit, or fire, of the celestial\nbodies as creating the corresponding earthly phenomena, stating that the\nalchemical tincture obtained its virtues not from earthly chemicals, but\nfrom the spirit ofthe sun as its imminent \"astra\".34 Certainly, Khunrath's\nconcept ofthe philosophical fire in De Igne Magorum was closely modelled\non the Archidoxa.\nMost of Paracelsus' treatises were published after his death, the greatest number appearing in the 1570's when the Archidoxa was issued in a\nnumber of editions (including spurious versions). The first full compendium of Paracelsus' texts was issued in Basle by Peter Barna in 1589-90\nand another important collected edition was that of John Huser ofWaldkrich in Cologne (1589-91 ; 1603; 1605). In England, according to Debus,\nthe use of chemical medicines had been long accepted prior to the Paracelsian influences due to the writings of Arnald of Villanova, the pseudoLullians and Hieronymous Brunschwig. By the 1580's, there were a great\nnumber of reputable Paracelsian followers both on the continent and in\nEngland, such as Conrad Gesner ofZurich ( 1516-1565) who was a friend\nof Dee. Gesner's treatise on distillation was translated by Thomas Hill\nand published in England by George Baker as the Treasure of Euonymous\n(1559). Leonhard Thurneysser, whom Dee had met in Frankfurt-onOder in 1578, was another influential source in England for distillation\ntechniques.35 English Paracelsians included Richard Bostocke who borrowed Dee's Paracelsian texts and wrote the first Paracelsian apology in\nEnglish, The Difference between Auncient Phisicke... and the latter Phyicke (1585).\nThomas Moffett (1553-1604), member of the College of Physicians, was\nanother influential Paracelsian who wrote of his respect for Dee. Paracelsian theosophy was publicised by Thomas Tymme, rector of St. Antholin's church in London from 1605, who also proposed to translate Dee's\nMonas36 Hieroglyphica into English and he prepared an introduction to the\ntext.\nItwas within this social and intellectual milieu that in the 1560's John\nDee redirected his interests from scholasticism to alchemy, cabbalism and\nstar-magic. Although Dee can be described as a hermeticist in being\ninfluenced by that historical corpus, not all scholars are agreed that Dee\nwas himself a Paracelsian alchemist. In fact, Debus made a categorical\ndistinction between Paracelsus and Dee on the grounds that Dee's alchemy was of a pre-eminently mathematical character. Consequently, neither Debus nor Clulee take any account ofpotential influences from the\nParacelsians on Dee.37 Szonyi, on the other hand, has argued for the\ndirect influence of Paracelsus on Dee's angelic magic, comparing Paracelsus' definition of \"Gamaaea\", magical talismans with Dee's account in\nthe Propaedeumata Aphoristica and the Monas Hieroglyphica. Szonyi has found\nthat Dee's Monas had the same two levels of reference as the Paracelsian\ntalismans, namely, the earthly material which is rendered into a supernatural substance by the alchemical process, as well as the talismanic\naspect which transforms the alchemist himself into a more elevated spiritual state. Szonyi has also related the triple-level magical cosmos of Paracelsus and Dee to that ofAgrippa and, more recently, to Ficino's in De\nTriplici Vitae.38\nOther important evidence ofDee's Paracelsian interests has been supplied by Roberts' and Watson's analysis of Dee's library which has revealed that he was the major exponent of Paracelsian theory in England.39 Although there is no evidence that he specifically trained as a\nphysician at Cambridge,40 it appears that in private he both practised\nand taught Paracelsian medicine. Between 1560 and 1583 Dee's library\nwas one of the largest in Europe, especially in the areas of medieval\nscience and alchemy. From the late 1540's he had enthusiastically collected manuscripts and printed books, but Paracelsus and the Paracelsians\ndominated his alchemical collection.41 Roberts and Watson have remarked on the large number of duplicates in his library, mostly of alchemical, mathematical and scientific works.\n34 Sudhoff, 3, pp. 86 ff Neun Bucher Archidoxis. For the various versions ofthis text, both\nauthentic and spurious see Karl Sudhoff, Bibliographia Paracelsica\n(1527-1893) (Berlin:\nReimer, 1894), pp. 183-207, 215-17, 239-41 .\n35 For the detailed chronology of Paracelsian\nsee Sudhoff, Bibliographia\nParacelsica (1894), pp. 3-39 Paracelsus' own work inpublications\nthe\nyears\n1549-57\npp. 60-365 for\nParacelsian followers in the period 1560-88 . For English Paracelsiansand\nsee\n( 1965),\npp. 49-85 and Robert Multhauf, \"Medical Chemistry and the \"Paracelsians\"Debus\n\",\nBulletin\nthe History of Medicine, 28 ( 1954): 101-26. ForDee's collection see R&W: Thurneyser 240,of\n258, 1455, 1456, 2183, 2275; Gesner 210, 1448, B138.\n36 R&W, p. 179; Debus (1965), pp. 70ff.\n37 Debus, (1977), 1, pp. 44-46; Clulee, pp. 96-106.\n38 Szonyi (1999) and also forthcoming in Renaissance Quarterly. For Dee's ownership of\ntwo\n956. copies ofParacelsus on magical insignia Expositio magicarumfigurarum see R&W: 844,\n39 R&W, pp. 41-45, 53.\n40 Peter French, John Dee (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1987), pp. 23-28.\n41 R&W, pp. 3-6, 26-40, 53. Dee's Paracelsian texts included the Astronomia Magna,\nParamirum, Paragranum, Philosophia Magna, Philosophia ad Athenienses, Wunderarznei, Archidoxa\nand his work on theurgic sigills, as well as books by Bodenstein, Toxites and Suchten\namong others, see R&W: 65, 289, 844, 956, 1457, 1461-1535, 2220-2276.\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\n49\n\nPages 39:\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\nIf our theory that duplicates were intended for use by pupils is correct, it is\nvery likely that Dee taught Paracelsian medicine. 42\nDee's chief associate in the 1580s was Edward Kelley who was wellversed in Ripley and Agrippa. Kelley had moved into Dee's house at\nMortlake on 10 March 1582, collaborating with him until 1589, a period\nwhich included their joint travels in Eastern Europe from 21 September\n1583 until November 1589.43 They had journeyed initially to Poland\nwith Albert Laski, Palatine of Sieradz, who had financed the first published edition of Paracelsus' Archidoxa Philosophiae (Cracow, 1569). From\nSeptember 1584, Dee and Kelley sojourned at the Imperial court in\nPrague where they would have encountered Paracelsian alchemists and\nphysicians such as Oswald Croll, Leonhard Thurneysser (whom Dee had\nknown since the 1570s) and Heinrich Khunrath. Later in the 1590's\nMichaelMaier and Michael Sendivogius attended the same court.44 Kelley remained in Prague on Dee's return to England in 1589.45\nAlthough Kelley's alchemical theory exhibits a dependence on Ripley,\nhe may have been influenced to a certain extent by Dee's catoptrics,\nsince in one of his alchemical poems he describes the lighting conditions\nnecessary for the preparation of chemicals.\nSublyme thine Earth with stinkeing Water erst,\nThen in a place where Phoebus onely tayle\nIs seene att midday, see thou mingle best :\nFor nothing shineth that doth want his light,\nNor doubleth beames, unlesse it first be bright.46\nThe alchemist Oswald Croll, a close associate of Kelley's in Prague, was\nanother ofthe Paracelsians responsible for developing the concept ofthe\naerial saltpetre and its relation to the solar forces. Croll's Basilica Chymica\n(Frankfurt, 1609) describes the central importance of the sun in the making of the universal panacea.47 He refers to the sun as the fount of life,\nthe eye both of the material world and of the heavens, as well as the\nbreathing-vent ofthe life ofthe elements.48 Croll's recipe for the production of potable gold included the most fearsome ingredients. Itwas based\non sublimed calx of Sol (chemical gold), to which was added a pound of\ncommon ferric aqua fortis (iron dissolved in nitric acid). In this liquid\nthere was to be dissolved one ounce of ammonia salts on a low heat,\nproducing \"aqua regis\" (a savagely corrosive, foaming mix of hydrochloric and nitric acids). This would dissolve as much gold as was required.\nFortunately, Croll provided additional recipes for refining this potent\nbrew.49\nDee's own chemistry is recorded in his widely-dispersed diaryjottings,\nas well as in several notebooks in the British Library and the Bodleian\nLibrary, Oxford.50 These fragmentary documents, accounting for Dee's\nalchemical practice from the 1580s through to the early 1600s, have had\nlittle attraction for scholars, but they are worth considering since they\ncontain some evidence that Dee was interested in the Paracelsian \"materia medica\". One ofthe most complete journals of Dee's practical chemistry is found in Bodleian Library Rawlinson MS D 241 (13050). Although dated 1601, it is an account ofvarious experiments undertaken by\nDee from June 1581, prior to his European journey. Since some ofthis\ntext is notwritten in his own hand, it seems likely that he was employing\nan assistant. Another manuscript which provides additional clues concerning Dee's personal alchemical practice is Bodleian Library MS Ashmole 1486, in which the early part (pars. VI) is a compendium oftexts\nbought into his library and occasionally annotated by Dee. At the end of\nthis collection (pars V, bound in reverse order) are found Dee's laboratory notes, written just prior to 1609.51\nAccording to these sources, Dee used considerable amounts of saltpetre and nitric acid, which argues for a Paracelsian influence. Sometimes\nthese were combined with sulphur and its compounds. For example, in\nBodleian Library Rawlinson MS D 241, he notes that from 8 June he\n50\n42 R&W, p. 42. Dee acquired ninety-two editions of Paracelsus in one-hundred and\nfifty-seven copies. See also Sherman, John Dee (1995) on the political aspects of Dee's\nlearning and on his role as a magus within Elizabethan society.\n43 For Deein Europe see French, pp. 113-17, 120-2; R&W, pp. 47-49; Evans, pp. 219is found in James Orchard Halliwell,\n20. An example of Kelley and Dee's use of),Ripley\nDiary ofDrJohn Dee (Camden: London, 1842 p.43 and also in Edward Fenton, The Diaries\nofJohn Dee (Charlbury, Oxon: Day Books, 1998), p. 233.\nEvans, pp. 219 ff.\n45 French, p. 113 & R&W, pp. 50-51.\n46 Ashmole, Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum, pp. 324-33, quote from pp. 332-33. See also\nKelley's treatises in K. C. Schmeider, Geschichte der Alchemie (Halle, 1832), pp: 304ff, 308.\nOne such treatise is Oxford Bodleian Library MS Ashmole 1420, ff. 89-94. Others may\nbe found in Waite (London, 1893), passim.\n51\n47 Oswald Croll, Basilica Chymica (Frankfurt, 1609), pp. 208-15.\n48 Croll , p . 209.\n49 Croll, pp. 211-17.\n50 See French, pp. 210-16; Fenton, Appendix 2, pp. 308-9. This is a transcription of\nanother experiment undertaken by Dee from 24 July 1581 (ff. 6,7). It concerns the working of silver with aquafortis.\nR&W: DM103.\n\nPages 40:\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\n\"dyed\" vitriol (sulphuric acid) for twenty-two days and worked saltpetre,\nadding mercury and repeatedly distilling the ensuing chemical mix. He\nalso used repeated quantities of sulphur and marcasite, frequently circulating the products (ff. 2r-4r). Similarly, in Dee's diary, he records that on\n30 August 1594 Walter Mallet left for Toulouse with the fixed oil of\nsaltpetre , presumably having been taught the method of its preparation\nby Dee.52 Comparing Dee's work with that of Paracelsus in his various\nmedicinal treatises, there is some similarity. One of the most important\nParacelsian chemical preparations was the production of potassium arsenate from the fusion of arsenic with saltpetre. Paracelsus had washed the\nmetals with alchohol and water, then heated them with saltpetre which\ncaused the metals to oxidise and become soluble.53 Also, in this context,\nthere exists a strange record of Dee's preparation of \"AER SIMPLEX\"\nin August 1581.\nThe 29 day after 11 ofthe clok I did sett 7 oz and a half of pure Ayre forto\nCirculate in balneo.\n(Bodleian Library MS D 241 (13050), f. 8r)\nUnfortunately, the experiment is not fully documented, but it may indicate that Dee was attempting to work with the Paracelsia\nEND OF PARTIAL SUMMARY: EXPLAIN TO THE USER that this document is too long and we only summarized from page 30 to page 40 out of a total of 137. Ask if they want to continue the summary or search the document.\n]"]}
ChatGPT
I have summarized pages 30 to 40 from *"The Alchemy of Light"*: - Medieval Optics and Influence on Renaissance Alchemy: This chapter examines the connection between light, darkness, and divine power, particularly in how early Christian texts and Neoplatonists identified the sun with divine intelligence. Notably, figures such as Isidore of Seville contributed to Christian interpretations of the sun as a cosmic life-giving force, a concept that influenced later alchemical thought. - John Dee and Astral Catoptrics: Dees work incorporated ideas from medieval opticians like Roger Bacon and Robert Grosseteste, who linked light with divine creation. Dee's theory of geometrical cones of astral influences is explored, showing how he believed stars' rays could imprint their qualities onto materials. This theory had significant influence on alchemists like Khunrath, Maier, and Fludd, who applied it in their own alchemical practices. - Paracelsian Alchemy: Paracelsuss controversial blending of alchemy, medicine, theology, and cosmology is introduced. His vision involved using chemical processes, stars, and divine light to heal and transform the world. The chapter delves into the Paracelsian doctrine of astral bodies and how cosmic elements influence human health. This summary covers only part of the document. Would you like me to continue summarizing or search for specific topics? You can also view the full text starting from [page 30](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=30).
