{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=31\nPages: 31\nadditional ideas being drawn from the Arabs, Grosseteste, Witelo and\nJohn Pecham.28 It may be that further investigation by Szonyi will lead to\na re-assessment of Clulee's argument.\nDee had a great interest in catoptrics, as is demonstrated in Roberts\nand Watson's catalogue of his library which contains many Arabic and\nscholastic resources. Catoptrics was a branch of the science of optics\ninitiated by the ancient Greeks and defined by Archimedes as the study\nof the refraction and reflection of light-rays by mirrors or prisms. The\nincendiary properties of parabolic mirrors, which collected and focused\nthe rays ofthe sun, had already been known in the sixth century AD by\nphilosophers such as Anthemius of Thralles.29 In the medieval period,\n129-31. For Boehme's account of Christ as the redeeming light see Will-Erich Peuckert,\nBoehme. Samtliche Schriften (Stuttgart: Frommanns Verlag, 1955), 1, \"Aurora Signatura Rerum oder Morgenrothe in Anfang\", pp. 263-84.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=61\nPages: 61\nthe Zoroastians by further consideration of their god \"ORIMASDA\"\nwhose form was that of eternal fire. Khunrath provides an account of\nvarious other religions and philosophies which have venerated the fire as\nsacred, most of his examples being taken from the Old Testament, with\nsome from Greek and Roman classical literature, such as stories of the\nVestal Virgins, as well as other ancient sacrifical fire cults. All ofthese he\nconsiders to be the secret external fire of the sages (De Igne: 4-20).\nFrom the very beginning of his treatise, Khunrath promotes the use of\ncatoptrics in alchemy, by initially recalling the words of Paracelsus in\nBook VII of the Rerum Naturalium de transmutatione (De Igne: 26) on the\ndegrees ofheat to be used in alchemy. He relates these pyromantic theories to catoptrics, describing how the virtues of the sun are to be deployed in alchemy by means of steel or crystal mirrors . In this celestial]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=74\nPages: 74\nHuc pertinet Cabalistarum Gimetria; Teusrasche; et Neoteriken. Sive (ut\nJoannes ab Dee Londinensis exprimit, in suis ad Parisienses Aphorismis, etin\nPraefatione ad Regem Maximilianum Monadi Hieroglyphicae praefixam)\nGeometria, Notariacon et Tzyruph (Khunrath, 1609: 6)\nFurthermore, there are allusions to catoptrics in certain details of the\nillustrations in the Amphiteatrum, such as the hand-lens in Khunrath's portrait of 1602, which depicts him holding pair of dividers with which heis\ninscribing a circle (a Pythagorean reference) (fig. 26). Similarly, in de\nVries' engraving of the Oratory-Laboratory, a hand-mirror is depicted\namong the objects on the table (frontispiece). The owl in Khunrath's\nemblem of 1599 is also provided with optical and luminary accessories\nsuch as spectacles, tapers and candle-sticks (fig. 28). It is probable, in fact,\nthat Khunrath was writing his treatise on alchemical catoptrics De Igne\nMagorum, in the same years, 1602-4, as he was reworking the Amphiteatrum.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=63\nPages: 63\ncorpus with its astrology, the Rosarium, Dee's catoptrical theories and\nKhunrath's De Igne Magorum all produce the impression that celestial rays\nwere, indeed, being employed by alchemists to \"animate\" their materials.\nIn De Igne Magorum, as well as citing Paracelsus and the medieval\ncorpus , Khunrath also refers to the \"twelve books\" of Giambattista della\nPorta's Magia Naturalis, referring, thereby, to the enlarged second edition\nof 1589 (De Igne: 94). Other authorities mentioned in his account of the\nastral fires and catoptrics include Hermolaus Barbarus in Corollario super\nDioscorides ubi de Aquis in Commune (De Igne: 90), Trithemius in the Aureum\nvellus (De Igne: 94), Joannes Pontanus and Penotus's letter to Joannes Bartholomeus Burggravius (De Igne: 96, 103).\nThe most immediate influence of Khunrath's alchemical catoptrics\nwas on Stefan Michelspacher's Cabala, Spiegel der Kunst und Natur (Augsburg, 1615-1616), consisting of four engravings which represent mirrors]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=48\nPages: 48\nItalian medical chemistry, such as Hieronymous Brunschwig (circa 14501533), Liber de arte distillandi (1500-1512) and Pierandrea Mattioli (15001577) \"De ratione distillandi aquas\" in his Commentarii a Dioscoride , Venice (1544). Another influence was Conrad Gesner in his Thesaurus Euonymi\nPhiliatri (1555).46\nIt was Khunrath who related della Porta's catoptrics specifically to\nalchemy, mentioning him in the Amphiteatrum of 1609 as well as in De Igne\nMagorum (circa 1602-1604). Subsequently, Athanasius Kircher (1602-80)\nclaimed to have invented distillation by means of catoptrics, illustrating\nthe process in his Mundus subterraneus (Amsterdam, 1665) (fig. 20).47 His\nclaim for primacy has to be disregarded since by this date the catoptrical\ndistillation process was well-established. For example, there exists an earlier drawing of similar apparatus in the Mellon collection of occult and\nalchemical manuscripts (circa 1625), belonging to an anonymous Italian]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=63\nPages: 63\ndisguised willy-nilly in the texts.31\nIt is certainly true that this process of vivification was never clearly described bythe alchemists, as in the case ofthe section concerning \"Illuminatio\" in the Rosarium. The illustration plainly shows the sun enteringthe\ntomb ofdead matter (fig. 10), but the accompanying text speaks only of\nperfect circles and the astronomical role of the sun. It is Khunrath's De\nIgne Magorum which had, in fact, provided the first clear instructions for\nthe practice of catoptrics in an alchemical context, on the basis ofJohn\nDee's technique in the Mathematicall Preface and the Monas Hieroglyphica.\nDobbs argued further that\nthe activating agent in illumination was broadly conceived and was related to\nvisible light more metaphorically than literally.32\nIn this conclusion, she was being too cautious since the pseudo-Lullian\ncorpus with its astrology, the Rosarium, Dee's catoptrical theories and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=61\nPages: 61\nfire the three principles of alchemy (Sulphur-Mercury-Salt) are refined.\nEs ist ein Unsichtbar Feuer, darbei wir vermeinen die radios oder strahlen\nder Sonnen, welches Feuer durch einen stahlenen Spiegel oder Christallen\nsich er offnet ... Mit diesem Feuer die Drei Principia, von einem jeden\nCorporalischen dinge/ frei auff einem tische gescheiden werden (De Igne:\n26-27)\nKhunrath continues his examination of catoptrics at length, referring also\nto Agrippa's description of magical mirrors in De Occulta Philosophia (De\nIgne: 28-32). He quotes Paracelsus once more in order tojustifythe use of\ncatoptrics in alchemy, employing his concept of the \"Arcanum\", the hidden virtue in nature which is the true medicine (De Igne: 27-28). He\nrecalls how Paracelsus had explained that the effectiveness of the \"Arcanum\" was dependent on the method of its preparation. This had to be\nundertaken during the appropriate period of the sun's cycle in order to]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=62\nPages: 62\nalchemical furnace, as a form of sympathetic magic (De Igne: 53). In this\noperation, he seems to intend the use of catoptrics, since later in the text\nhe provides some general instructions on the use of the catoptrical mirror, which appears in a little drawing at the side of the text, emphasising\nthe importance of these instructions (De Igne: 70). Like Dee in theMonas\nHieroglyphica, Khunrath advises that the alchemical work should be started under the astrological sign of Aries (March) at the beginning of the\nNew Year.28 In this context, he explains how to practice Paracelsian\nsympathetic magic through the use of the magnet (De Igne: 71), also referring to another aspect of Paracelsian theurgy (in De Tempore) by recommending the \"irradiation\" of the materials. A little is enough. The process of irradiation involves the exposure of the alchemical matter to the\nastral rays by means of catoptrics.\nwelches zwar wunderbarlich/jedoch die Weisen lehrens! zu bequemen Zeit/]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=94\nPages: 94\nas being related to the use of catoptrics.\nWithplants and animals reproduction takes place by means ofseed, but with\nsimple bodies or bodies of a simple composition this takes place by introducing force and by means of assimilation.\nThus, the sun, the celestial luminary, sends its beams to the earth and when\nthese beams are bundled in a sun-glass, shapes are seen, which are, as it\nwere, form projections ofthe sun. On these grounds it is established that sunbeams are nothing but flames offire, which are spread out over a wide space;\nwhen, however, they are focused, they burn everything that comes within the\npoint offocus33\nMaier frequently refers to the secret fire of alchemy, the quintessence, as\nin Emblem XXXVII (Maier, 1618: 158-59).34\nThe quintessential fire is the theme also of Emblem VIII, which alludes to alchemical geometry and catoptrics (fig. 41) on the model ofde\nVries' engraving for Khunrath's Amphiteatrum. The illustration displays an]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=82\nPages: 82\nenhanced.53Engravings intended to be viewed by means of the \"Vue d'\nOptique\" depict a long depth-of-field, as well as strong contrasts oflight\nand shadow in the foreground. Thus, by means of catoptrics de Vries\ncould have been attempting to produce an unbroken spatial (indexical)\ncontinuum between the physical world and the illustration. For that very\npurpose Alberti in his De Pictura (1435) had originally introduced the\ndevice of single-point space into painting, in order to blur the division\nbetween imagination and reality. Alberti's spatial geometry was primarily\na rhetorical device designed to slip a message effortlessly pastthe viewer's\nobjective judgement. According to Obrist, the medieval alchemists had\nprovided visual depictions oftheir ideas with the same intention of confusing the viewer's sense of reality.54 Paracelsus had also considered the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96\nPages: 96\ncone oflight.\nIn the Propaedeumata Aphoristica Dee had emphasised the theurgic power of the centric-rays emitted by the celestial spheres, which could be\n43 Yates (1969), pp. 112-35.\n44 Fludd, \"Microsocm\", UCH, 2 (Oppenheim: J.T. de Bry, 1619), Tract I, Sect II, pp.\n58, 64.\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\n165\ndeployed by the astronomer using catoptrical apparatus.\"45 Hence, in\nMaier's emblem the centric axis passing through the egg to the vanishing-point symbolises the transmutatory effects of the celestial influences\nand it alludes to the use of catoptrics. Maier states in his commentary on\nthe emblem that the aim of human life is to pass from a vegetable existence in the womb to the more perfect light of the macrocosm , just as\nwhen an egg is \"killed\" it attains the higher form ofa bird. This imagery\nalso refers to sexual impregnation which generates new life.46 The alchemical male and female principles may die in their old forms, but,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10\npragmatic body of knowledge for more esoteric purposes. Specifically,\nby means ofcatoptrics (the reflection and refraction of light-rays by mirrors and lenses), Dee thought that celestial rays could be manipulated\nmore reliably to enhance all aspects of human affairs. The metaphysical\nrationale for Dee's astronomical and optical magic was provided bythe\ncabbalah, which he integrated into his alchemy in the 1560s. His fully\ndeveloped system of natural philosophy was published in the Monas Hieroglyphica (1564) which combined optics, geometry, magic, alchemy, medicine and cabbalism.8\nDee's last published treatise was the Mathematicall Preface to Henry\nBillingsley's translation of Euclid's Principles of Geometry (1570). Although\nthis essay has not been related to alchemy by Dee's scholars, nonetheless,\nitmay have been an additional influence on Maier, Khunrath and Fludd.\nIn the Mathematicall Preface Dee examined Pythagorean geometry in its]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=64\nPages: 64\nmirror on the earth into a dark cave. Kircher's illustration describes the\nvarious lights of nature, the senses and the intellect.\nIt remains to discuss the specific influences triggering Khunrath's\nideas concerning the use of astral virtue and catoptrics in alchemy. These\nmay have been inspired by the publication of Paracelsus' completeworks\nin the Basle edition of 1589-90, as well as the appearance ofdella Porta's\nsecond Magia Naturalis (1589). Another influence was undoubtedly Dee's\ncabbalistic astrology and catoptrics, as well as the enduring effects of Pico\ndella Mirandola's and Reuchlin's Christian cabbalism. In the context of\nthe political pressures on his pietistic beliefs between circa 1595 and\n1604, these influences led Khunrath to devise a cabbalistic alchemy of\nlight, founded on Paracelsian theosophy and Renaissance optical science.\nIOO\n34 Peuckert and Zeller (eds), Valentin Weigel. Samtliche Schriften (Stuttgart, 1962-78), 2,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=32\nPages: 32\nThere are more Syrian and Hebrew grammars through-out the rest of the R&W catalogue,\nPostel. as well as the cabbalistic treatises ofps. Lull, Pico della Mirandola, Reuchlin and\nTHE INFLUENCE OF MEDIEVAL OPTICS ON RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\n37\n52\nEarl of Northumberland.38 It has been established that Dee also gained\ninformation concerning the properties of lenses and mirrors from Gogava's edition ofAlhazen on catoptrics (included in his translation ofPtolemy\nOpus quadripartium, 1548). Gogava probably instructed Dee in the manufacture and use of astronomical and optical apparatus.39\nDee himself wrote an richly illustrated but unfinished tract on catoptrics (dated 1558) which is found in British Library MS Cotton Vitellius\nC.VII, art. 5, De Speculis comburentibus libri 5 (ff. 280r-309v) (figs. 12-15).\nFrom the internal evidence, it seems that Dee intended to prepare this\nmanuscript for publication. In the text he states briefly that his ideas were]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=48\nPages: 48\nalchemical manuscripts (circa 1625), belonging to an anonymous Italian\ntext on distillation.48 In addition, there are other seventeenth century\nillustrations which depict alchemical catoptrics, for example, Mylius in\nhis pictorial chronology of famous alchemists depicts \"Ademarus philosophus\" reflecting the sun in a mirror (Opus Medico-Chymicum, Frankfurt:\nLucas Jennis, 1618). Also, later seventeenth practical chemists are sometimes shown employing the sun's rays to calcinate antimony, such as an\nimage in Nicasius le Febure's A Compleat Body of Chemistry (London,\n1670).49\nOther related seventeenth century texts and illustrations such as those\nof Stefan Michelspacher, Jacob Boehme and Isaac Newton will be considered in relation to Khunrath's metaphysics of light and his catoptrical\npractice of \"irradiating\" alchemical prime matter.\n43 Giambattista della Porta, Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti (Naples: Horatius Salvianus,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=94\nPages: 94\nparticular image was taken from the Rosarium, in which the analogy of\nthe sun and its shadow appears in its account of the illumination ofthe\nalchemical substance by the sun.\nThe use of catoptrical mirrors as a source of heat is described in\nEmblem XXIII where Maier explains the manner in which celestial influences are transmitted to the earth by the sun's rays (fig. 40). The\nillustration shows the alchemist, clad in the martial robes of Mars, splitting the head of Saturn to release the form of Pallas Athena. In the\nbackground appears a statue of the Apollo of Rhodes, whose head is\nencircled by an aureole of light. Meanwhile, on the right of the picture\nthe sun-god engages in sexual dalliance with Venus, while storm clouds\nshower rays of coins. The conjunction ofthe sun and Venus is a catoptrical hieroglyph in which the sun's rays are caught by a mirror (the emblem of Venus). Maier's commentary explains the meaning of the image\nas being related to the use of catoptrics.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52\n(f. dijv)\nAmong the true \"Zographers\", Dee included the art-theorists Giorgio\nVasari, Pietro Aretino and Pomponius Gauricus.\nZographie, is an Arte Mathematicall, which teacheth and demonstrateth,\nhow, the Intersection of all visuall Pyramides, made by any playne assigned,\n(the Centre, distance, and lightes, beying determined) may be, by lynes, and\ndue propre colours, represented (f. dijv)\nIn Dee's ideas, \"Zographie\" was related integrally to his optical theories,\nsince the Pythagorean-based system ofsingle-point perspective was a type\nof magical catoptrics, with the same function as the catoptrics of the\nPropaedeumata Aphoristica and the later Monas Hieroglyphica. He seems to\nhave believed that a painting whose spatial system was organised in accordance with Pythagorean geometrical ratios would theurgically attract\nthe corresponding planetary influences. In other words , a painting could]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=32\nPages: 32,33\n39 Shumaker, Prop. Aph, pp. 62-64; Clulee, p. 31. In the Propaedeumata Aphoristica, Dee\nalso acknowledged the influence of Gerard Mercator, Gemma Frisius and Gaspara\nMirica.\n40 Shumaker, p. 53.\n41 Shumaker, p. 51. The provenance and form of Dee's mirror is discussed by Clulee,\np. 262: n. 120.\n42 Shumaker, p. 67.\nAphorism LII\nIf you were skilled in \"catoptrics\" you would be able, by art, to imprint the\nrays of any star much more strongly upon any matter subjected to it than\nnature itself does. This, indeed , was by far the largest part of the natural\nphilosophy of the ancient wise men. And this secret is not of much less\nthe philosophers , called inferior,\ndignity than the very august astronomy ofcertain\nMonad 43\nwhose symbols ... [are] ... enclosed in a\nAccording to Dee, mirrors could imitate planetary influences, increasing\nand decreasing the intensity oftheir radiations catoptrically and imprinting their influences on matter and magical gems.44 In these statements,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52,53\n16 Szonyi, \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim.\n17 Yates, Rosicrucian Enlightenment (1986), p. 83.\n77\n78\nCHAPTER SIX\nIn answer to Yates' query, it may now be possible to suggest that, first,\nthe image in Emblem VIII does not present mathematics in the guise of\nalchemy, but alchemy in the guise of optics . Second, the missing link in\nestablishing the meaning ofthis engraving is Dee's catoptrics and \"zographie\". It could be added that, from the internal evidence oftheir texts,\none of the purposes of Khunrath's and Maier's employment of singlepoint perspective and classical architecture was to instruct the alchemist\nin the science of catoptrics. An important influence on the development\nof this practice was Dee's astrological catoptrics, Pythagorean geometry\nand cabbalism.\nMaier would have been able to read the Mathematicall Preface since he\nknew English, but it is not possible to assume that Khunrath would have\nknown the contents of this treatise since there is no evidence that he]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=74\nPages: 74\nnature, rather than with his hands.\nsine manuali cooperatione, solius Naturae laboribus\n(Khunrath, 1609: 201)\nInthe last stages ofthe alchemical process, he explains, when the purified\nbody and spirit ofthe materials are being re-united, the alchemist should\nuse the \"Olympian fire\" (Khunrath, 1608: 73-74). He refers less directly\nto the practice ofcatoptrics in the Amphiteatrum, informing the reader only\nthat he has to work in an occult manner with fire, or by means ofdivine\npower in a cabbalistic manner.224 This work takes three days to complete\nand it involves all the levels of creation, divine, macrocosmic and microcosmic (Khunrath, 1609: 203).\nThis catoptrical reference is related to John Dee's ideas, since in an\nearlier section ofthe Amphiteatrum, Khunrath had referred to Dee's cabbalism in the Propaedeumata Aphoristica and the Monas Hieroglyphica.\nHuc pertinet Cabalistarum Gimetria; Teusrasche; et Neoteriken. Sive (ut]"]}
ChatGPT
The concept of catoptrics, which refers to the study of the reflection and refraction of light, plays a significant role in alchemical theories, particularly in the works of John Dee and Heinrich Khunrath. In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* the following key points about catoptrics are highlighted: 1. Catoptrics and Alchemy: Catoptrics was viewed as a method for manipulating celestial rays and enhancing their power for alchemical purposes. Khunrath emphasized the importance of mirrors, such as steel or crystal mirrors, to focus the sun's rays, which could then be used in alchemical processes: > Khunrath promotes the use of catoptrics in alchemy, describing how the virtues of the sun are to be deployed by means of steel or crystal mirrors. [Urszula Szul, page 61](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=61). 2. Celestial Rays and Catoptrical Mirrors: John Dee and Khunrath believed that celestial rays could be concentrated through catoptrical apparatus, focusing the divine powers for use in alchemical transmutation: > Dee emphasized the theurgic power of the centric-rays emitted by the celestial spheres, which could be deployed by the astronomer using catoptrical apparatus. [Urszula Szul, page 96](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96). 3. Applications in Khunrath's Work: Khunrath expanded on the practical use of catoptrics by explaining how astral rays could be manipulated through mirrors to animate alchemical materials. This idea was part of his broader theosophical vision, combining optical science with Paracelsian theosophy: > Khunrath provided the first clear instructions for the practice of catoptrics in an alchemical context, on the basis of John Dee's technique. [Urszula Szul, page 63](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=63). Catoptrics thus served as a bridge between optical science and alchemical practice, reflecting light as a metaphor for divine illumination and transformation in the material world. You can explore more details on these ideas starting from [page 61](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=61).
You
paracelsian

ForDee's collection see R&W: Thurneyser 240,of\n258, 1455, 1456, 2183, 2275; Gesner 210, 1448, B138.\n36 R&W, p. 179; Debus (1965), pp. 70ff.\n37 Debus, (1977), 1, pp. 44-46; Clulee, pp. 96-106.\n38 Szonyi (1999) and also forthcoming in Renaissance Quarterly. For Dee's ownership of\ntwo\n956. copies ofParacelsus on magical insignia Expositio magicarumfigurarum see R&W: 844,\n39 R&W, pp. 41-45, 53.\n40 Peter French, John Dee (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1987), pp. 23-28.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nThe influence of Paracelsian theosophy on German pietists such as Valentin Weigel and Johannes Arndt19 and their subsequent effects on alchemical ideas will be discussed in a later chapter.\nIn the immediate context, it is evident that Paracelsus' concept ofthe\nrole of the imagination in both magical and spiritual practices would\nencourage the use of visual imagery. For example, Khunrath's \"amphi-\ntheatre\" of 1595 and 1609 provides a public spectacle for an audience,\ndisplaying the actions of Eternal Wisdom on the physical chemistry ofthe\nmanifested creation. In Paracelsian terms, Khunrath shows how the\nphysical world is united to the divine principle by means ofthe \"quintessence\" or \"azoth\". The Paracelsian \"azoth\" was a concept adopted from\nthe late medieval theory ofthe \"coelum\", a medium between matter and\nsoul, world and God, in other words an \"astral\" substance, both physical\nand spiritual in nature. Therefore, it had exactly the same character and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\ndeveloped the alchemical concept of the fifth essence into a medical\ntheory. Paracelsian alchemy was not concerned with transmutation, but\nwith the preparation ofmedicines. Paracelsus departed from Arabic medicine mostly in his conviction that chemically prepared inorganic medicines were superior to the herbal preparations ofmedievalphysicians. To\nthis end, he stressed the importance of the metals, particularly mercury,\nantimony and iron salts, advocating also the medicinal use of poisons,\nsuch as arsenic, in strict dosages.22 He prepared these by means of distillation in order to purify and intensify the volatile spirits ofthe substance\nby removing the impure earths. This would introduce the hidden virtue\nof the star governing the disease and induce healing by homeopathic\nmeans.23\nAccording to the Paracelsian doctrine of signatures, the \"astra\" (stellar\nvirtues) present within all natural bodies were the foundation of practical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=38\nPages: 38\ntechniques.35 English Paracelsians included Richard Bostocke who borrowed Dee's Paracelsian texts and wrote the first Paracelsian apology in\nEnglish, The Difference between Auncient Phisicke... and the latter Phyicke (1585).\nThomas Moffett (1553-1604), member of the College of Physicians, was\nanother influential Paracelsian who wrote of his respect for Dee. Paracelsian theosophy was publicised by Thomas Tymme, rector of St. Antholin's church in London from 1605, who also proposed to translate Dee's\nMonas36 Hieroglyphica into English and he prepared an introduction to the\ntext.\nItwas within this social and intellectual milieu that in the 1560's John\nDee redirected his interests from scholasticism to alchemy, cabbalism and\nstar-magic. Although Dee can be described as a hermeticist in being\ninfluenced by that historical corpus, not all scholars are agreed that Dee\nwas himself a Paracelsian alchemist. In fact, Debus made a categorical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\nhigher \"gnosis\" ofthe spirit, Paracelsus was drawing on cabbalistic thinking.18\nParacelsus rejected the ancient natural philosophers, replacing Aristotle with christianised neo-platonic and hermetic authorities, discarding\nalso the medical canon of Avicenna and Galen. 19 Instead , he believed\nthat physical ailments were the result of external forces rather than ofan\nimbalance offluids, as in the medieval theory ofthe four humours. Each\norgan of the body, Paracelsus explained, contained a dynamism called\nthe \"archeon\" which functioned as an internal alchemist. Moreover, he\nbelieved that each illness originated in a particular star whose virtue was\nembodied in the corresponding earthly \"arcanum\", a medicine which\ncould heal the ailment.20\nParacelsus was not the first to adapt alchemy to medicine, since John\nof Rupescissa and Arnold of Villanova in the fourteenth-century had\ndeveloped the alchemical concept of the fifth essence into a medical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16\nsimilar tothatofthe trance induced by the magical practice of\"scrying\",\nor looking into the astral realms with the aid ofmirrors and crystals, as in\nJohn Dee's sceances with Edward Kelley.12\nItis not coincidental that the philosophical context ofthese very elaborate, late Renaissance illustrations is that of Paracelsian theosophy.\nThey began to appear soon after the publication of Paracelsus' collected\nwritings in 1589-90 in the editions of Peter Barna in Basel and in those of\nJohn Huser in Cologne (1589-91; 1603; 1605). The first Paracelsian illustrative cycle was produced by Khunrath between 1595 and 1602 and the\nnext, in order of production, may have been Fludd's cosmological diagrams, since he claimed to have written most of his \"Macrocosm\" before\n4\n10 Stephen Clucas, \" \"Non est legendum sed inspicendum solum\": Inspectival knowledge and thevisual logic ofJohn Dee's LiberMysteriorum\", Glasgow Emblem Studies, 3 (1998),]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=34\nPages: 34,35\nform was that of an alchemical still,4 fabricating a monistic model of the\nworld's emergence from the \"mysterium magnum\", a prime matter un-\n58 Clulee, p. 106.\n1 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" (1979), pp. 60-62, 70-74. For Erastus see\nThorndike, M&ES, 5, pp. 617-51. See also Frick, Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 112-122.\n2 Debus (1977), 1, pp. 129-34; Thorndike, M&ES, 5, pp. 652-67.\n3 Walter Pagel, \"The Prime Matter of Paracelsus\", Ambix, 9 (1961): 117 ff.\n4 Debus (1977), 1, pp. 51-61, 76, 86-87. In the primal creative act God separated\nthe elements7 from each other, acting in the manner of a chemist in his]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=38\nPages: 38,39\n40 Peter French, John Dee (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1987), pp. 23-28.\n41 R&W, pp. 3-6, 26-40, 53. Dee's Paracelsian texts included the Astronomia Magna,\nParamirum, Paragranum, Philosophia Magna, Philosophia ad Athenienses, Wunderarznei, Archidoxa\nand his work on theurgic sigills, as well as books by Bodenstein, Toxites and Suchten\namong others, see R&W: 65, 289, 844, 956, 1457, 1461-1535, 2220-2276.\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\n49\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\nIf our theory that duplicates were intended for use by pupils is correct, it is\nvery likely that Dee taught Paracelsian medicine. 42\nDee's chief associate in the 1580s was Edward Kelley who was wellversed in Ripley and Agrippa. Kelley had moved into Dee's house at\nMortlake on 10 March 1582, collaborating with him until 1589, a period\nwhich included their joint travels in Eastern Europe from 21 September\n1583 until November 1589.43 They had journeyed initially to Poland]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=34\nPages: 34\nthat alchemy was of interest to Dee in the 1550s, there are, nevertheless,\nsufficient hints within the text of the Propaedeumata Aphoristica to indicate\nthat Dee envisaged an alchemical purpose for his astral catoptrics.\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY:\nTHE \"ASTRAL VIRTUE\" AND\nTHE \"AERIAL SALTPETRE\"\nThe controversy generated by the medical theories of Paracelsus (14931541) was caused not only by his adoption of alchemical methods for\npreparing medicines and his innovatory use of inorganic substances, but\nalso by his disturbing synthesis of medicine, magic, theology and cosmology. Paracelsus' ambitiously expansive (and often self-contradictory) vision forced his educated contemporaries to re-assess both their professional activities as physicians, as well as their philosophical systems and\neven their religious beliefs.\nParacelsus' own Christian commitment cannot be doubted, for this\nwas one of his declared reasons for his attack on pre-Christian medical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17\nPages: 17\nearthly phenomena, therefore , through the \"astra\" it was possible for\nhumans to comprehend all phenomena, both natural and supernatural.\nParacelsus conceived of human intelligence as merging with its object of\nstudy, so that it gained knowledge, not by rational logic, but through an\nempathetic union with the world, that is, through \"gnosis\".\nAccording to Pagel, the Paracelsian universe was a monistic construct\nin which the world and the human-being formed a single identity. Paracelsus had drawn some of his ideas from the neoplatonic and cabbalistic\nmyth of\"Anthropos\", the primeval cosmic being who was both the exemplar and the constituent material ofthe physical universe. This cabbalistic idea had originated in the neoplatonic concept of the demi-urge, or\n\"Anthropos\", out of whose macrocosmic body the lesser material world\nwas made, remaining dependent on the stellar \"arcana\" (astral virtues) in\nthe celestial sphere.15]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=40\nPages: 40\nsaltpetre, then pouring the mixture onto a slab of marble and standing it\nin a cool place. This would become a dough-like substance which required repeated kneading. The Paracelsian alchemist known by the name\nof\"Basil Valentine\" (probably to be identified with his \"editor\"Johannes\nTholde) was a popular source from the 1580s for a potable antimony.\nThis medicinal potion, apparently, was sweet in smell and taste and coloured ruby-red.54\nAt the end of Bodleian MS Ashmole 1486, Dee records that he used a\nmix of two ounces of maracasite, four ounces of vitriol, common tartar,\none ounce of gold and sal ammoniac. There followed much distilling\nwhich indicates that he was attempting to dissolve metals in vitriol. Paracelsian remedies against the plague included sulphur and metals in the\nform of spirit of vitriol, that is, sulphur sublimate. Sulphur derived from\nvitriol and its salts has narcotic and analgesic properties.5\nThis small selection of items from Dee's record can only be indicative]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=40\nPages: 40\nmedicinal treatises, there is some similarity. One of the most important\nParacelsian chemical preparations was the production of potassium arsenate from the fusion of arsenic with saltpetre. Paracelsus had washed the\nmetals with alchohol and water, then heated them with saltpetre which\ncaused the metals to oxidise and become soluble.53 Also, in this context,\nthere exists a strange record of Dee's preparation of \"AER SIMPLEX\"\nin August 1581.\nThe 29 day after 11 ofthe clok I did sett 7 oz and a half of pure Ayre forto\nCirculate in balneo.\n(Bodleian Library MS D 241 (13050), f. 8r)\nUnfortunately, the experiment is not fully documented, but it may indicate that Dee was attempting to work with the Paracelsian aerial virtue.\nDee also favoured \"maracasite\" ( Bodleian Library MS D 241, ff. 2r,\n2v, 3r, 5r), distilling it with sulphur and sulphuric acid (f.5r). (Marcasite is\ncommonly denoted by the symbol of a star). Unfortunately, the name was]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=38\nPages: 38\nTriplici Vitae.38\nOther important evidence ofDee's Paracelsian interests has been supplied by Roberts' and Watson's analysis of Dee's library which has revealed that he was the major exponent of Paracelsian theory in England.39 Although there is no evidence that he specifically trained as a\nphysician at Cambridge,40 it appears that in private he both practised\nand taught Paracelsian medicine. Between 1560 and 1583 Dee's library\nwas one of the largest in Europe, especially in the areas of medieval\nscience and alchemy. From the late 1540's he had enthusiastically collected manuscripts and printed books, but Paracelsus and the Paracelsians\ndominated his alchemical collection.41 Roberts and Watson have remarked on the large number of duplicates in his library, mostly of alchemical, mathematical and scientific works.\n34 Sudhoff, 3, pp. 86 ff Neun Bucher Archidoxis. For the various versions ofthis text, both\nauthentic and spurious see Karl Sudhoff, Bibliographia Paracelsica]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=57\nPages: 57\nexists within the materials in the flask.20 The central interest in theAthanor is the Paracelsian preparation of medicines by means of the \"Magnesia\nUniversalis\" and \"mercurial waters\". The \"Magnesia\" is the Paracelsian\nprime matter, also known as the Salt, or Sulphur, \"sal sapientiae naturae\nsive sulphure\" (Athanor (1615): 12-14, 19-20). Khunrath provides an account of the alchemical fires, the process of digestion, the humid heat of\nthe \"balneum\" and the use ofthe philosophical glass- vessel. The philosopher's stone, he explains, contains its own intrinsic heat which is a volatile aether, awakened by the application of external heat.21 Finally,\nKhunrath mentions his Amphiteatrum, briefly referring to the cabbalah\nand the \"Gradus Magie\" (Athanor (1615): 59).\n86\n87\n19 For Paracelsian medical theory see Pagel (1982), pp. 104-9.\n20 Heinrich Khunrath, Athanor, 3rd ed. (Magdeburg: In Verlegung des Autoris, 1615),\npp. 32, 10-11 , 28-29.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=73\nPages: 73\nUNIVERSUM mundanum tripliciter distribuit ELOHIM (Khunrath, 1609:\n127)\nKhunrath describes a Paracelsian cosmos in which the macrocosmic\n\"caelum\" generates the physical species,17 while in its lower material\nform, the \"caelum\" is the chemical spirits of wine, purified by fire and\nreleased from impure matter.18 In \"Gradus Quintus\" and \"Gradus Sixtus\", Khunrath explains further the astrological basis of his Paracelsian\nalchemy, referring to Paracelsus' interpretation of the creation of the\nstars in Genesis, 1. He explains that all natural objects manifest various\nsigns, constituting an alphabet in the book of the world,19 produced by\nthe innate\"astra\", mirroring those in the heavens (Khunrath, 1609 : 142).\nThe alchemist 20must, therefore, know astronomy and watch the progress\nof the seasons. Khunrath refers specifically to Paracelsus' \"doctrine of\nsignatures\", calling him the \"Germanicus Asclepiades\" and quoting him\non reading the book of nature. In this context, Khunrath also names]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=26\nPages: 26\nproperties of air in his Chymisticum artificii (1569). John Dee owned copies\nof Rupescissa's original treatise, in one instance bound together with\nParacelsus Wunder Artznei, and he also acquired various works by Dorn,\nincluding the Chymisticum artificii.\nAccording to Debus it was the Paracelsian chemists ofthe early seventeenth century who developed the specific theory of the vital saltpetre in\nair, withJoseph Du Chesne (Quercetanus) producing the full theory.\nBy the year 1600 it had become a basic part of the Paracelsian tradition to\nspeak ofthe vital air, or more specifically, theflamma vitalis or the vital aerial\nSulphur.44\nKhunrath integrated Rupescissa's quintessence into his own theoretical\nprogramme as the Paracelsian \"azoth\". This aetherial fire increased in\nsignificance from its first mention in his Amphiteatrum of 1595, becoming\nthe main subject of De Igne Magorum (circa 1602-1604). Khunrath also\ncommented extensively on the \"azoth\" in his second Amphiteatrum of]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=38\nPages: 38\nwas himself a Paracelsian alchemist. In fact, Debus made a categorical\ndistinction between Paracelsus and Dee on the grounds that Dee's alchemy was of a pre-eminently mathematical character. Consequently, neither Debus nor Clulee take any account ofpotential influences from the\nParacelsians on Dee.37 Szonyi, on the other hand, has argued for the\ndirect influence of Paracelsus on Dee's angelic magic, comparing Paracelsus' definition of \"Gamaaea\", magical talismans with Dee's account in\nthe Propaedeumata Aphoristica and the Monas Hieroglyphica. Szonyi has found\nthat Dee's Monas had the same two levels of reference as the Paracelsian\ntalismans, namely, the earthly material which is rendered into a supernatural substance by the alchemical process, as well as the talismanic\naspect which transforms the alchemist himself into a more elevated spiritual state. Szonyi has also related the triple-level magical cosmos of Paracelsus and Dee to that ofAgrippa and, more recently, to Ficino's in De]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36,37\n(1979), pp. 59, 65-66\n19 J. R. Partington, A History of Chemistry, 2 (London: Macmillan, 1961), pp. 115-51;\n(1982): 130-58.\nPagel\n20 Pagel\n(1982): 105-12; Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), p. 85 \"jede\nKrankheit ein Stern\".\n21 Thorndike, M&ES, 3, pp. 347-69; 4, pp. 37-41; F. N. L. Poynter (ed), Chemistryin the\nService ofMedicine (London, 1963), pp. 5-26, esp p. 17.\n22 Pagel (1982), pp. 133-56.\n23 Pagel (1982), p. 70; Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), p. 63.\n45\n24 Pagel (1982), pp. 67-71. Pagel gives an excellent explanation of the Paracelsian\n\"astra\" in his \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), pp. 70-74.\n25 Pagel ( 1982), pp. 59-61.\n26 Michel Foucault, The Order of Things (London; New York: Tavistock; Pantheon,\n1970), pp. 30-94. For a more specific historical account ofthe epistemologicalchanges in\nsixteenth century culture see Will-Erich Peuckert, Die Grosse Wende (Hamburg: Claassen\nand Goverts, 1948), pp. 299-474.\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=38\nPages: 38\nnumber of editions (including spurious versions). The first full compendium of Paracelsus' texts was issued in Basle by Peter Barna in 1589-90\nand another important collected edition was that of John Huser ofWaldkrich in Cologne (1589-91 ; 1603; 1605). In England, according to Debus,\nthe use of chemical medicines had been long accepted prior to the Paracelsian influences due to the writings of Arnald of Villanova, the pseudoLullians and Hieronymous Brunschwig. By the 1580's, there were a great\nnumber of reputable Paracelsian followers both on the continent and in\nEngland, such as Conrad Gesner ofZurich ( 1516-1565) who was a friend\nof Dee. Gesner's treatise on distillation was translated by Thomas Hill\nand published in England by George Baker as the Treasure of Euonymous\n(1559). Leonhard Thurneysser, whom Dee had met in Frankfurt-onOder in 1578, was another influential source in England for distillation]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21\nPages: 21,22\nlibriArchidoxis and vol. 12, pp. 1-444, Astronomia Magna, as well as vol. 12, pp. 503-5, Ars\nsignatoria.Another central Paracelsian text concerning the influence ofthe stars on a long\nand healthy life is De vita longa, Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 221-48 (German text), 249-92 (Latin\nversion). The standard authority on the Paracelsian system is Walter Pagel, Paracelsus\n(Basel: Karger, 1982), see pp. 64-71.\n13 E. J. Holmyard, \"The Emerald Table\", Nature (1923): 525-26; Robert Steele and\nDorothea Waley Singer, \"The Emerald Table\", Proceedings ofthe Royal Society ofMedicine, 21\n(1928): 41-57. For an account of hellenistic hermeticism and alchemy see Frick, Die\nErleuchteten (1973), pp. 72-88.\n16\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nwho developed the full procedure in the seventh century. 14 In Arabic and\nmedieval European alchemy, the Emerald Table came to be regarded as a\nmetaphor ofthe circular process of distillation in which the volatile spirits]"]}
ChatGPT
The concept of Paracelsian alchemy is central to *"The Alchemy of Light"* and describes a unique fusion of alchemy, medicine, theology, and cosmology. Paracelsus (14931541) challenged classical and medieval medical systems and replaced them with a Christianized form of Neoplatonism and Hermeticism. Here are some key points from the document: 1. Paracelsus Departure from Classical Thought: Paracelsus rejected the established theories of Avicenna and Galen, focusing instead on the idea that diseases were caused by external forces, rather than imbalances of bodily fluids. He proposed that illnesses were connected to particular stars, and healing could be achieved through astral influences: > "Paracelsus explained that each illness originated in a particular star whose virtue was embodied in the corresponding earthly 'arcanum,' a medicine which could heal the ailment." [Urszula Szul, page 36](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36). 2. Alchemy as a Medical Practice: Paracelsus version of alchemy was not primarily concerned with the transmutation of metals but with the preparation of medicinal substances. He introduced the use of chemicals like mercury and arsenic in strictly controlled doses, employing distillation to purify these substances and draw out their hidden virtues: > "Paracelsian alchemy was not concerned with transmutation, but with the preparation of medicines." [Urszula Szul, page 36](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36). 3. Imagination and the Quintessence: The Paracelsian concept of "azoth" or quintessence was an astral substance that united the physical world with the divine. This idea influenced many alchemists, including Khunrath, who used Paracelsian ideas to show how imagination could transform physical and spiritual realities: > "In Paracelsian terms, Khunrath shows how the physical world is united to the divine principle by means of the 'quintessence' or 'azoth'." [Urszula Szul, page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18). 4. Paracelsian Cosmos: In Paracelsian alchemy, the cosmos was understood as a monistic entity, where the human being and the world were seen as a single organism. The astral virtues present in the celestial spheres influenced all material phenomena: > "The Paracelsian universe was a monistic construct in which the world and the human-being formed a single identity." [Urszula Szul, page 17](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17). These ideas were revolutionary and highly influential in the development of early modern alchemical and medical theories. For further reading on Paracelsian concepts, you can refer to [page 36](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36) and [page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18).
You
Christianized form of neoplatonism and hermeticism
