{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nearlier hermetic corpus by the second century AD. According to Copenhaver, these alchemical texts, as well as other magical treatises, are integrally related to the seventeen, purely theological, hermetic writings. He\nargues that eighteenth century scholars, prejudiced against occultism,\nhad made a false distinction between the various components of the corpus which would have been meaningless to the contemporary followers of\nthe original school of thought. Consequently, hermeticism is not only a\ntheosophical system, but also a practical theurgy.\nThe development of hermeticism was historically distinct from that of\nneoplatonism and it had been ruthlessly criticised by Plotinus for its superstitious practices and inconsistent theological structures. Nevertheless,\nRenaissance philosophers, such as Ficino, disregarded Plotinus' animosity\ntowards the hermeticists and they accomodated both systems within their]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9,10\ntowards the hermeticists and they accomodated both systems within their\nvision of a \"prisca theologia\" anticipating the Christian religion.5 Plotinus' sophisticated theogony of light was received by medieval Western\nphilosophers in the moderated Christian versions of Pseudo-Dionysos\nand St.Augustine. In the fifteenth century, as a result ofthe recovery and\n3 Allen G. Debus, \"The Sun in the Universe ofRobert Fludd\", Le Soleil a la renaissance\n(Brussels, 1965).\n4 Nicholas Clulee, John Dee's Natural Philosophy (London; New York: Routledge, 1988).\n5 For discussion of the hermetic corpus see Brian P. Copenhaver, Hermetica (Cambridge University Press, 1992), pp. xxxii-l.\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\ntranslation of the neoplatonic and hermetic Greek texts, the Florentine\nhumanist Marsilio Ficino began to promote the use of astral rituals in a\nmedical and psychological context. His younger contemporary Pico della\nMirandola, like Ficino, integrated these practices with Christianity, butin]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=12\nPages: 12\ndisconnect its origins from those of Yates' proto-Rosicrucian circles.22\nFurthermore, Yates' alignment of the Protestant cause with hermeticism was countered by scholars eager to distance Lutheranism from such\nobjectionable associates. In particular, Montgomery, adopting a conservative Lutheran perspective, argued for the negative effects ofhermeticism\non the reformed Church in Germany. He refuted Yates' interpretation of\nthe Rosicrucians as being the esoteric outpost ofthe Protestant reformed\nchurch, especially removing the theologian Johann Valentin Andreae\n(1586-1654) from that context. Montgomery, in fact, developed a contrary argument to Yates, considering that neoplatonic and hermetic literature had inspired the educated German elite to devise a paganistic system, decentering Christ from his redemptive role in human salvation.23\nIn this line ofthinking he concurred with Frick (though from a different]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=8\nPages: 8\nthe repentant sinner with God. Subsequently, this vision of the divine\nlight of the Holy Spirit, as the instrument of union with God, was expressed less doctrinally in the moderated pietism ofthe seventeenth century Cambridge Platonists. Such historical currents evolving a personalised interpretation of scripture, in which God and human were united\nthrough the indwelling light ofthe Spirit, rather than through the rites of\nthe Church, were strengthened in hermetic and neoplatonic circles bythe\nChristian cabbalah. This theosophical system envisaged God creating the\nworld out ofhis own divine luminosity; hence, for cabbalists, the universe\nwas not only pervaded by the divine light of God, it was united monistically to him.\nAlthough there has been much dispute among historians concerning\nthe specific role of hermetic theosophy in the development of Lutheran\npietism, scholars, such as Peuckert and Stoeffler, have acknowledged that]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21\nPages: 21\ncircle of time. By the late hellenistic period, alchemy was conceived as\nbeing a circular process which began with perfection (the origins ofmatter in God) and ended in perfection (the spiritualised matter produced by\nthe alchemist). Hence, the geometric form of the circle was the fundamental signifier of alchemy.\nAnother basic tenet of hellenistic hermeticism and alchemy in the first\nChristian centuries was that of the unity and dynamic interaction between God and human, spirit and matter, heaven and earth, body and\nsoul. It was believed that God enacted his will on the earth through the\nagency of the stellar spheres and planets. In alchemy the inter-relationship ofspirit and matter was represented by the marriage ofthe Sun and\nthe Moon (spirit with matter), whose offspring was the philosopher's\nstone ofthe medieval alchemists. Its essential form was the perfect circle,\ninsusceptible to the corrupting effects of natural transmutation.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nand theurgical ritual. Indeed, late Renaissance alchemists developed a\nconceptual structure which could be called an \"alchemy oflight\", a syncretic philosophy integrating the discrete intellectual and mystical currents of Pythagorean geometry, neoplatonism, medieval optics, Paracelsian alchemy and cabbalism.\nThe concept of the divinity of light had been transmitted from the\nmost ancient times to the late hellenistic philosopher Plotinus, as well as\nto various gnostic and hermetic groups, such as those connected with the\ntheosophical writings known to the Renaissance as the Pymander of\nHermes Trismegistus. In origins the term \"hermeticism\" referred to the\nlate hellenistic teachings ofTrismegistus and his followers, such as Asclepius. This theosophical system had emerged by the second century BC in\nEgypt, but at first it did not include alchemy which developed only during the first Christian centuries, alchemical literature being added to the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=29\nPages: 29,30\n13 M. D. Lambert, Medieval heresy (London: E. Arnold, 1977); Geo Widengren,Maniand\nManicheism (London: Weidenfeld and Nicholson, 1965).\n53.14 F. C. Copleston, A History ofMedieval Philosophy (London; Methuen, 1980), pp. 35, 52-\n32\nCHAPTER THREE\nTHE INFLUENCE OF MEDIEVAL OPTICS ON RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\ncosmogony of light and darkness. Christ was occasionally given the Mithraic title of \"Sol Invictus\".15 Similarly, contemporary late Alexandrian\nneoplatonists and hermeticists identified the sun withthe divine firstprinciple. Thus, Asclepius had regarded the sun as the transmitter of God's\nbeneficence to the earth, nullifying the effects of the negative demonic\npowers.16 Subsequently, the neoplatonist Pseudo-Dionysos the Aeropagite propagated a Christian image of the sun as representing the quality of\nGod's Divine Intelligence.17\nIn the seventh century, Isidore of Seville integrated Christian and\nneoplatonic conceptions ofthe sun with those ofnaturalphilosophyin his]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\nhigher \"gnosis\" ofthe spirit, Paracelsus was drawing on cabbalistic thinking.18\nParacelsus rejected the ancient natural philosophers, replacing Aristotle with christianised neo-platonic and hermetic authorities, discarding\nalso the medical canon of Avicenna and Galen. 19 Instead , he believed\nthat physical ailments were the result of external forces rather than ofan\nimbalance offluids, as in the medieval theory ofthe four humours. Each\norgan of the body, Paracelsus explained, contained a dynamism called\nthe \"archeon\" which functioned as an internal alchemist. Moreover, he\nbelieved that each illness originated in a particular star whose virtue was\nembodied in the corresponding earthly \"arcanum\", a medicine which\ncould heal the ailment.20\nParacelsus was not the first to adapt alchemy to medicine, since John\nof Rupescissa and Arnold of Villanova in the fourteenth-century had\ndeveloped the alchemical concept of the fifth essence into a medical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=22\nPages: 22\nexplain the order of creation, obtaining these from a musical model, that\nof the monochord, which he believed to be generated by the motions of\nthe stellar spheres and planets.15\nArabian scholars translated many of the late hellenistic neoplatonic,\nneopythagorean and hermetic treatises and, through Latin\nfrom the Arabic in the late twelfth century, some ideas were translations\ntransmitted\nto the West.16 In the early medieval period, the Christian philosopher\nBoethius produced an influential doctrine based on Pythagorean geometryand arithmetic which he expounded in his De Institutione Musica andDe\nInstitutione Arithmetica.17 These works laid the foundation of medieval\nscholarship and his ideas supplied the parameters for the world-view of\nthe medieval period. Due to Boethius, Pythagorean mathematics, geometry and music were introduced into the medieval universities, becoming\nthe \"lingua franca\" of European science and art. This mystical ideology]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=29\nPages: 29\nfull logic ofthe ontological anxieties concerning the nature ofthe Divine.\nIn a bold, but not altogether heretical, gesture he produced a unique\nalchemical image in the Medicina Catholica (Frankfurt: William Fitzer,\n1629-31) which promoted the idea that light and darkness were two\ndispositions of the same God (fig. 50).\nIn response to Gnostic qualms concerning the nature ofAbsolute Being, Christianity produced a symbol of Christ as the one pure Light, an\nimage which was developed into a Christian tenet by St. Augustine, a\nformer Manichean. Influenced by neoplatonism, Augustine also created\nan aesthetic in which divine light manifested in the natural world as\nabsolute beauty.14 Another image incorporated into early Christian iconography was adapted from the late Roman cult of Mithras, a dualistic\n30\n5 David C. Lindberg, Theories of Visionfrom Al-Kindi to Kepler, (Chicago; London: University ofChicago Press, 1976), pp. 58-67; Ronchi, pp. 15-26.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=12\nPages: 12\nhermetic circles and also as an expression of a pietistic Lutheranism\nwhich was critical of the doctrinaire, institutionalised creed of the time.\nHis work, thus, belongs to the diverse ideological currents of the late\nsixteenth and early seventeenth centuries which, subsequently, manifested as the \"Rosicrucian\" movement. The supporters of the \"Rosicrucian\nManifestos\" (1614; 1615) were a heterogeneous mix of reformist Lutherans, hermeticists, neoplatonists and practitioners of Agrippan and Paracelsian theurgy. Although many devoted Protestants , such as Maier and\nFludd, polemicised on behalf of the Rosicrucians, there were also pagan\nand non-Christian influences within the movement related to the chiliasm ofSimon Studion, Julius 19Sperber, Christoph Besold and Tobias Hess\nin the late sixteenth century.\"\nAccording to Yates, it was Dee's travels in central Europe in the 1580s\nwhich had stimulated the reformist currents that later emerged as the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=87\nPages: 87\norderfrom that ofWeigel, Arndt or Khunrath. Studion and Hess seem to\nhave favoured the idea of reform almost as an end in itself, fascinated\nwith cabbalistic techniques of prognostication and the image of the allpowerful magus, whereas the three pietists were using cabbalism and\nParacelsian alchemy for the sake of a reformed Protestant Christianity.\nConsequently, although Khunrath's work should be placed within the\nhistory of German pietism, in contrast, that of Studion and Hess belongs\nto the broader intellectual currents diverting central European culture\naway from the Christian tradition.\nItis clearthat Khunrath was deeply troubled and aggravated by such\ntendencies and, at the time that Studion and Hess were evolving their\nsystem, he may have turned to Weigel's theosophy as a basis for recentering Christ at the heart of hermetic concerns. Khunrath's view of the role\nof Christ is far more specific than that of the subsequent Rosicrucian]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=88\nPages: 88\nuse of Christian doctrine is slight.\nIn the period 1595 to circa 1620, Khunrath placed an unusual emphasis on the structural role of Christ in his theosophy, the nearestresemblance to his alchemical system being found in the mystical writings of\nJacob Boehme (1575-1624) . It is probable, in fact, that, from the date of\nthe 1595 Amphiteatrum, Khunrath was removing himself from the euphoric intellectual experimentation of chiliastic circles, such as those at Tubingen, which were relatively politically secure. Increasingly, he grew\nmore concerned with the encouragment of reformist pietism in the devastated religious community of the eastern Lutheran states. Thus, Khunrath in the late 1590s had more pressing issues at stake than those ofthe\nacademic hermeticism of Tubingen, his unsatisfactory relations with\nmembers ofthat coterie being evidenced by an indirect reference to his]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=42\nPages: 42\nyears and its effect is found in the work of Meister Eckhart and Ramon\nLull. The cabbalistic texts are based on the early chapters of the biblical\nbooks of Genesis and Ezekiel, but in the course of the middle ages further\nideas were adopted from Christian neo-platonism. These included the\ntrinitarian dialectic of divine manifestation, known as the \"Tree ofLife\".\nThe oldest cabbalistic text appears to be the Book of Formation or Book of\nCreation (Sepher Jezirah) (circa 600 AD) which is a cosmological account.\nModelled on the Pythagorean system, it states that the fundamental principles of all things are numbers, letters and sounds. Furthermore, the\nHebrew alphabet is said to have been composed by God himself.6\nCabbalists described the Hebrew alphabet as being composed out of\nthe divine flame, or light, of God. The central cypher which generated\nthe rest of the letters was \"Jod\", meaning \"flame\" and, moreover, the\nvery form of this sign was said to resemble that of a flame. Hence, the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=87\nPages: 87\nthe pietistic atmospheric ofKhunrath's treatises could not be more different from the obsessive manipulations of Studion's cabbalistic cryptography. In fact, Studion's graphic structures, as well as those ofTobias Hess,\nare related to the theurgic emblems of Peter of Abano and other medieval necromancers publicised by Agrippa. These may, in fact, have been\nthe \"pentacles\" denounced by Khunrath in the 1595 Amphiteatrum for\ntheir anti-Christian connotations, while pronouncing his own \"annulus\"\nof Christ as the \"azoth\" to be the true cabblistic insignia. Such differences in the interpretation of cabbalism and Paracelsian theosophy by different German philosophers raise the question, discussed by Stoeffler, concerning the exact role of hermeticism in the history of religious\nreformism.21 Certainly, the ideological position ofStudion and hiscollaborator, Tobias Hess, in their jointly-authored Prophetica is ofa different\norderfrom that ofWeigel, Arndt or Khunrath. Studion and Hess seem to]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11,12\nXVII\n16 Roland Barthes, Mythologies (Paris: Seuil, 1957), pp. 109-59.\n17 Kubovy, pp. 166-72. See also James S. Ackerman, \"Alberti's Light\" in Irving Lavin\nandJohn Plummer, Studies in Late Medieval and Renaissance Painting in Honour ofMillard Meiss\n(New York, 1978), pp. 1-27.\n18 Peirce, 2, pp. 170-72.\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\napply cabbalism to alchemy, since Joannes Pantheus of Venice had devised a comparable system in his Voarchadumia (1530) and Dee had also\nproduced a cabbalistic alchemy in the Monas Hieroglyphica (1564). Khunrath, however, placed his cabbalism within a Christological framework,\nso much so, that his main concern from 1595 was not alchemical theory,\nbut pietistic Christian theology, anticipating, perhaps, the alchemical\nmysticism of Jacob Boehme.\nKhunrath may have developed his Christological alchemy in the mid1590s, both as a response to anti-Christian tendencies within German\nhermetic circles and also as an expression of a pietistic Lutheranism]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=87\nPages: 87\nthe tomb of their founder.16 Despite these apparent Lutheran loyalties,\nMontgomery, nevertheless, contended against Yates that the Manifestos\nwere fundamentally anti-Christian, since they had discarded the redemptive role ofChrist, favouring both private contemplation on the neoplatonic model, as well as privileged initiation into a path of spiritual knowledge unrelated to Christian doctrine. Yates, in fact, had emphasised the\ncommunity character17 ofthe Rosicrucian Brotherhood, in contrast to the\nself-inspired magus.\nBoth scholars associated the Manifestos with the circles ofSimon Studion, whose Naometria had been circulating in manuscript since the late\n1580s, or early 1590s. Influenced by the chiliasm ofJoachim of Fiore,\nStudion predicted that the third age of the Holy Spirit would be inaugurated by a major political and social change in the European order,\ncommencing in 1604. He even delayed the completion of his treatise]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=30\nPages: 30\nmeaning by this period, therefore, Ficino's magical operations involving\nthe solar rays had a particularly numinous potency. His method, however, was a misapplied semiotic system, that is, he reified immaterial metaphors by means of false analogies between the abstract sign and its, supposedly physical, referent. In other words, the conceptual contents ofa\n15 Franz Cumont, The Mysteries of Mithra (New York, 1956), passim.\n16 Copenhaver, Hermetica (1992), pp. 59-61.\n17 There is a full discussion of neoplatonic and hermetic solar imagery in Debus (1965).\n18 Fridericus Osannus, Lucius Annaeus Cornutus. De natura deorum (Gottingen: Johannis\nBapt. Casp. d'Ansse, 1844), pp. 194, 200, 225, 328, 372-77, 433, 516-17,\n524; H. I. Rose,\nHygini Fabulae (Brussels: A.W. Sijthoff, 1978), pp. 12, 15, 20, 22, 36, 38; Percival Vaughan\nDavies, Macrobius the Saturnalia (New York: Columbia UP, 1969), Bk I, Caps 17-23, pp.\n137-46.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=42\nPages: 42\nSzonyi, on the other hand, has considered a more immediate source\nfor Dee's astral rituals and sympathetic magic in Renaissance neoplatonism and hermeticism. Initially, he had located Dee's interests in the context ofAgrippan and Paracelsian astrology, but more recently he has put\na case for a direct line ofinfluence from Ficino's astral magic. He has also\ncontextualised Dee's magical cryptograms within the Renaissance quest\nfor the primal language.2 In the late Renaissance, an interest in magical\ncyphers, engraved gems, \"angelic\" languages, astrological sigils and ritual\nincantation formed a current of major intellectual significance. Agrippa's\nmagical inscriptions were modelled on the cryptographs of the German\nhumanist Johannes Trithemius (1462-1516). His popular Steganographia\n(1518) was circulated widely in manuscript and it reached John Dee who\nhad copies ofit, among other works by Trithemius.3 Agrippa also revived]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=69\nPages: 69\nParacelsian model, he considers the central fires within the earth.16\nCentrum Terrae physice, ubi fit, Vulcan. Is ex quibus corpore terreno, obstericaute Neptuni limpidissima ... candidissimum Physico Chemice manifestando, ad sensum omnes tibi demonstrabit: Videbis illud: fig. 3 (Par. 111).\nKhunrath next instructs the reader that the philosopher's stone is Christ\nand that God is reconciled with humanity through Christ's sacrifice on\nthe cross. The cross of Christ is the \"Salt\" which conquers demonic\nrealms. He mentions vitriol, thus, in Weigelian terms, integrating Paracelsian alchemy into his Christology and referring the reader to the first\nfigure of the treatise for an explanation of these analogies.\nCrux Sancta Christi ipse crucifixus, fig. Amph. huius prima Cruciformitvincens diaboli regnum ...\n= SAL\nSapientia antiquissimum vitriolum naturae catholicon (Par. 237)]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light"*, the Christianized form of Neoplatonism and Hermeticism is discussed as part of a broader attempt by Renaissance thinkers to integrate classical philosophies with Christian theology. This synthesis created a system where the divine and the natural world were seen as intimately connected, and knowledge of the divine could be accessed through both philosophical reasoning and mystical practices. 1. Hermeticism and Neoplatonism: Hermeticism was initially distinct from Neoplatonism, but during the Renaissance, figures like Marsilio Ficino combined both systems into a unified vision of "prisca theologia"an ancient theology that anticipated Christianity. Neoplatonism, with its theogony of light, was adapted by Christian philosophers such as Pseudo-Dionysius and Augustine: > Renaissance philosophers, such as Ficino, disregarded Plotinus' animosity towards the hermeticists and they accommodated both systems within their vision of a prisca theologia anticipating the Christian religion. [Urszula Szul, page 9](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9). 2. Theosophy and the Christian Cabalistic System: This Christianized form of Neoplatonism and Hermeticism emphasized the divine light as the unifying force between God and creation. The Christian cabbalah introduced by figures like Johannes Reuchlin combined mystical interpretations of scripture with Hermetic ideas of a cosmos suffused with divine wisdom: > This theosophical system envisaged God creating the world out of his own divine luminosity; hence, for cabbalists, the universe was not only pervaded by the divine light of God, it was united monistically to Him. [Urszula Szul, page 8](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=8). 3. Integration of Hermetic and Neoplatonic Practices: Figures like Ficino and Pico della Mirandola played crucial roles in the Renaissance revival of these ideas. They incorporated astral rituals and theurgical practices into a Christian framework, merging Hermetic magical techniques with Neoplatonic ideals of divine emanation and light: > In the fifteenth century... Marsilio Ficino began to promote the use of astral rituals in a medical and psychological context. [Urszula Szul, page 10](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10). This syncretic approach created a powerful intellectual and mystical framework that influenced many Renaissance alchemists and thinkers. You can explore these ideas further starting on [page 9](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9).
You
paracelsian cosmos and astral virtues
Tool
{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=34\nPages: 34\nthat alchemy was of interest to Dee in the 1550s, there are, nevertheless,\nsufficient hints within the text of the Propaedeumata Aphoristica to indicate\nthat Dee envisaged an alchemical purpose for his astral catoptrics.\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY:\nTHE \"ASTRAL VIRTUE\" AND\nTHE \"AERIAL SALTPETRE\"\nThe controversy generated by the medical theories of Paracelsus (14931541) was caused not only by his adoption of alchemical methods for\npreparing medicines and his innovatory use of inorganic substances, but\nalso by his disturbing synthesis of medicine, magic, theology and cosmology. Paracelsus' ambitiously expansive (and often self-contradictory) vision forced his educated contemporaries to re-assess both their professional activities as physicians, as well as their philosophical systems and\neven their religious beliefs.\nParacelsus' own Christian commitment cannot be doubted, for this\nwas one of his declared reasons for his attack on pre-Christian medical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17\nPages: 17\nearthly phenomena, therefore , through the \"astra\" it was possible for\nhumans to comprehend all phenomena, both natural and supernatural.\nParacelsus conceived of human intelligence as merging with its object of\nstudy, so that it gained knowledge, not by rational logic, but through an\nempathetic union with the world, that is, through \"gnosis\".\nAccording to Pagel, the Paracelsian universe was a monistic construct\nin which the world and the human-being formed a single identity. Paracelsus had drawn some of his ideas from the neoplatonic and cabbalistic\nmyth of\"Anthropos\", the primeval cosmic being who was both the exemplar and the constituent material ofthe physical universe. This cabbalistic idea had originated in the neoplatonic concept of the demi-urge, or\n\"Anthropos\", out of whose macrocosmic body the lesser material world\nwas made, remaining dependent on the stellar \"arcana\" (astral virtues) in\nthe celestial sphere.15]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nstars, but a coherent theory ofthe astral virtues began to develop only in\nthe late fourteenth century, appearing in its full expression in the work of\nParacelsus ( 1493-1541). In addition, John Dee added his own distinctive\ncontribution to the sixteenth century theory ofthe generative stellar rays.\nThese alchemists provided the basic foundation for Khunrath's alchemi-\ncal deployment of light-rays and astral virtues, but Khunrath went beyond his original sources in uniting Paracelsian cabbalism with Weigel's\npietistic Christology, producing, thereby, an alchemical polemic expressing the concept of Christ as the philosopher's stone who transmuted the\nsoul through the light of Eternal Wisdom. Thus, by the early seventeenth\ncentury, the alchemical use of celestial rays and natural sun-light involved more than chemistry, since this practice was, in effect, a religious\nand theurgical ritual. Indeed, late Renaissance alchemists developed a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=25\nPages: 25,26\nJean de Thoumes, 1549; Milan: Bibliotheca Hermetica, 1971). For an examination ofhis\ntheories see Thorndike, M&ES, 4, pp. 37-41; 5, pp. 630-32.\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\noriginating in the celestial bodies, while in the Liber Azothhe spoke ofthe\nastral virtue as a fire, or a vital saltpetre, or nitre. Through pseudoLullian texts, the followers of Paracelsus related the Paracelsian stellar\nfire to that of Rupescissa's \"coelum\", specifically Blaise de Vigenere\n(1523-1596) in his Discourse ofFire and Salt (1608). Vigenere described the\nlife-giving property in air as a vital Sulphur, or fire and Salt, stating that\nthese were the basic components of saltpetre. Peter Severinus (15421602), physician to the Danish court, related the properties of the thunder to that of saltpetre. Another Paracelsian, Gerhard Dorn, borrowed\ndirectly from Rupescissa's original text for his description of the vital\nproperties of air in his Chymisticum artificii (1569). John Dee owned copies]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=37\nPages: 37\nnot exist: it functions.28\nFor Paracelsus, the primal language of signatures was inspired by God's\nmanner of sustaining the cosmic order, inscribing the forms of all manifestation with a stellar emanation, the \"azoth\". In his Liber Azoth he had\nreferred to it as an aerial nitre, or saltpetre, transmitted by the rain to the\nearth from the spirit of the sun.29 His followers, Severinus, de Vigenere,\nSendivogius, Quercetanus and Fludd developed the full idea ofthe aerial\nsaltpetre at the end of the sixteenth and in the early years of the seventeenth centuries. Another origin for the concept of this astral virtue was\nthe use of nitrates in the manufacture of gunpowder, a major European\nindustry in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. In the industrial\nprocess, nitrate salts were exposed to the elements and the solar rays in\norder to enhance their explosive, preservative and generative properties.\nParacelsus in the Grossen Wunderarznei considered that such virtues were]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=136\nPages: 136\nOvide\n, 32\nsemiotics\nofillusmoralisee\n153-55,\n174;\n84, 152,\ntrations, 158, 164-65, 181; Septimana\nPhilosophica, 101, 154, 178; Symbola Aureae Pacioli, Luca, 727\nMensae, 133-34, 153; Themis Aurea, 154; Pagel, Walter,\nTripus Aureus, 21, 155, 163; Viatorium, 21 Panofsky, Erwin, 3,\nManicheans, 31\nPantheus, Joannes, xviii, 4, 20-21, 56, 62\nParacelsians, 48\nManutius, Aldus, 64\nParacelsus, 5, 40, 41-52, 84; alchemy, 13,\nMasaccio, xv\nMattioli, Pierandrea, 68\n41, 43, 47-48, 52; Archidoxa, 47, 48, 50,\nMcLean, Adam, 153, 160\n98; astrology, 15, 42-43, 44-45; astral.\nMederus, David, 84\nbody, 7-8, 42-43, 61, 77; astral virtue,\nmedieval alchemical illustration, 17-18, see xii, xiv, 7-8, 23-24, 42-45, 46, 48; AstronoObrist\nmia magna, 43; azoth (quintessence)55,, xvii,\n23-24, 44, 46-47, 61; cabbalism, 58;\nMelancthon, xii, 150\nMerian, Matthieu, 159, 163\ncosmogony, 41-42; De pestilate, 42; docMersenne, Martin, 58, 174, 178\ntrine of signatures, xiv, 45-46; Expositio]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=64\nPages: 64\nmirror on the earth into a dark cave. Kircher's illustration describes the\nvarious lights of nature, the senses and the intellect.\nIt remains to discuss the specific influences triggering Khunrath's\nideas concerning the use of astral virtue and catoptrics in alchemy. These\nmay have been inspired by the publication of Paracelsus' completeworks\nin the Basle edition of 1589-90, as well as the appearance ofdella Porta's\nsecond Magia Naturalis (1589). Another influence was undoubtedly Dee's\ncabbalistic astrology and catoptrics, as well as the enduring effects of Pico\ndella Mirandola's and Reuchlin's Christian cabbalism. In the context of\nthe political pressures on his pietistic beliefs between circa 1595 and\n1604, these influences led Khunrath to devise a cabbalistic alchemy of\nlight, founded on Paracelsian theosophy and Renaissance optical science.\nIOO\n34 Peuckert and Zeller (eds), Valentin Weigel. Samtliche Schriften (Stuttgart, 1962-78), 2,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=60\nPages: 60\nvirtue is derived from the \"azoth\" and the Salt which are related to the\n\"Magnesia\" (Chaos: 230).\nIn the Chaos of circa 1597 the strongest influences are those of Paracelsian alchemy, the cabbalah and Lutheran pietism on the model of\nWeigel, but Khunrath makes no reference either to astrology, or to catoptrics. These are encountered in, possibly his last treatise, De Igne Magorum Philosophorumque (Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner, 1608) which interprets\nthe alchemical furnace in mystical terms as the site in which the aetherial\nlight and the astral virtues work their effects. The properties of the alchemical furnace are determined by the sacred fire of the divine light, as\nwell as by the natural virtues of the sun. For the first time, Khunrath\ngives clear instructions for the use of catoptrics in order to draw the astral\nvirtues into the alchemical work. In its medical theory, De Igne Magorum is\npre-occupied with the subject of the \"aurum potabile\". Thus, fire is a unity,\nbut it takes both an internal and an external form; the former is natural\nand the latter is artificial. Neither is effective without the other. The\nexternal natural quality is the sun which operates as the inner virtue of\nthe artifical spagyric fire in alchemy. This is a reference to Paracelus'\ntheory ofthe astral virtue of the sun within material fire (De Igne: ff4v-5r).\nThe main text by Khunrath commences by mentioning his earlier\ntreatise, the Athanor (De Igne: 2-3). He elaborates on his earlier account of\nthe Zoroastians by further consideration of their god \"ORIMASDA\"]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nmajor alchemists of the period, such as Khunrath and Maier, still await a\ndefinitive study.\nIn view of the fact that scholarly research into the alchemical discourse oflight is relatively little developed, the present study will attempt\nto redress this absence byfocusing on Renaissance ideas ofthe generative\npower ofthe light of the sun, stars and planets. Renaissance alchemists,\nsuch as Khunrath and Fludd, conceptualised the astral rays of light as\nbeing the agents ofthe \"anima Mundi\", the cosmic soul or \"Anthropos\",\nout of whose primeval substance, the quintessence or \"azoth\", the universe was generated. Cabbalistic alchemists, moreover, identified the cosmic Anthropos with Christ, whose sacred presence within the alchemical\nprocess transformed it into a sacramental act, paralleling that of the\nLutheran Eucharist.\nAlchemists, since hellenistic times, had relied on the effects of the\nstars, but a coherent theory ofthe astral virtues began to develop only in]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10\nMirandola, like Ficino, integrated these practices with Christianity, butin\naddition he introduced the cabbalah into Renaissance hermeticism.6\nThe German natural philosopher and magus Cornelius Agrippa\n(1486-1533) popularised astral magic through his treatise, De Occulta\nPhilosophia (1533), justifying such practices by claiming the existence of a\nnatural sympathy between the human-being and the universe, an idea\nalready well-known to the middle ages. On the model of Agrippa, this\nvenerable notion of the harmony between celestial and human realms\nwas systematised for medical use by Paracelsus who created an analogical\nstructure known as the \"doctrine of signatures\". He taught that in all\nmaterial entities there existed hidden virtues whose qualities corresponded to those ofthe planetary bodies in the heavens. These occult virtues he\ncalled \"astra\" to designate the \"signatures\" (the impressions) of the stars\non matter. Paracelsus argued that, due to the intimate unity between]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=27\nPages: 27\n\"Revificatio\" which completes the making of the philosopher's stone and\nis signified by a picture of the soul returning to the bodyfrom heaven.56\nA common factor in all these alchemical theories, those of pseudoLull, Ripley, Norton and the Rosarium, is that the celestial virtue (occasionally related to the sun's rays) is often conceptualised by geometrical\nparadigms. It may be concluded that the geometry of these alchemical\ntreatises signifies the use of astrology which is wholly dependent on mathematics and geometry. Out of this general historical context, John Dee\nwas to devise a more specific deployment ofthe astral virtues in alchemy\nby means of scholastic optical theory and astronomy and, subsequently,\nby the cabbalah.\n48 Claren and Huber, p. 81. For more information see Pagel (1982), pp. 59-61, including the well-known portrait of Paracelsus in which the word \"azoth\" is written on the\nknob\nof his walking-stick. See also Debus (1964): 43-61.\n49 Claren\nand Huber, p. 86.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=34\nPages: 34\nwas one of his declared reasons for his attack on pre-Christian medical\ntheorists such as Galen. Nonetheless, Paracelsus developed a monistic\ntheosophical structure for his chemical universe in his account of the\nunion between the astral human faculties and the macrocosm. Similarly,\nin his cosmogenical theories, the primal four elements emerged directly\nfrom the soul of the universe. The chief adversary of Paracelsus in the\nsecond half of the sixteenth century was the Protestant theologian Thomas Erastus (1523-1583) who castigated Paracelsus for his superstitious\nmedical practices, specifically his use of astrology.2 Alchemists such as\nKhunrath and Fludd who joined the Paracelsian school had to address\nsignificant theological issues to avoid constructing a philosophical system\nequating God with nature.\nIn the Philosophia ad Athenienses, Paracelsus described a cosmos whose\nform was that of an alchemical still,4 fabricating a monistic model of the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nvirtues) present within all natural bodies were the foundation of practical\nmedicine, since each person had an astral body which overlay and penetrated his physical body, so that the external and imminent \"astra\" were\neffectively the same entity. Thus, Parcelsus stated, a remedy was dependant on the astrological effects of the heavens.24 In the Volumen medicinae\nparamirum (circa 1520), he urged the physician to acquire a sound knowledge ofastronomy in order to understand the effects ofthe astral emanations by means of which God had impressed earthly things with \"signatures\",25\nFor a clearer understanding of Paracelsus' theory of\"signatures\", it is\nhelpful to consider Foucault's analysis of the Renaissance concept ofthe\nworld as being constructed on the basis of similitude and difference. The\nRenaissance taxonomy of phenomena, whether spiritual, physical, aesthetic or linguistic, was based on the idea that representation (similitude)]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=134\nPages: 134\nArchimedes, 35\nAretino, Pietro, 76\nAristotle, 13, 17, 18-19, 23, 26, 44, 155, 160\nArnald of Villanova, 13, 44, 48, 88, 93\nArnold, Gottfried, 83-86, 142\nArndt, Johannes, xi, xxi, 8, 80-81, 83, 86,\n105, 121-21, 127-27, 145, 147, 150-52\nAsclepius, 32\nastral virtues, xiii, xiv, see Paracelsus\nastrology,\n160 xii, 15-16, 22, 27, 33-34, 37-40,\nAugustine, xiii, 31, 178\nAugustus (Elector ofSaxony), 141-42\naurum potabile, see universal panacea\nAvicenna, 29, 30, 44\nazoth, see Paracelsus, Khunrath,\nMichelspacher\nBacon, Roger, 22, 29, 35, 36, 39, 56, 84\nBaker, George, 48\nBaltens, Raphael, 99\nBarbarus, Hermolaus, 99\nBarthes, Roland, xvii, 1, 10, 140\nBarna, Peter, 5, 48\nBerchorius , Petrus, 32\nBesold, Christoph, xviii, 82\nBoehme,Jacob, xviii, 20, 34, 69, 83, 108 n.\n14, 117, 142, 148; Gichtel's illustrations,\n179-82\nBoethius, 17, 22, 157\nBook of Concord, 141-42, 149\nBosch, Hieronymous, 135, 140\nBostocke, Richard, 48\nBredling, Friedrich, 84, 85\nBrentius, Johan, 150\nBrocard,Jakob, 150]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=73\nPages: 73\nUNIVERSUM mundanum tripliciter distribuit ELOHIM (Khunrath, 1609:\n127)\nKhunrath describes a Paracelsian cosmos in which the macrocosmic\n\"caelum\" generates the physical species,17 while in its lower material\nform, the \"caelum\" is the chemical spirits of wine, purified by fire and\nreleased from impure matter.18 In \"Gradus Quintus\" and \"Gradus Sixtus\", Khunrath explains further the astrological basis of his Paracelsian\nalchemy, referring to Paracelsus' interpretation of the creation of the\nstars in Genesis, 1. He explains that all natural objects manifest various\nsigns, constituting an alphabet in the book of the world,19 produced by\nthe innate\"astra\", mirroring those in the heavens (Khunrath, 1609 : 142).\nThe alchemist 20must, therefore, know astronomy and watch the progress\nof the seasons. Khunrath refers specifically to Paracelsus' \"doctrine of\nsignatures\", calling him the \"Germanicus Asclepiades\" and quoting him\non reading the book of nature. In this context, Khunrath also names]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=135\nPages: 135\nJung, Friedrich, 104, 136\nKelley, Edward, 5, 21, 40, 50, 53\nKepler, Johannes, 58, 158-59\nKhunrath, Heinrich, xi, xv, 79-137; MS\nAlnwick 571, 106-10, 131, 149, 161; Amphiteatrum Sapientiae Aeternae, xv, xvii, 5, 9,\n20, 25, 31, 68, 77-79, 81, 84-86, 89-91,\n98, 103-37, 139-40, 142, 145, 147-49,\n151, 173, 174; andAndreae, xx, 85, 145-\n243\n46, 149-52; and Arndt, xx, 80, 85, 12122, 145, 151; astral virtues, xii-xiii, 93,\n94, 119; Athanor, 86-90, 98, 105, 142;\nazoth (quintessence), xvii, 9, 24, 87, 90,\n92-94, 96, 109, 111, 118, 120, 122-22,\n129, 132, 144, 147-48; cabbalism, xiii,\nxvii-xviii, 24, 31, 59, 87, 89-93, 109-9,\n116, 118, 120-22, 127, 144-45, 147-48;\nChaos, xvii, 82, 84-86, 88-93, 105, 147;\nChristology, xiii, xviii, 24, 80, 88, 90, 9293, 108-110, 113, 117-17, 120, 122-24,\n127-29, 132, 135, 144-45, 147-49; Dee's\ninfluence, xv, xvii, xviii, 6, 39-40, 50, 7779, 91, 97, 101, 121, 125-25, 135, 158,\n183; De Igne, xvii, 31, 48, 68, 81, 87, 90,\n93-100, 121, 149, 162, 176; and Hess,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=47\nPages: 47\nsympathetic magic which would eliminate, at a stroke, the confusions in\ntraditional alchemical discourse.\nAnother natural philosopher who located Dee's optics within a Paracelsian context was the alchemist and cosmologist Nicholas Hill who had\noriginally been a member of the retinue of Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland where he would have encountered the direct legacy ofDee's\ninfluence, as well as the optical interests ofthat circle. In his Philosophia\nEpicurea (Paris, 1601), Hill discussed the astral influences transmitted by\nlight -rays, relating this effect to Paracelsian alchemy. He stated that the\nextraction of the elixir of life and the transmutation of metals were a\ndivine process equivalent to the emanation of the second person ofthe\nHoly Trinity from the Father. He believed that light was the impression\nof God in nature and that it gave both form and life to matter.42]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nnature\" is one of the foundations of Khunrath's alchemy in which he\ndescribes an unbroken continuum of illuminated wisdom, incorporating\nboththe practical experience ofthe natural world, as well as the spiritual\nvision of the mystic.17\nIn Paracelsian theosophy, empathetic imagination was not a subjective and, therefore, neglible factor in human affairs, but a powerful astral\nforce which provided the basis for theurgy and prognostication, as well as\nfor prophecy and mystical inspiration. Consequently, the Paracelsian\ntheosophical system eliminated, or diminished, the role of the institutionalised Christian church as the interpreter of God's will by means ofthe\ncanonical scriptures. Replacing external authority, the individual intuition became a more immediate and truer guide to divine knowledge.\nEven more radically, Paracelsus stated that through the imaginative faculties ofthe astral body a human could attain beatific union with God.18]"]}
ChatGPT
The Paracelsian cosmos and astral virtues are integral to Paracelsus' alchemical and cosmological theories, wherein the universe and the human being form a monistic entitya single system governed by astral forces. Key points include: 1. Monistic Cosmos: Paracelsus viewed the cosmos as a monistic construct, meaning that the human being and the world are part of a unified whole. This idea was influenced by Neoplatonic and Cabbalistic concepts, especially the myth of "Anthropos," the cosmic being who embodies both the spiritual and material worlds: > "Paracelsus had drawn some of his ideas from the Neoplatonic and Cabbalistic myth of 'Anthropos,' the primeval cosmic being who was both the exemplar and the constituent material of the physical universe." [Urszula Szul, page 17](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17). 2. Astral Virtues: In the Paracelsian system, astral virtues are the hidden powers within natural bodies, believed to originate from the stars and celestial bodies. These virtues are considered the signatures left by the stars, imbuing all material things with qualities that mirror their celestial origins: > "Paracelsus argued that, due to the intimate unity between the human being and the stars, it was possible to comprehend all natural and supernatural phenomena through the 'astra' (astral virtues)." [Urszula Szul, page 17](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17). 3. The Role of the Astral Body: Paracelsus introduced the idea that humans possess an astral body which interacts with these celestial influences. This astral body is capable of empathetic union with the world, allowing a person to gain knowledge through direct, spiritual experience rather than through rational means. This knowledge is understood as gnosis: > "Paracelsus conceived of human intelligence as merging with its object of study, so that it gained knowledge, not by rational logic, but through an empathetic union with the world, that is, through 'gnosis.'" [Urszula Szul, page 17](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17). 4. Astral Emanations in Medicine and Alchemy: The astral virtues were also fundamental in Paracelsus' medical and alchemical practices. He believed that each physical illness was linked to a specific astral influence and could be treated using remedies derived from the corresponding earthly "arcana"the material substances that carry the star's power: > "In his Volumen Medicinae Paramirum, Paracelsus urged the physician to acquire a sound knowledge of astronomy in order to understand the effects of the astral emanations by means of which God had impressed earthly things with 'signatures.'" [Urszula Szul, page 36](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36). This interconnected cosmos of Paracelsus emphasized the astral forces as the underlying principle guiding both natural phenomena and human health. You can explore further details on [pages 17](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17) and [36](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36).
You
astral emanations and theurgic rituals
Tool
{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nstars, but a coherent theory ofthe astral virtues began to develop only in\nthe late fourteenth century, appearing in its full expression in the work of\nParacelsus ( 1493-1541). In addition, John Dee added his own distinctive\ncontribution to the sixteenth century theory ofthe generative stellar rays.\nThese alchemists provided the basic foundation for Khunrath's alchemi-\ncal deployment of light-rays and astral virtues, but Khunrath went beyond his original sources in uniting Paracelsian cabbalism with Weigel's\npietistic Christology, producing, thereby, an alchemical polemic expressing the concept of Christ as the philosopher's stone who transmuted the\nsoul through the light of Eternal Wisdom. Thus, by the early seventeenth\ncentury, the alchemical use of celestial rays and natural sun-light involved more than chemistry, since this practice was, in effect, a religious\nand theurgical ritual. Indeed, late Renaissance alchemists developed a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=42\nPages: 42\nSzonyi, on the other hand, has considered a more immediate source\nfor Dee's astral rituals and sympathetic magic in Renaissance neoplatonism and hermeticism. Initially, he had located Dee's interests in the context ofAgrippan and Paracelsian astrology, but more recently he has put\na case for a direct line ofinfluence from Ficino's astral magic. He has also\ncontextualised Dee's magical cryptograms within the Renaissance quest\nfor the primal language.2 In the late Renaissance, an interest in magical\ncyphers, engraved gems, \"angelic\" languages, astrological sigils and ritual\nincantation formed a current of major intellectual significance. Agrippa's\nmagical inscriptions were modelled on the cryptographs of the German\nhumanist Johannes Trithemius (1462-1516). His popular Steganographia\n(1518) was circulated widely in manuscript and it reached John Dee who\nhad copies ofit, among other works by Trithemius.3 Agrippa also revived]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9,10\ntowards the hermeticists and they accomodated both systems within their\nvision of a \"prisca theologia\" anticipating the Christian religion.5 Plotinus' sophisticated theogony of light was received by medieval Western\nphilosophers in the moderated Christian versions of Pseudo-Dionysos\nand St.Augustine. In the fifteenth century, as a result ofthe recovery and\n3 Allen G. Debus, \"The Sun in the Universe ofRobert Fludd\", Le Soleil a la renaissance\n(Brussels, 1965).\n4 Nicholas Clulee, John Dee's Natural Philosophy (London; New York: Routledge, 1988).\n5 For discussion of the hermetic corpus see Brian P. Copenhaver, Hermetica (Cambridge University Press, 1992), pp. xxxii-l.\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\ntranslation of the neoplatonic and hermetic Greek texts, the Florentine\nhumanist Marsilio Ficino began to promote the use of astral rituals in a\nmedical and psychological context. His younger contemporary Pico della\nMirandola, like Ficino, integrated these practices with Christianity, butin]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=106\nPages: 106\ndisregard the visual imagery as if this were mere decoration. Hence,\nbetween the extremes of the twentieth century theosophists who will not\nread the texts and the historians of science who will not read the visual\nimagery, the \"alchemy of light\" has diminished in significance, since only\nthe study of both the visual and the literary documentation, as well as\nknowledge of its political context, can reveal the considerable importance\nof this alchemical concept in the late Renaissance.\nThe present work has taken an extended historical view of the evolution of Paracelsian astral and solar theurgy and its deployment by German theosophists in the late sixteenth century, as well as by some of their\nRosicrucian followers. Such a lengthy over-view has necessitated too brief\na mention of much important contextual history, nor has it been possible\nto provide an extensive analysis of specific theories. Further study is required to validate many of the suggestions concerning cross-influences]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nand theurgical ritual. Indeed, late Renaissance alchemists developed a\nconceptual structure which could be called an \"alchemy oflight\", a syncretic philosophy integrating the discrete intellectual and mystical currents of Pythagorean geometry, neoplatonism, medieval optics, Paracelsian alchemy and cabbalism.\nThe concept of the divinity of light had been transmitted from the\nmost ancient times to the late hellenistic philosopher Plotinus, as well as\nto various gnostic and hermetic groups, such as those connected with the\ntheosophical writings known to the Renaissance as the Pymander of\nHermes Trismegistus. In origins the term \"hermeticism\" referred to the\nlate hellenistic teachings ofTrismegistus and his followers, such as Asclepius. This theosophical system had emerged by the second century BC in\nEgypt, but at first it did not include alchemy which developed only during the first Christian centuries, alchemical literature being added to the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96\nPages: 96\npurified by fire, they will arise in the perfected form of the philosopher's\nstone. Hence, in Emblem VIII, the perspectival grid signifies the divine\nlight of the heavens, the alchemical quintessence which carries the seed\nof gold from the sun. It is placed directly above the egg to denote the\npotential evolution of prime matter to a higher spiritual condition.\nTherefore, the theurgic meaning of Emblem VIII lies within a set of\nassociations inter- relating Vitruvian architecture, perspectival geometry\nand catoptrics, in short, the same themes explored by Dee. Consequently,\nMaier's emblem, like that of Khunrath, explains the theory of an alchemy of light. The diagrammatic tunnel of orthogonal lines, like de Vries'\nhallway, refers to Paracelsian astral influences and Dee's astrological catoptrics. This geometrical structure, with its base on the earth and its\napex in heaven (signified by the vanishing-point), represents the quest for]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=93\nPages: 93\nThe effect of adding Pythagorean musical ratios to Maier's alchemical\nimagery was that it transformed them into theurgical talismans . Just as\nDee's and Khunrath's use of Pythagorean geometry was a means ofcapturing the astral forces in their theurgic sigils, in the same way, Maier's\nPythagorean music attracted the celestial powers into his emblems, turning them into magical instruments. In particular, the fifth interval, representing the solar rays and the philosopher's stone, magnetically attracted\nthe sun, introducing a potent theurgic charge into the alchemical procedure. (This motif may have even been a reference to the process of\ndistillation by the heat of the sun). Reinforced by the music, Maier's\nemblems were intended to become transmutatory instruments of the\nsame type as the catoptrical mirrors described by John Dee in the Monas\nHieroglyphica and the \"annuli\" pictured by Khunrath in the Amphiteatrum.\nIn these ideas, Maier could have been influenced by a reference in the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nthis as being a poetic expression of some vague mystical experience, or a\nflowery literary convention. Debus is one of the few to have discussed this\nParacelsian metaphysics of light in his extensive studies of Fludd's alchemy.3 More recently, Clulee has examined the natural philosophy ofthe\nElizabethan theurgist, John Dee (1527-1609), noting, in particular, Dee's\nuse ofscholastic optical theory in the astronomical magic ofhis Propaedeumata Aphoristica (1558). Clulee, however, did not relate Dee's astral theurgy to alchemy, nor to theosophy, since he did not consider Dee to be a\nParacelsian, although he acknowledged the innovatory significance of\nDee's cabbalism in his later alchemical treatise, the Monas Hieroglyphica\n(1564). Few other scholars have examined critically the references to\ncelestial light in late Renaissance alchemical texts and illustrations and\nmajor alchemists of the period, such as Khunrath and Maier, still await a\ndefinitive study.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nmajor alchemists of the period, such as Khunrath and Maier, still await a\ndefinitive study.\nIn view of the fact that scholarly research into the alchemical discourse oflight is relatively little developed, the present study will attempt\nto redress this absence byfocusing on Renaissance ideas ofthe generative\npower ofthe light of the sun, stars and planets. Renaissance alchemists,\nsuch as Khunrath and Fludd, conceptualised the astral rays of light as\nbeing the agents ofthe \"anima Mundi\", the cosmic soul or \"Anthropos\",\nout of whose primeval substance, the quintessence or \"azoth\", the universe was generated. Cabbalistic alchemists, moreover, identified the cosmic Anthropos with Christ, whose sacred presence within the alchemical\nprocess transformed it into a sacramental act, paralleling that of the\nLutheran Eucharist.\nAlchemists, since hellenistic times, had relied on the effects of the\nstars, but a coherent theory ofthe astral virtues began to develop only in]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=63\nPages: 63\ncorpus with its astrology, the Rosarium, Dee's catoptrical theories and\nKhunrath's De Igne Magorum all produce the impression that celestial rays\nwere, indeed, being employed by alchemists to \"animate\" their materials.\nIn De Igne Magorum, as well as citing Paracelsus and the medieval\ncorpus , Khunrath also refers to the \"twelve books\" of Giambattista della\nPorta's Magia Naturalis, referring, thereby, to the enlarged second edition\nof 1589 (De Igne: 94). Other authorities mentioned in his account of the\nastral fires and catoptrics include Hermolaus Barbarus in Corollario super\nDioscorides ubi de Aquis in Commune (De Igne: 90), Trithemius in the Aureum\nvellus (De Igne: 94), Joannes Pontanus and Penotus's letter to Joannes Bartholomeus Burggravius (De Igne: 96, 103).\nThe most immediate influence of Khunrath's alchemical catoptrics\nwas on Stefan Michelspacher's Cabala, Spiegel der Kunst und Natur (Augsburg, 1615-1616), consisting of four engravings which represent mirrors]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52\nhuman-being had both a physical and an astral body, but that his real\nbody was astral. It was by means of the imagination located in the astral\nbodythat a person could attain to \"gnosis\" and, thereby, learn to control\nphysical manifestation through the \"astra\" present within all things.\nThus, for the Paracelsian magus it was sufficient to contemplate an object, instead of manipulating it physically. Visual imagery, such as talismanic cyphers or alchemical pictures, provided a stimulus to the imagination of the magus and acted as simulacra of the objects under his\ncontrol.\nDee's view of the theurgic function of Pythagorean-based drawing\nmay explain two particular alchemical images which Yates stated that she\nfound incomprehensible. The alchemical image which specifically puzzled her was Emblem VIII from Maier's Atalanta Fugiens (1617) (fig. 41).\nHer attribution of a conceptual influence on Maier from Dee in this\ncontext is accurate, but she did not connect Emblem VIII specifically to]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=105\nPages: 105,106\nIn the history of alchemy, perhaps the most important change in its\ncentral concepts occurs in the period from the late 1550s to the early\n1600s in which appeared Dee's and Khunrath's Paracelsian treatises on\nthe use of astral magic and light-rays in the alchemical process. The\ninteresting aspect oftheir work is that they were still advocating practical\nwork, as well as contemplative practices involving visual imagery. This is\nan important point which modern scholarship, influenced by nineteenth\ncentury theosophy and Jungian psychology, tends to under-estimate.\nMost ofthe authors who have written popularised interpretations ofRenaissance alchemical illustration have rarely bothered to read the dense\naccompanying texts, still less have they attempted to place the visual\nimages in any historical context. Whereas it is true, as previously de-\n184\nCONCLUSION\nscribed, that the pictures were becoming transmuting philosopher's]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=47\nPages: 47\nsympathetic magic which would eliminate, at a stroke, the confusions in\ntraditional alchemical discourse.\nAnother natural philosopher who located Dee's optics within a Paracelsian context was the alchemist and cosmologist Nicholas Hill who had\noriginally been a member of the retinue of Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland where he would have encountered the direct legacy ofDee's\ninfluence, as well as the optical interests ofthat circle. In his Philosophia\nEpicurea (Paris, 1601), Hill discussed the astral influences transmitted by\nlight -rays, relating this effect to Paracelsian alchemy. He stated that the\nextraction of the elixir of life and the transmutation of metals were a\ndivine process equivalent to the emanation of the second person ofthe\nHoly Trinity from the Father. He believed that light was the impression\nof God in nature and that it gave both form and life to matter.42]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=64\nPages: 64\nmirror on the earth into a dark cave. Kircher's illustration describes the\nvarious lights of nature, the senses and the intellect.\nIt remains to discuss the specific influences triggering Khunrath's\nideas concerning the use of astral virtue and catoptrics in alchemy. These\nmay have been inspired by the publication of Paracelsus' completeworks\nin the Basle edition of 1589-90, as well as the appearance ofdella Porta's\nsecond Magia Naturalis (1589). Another influence was undoubtedly Dee's\ncabbalistic astrology and catoptrics, as well as the enduring effects of Pico\ndella Mirandola's and Reuchlin's Christian cabbalism. In the context of\nthe political pressures on his pietistic beliefs between circa 1595 and\n1604, these influences led Khunrath to devise a cabbalistic alchemy of\nlight, founded on Paracelsian theosophy and Renaissance optical science.\nIOO\n34 Peuckert and Zeller (eds), Valentin Weigel. Samtliche Schriften (Stuttgart, 1962-78), 2,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\nnature\" is one of the foundations of Khunrath's alchemy in which he\ndescribes an unbroken continuum of illuminated wisdom, incorporating\nboththe practical experience ofthe natural world, as well as the spiritual\nvision of the mystic.17\nIn Paracelsian theosophy, empathetic imagination was not a subjective and, therefore, neglible factor in human affairs, but a powerful astral\nforce which provided the basis for theurgy and prognostication, as well as\nfor prophecy and mystical inspiration. Consequently, the Paracelsian\ntheosophical system eliminated, or diminished, the role of the institutionalised Christian church as the interpreter of God's will by means ofthe\ncanonical scriptures. Replacing external authority, the individual intuition became a more immediate and truer guide to divine knowledge.\nEven more radically, Paracelsus stated that through the imaginative faculties ofthe astral body a human could attain beatific union with God.18]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nvirtues) present within all natural bodies were the foundation of practical\nmedicine, since each person had an astral body which overlay and penetrated his physical body, so that the external and imminent \"astra\" were\neffectively the same entity. Thus, Parcelsus stated, a remedy was dependant on the astrological effects of the heavens.24 In the Volumen medicinae\nparamirum (circa 1520), he urged the physician to acquire a sound knowledge ofastronomy in order to understand the effects ofthe astral emanations by means of which God had impressed earthly things with \"signatures\",25\nFor a clearer understanding of Paracelsus' theory of\"signatures\", it is\nhelpful to consider Foucault's analysis of the Renaissance concept ofthe\nworld as being constructed on the basis of similitude and difference. The\nRenaissance taxonomy of phenomena, whether spiritual, physical, aesthetic or linguistic, was based on the idea that representation (similitude)]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=69\nPages: 69\nIII\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE 1595 AND 1602 EDITIONS\nHermes Trismegistus and Julius Caesar Scaligerus (Par. 53). Khunrath\nadmonishes true Christian alchemists that they should be meditating,\npraying, walking, reading scripture, as demonstrated in the second, third\nand fourth figures of his treatise (Par. 71). In contrast, he attacks blasphemers and black-magicians who operate with the sign of the pentacle,\ndirecting his reader, instead, to the fourth figure of his treatise in which\nthere appear the proper, truly spiritual, figures which are to be used in\nalchemy. This is probably an allusion to the 1595 engraving of the\nLullian-cabbalistic circles of the \"Archetypos\" (fig. 33), which is, however, absent from MS Alnwick 571.\nHic ANNULUM assistentia spiritu boni, Theosophorum: (In Tabulis Cordis)]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=34\nPages: 34\nthat alchemy was of interest to Dee in the 1550s, there are, nevertheless,\nsufficient hints within the text of the Propaedeumata Aphoristica to indicate\nthat Dee envisaged an alchemical purpose for his astral catoptrics.\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY:\nTHE \"ASTRAL VIRTUE\" AND\nTHE \"AERIAL SALTPETRE\"\nThe controversy generated by the medical theories of Paracelsus (14931541) was caused not only by his adoption of alchemical methods for\npreparing medicines and his innovatory use of inorganic substances, but\nalso by his disturbing synthesis of medicine, magic, theology and cosmology. Paracelsus' ambitiously expansive (and often self-contradictory) vision forced his educated contemporaries to re-assess both their professional activities as physicians, as well as their philosophical systems and\neven their religious beliefs.\nParacelsus' own Christian commitment cannot be doubted, for this\nwas one of his declared reasons for his attack on pre-Christian medical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10\nMirandola, like Ficino, integrated these practices with Christianity, butin\naddition he introduced the cabbalah into Renaissance hermeticism.6\nThe German natural philosopher and magus Cornelius Agrippa\n(1486-1533) popularised astral magic through his treatise, De Occulta\nPhilosophia (1533), justifying such practices by claiming the existence of a\nnatural sympathy between the human-being and the universe, an idea\nalready well-known to the middle ages. On the model of Agrippa, this\nvenerable notion of the harmony between celestial and human realms\nwas systematised for medical use by Paracelsus who created an analogical\nstructure known as the \"doctrine of signatures\". He taught that in all\nmaterial entities there existed hidden virtues whose qualities corresponded to those ofthe planetary bodies in the heavens. These occult virtues he\ncalled \"astra\" to designate the \"signatures\" (the impressions) of the stars\non matter. Paracelsus argued that, due to the intimate unity between]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=82\nPages: 82,83\nhuman imagination to be an astral force, capable of theurgically manipulating the world of time and space. Hence, the prime function of de\nVries' engraving was to validate Khunrath's cabbalistic Christological\nalchemy.\nThere are two other pictures in Khunrath's iconographic repertoire\nwhich similarly provide a rhetorical defence of his position as a spiritual\nalchemist against the rising tide of objections to his theosophical Christology. These are the Magdeburg emblem of an owl and the 1602 image of\nthe \"calumniatores\".\n136\n52 Jung's drawing in Bibliotek Kopenhagen, MS GKS 1765 may be seen in thereproduction in Gilly, Cimelia Rhodostaurotica (1995), p. 14, Item 12b.\n137\n53 Henry Moore Institute, Leeds, Peter Scheemakers: \"The Famous Statuary\" (1691-1781),\n1966, exhibition catalogue, No. 6, Vue d'Optique engraving, c. 1750, with mahogany\nand glass viewing machine.\n54 Obrist, pp. 55-65, 248-49.\nCHAPTER TEN\nEPICUREANS, BLASPHEMERS, SOPHISTS AND\nBLACK-MAGICIANS: THE PERSECUTION OF]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light"*, astral emanations and theurgic rituals are deeply interconnected within the Paracelsian framework, particularly through their role in both alchemical and mystical practices. Here are key points regarding these concepts: 1. Astral Emanations: Astral emanations are described as the hidden virtues or "signatures" left by celestial bodies (e.g., stars and planets) on earthly matter. These emanations influence the physical world and human health, a key concept in Paracelsian alchemy: > "In the Volumen Medicinae Paramirum (circa 1520), Paracelsus urged the physician to acquire a sound knowledge of astronomy in order to understand the effects of the astral emanations by means of which God had impressed earthly things with 'signatures.'" [Urszula Szul, page 36](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36). 2. Theurgical Rituals: In Paracelsian theosophy, the imagination was considered an astral force that could be used for theurgical rituals. These rituals aimed to manipulate astral forces for spiritual enlightenment or practical purposes, such as alchemical transmutation. The use of imagination in these rituals allowed practitioners to engage with the divine and astral realms directly: > "In Paracelsian theosophy, empathetic imagination was not a subjective... but a powerful astral force which provided the basis for theurgy and prognostication, as well as for prophecy and mystical inspiration." [Urszula Szul, page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18). 3. Alchemical Use of Astral Rays: Alchemists like John Dee and Heinrich Khunrath expanded on Paracelsian ideas by using astral rays in alchemical procedures. These rays were believed to carry divine power, and their manipulation through mirrors (catoptrics) or rituals allowed alchemists to influence both material and spiritual processes: > "Khunrath promoted the use of catoptrics in alchemy, describing how the virtues of the sun are to be deployed by means of steel or crystal mirrors." [Urszula Szul, page 61](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=61). These practices formed the basis of the alchemy of light, where celestial forces were harnessed to transform both physical materials and the soul through theurgical, mystical, and alchemical rituals. For further exploration, you can refer to [page 18](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18) and [page 36](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36).
You
continue with the summary
Tool
{"result":["[Summary from page 40 to page 51 out of a total of 137:\nPages 40:\nCHAPTER FOUR\nPARACELSIAN ALCHEMY\n\"dyed\" vitriol (sulphuric acid) for twenty-two days and worked saltpetre,\nadding mercury and repeatedly distilling the ensuing chemical mix. He\nalso used repeated quantities of sulphur and marcasite, frequently circulating the products (ff. 2r-4r). Similarly, in Dee's diary, he records that on\n30 August 1594 Walter Mallet left for Toulouse with the fixed oil of\nsaltpetre , presumably having been taught the method of its preparation\nby Dee.52 Comparing Dee's work with that of Paracelsus in his various\nmedicinal treatises, there is some similarity. One of the most important\nParacelsian chemical preparations was the production of potassium arsenate from the fusion of arsenic with saltpetre. Paracelsus had washed the\nmetals with alchohol and water, then heated them with saltpetre which\ncaused the metals to oxidise and become soluble.53 Also, in this context,\nthere exists a strange record of Dee's preparation of \"AER SIMPLEX\"\nin August 1581.\nThe 29 day after 11 ofthe clok I did sett 7 oz and a half of pure Ayre forto\nCirculate in balneo.\n(Bodleian Library MS D 241 (13050), f. 8r)\nUnfortunately, the experiment is not fully documented, but it may indicate that Dee was attempting to work with the Paracelsian aerial virtue.\nDee also favoured \"maracasite\" ( Bodleian Library MS D 241, ff. 2r,\n2v, 3r, 5r), distilling it with sulphur and sulphuric acid (f.5r). (Marcasite is\ncommonly denoted by the symbol of a star). Unfortunately, the name was\nused by alchemists to describe a wide range of different substances. Genuine marcasite is a mineral form of iron disulphide (FeS2), having the\nsame composition as pyrites, but with a different crystalline structure as\nwhite iron pyrites. In fact, marcasite is simply an immature metallic substance. White marcasite is bismuth, a metal which was attracting considerable attention in the sixteenth century and which was confused with\nantimony. Marcasite of lead is antimony. The most interesting, though\nunproveable, interpretation would be to identify Dee's \"marcasite\" with\nantimony, a poisonous semi-metal much used by the Paracelsians.\nParacelsus had given directions for removing the lethal qualities of\npoisonous minerals and metals in order to render them suitable for homeopathic use. His method involved mixing the poisonous mineral with\nsaltpetre, then pouring the mixture onto a slab of marble and standing it\nin a cool place. This would become a dough-like substance which required repeated kneading. The Paracelsian alchemist known by the name\nof\"Basil Valentine\" (probably to be identified with his \"editor\"Johannes\nTholde) was a popular source from the 1580s for a potable antimony.\nThis medicinal potion, apparently, was sweet in smell and taste and coloured ruby-red.54\nAt the end of Bodleian MS Ashmole 1486, Dee records that he used a\nmix of two ounces of maracasite, four ounces of vitriol, common tartar,\none ounce of gold and sal ammoniac. There followed much distilling\nwhich indicates that he was attempting to dissolve metals in vitriol. Paracelsian remedies against the plague included sulphur and metals in the\nform of spirit of vitriol, that is, sulphur sublimate. Sulphur derived from\nvitriol and its salts has narcotic and analgesic properties.5\nThis small selection of items from Dee's record can only be indicative\nof his general interests. The most important question arising from these\nmanuscript notes is whether Dee was intending in his laboratory workto\nproduce medicines, or whether he was still in quest of the philosopher's\nstone. The latter purpose certainly dominates Kelley's alchemical practice. Similarly, Dee's questions to the angels during his spiritual sceances\nin Eastern Europe, as well as the notes in his diary during the time ofhis\ncollaboration with Kelley, suggest that he was still preoccupied with the\ntraditional alchemical goal of transmutation.56 In contrast, Dee's alchemical diaries show that he had developed an interest in nitric preparations\nand, possibly, in those involving antimony which indicates some medical\nintention. Unfortunately, his laboratory notes are limited remains only,\nscribbles written in haste, and they cannot provide a full picture ofDee's\nalchemy. They have to be read against the broader record of his intellectual life.\n52\n52 Halliwell, p. 50; Fenton, p. 267.\n53 Pagel (1982), p. 276.\n53\n54 For example, Paracelsus on antimony in Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 275-76. See also J. R.\nPartington, A History ofChemistry (London : Macmillan, 1961), pp. 146-51 and BasilValentine, Der Triumph-WagenAntimonii (Leipzig, 1604). Suchten issued an influentialtexton\nantimony see Sudhoff, Bibliographia Paracelsica (1894), pp. 280-81.\n55 Pagel (1982), pp. 87: n. 230, 276-77.\n56 See Clulee, pp. 203-30; Clucas, \"Non est legendum sed inspicendum solum\" (1998),\nPP. pp. 109-32.\n\nPages 41:\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT:\nTHE MONAS HIEROGLYPHICA AND THE CABBALAH\nParacelsian theosophy was related conceptually to other neoplatonised\nmetaphysical structures, such as the cabbalah, which entered the western\nphilosophical context in the early sixteenth century. The distant ancestor\nof both the Paracelsian chemical cosmogony of the aerial fire and that of\nthe cabbalistic divine light is to be found in late hellenistic esotericism.\nThe present study will analyse the manner in which the cabbalah, specifically the cosmogenical account in the Zohar, provided a theologicaljustification for an \"alchemy of light\" through its vision ofthe world's emanation from God by means of his divine will, \"Kav\", in the form ofa beam\noflight.\nKnowledge of cabbalistic texts was dispersed through-out Europe on\nthe expulsion ofthe Jews from Spain in 1492. A Christian version ofthe\ncabbalah was devised by Giovanni Pico della Mirandola (1463-1494) in\nhis Nine Hundred Theses (1496), which provided the model for the more\ndetailed version ofthe German humanist Johannes Reuchlin (1455-1522)\nin De Verbo Mirifico (1494) and De Arte Cabbalistica (1517). In the early\nsixteenth century, cabbalism supported a natural philosophy orientated\ntowards magic. The work of Pico and Reuchlin was publicised by Cornelius Agrippa in his De Occulta Philosophia (1533) and further developed\nby Guillaume Postel, Johannes Pistorius and John Dee. Agrippa was the\nmain source ofpublic information concerning theurgical systems and his\naccount ofmystical practices influenced both Paracelsus' theurgy, as well\nas his theosophical system.\nScholars differ in their accounts of the sources ofJohn Dee's angelic\nmagic and cabbalism, his \"Ars Sintrilla\". It was Yates who first laid stress\non the importance of Dee's theurgic mathematics for the empirical sciences ofthe seventeenth century. Both Clulee and Clucas considered that\na significant influence on the development of Dee's magical practices,\nJohannes Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico; De Arte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart: Frommann,\n1964), facsimiles offirst editions. See Charles Zika, \"Reuchlin's \"De Verbo Mirifico\" \",\nJWCI (1976): 104-38; Pico della Mirandola, Conclusiones Nongentae (1532 ed), pp. 151-64;\nScholem, Major Trends in JewishMysticism (New York: Schocken, 1973), pp. 244\nffGershom\n.\n\nPages 42:\n56\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nparticularly on his esoteric linguistics, came from medieval theurgy since\nhe had copies, for example, of Roger Bacon's work on sigils, as well as\nthat ofPeter ofAbano. Clulee was also inclined to favour Trithemius and\nPantheus as additional Renaissance mentors for Dee's occultist linguistics. Sherman, however, has concentrated on the syncretic aspects of\nDee's learning, tending to view his magical interests as an almost counter-humanistic enterprise which favoured the medieval concept of \"given\" esoteric knowledge, instead of empirical experimentation.\nSzonyi, on the other hand, has considered a more immediate source\nfor Dee's astral rituals and sympathetic magic in Renaissance neoplatonism and hermeticism.
