Initially, he had located Dee's interests in the context ofAgrippan and Paracelsian astrology, but more recently he has put\na case for a direct line ofinfluence from Ficino's astral magic. He has also\ncontextualised Dee's magical cryptograms within the Renaissance quest\nfor the primal language.2 In the late Renaissance, an interest in magical\ncyphers, engraved gems, \"angelic\" languages, astrological sigils and ritual\nincantation formed a current of major intellectual significance. Agrippa's\nmagical inscriptions were modelled on the cryptographs of the German\nhumanist Johannes Trithemius (1462-1516). His popular Steganographia\n(1518) was circulated widely in manuscript and it reached John Dee who\nhad copies ofit, among other works by Trithemius.3 Agrippa also revived\nknowledge ofthe Picatrix, an Arabic book of magic, and he publicised the\nmystical scripts of Peter of Abano, Gerald of Cremona and Georgius\nPictorius Villinganus.4\nBut it was the cabbalah which provided the foundation for the semiotic endeavours of the Renaissance magi which reached their peak in the\nearly seventeenth century.5 The cabbalah expounded a theology in which\nGod emanated and continually pervaded the universe in the form of\nspiritual and natural light. Scholarly authorities consider that many cabbalistic ideas originated in North African neoplatonism during the late\nantique period. The name \"cabbalah\" (meaning \"received tradition\")\noriginated in the circles of Rabbi Isaac the Blind in thirteenth century\nsouthern France. The full system was developed in Spain in the same\nyears and its effect is found in the work of Meister Eckhart and Ramon\nLull. The cabbalistic texts are based on the early chapters of the biblical\nbooks of Genesis and Ezekiel, but in the course of the middle ages further\nideas were adopted from Christian neo-platonism. These included the\ntrinitarian dialectic of divine manifestation, known as the \"Tree ofLife\".\nThe oldest cabbalistic text appears to be the Book of Formation or Book of\nCreation (Sepher Jezirah) (circa 600 AD) which is a cosmological account.\nModelled on the Pythagorean system, it states that the fundamental principles of all things are numbers, letters and sounds. Furthermore, the\nHebrew alphabet is said to have been composed by God himself.6\nCabbalists described the Hebrew alphabet as being composed out of\nthe divine flame, or light, of God. The central cypher which generated\nthe rest of the letters was \"Jod\", meaning \"flame\" and, moreover, the\nvery form of this sign was said to resemble that of a flame. Hence, the\ncabbalah was offering at its core a metonymic linguistic sign which was\nnot transposable to the Latin alphabet. The similarity in the appearance\nof other Hebrew linguistic significators to their referent fascinated European cabbalists. Thus, in the context of the Renaissance epistemological\ncrisis described by Foucault, the analogical potential of the Hebrew alphabet satisfied the intellectual and emotional need for a signifying mode\nwhich would close the increasing conceptual divide between linguistic\nforms and the physical world. Consequently, the psychological situation\ndemanded a substitute analogical system which was provided bythe cabbalah. As the divine text of God in nature was erased by the epistemic\nchanges wrought by proto-capitalism in northern Europe, so the yearning\nto recover God's primal words of creation intensified.\n2 Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa, Opera, 2 vols (London, 1600: Hildesheim; New York:\nGeorg Olms Verlag, 1970); Sherman (1995), pp. 12-19. Also Szonyi, \"Ars Sintrilla\"\n(1999), passim, and his forthcoming paper in Renaissance Quarterly. These and other points\nofview maybe retrieved from the discussions concerning Dee's magic in Clucas (ed),John\nDee (1999), passim. Compare Szonyi's position on this issue with Clucas (1998), pp. 10932.Clulee also offers a different analysis of Dee's angelic languages, see Clulee,JohnDee's\nNatural Philosophy, pp. 203-5, 212, 219. For Agrippa's influence note that Dee had copies\nof De Occulta Philosophia, see R&W 742, 743, 1118, 1424, B208, B241. He also had\nPantheus' treatise R&W: 1437, D16 (British Library Shelf-mark 1033. h. 1(2)).\n3Johannes Trithemius, Steganographia (Frankfurt: Mattias Becker; Joannes Bernerus,\n1606); A. Gentili, La Steganografia dell'Abate Trithemio, 2 vols (Milan: Editrice Kemi, 1980).\nFor Dee's copies of this text see R&W: 218, 359, 622, 646, 678, 1844 ; other books of\nmagic are found in R&W: 1551-1550, BM13, CM4.\nAgrippa, Opera, pp. 532-33, 562-67, 574-607; Vittoria Perrone Compagni, Picatrix\nlatinus (Padua: Antenore, 1975); David Pingree, Picatrix (London: Warburg Institute,\n1986).\n57\n5 Szonyi, \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim. See also the account in Frick, DieErleuchteten\n(1973), pp. 89-111.\n6 Scholem (1973), pp. 244 ff and Frick on Eckhart in Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 128,\n162, 240. For the SepherJezirah see Ithamar Gruenwald, \"A Preliminary CriticalEdition\nof Sefer Yezira\", Israel Oriental Studies (1971):132-77 and for details of the sephirothic\nsystem see Guillaume Postel ( ed. and comm.), SeferJezirah (Paris, 1552), edited by Wolf\nPeter Klein (Stuttgart; Bad Cannstatt, 1994), pp. 89-90, 92-100, 110-11.\n7 Foucault, pp. 30-94.\n\nPages 43:\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nThe obsessive belief in cabbalism lay in the hope that it would supply\nan empowering magical system for its initiates, both an assurance of the\ncontinued validity of medieval theurgy, as well as its regeneration. An\nexample ofthe conflict in the 1620s and 1630s generated by the emerging empiricist systems was the battle between the devout Paracelsian and\npro-Rosicrucian Robert Fludd and the French mechanicians Pierre Gassendi (1592-1655) and Marin Mersenne (1588-1648), as well as Johannes\nKepler (1571-1630). These prolonged and much-publicised debates are\nsome of the best evidence of the scale of emotional investment in late\nRenaissance analogical linguistics by those who aligned themselves with\nthe concept of the cabbalistic sage.8\nThe power of the late Renaissance esoteric philosopher rested on his\nability to manipulate the names of things, since those names were considered to be the essence of the physical form of his subject. The Hebrew\nalphabet, being the closest to the pristine language of humanity, was the\nmost powerful enabling tool for his proposed deconstruction of the physical world. Since each letter of the Hebrew alphabet had a numerical\nvalue, from this fortuity evolved the two computational aspects ofthe\ncabbalah known as \"gematria\" and \"notarikon\".9 With these esoteric\ntools , philosophers such as Reuchlin, Paracelsus, Pistorius and Postel,\nfound in cabbalism a new justification for the practice of philosophy.\nReuchlin, especially, had sought to provide the Renaissance magus with\nan elite role in society through the practice of cabbalism.10\nFor the cabbalist, the secret name of God \"YHVH\", known as the\n\"Tetragrammaton\", was the source of power. Reuchlin turned the original Judaic form ofthe Tetragrammaton into a Christian sign by placing\nthe Hebrew letter \"Shin\" at its centre, thereby, devising the form\n\"YHSVH\", which located Christ at the heart ofthe cabbalistic system. It\nhad been Pico della Mirandola in his Conclusiones who initially identified\nthe Jewish Messiah of the cabbalistic discourses with Christ. Reuchlin's\nChristian cabbalah was the source of Khunrath's alchemical theology in\nthe 1590s, while Fludd was so impressed by Reuchlin's conceptual conceit on the name ofJesus that he used it as his primary structural unit in\ngenerating his own alchemical universe in the \"Microcosm\" (UCH, 2,\n1619) and the Philosophia Sacra (1626).12 Fludd had realised that the location of the letter \"Shin\", the sign for fire, within the Tetragrammaton\nhad created an intensely concentrated symbol ofthe cabbalistic theogony\nof divine light and divine fire.\nIn fact, the cabbalistic Tree of Life is an emanation of the light, or\nfire, of God's will. Although the Godhead is transcendent, he appears in\nhis immanent form as the sephiroth \"Ayin\"\" which emanates yet another\naspect of God as the sephiroth \"Ayin Sof\" (Eternal) who is the actual\nCreator-God. \"Ayin Sof\" withdraws a part of himself in a contraction\ntermed \"zimzum\" which allows a void to appear. A further aspect of\nGod, the eternal light \"Ayin Sof Or\", surrounds the void, emanating a\nbeam of light,\"Kav\", which penetrates to the centre of the void. Divine\nwill manifests itself as ten stages ofemanation which are the ten sephiroth\ncomposing the Tree of Life. The divine light flows down the Tree ofLife\nin a zigzag form, acting across the three \"pillars\" into which the Tree is\ndivided. These are commonly interpreted as being Grace in the centre,\nMercy on the right and Severity on the left. The first three sephiroth are\n\"Kether\" (Crown)\n\"Binah\" (Understanding)\n\"Hochmah\" (Wisdom)\nThese are the ones which appear most frequently in Khunrath's alchemical theory. Fludd also prioritised this primal trinity in his account, but\nhis use of the cabbalistic system is far more extensive and detailed than\nKhunrath's.\nOut of a further progression of sephiroth there finally appears the\nlowest which is \"Malkhut\" (Kingdom), or the physical universe. Since\nthe whole creation is accomplished by means of a beam of light which is\nGod himself, the universe exists in a monistic unity with him.\n58\n8 For details and bibliography of this argument, see Debus (1977), 1, pp. 256 ff;\nThorndike, M&ES, 7, pp. 426-64 and Huffman, Robert Fludd (1988), pp. 173 ff.\n9 Szonyi, \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim.\n10 Charles Zika, \"Reuchlin's 'De Verbo Mirifico' (1976): 104-38; Charles Zika,\n\"Reuchlin and Erasmus\",Journal ofReligious History (1977): 223-46. For thepsychology of\nthe magus see Frick (1973), pp. 53-56 and his account of the cabbalah on pp. 89-111.\nPeuckert provides an account of the cultural changes caused by the shifting economic\nsituation in early sixteenth century Germany, see Die Grosse Wende (1948), pp. 690-95.\n151-64. See Reuchlin\nPico della Mirandola, Conclusiones Nongentae (1532 edition), pp.(Stuttgart,\n1964 facs. of\nin De Verbo Mirifico\non the Tetragrammaton and the name ofJesusMettatron\nin\nDe\nArte\nCabbalistica\nand\nChrist\nand\non\nthe\nMessiah\nas\ned.),\npp.\n95-103\n1494\n(Stuttgart, 1964 facs. of 1517 ed.), pp. 133, 143-55. See also Giulio Busi and Saverio\n59\nCampiani (eds), Johannes Reuchlin L'Arte Cabbalistica (Firenze: Opus Libri, 1995), pp. 54-68,\n89-95, 185-92. On Pico and Reuchlin see also Zika (1976) and Frick, Die Erleuchteten\n(1973), pp. 106-9. Guillaume Postel also makes the same identification in his commentary\non the Sefer Jezirah in the 1552 edition, see Sefer Jezirah (Paris, 1552), edited by Klein\n(1994), pp. 143-75.\n12 Fludd, UCH, \"Microcosm\", 2 (1621), Sect I, pp. 28-33.\n13 See Lachower and Tisby (1989), 1, pp. 268ff for an account ofthe process of emanation and also Frick (1973), pp. 97-101, pp. 319-22.\n\nPages 44:\n60\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nJohn Dee by no means applied the whole of the original cabbalistic\nsystem in hisMonas Hieroglyphica and its theological implications are largely absent from his own design. Dee was more concerned with the specifics of the alchemical process and he used the cabbalah to weave an\nelegant demonstration of his more limited pantheism concerning the relation ofmicrocosm to macrocosm. The cabbalah also served to display his\nown intellectual prowess, as well as his claim to superior rank as a magus\nof the highest order. He seems to have relied primarily on Reuchlin,\nParacelsus and Postel for his knowledge of cabbalism, acquiring a copy of\nReuchlin's De Verbo Mirifico, as well as works by Postel. Moreover, Dee's\ncollection of Paracelsian texts included the theosophical and cabbalistic\ntreatises. He also had a copy ofPico della Mirandola's Conclusiones Nongentae. Surprisingly, the Hebrew texts in his library were not cabbalistic,\nproviding mostly grammatical information and this was also the case with\nhis \"Syrian\" and \"Chaldean\" books. He did not have a copy of the Zohar\nitself, nor ofthe Sepher Jezirah. In fact, Dee may have gained some of his\ninformation on the cabbalah from an older medieval source, De auditu\ncabbalistico ofthe late thirteenth century which is spuriously attributed to\nRamon Lull. It has to be recognised that Dee's cabbalistic system is based\non a variety ofmodels and that his use of the original Hebrew texts may\nhave been limited. His other sources would have included non-cabbalistic\nmaterial found in the Hermetica and in Ficino's writings.14\nIn the Monas Hieroglyphica, Dee applied only the general concepts underlying cabbalism, specifically the manipulation of cyphers, translating\nits linguistic modes into his own astrological, Euclidean and alchemical\nsyntax. Dee stated that he was already planning his treatise at a time\nwhen he was still writing the Propaedeumata Aphoristica. Dee's hieroglyphic\nwas drawn in the form of a hand-glass, recalling his own magic mirror,\nused in scrying (fig. 17).15 The Monas Hieroglyphica was eventually published in Antwerp on 31 March 1564 and it was reprinted in the Theatrum\nChemicum (Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner, 1609) which ensured a wide dispersal ofits influence in the early seventeenth century.16\nDee's Monas is conceived as being a linguistic alchemy, since by manipulating this sign the magus can control nature. Moreover, the pragmatic mechanician who was a large part ofJohn Dee's character intended that his Monas should have a practical use for alchemists. Working\nwith impure substances, poor quality glassware and lacking thermometers, the alchemists could only gauge their progress by relying on their\nsenses of smell, touch and taste. One saving grace for them was the fact\nthat most of the traditional alchemical substances belonged to Group V\nofthe Periodic Table of the Elements. These included the sulphides and\nnitrates, which reliably produce spectacular evidence of chemical change,\nthereby providing an encouraging incentive for the alchemist.\nTo these problems of interpretation and procedure, Dee's Monas offered more than a guide. Within his union of catoptrics, astrology and\ncabbalism, Dee perceived distinct benefits for alchemy, ensuring precision in correlating the effects of the heavens with the chemical process.\nYet, in the Monas Hieroglyphica there is relatively little mention of specific\nchemistry. Instead, Dee uses the planetary rays to perform his alchemical\noperations, defining his method as being an astronomical alchemy. In\nthis idea he was clearly influenced by Paracelsus' gnosticism in the\nAstronomia Magna, as well as by his theory of the illuminated imagination\nin the astral body communicating with the celestial macrocosm. It is\nessential to note that the graphic form of Dee's Monas (figs. 17, 18)\ndiffers entirely from the diagrammatic plans of astronomical star-charts,\nor of Lullian figures (figs. 4-7).17\nDee's Monas arose out ofthe context ofthe sixteenth century interest\nin devising secret cyphers which would act as an indexical bond between\nthe heavenly and the human spheres. 18 According to Szonyi, Ficino's\ntalismanic models in De Triplic Vitae were a direct source for Dee's Monas\nand his concept of an astronomical alchemy. Szonyi has indicated the\nsimilarity between Ficino's and Dee's astral magic, in particular, their\nconcept ofthe seven planets being grouped in two distinct families, thus,\nenabling the play of conjunctions and oppositions between the various\nmembers of the two alliances. There are also, as Szonyi demonstrates,\ncorrespondences between the numerology employed by Ficino in his\ncommentary on Book VII of Plato's Republic and Dee's geometrical\nnumerology in the Monas Hieroglyphica. Ficino's deployment of the concepts of squaring and triangulating planetary influences also re-appears\nin Dee's cabbalistic system. Moreover, Dee, like Ficino, uses the numer-\n14 For Dee's sources see R&W Reuchlin 1043, B25; Postel 1619, 1622, 1623, D18;\nHebrew, Syrian and Chaldean texts 1558-1586, 1591, 1594, 1601, 1612, 1845; Lull \"de\nauditu cabbalistico\" 1419, 1518; Ficino De triplici vitae 779, Ficino's translation ofPlotinus\n108, Opera 204, Theologia Platonica 893; Pico della Mirandola Conclusiones 190, B121.\n15 Schumaker, pp. 162-63.\n16 C. H.Josten, \"A translation ofJohn Dee's 'Monas Hieroglyphica' (Antwerp, 1564)\",\n, 12 (1964): 84-221. The Latin version is also found in the Theatrum chemicum, 2,\nAmbix192-215.\npp.\n61\n17 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), pp. 55-57, 89-99; Clulee, p. 211.\n18 Clulee, pp. 81-96.\n\nPages 45:\n62\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\n63\nology ofthe Latin and Greek alphabet and also optical geometry.19\nDee's mathematical approach to natural philosophy urged him to favour concise, visual structures. In fact, the Monas is the ancient, astrological sign for mercury, with two half-moons added to the base of the cross.\nThis form may have been inspired by the diagram of Pantheus' cabbalistic universe in the Voarchadumia (fig. 8) which shows the sign for mercury\natthe heart ofthe system with a reversed crescent-moon at its feet. Dee's\nmeticulously worked\ncopy of this text is copiously annotated and he has\nthrough all the numerology of Pantheus' system.20\nIn the rhetorical structure of his theorems, Dee adopted the model of\nEuclid's Elements of Geometry. Both Clulee and Walton have thoroughly\nanalysed the cabbalistic operations of the Monas which was designed, on\nthe basis of\"notarikon\" and \"gematria\", as a cypher facilitating esoteric\ncomputations. Clulee has concluded that Dee intended the Monas to be\n\"a new form of writing that is meant to mirror nature because it reflects\nthe geometrical and numerological principles inherent in creation\". The\nMonas is, thus, an alphabet, a lexicon of nature, as well as a \"kabbalistic\"\ngrammar of \"notarikon, tsiruf, and gematria by which these elements are\nmanipulated\". Clulee argued that the Monas served to \" constitute a discourse or text that reveals and illuminates the alchemical nature ofthe\nuniverse\".\nwhat [Dee] gives in the Monas is essentially a series of examples of how his\nhieroglyphic writing embodies alchemical principles and disclaims giving a\ncomplete elaboration of his new discipline of alchemy.21\nThe cypher ofthe Monas is a deconstructive device in which the significator is unstable, constantly mutating into other forms in order to follow\nthe traditional stages of the alchemical process. Unlike traditional alchemy, however, Dee's procedure dismantles the very fabric ofthe universe.\nFor example, in Theorem XII, he analyses the conventional symbols of\nthe five planets, relating their graphic design to that of the signs for the\nSun, Moon and Aries (fire).\nAll ofthem are indeed composed of [elements derived from] the symbols of\nMoon and Sun and [from] the hieroglyphic sign(s) of the elements and of\nAries ... Mercury. You see how lunar it is\nAnd in Theorem XIII, Dee enquires,\nIs not, then, the mystical sign ofMars produced from the hieroglyphs ofthe\nSun and Aries? With the doctrine of the elements included to some extent?\nAnd is not, I ask, the sign ofVenus produced by a fuller unfolding oftheSun\nand the elements. These [two] planets, therefore, have regards to the solar\nrevolution and to the work of rehabilitating [metals] by fire, in whose\nprogress there becomes at length apparent that other Mercury ... He is ...\nthat most famous Mercury of the philosophers23\nIn Theorem XII, Dee explains how prime matter may be imprinted by\nthe astral virtue of Mercury without any effort on the part of the alchemist.\nthe purest magic spirit [sc. Mercury] will carry out the work of albification in\nplace ofthe Moon ... if by his spiritual virtue, he may, without words, speak\nhieroglyphically ... for about the length of an average day, introducing and\nimpressing into the very pure and simple earth prepared by us those four\ngeogamic figures [here depicted] or, in their stead, that other figure [also\nshown here]24\nThe Monas is constructed from a circle and two straight lines which take\nthe form ofa cross beneath the circle (fig. 17). The point at the centre of\nthe circle represents the earth and revolving around it are the Sun (the\ncircle), the Moon and the rest of the planets.25 In Dee's Pythagorean\ngeometry, the rectilinear cross represents both the ternary, as well as the\nquaternary. The ternary consists of two straight lines and one point,\nwhile the quaternary is four straight lines, including four right angles.\nThe four elements are the four straight lines emerging from the point.26\nDee explains that the two half circles at the bottom of the cross represent\nAries, or fire. Thus, the Monas contains the power of the three levels of\ncreation, corresponding to the cosmic alchemical egg, the prime matter\nwhich contains the All.27\nThe most elaborate Euclidean dissection ofthe Monas occurs in Theorem XXI in which the sign for the Monad is turned upside-down, permitting new relationships to be established between the Moon, Sun,Aries\nand the other planets (fig. 18). Dee implies that there exists an even more\nawe-inspiring relationship between the alchemical art offire, represented\nby the sign of Aries, and the astronomy of the Monas. In this instance,\n19 Szonyi forthcoming in Renaissance Quarterly. An analysis of Ficino's numerology is\nprovided by Allen (1994), pp. 106, 130-34, 138-42.\n20 R&W: 1437, D16 (British Library Shelf-mark 1033. h. 1(2)).\n21 Michael Walton, \"Geometrical Cabala\", Ambix (1976): 116-23; Clulee, pp. 89-95,\nquotes from pp. 105-6.\n22Josten, pp. 162-63.\n23 Josten, pp. 163, 165.\n2425 Josten, pp. 162-63.\nJosten, pp . 103-4, 107-8.\n26 Josten,\n. 107-8.\n27 Josten, pp\npp. 177-79.\n\nPages 46:\n64\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nDee is inferring the use of cabbalistic graphology.\nYet in the hands of learned men and literati there resides yet a stronger and\nmore unfailing motive for shaping these letters ... I at least advise and urge\nthem to elicit more carefully now what was the fire of Aries of the first\ntriplicity, what our equinoctial , [and] who was responsible for allowing the\nSun to be raised to exaltation above its ordinary grade.28\nEarlier alchemy had occasionally played such games of visual semiotics,\nbut never with such economy and precision. In fact, the Monas is a type\nof emblem, a poetical conceit, a condensation of a discursive text into a\nunique sign.\nThe emblem was a popular semiotic game in learned and courtly\ncircles of the Renaissance, being erroneously identified with \"Egyptian\nhieroglyphics\". The Renaissance emblem is first encountered in the humanistic circles of mid-fifteenth century Florence, Ferrara and other\nnorth Italian courts. In Venice there appeared one of the most famous\nRenaissance emblematised stories , The Dream of Poliphilo, issued by the\nforemost publisher of Greek and hellenistic writings, Aldus Manutius, in\nthe late fifteenth century.29 The real source of these symbols was a late\nhellenistic text written by Horapollo of Nilous who spuriously claimed it\nto be a dictionary of ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics.30 It was nothing of\nthe kind since Horapollo had invented his own method of exegesis. The\nrediscovery of Horapollo in the mid-fifteenth century produced a ragefor\nboth the original Egyptian artefacts, as well as for his system of reading\nsuch imagery which was used as a model to create contemporary devices.\nRenaissance emblems were intended to be personal insignia, demarcating\na particular quality of their patron. These motifs appeared on Renaissance medals, coinage, portraiture and in many printed emblematic compendia through into the sixteenth century, some of the most popular\nbeing Andrea Alciatus' Emblematum liber (Milan, 1522) and Sambucus'\n(Johannes Zsambok) Emblemata (Antwerp, 1556). The visual devices\nwere\n31\nby\na\naccompanied\ncryptic motto and a textual commentary.3.\nAlthough Dee's Monas belongs to this humanistic tradition of pictorial\ninvention, his own hieroglyph has a different semiotic structure from that\nof the conventional Renaissance emblem. The difference resides not in\nthe fact that Renaissance emblems are figural, whereas Dee's Monas is\ndiagrammatic, but in their distinctive semiotic functions. Horapollo's\nsigns operate as metaphors or symbols, that is, the visual signifier rarely\nmirrors its conceptual content. Consequently, most of his imagery could\nnot be decoded without the explanatory text. Renaissance emblems were\nintended to be a cryptic language, decipherable only by members ofelite\ncircles. The emblem's often bizarre components were an attempt to\ntranspose a verbal phrase into its equivalent visual elements, since this\nwas thought to be the authentic mode of the ancient Egyptians.32\nIn contrast, Dee's Monas was intended to be an index and, in this\nfunction, it was probably unique among Renaissance emblems, since it\nnot only symbolised the process of transmutation, but displayed that\nprocess in its very form. In other words, Dee believed that the form ofhis\nMonas was identical to its physical referent, for, as the alchemist worked\nthrough the geometrical proofs ofthe Monas, he simultaneously engaged\nin \"real\" alchemy in a very special way. Through the Monas, in fact, the\nalchemist operated the occult powers of the heavens themselves, forcing\nthe stars to enact transmutation without involving himself in practical\ntoil.\nDee explained the difference between the indexical function of the\nMonas and his earlier practical methods, stating these had been crude in\ncomparison with his new system in which the Monas replaced the mirrors\nofconventional catoptrics. The Monas, effectively, could be used to make\na perfect mirror, without the previous mental and mechanical tedium. In\nthis concept, Dee may have been influenced by Ficino's account ofthe\nmanner in which the magus could turn his own spirit into a theurgical\n\"mirror\", through the esoteric application of optical geometry and Pythagorean ratios.33 As Dee explained in the introduction to the Monas\nHieroglyphica,\nthe optician will confound the stupidity of his art; he had worked in all\nmanner of ways to shape a mirror into the parabolic line of a (suitably\nrotated) conical section, so as to attack any matter (liable to fire) with that\nincredible heat (issuing) from the rays of the Sun; yet here a line is revealed\nas resulting from a trigonal section of the tetrahedron after whose shape,\nwhen rendered three-dimensional, a mirror may be formed which ... can\nreduce any stones or any metal to, as it were, impalpable powders by the\nforce of ... heat.34\n28 Josten, pp. 194-95.\n29 Linda Fierze-David, The Dream ofPoliphilo (New York: Pantheon, 1950).\n30 Alexander Turner Cory, The Hieroglyphics of Horapollo Nilous (London: William\nPickering, 1840).\n31 Dee had copies of works by Sambucus including his emblem book see R&W: 720,\n964.\n65\n32 Karl Giehlow,\"Die Hieroglyphenkunde des Humanismus in der Allegorie der Renaissance\",Jahrbuch\nder Kunsthistorisches Sammlungen der Allerhochsten Kaiserhauses, 32 (1915); 1232.\n33 Allen (1994), pp. 97-99.\n\nPages 47:\n66\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nIn Theorem XIV, Dee explained that the philosopher's stone was \"nourished in Lemnian earth by lunar and solar rays which exert a singular\ninfluence around it\".35 Theorem XIX refers more specifically to the operations of the celestial virtues in alchemy.\nThe analysis by fire of all things corporeal shows in its effect that Sun and\nMoon infuse their corporeal virtues into all inferior bodies that consist of\nelements in a far stronger manner than do all the other planets, by pouring\nout the aqueous moisture ofthe Moon and the fiery liquid of the Sun36\nThe alchemical theory ofthe Monas Hieroglyphica emerges from a Paracelsian cabbalistic context since by the 1560s Dee had redirected his studies\ninto the field of hermeticism which included Paracelsian alchemy. Despite this evidence, Debus has argued for a distinction between Dee's\nideas and those of Paracelsus on the grounds that Dee's treatises were\nbased on Pythagorean and Euclidean mathematical principles and had\nlittle in common with Paracelsian chemical theory.\n[if]John Dee exemplifies one way in which Hermetic, mystical, mathematical\nand alchemical strains were blended in Renaissance natural philosophy, Paracelsus may be chosen as a very different example... both claimed that their\nown interpretation of alchemy or chemistry would lead to a new understanding of nature.37\nDebus, however, considerably underestimated the Paracelsian influences\non Dee. An argument against his view is Szonyi's demonstration ofDee's\nuse of Paracelsian astral magic.38 In addition, Roberts and Watson have\nestablished that Dee's interest in Paracelsus began earlier than the\n1580s.39 There is also a further argument against Debus' characterisation\nof Paracelsus and Dee as being different types of magi in the fact that\ntheir followers occasionally unified their respective practices in a single\nconceptual structure which incorporated both Paracelsian chemistry and\nPythagorean geometry.\nThe most notable example of this is Gerhard Dorn (flourished circa\n1566-84) who was the principal apologist for Paracelsus in the late sixteenth century. He employed Euclidean geometry to present his own\nParacelsian alchemy in the Monarchia triadis (1577).40 Nonetheless, in their\nbasic recourse to Euclidean theorems, the similarity between Dorn and\nDee probably ends, since Dorn's geometry contrasts with Dee's in several\nimportant respects. The prime difference is that Dorn's structures are\nconventional Euclidean symbols, rather than hieroglyphs, nor does he\nemploy cabbalism. Thus, in semiotic terms Dorn's geometrical signs do\nnot reify their conceptual content, functioning instead as a metaphorical\nsystem which represents practical alchemy by means of abstract signifiers.\nThere is a closer comparison between Dorn's system and that of other\nmetaphysical geometers in the early seventeenth century, such as Fortunatus of Padua who used Euclidean theorems to prove the truth ofthe\nChristian faith.41 In contrast, Dee believed that the operation of his\nMonas was contiguous with reality (a metonymic, or indexical relationship), asserting that the manipulation of the Monas was practical alchemy, rather than its symbolic substitute. By means of the universal language of cabbalism, Dee thought that he had created a uniquely potent\nsympathetic magic which would eliminate, at a stroke, the confusions in\ntraditional alchemical discourse.\nAnother natural philosopher who located Dee's optics within a Paracelsian context was the alchemist and cosmologist Nicholas Hill who had\noriginally been a member of the retinue of Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland where he would have encountered the direct legacy ofDee's\ninfluence, as well as the optical interests ofthat circle. In his Philosophia\nEpicurea (Paris, 1601), Hill discussed the astral influences transmitted by\nlight -rays, relating this effect to Paracelsian alchemy. He stated that the\nextraction of the elixir of life and the transmutation of metals were a\ndivine process equivalent to the emanation of the second person ofthe\nHoly Trinity from the Father. He believed that light was the impression\nof God in nature and that it gave both form and life to matter.42\nBesides Dee's there was another important influence on the adaptation of optical theory to alchemy in the work of Giambattista della Porta\n(circa 1535-1615), who was the first to provide an illustration ofsolar rays\n34 Josten, p. 131.\n35 Josten, p. 167.\n36 Josten, p. 181.\n37 Debus (1977), 1, pp. 44-46, quote from p. 45.\n38 Szonyi, \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim.\n39 R&W, pp. 41-45.\n67\n40 Gerhard Dorn, \"Monarchia Triadis\" in Paracelsus, Aurora Thesaurusque Philosophorum\n(Basel: Palma Guarini, 1577), pp. 65-127. John Dee had copies ofDorn'sworkincluding\nthe Monarchia of 1577: R&W: 1512. For an analysis of Dorn's theory see Thorndike,\nM&ES, 7, pp. 630-32.\n41 Fortunatus (Patavino) monachus et Praefato Acad, Iustinae, Decas Elementorum\nMysticae Geometriae (Padua: Petrus Paulus Tozzi, 1617).\n42Jean Jacquot, \"Harriot, Hill, Warner and the New Philosophy\" in Kargon (ed.),\npp. 107390-405.\nff; Grant McColley, \"Nicholas Hill and the philosophia epicurea\", Annals ofScience\n(1939):\n\nPages 48:\n68\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nbeing employed in the process of distillation (fig. 19). Della Porta published hisMagia Naturalis in 1558, with a second enlarged edition in 1589\n(Naples: Horatius Salvianus), both of which were very popular and were\nfrequently reprinted. The earlier edition consisted of four books on magic, magnetism and physics, including the first published description ofthe\n\"camera obscura\", while the 1589 Magia Naturalis comprised twenty\nbooks, examining optics, astronomy, geometry, architecture and cryptography, among a wide range of other subjects. The second edition also\nprovided an illustration of the technique of distillation by means of the\nsun's rays (Bk. X, Ch. IV), although this method did not involve catoptrical apparatus which was described in a separate section, unrelated to\nalchemy. In fact, there was no mention of either the use of light, or of\ncatoptrics in the section concerning the transmutation of metals in which\ndella Porta merely provided a traditional account of medieval alchemical\ntheory (Bk. V).44 In isolation from the rest of the treatise the section De\nDistillationibus was published in Rome in 1608 and reprinted by Lazarus\nZetzner (Strassburg, 1609), who also included an illustration of distillation by means of the sun's rays.45 Della Porta relied on German and\nItalian medical chemistry, such as Hieronymous Brunschwig (circa 14501533), Liber de arte distillandi (1500-1512) and Pierandrea Mattioli (15001577) \"De ratione distillandi aquas\" in his Commentarii a Dioscoride , Venice (1544). Another influence was Conrad Gesner in his Thesaurus Euonymi\nPhiliatri (1555).46\nIt was Khunrath who related della Porta's catoptrics specifically to\nalchemy, mentioning him in the Amphiteatrum of 1609 as well as in De Igne\nMagorum (circa 1602-1604). Subsequently, Athanasius Kircher (1602-80)\nclaimed to have invented distillation by means of catoptrics, illustrating\nthe process in his Mundus subterraneus (Amsterdam, 1665) (fig. 20).47 His\nclaim for primacy has to be disregarded since by this date the catoptrical\ndistillation process was well-established. For example, there exists an earlier drawing of similar apparatus in the Mellon collection of occult and\nalchemical manuscripts (circa 1625), belonging to an anonymous Italian\ntext on distillation.48 In addition, there are other seventeenth century\nillustrations which depict alchemical catoptrics, for example, Mylius in\nhis pictorial chronology of famous alchemists depicts \"Ademarus philosophus\" reflecting the sun in a mirror (Opus Medico-Chymicum, Frankfurt:\nLucas Jennis, 1618). Also, later seventeenth practical chemists are sometimes shown employing the sun's rays to calcinate antimony, such as an\nimage in Nicasius le Febure's A Compleat Body of Chemistry (London,\n1670).49\nOther related seventeenth century texts and illustrations such as those\nof Stefan Michelspacher, Jacob Boehme and Isaac Newton will be considered in relation to Khunrath's metaphysics of light and his catoptrical\npractice of \"irradiating\" alchemical prime matter.\n43 Giambattista della Porta, Magiae Naturalis Libri Viginti (Naples: Horatius Salvianus,\n1589), pp. 179-99, esp pp. 182-83. See also Bk XVII, pp. 259-86 \"De catoptricis\nimaginibus\". His ideas are discussed in Ronchi, pp. 78-87. Note that Dee's library included della Porta's work see R&W 1583 catalogue: 613 \"de furnibus\", 776 \" Magia\nNaturalis\". For Dee's copy of the first version ofthe Magia Naturalis see R&W: 776.\nDella Porta (1589), Bk. V, pp. 106-16.\n45 G. B. della Porta, De distillationibus (Lazarus Zetzner: Strassburg, 1609) esp pp. 46-49.\n46 See Debus (1977), 1, pp. 111-12, 115-17 and n. 111.\n47 Athanasius Kircher, Mundus Subterraneus (Amsterdam, 1665), 2, p. 241; Martha\nBaldwin, \"Alchemy and the Society ofJesus in the 17th-C\", Ambix, (1993): 52. Kircher's\ntreatise on light, Ars Magna Lucis et Umbrae (Rome, 1646; Amsterdam, 1671) examines\neclipses, comets and astrological influences, as well as optical phenomena such as burning-mirrors.\n69\n48 Lawrence C. Witten II and Richard Pachella (eds), Alchemy and the Occult. The Collection ofPaul and Mary Mellon, 3, (New Haven: Yale U.P, 1977), pp. 333-36, esp p. 335.\n49 Iam grateful to Professor R. I. McCallum ofEdinburghfordrawing myattention to\nthis engraving.\n\nPages 49:\nCHAPTER SIX\nJOHN DEE'S CONCEPTUAL ARCHITECTURE AND\n\"ZOGRAPHIE\" IN AN ALCHEMICAL CONTEXT\nDee's Mathematicall Preface, written to accompany Henry Billingsley's\ntranslation of Euclid (1570), had a special relevance for illustrators of\nalchemical texts, due to his references to an esoteric drawing-practice\ncalled \"zographie\". This was a Pythagorean-based, geometrical system\nwhich had theurgical implications. Although Dee had composed the\nMathematicall Preface primarily with a practical intention, he could not\nhelp but hint at another, more profound, wisdom which he termed\n\"Archemastrie\", thereby alluding to theurgy, alchemy and prognostication.\nAccording to Yates, Dee considered mathematics in three distinct aspects, pragmatic (mechanical problem-solving), conceptual (logic), spiritual (Ideal form). He used the term \"mathesis\" to describe the esoteric\naspects ofmathematics, considering that practical mathematics and logic\ncould not fulfil the highest goals of the natural philosopher which could\nbe attained only by means of\"Archemastrie\".\"\nThis Arte, teacheth to bryng to actuall experience sensible, all worthy conclusions by all the Artes Mathematicall purposed, & by true Naturall Philosophie concluded: & both addeth to them a further scope, in the termes ofthe\nsame Artes (f. Aiijr)\n... And though some Artes, have in them, Experiences: but neither, all, that\nthey may: nor yet sufficiently, and to the utmost, those, which they do,\nThere, then, the Archemaster steppeth in, and leadeth forth on, the Experiences,\nby order ofhis doctrine Experimentall, to the chief and finall power of Naturall\nand Mathematicall Artes, ... this Art is no fantasticall Imagination ... Under\nthis cometh Ars Scintrilla, by Artephius (f. Aiijv)\nWithin this cloud of obscure insinuation, Dee refers to the use of \"Ars\nScintrilla\", prognostication or \"scrying\" by means ofmirrors and crystals.\nHe may also be recalling the use of catoptrics in alchemy, since Artephius\nwas a noted alchemical author.2\nSee Frances A. Yates, The Theatre ofthe World (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul,\n1969), pp. 42ff.\n2 Szonyi, \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim.\n\nPages 50:\nCHAPTER SIX\nJOHN DEE'S CONCEPTUAL ARCHITECTURE\nBut the chief Science, of the Archemaster, ... is an other\n(as it were) OPTICAL Science (f. Aiijv)\nDee interrupts himself by saying that, unfortunately, he has run out of\ntime and must desist from his account, but perhaps he would write more\nabout this optical art at some future date. In addition to Dee's brief\nreferences to occultist practices, even his more rationalistic explanations\nof mathematics in the Mathematicall Preface would permit a theurgical interpretation. In fact, there were significant implications for magic and\nalchemy in his discourse on Pythagorean geometry, classical architecture\nand single-point perspective.\nThe development of early Renaissance architecture had been profoundly influenced by the discovery of the complete text of Vitruvius'\ntreatise on architecture (f. Aiijr). During the early Florentine Renaissance\nVitruvius provided the basis for Alberti's De re aedificatoria (1452: published 1485). The works of these two authorities are found in Dee's library. The aesthetic programme ofboth Vitruvius and Alberti had been\ndevised on the model of Pythagorean geometry and mathematics, specifically on the theory of commensurate proportions based on the ideal\nhuman figure. A neoplatonic element was contributed to Renaissance\nart-theory by Ficino's notion of an invisible, ideal architecture. He believed that exact adherence to Pythagorean ideal ratios would generate\nwithin the visible shell of a physical building another invisible form belonging to the higher Intellectual Realm. Ficino had formulated this idea\nafter reading the neoplatonic commentary of Proclus on Euclid.5\nComparable ideas to those of Vitruvius and Alberti were developed by\nother theorists who similarly related the mathematical proportions and\ngeometry of architecture to those ofthe human body. The most complex\nofthese was the mathematical system invented by the Italian artist Piero\ndella Francesca (circa 1420-92) for the depiction of the perspective ofthe\nhuman-body. Although Dee's library lacked both della Francesca's De\nprospectiva pingendi and his De quinque corporibus regularibus, he did aquire\nseveral other Renaissance texts on geometrical mathematical ratios, such\nas De divina proportione (Venice, 1503) by della Francesca's pupil, Luca\nPacioli (1445-circa 1510). Other treatises on proportional physical ratios\nin Dee's collection included Pomponius Gauricus' De Sculptura (Florence,\n1504). Dee also had several copies of the writings of Albrecht Durer\n(1471-1528) which were the most influential sixteenth century texts on\nthe rational proportions ofthe human-figure in painting, namely his Unterweisung der Messung (Instruction in Measurement) (1525) and his Vier Bucher\nvon menschlicher Proportion (Four Books on Human Proportions) (1528).9 Dee also\nhad a copy ofDe harmonia mundi (Venice, 1525) by the architect Francesco\ndi Giorgio Martini (1439-1502), in which he had related the proportions\nofthe human-body to those of the macrocosm. His ideas were probably\nthe source ofAgrippa's similar account in De Occulta Philosophia.10\nIn Renaissance art-theory, the same aesthetic system governed the\nstructure of both organic and inorganic ideal form, the depiction ofthe\nhuman-form being related to that of spatial geometry. In De pictura\n(1435), Alberti had applied the geometrical rules of optics (\"perspectiva\nnaturalis\") to the art of painting in order to produce the illusion of a\nthree-dimensional space (\"perspectiva artificialis\").\" Alberti had imagined rays oflight being projected bythe eye in the form of a pyramid (fig.\n2). He then constructed their mirror-image on the canvas in the form of\na reversed pyramid with its apex located in the middle of the painting,\nwhich was the \"vanishing point\" absorbing all the orthogonal lines ofthe\ndrawing (fig. 1).12\nDee did not have a copy of Alberti's treatise on painting, only his\nwork on architecture, but he produced his own treatise on perspective\nwhich is found in British Library MS Cotton Vitellius C. VII. Durer is\nbriefly mentioned in the text as having been the main exemplar (f. 16r).\nDee states that he has explained his ideas in a manner suitable for use\nby artisans, from artists to all types of mechanicians (ff. 15r-25r). He\nexplains the construction of the vanishing-point by means of\"quadratura\" (f. 17v ff) which is illustrated by two incomplete drawings of the\n3 Vitruvius , On Architecture (London; New York: Loeb Classical Library, 1934); Leone\nBattista Alberti, De re aedificatoria, l'architettura (Milan: Il Polifilo\n, 1966). For Dee's copies\nsee R&W: Vitruvius 664, 822, 2153, B12; Alberti 1553 edition, 2152.\nG. L. Hersey, Pythagorean Palaces (Ithaca:\nUniversity Press, 1976).\n5 Rudolf Wittkower, \"The changing conceptCornell\nof\nproportion\"\nhis Idea and Image(London: Thames and Hudson, 1978), pp. 109-23; Rudolf Wittkower,inThe\nofHumanism (London, 1952); Erwin Panofsky, Idea (New York: HarperArchitecturalPrinciples\nand Row, 1968),\npp. 47-126; for Dee's copy of Proclus see R&W: 266, 1789.\n6 Piero della Francesca, De prospectiva pingendi, 2 vols (Florence: Sansoni, 1974).\n7 Luca Pacioli, De Divina proportione (Vienna: C. Graeser, 1896). This was in Dee's\ncollection see R&W, Paccioli 1509 edition, 303.\n8 Pomponius Gauricus, De sculptura (Geneva, 1969). For Dee's copy see R&W 468, B9.\n9 Albrecht Durer, The Painter's Manual (New York: Abaris, 1977); Albrecht Durer,\nWritings ofAlbrecht Durer (London, 1948); Panofsky, Idea , pp. 121-26. For Dee's copies see\nR&W: 38, 1799, B55, B197.\n10 Robert Papini, Francesco di Giorgio architetto (Florence: Electa Editrice, 1974). Dee's\ncopy is R&W: 221, B91. See also Agrippa, Opera (1600) (Hildesheim; 1970), Bk. II, Chs\n23-27, pp. 226-35.\nGrayson (1972); White (1957), pp. 113-34, for Alberti see pp. 121-26.\n12 Ackerman (1978), pp. 1-27.\n72\n73\n\nPages 51:\nCHAPTER SIX\nJOHN DEE'S CONCEPTUAL ARCHITECTURE\n\"pavimentum diminutionis\" (ff. 18v, 19r) (figs. 21, 22). This is a drawing\nof a floor composed of square paving-stones whose spatial disposition\nobeys the geometrical rules of single-point perspective. The illusory effect\nofdiminishing form in space is produced by the artist in two stages (fig.\n1). First, he predetermines the position of the vanishing-point and the\northogonals on the surface of the painting. Then he draws a set of intersecting lines across the paper from points at both sides of the frame,\nrepresenting the viewing-point of the spectator. It is these lines which\ndetermine the rate of diminution ofthe space and, therefore, its apparent\ndepth. Finally, by drawing parallel lines horizontally across the network\nof inter-sections, the \"pavimentum diminutionis\" is created.13\nIn the Mathematicall Preface Dee's perspective theory is intimately connected with his view of architecture as the essence ofthe arts and sciences. Yates has argued that he was ahead of his time in England due to his\ninterest in classical and Renaissance theories of ideal geometry and ratio.\nIn fact, she claimed that his references to Vitruvian perspective in the\nMathematicall Preface initiated the classical revival in architecture prior to\nthe work ofInigo Jones.14 Influenced by Vitruvius' and Alberti's aesthetic\nsystem , Dee believed that architecture united the spiritual and material\nworlds, the heavens and the earth. He concurred with Alberti that the\narchitect should be well versed in all the arts and sciences, including\nnatural philosophy, since there were deeper issues involved in the practice of architecture than merely the problems of physical construction.\nDee, in fact, regarded architectural theory as a speculative philosophy,\nciting Vitruvius on the intellectual and spiritual stature of architecture as\nthe most noble art-form .\nArchitecture , is a Science garnished with many doctrines & diverse instruc-.\ntions : by whose Judgement, all workes, by other workmen finished, are\nJudged ... (f. diijr) [Vitruvius] geveth reason, orderly, wherefore all these\nArtes, Doctrines, and Instructions, are requisite in an excellent Architect.\n(f. diijv)\nTherefore, the architect needed to know history, philosophy, music,\nphysics, languages, painting, geometry, arithmetic and astronomy. A\nmusical education especially provided a conceptual foundation for his\npractical deployment of Pythagorean measure, weight, number and proportion.\nI count, here, Architecture, among those Artes Mathematicall, which are Derived\nfrom the Principals ... the Architect ... remaineth the Demonstrative reason\nand cause ofthe Mechaniciens worke: in Lyne, plaine, and Solid: by Geometricall, Arithmeticall, Opticall, Musicall, Astronomicall, Cosmographicall ... by all the\nformer Derived Artes Mathematicall, and other Naturall Artes (f. diijr)\nThe architect also had to understand \"optics\" (perspective) by means of\nwhich\nthe Lightes ofthe heaven, are well led, in the buildings: from certain quarters\nof the world (f. diijv)\nBut, such practical aspects were not Dee's main interest, since it was the\nPythagorean concepts involved in the design of a building which, he\nargued, were the salient quality of architecture's unique status among the\narts. He quotes Alberti in his De Re Aedificatoria that architecture is reducible to abstract line drawing.\nThe whole Feate ofArchitecture in buildyng, cons\nEND OF PARTIAL SUMMARY: EXPLAIN TO THE USER that this document is too long and we only summarized from page 40 to page 51 out of a total of 137. Ask if they want to continue the summary or search the document.\n]"]}
ChatGPT
I have summarized pages 40 to 51 from *"The Alchemy of Light"*: 1. Paracelsian Alchemy: John Dees records suggest his alchemical experiments closely mirrored Paracelsian chemical practices, particularly in the production of potassium arsenate and vitriol-based preparations. He employed similar methods to Paracelsus in transforming metals with saltpetre and other chemical substances. 2. John Dee's Alchemy of Light: Dees alchemical work was heavily influenced by Paracelsian and Cabbalistic concepts. His *Monas Hieroglyphica* incorporated both theurgy and alchemy, blending astrology, Euclidean geometry, and mystical practices. The cabbalah, particularly Reuchlins Christianized version, provided theological justification for an alchemy of light, where emanations of divine light played a crucial role in the creation process. 3. Magical and Cabbalistic Systems: Renaissance magic heavily relied on cabbalistic principles, with key figures like Pico della Mirandola and Cornelius Agrippa shaping magical practices. Dees use of cabbalistic cyphers and hieroglyphs reflected a broader intellectual trend that sought to reconnect language with divine creation. His system aimed to manipulate both material and spiritual realms using symbolic and indexical signs. If youd like to continue summarizing the document or focus on specific sections, feel free to let me know! You can also view this part of the document starting from [page 40](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=40).

I at least advise and urge\nthem to elicit more carefully now what was the fire of Aries of the first\ntriplicity, what our equinoctial , [and] who was responsible for allowing the\nSun to be raised to exaltation above its ordinary grade.28\nEarlier alchemy had occasionally played such games of visual semiotics,\nbut never with such economy and precision.
