The distant ancestor]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=43\nPages: 43,44\n89-95, 185-92. On Pico and Reuchlin see also Zika (1976) and Frick, Die Erleuchteten\n(1973), pp. 106-9. Guillaume Postel also makes the same identification in his commentary\non the Sefer Jezirah in the 1552 edition, see Sefer Jezirah (Paris, 1552), edited by Klein\n(1994), pp. 143-75.\n12 Fludd, UCH, \"Microcosm\", 2 (1621), Sect I, pp. 28-33.\n13 See Lachower and Tisby (1989), 1, pp. 268ff for an account ofthe process of emanation and also Frick (1973), pp. 97-101, pp. 319-22.\n60\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nJohn Dee by no means applied the whole of the original cabbalistic\nsystem in hisMonas Hieroglyphica and its theological implications are largely absent from his own design. Dee was more concerned with the specifics of the alchemical process and he used the cabbalah to weave an\nelegant demonstration of his more limited pantheism concerning the relation ofmicrocosm to macrocosm. The cabbalah also served to display his]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=46\nPages: 46,47\n30 Alexander Turner Cory, The Hieroglyphics of Horapollo Nilous (London: William\nPickering, 1840).\n31 Dee had copies of works by Sambucus including his emblem book see R&W: 720,\n964.\n65\n32 Karl Giehlow,\"Die Hieroglyphenkunde des Humanismus in der Allegorie der Renaissance\",Jahrbuch\nder Kunsthistorisches Sammlungen der Allerhochsten Kaiserhauses, 32 (1915); 1232.\n33 Allen (1994), pp. 97-99.\n66\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nIn Theorem XIV, Dee explained that the philosopher's stone was \"nourished in Lemnian earth by lunar and solar rays which exert a singular\ninfluence around it\".35 Theorem XIX refers more specifically to the operations of the celestial virtues in alchemy.\nThe analysis by fire of all things corporeal shows in its effect that Sun and\nMoon infuse their corporeal virtues into all inferior bodies that consist of\nelements in a far stronger manner than do all the other planets, by pouring\nout the aqueous moisture ofthe Moon and the fiery liquid of the Sun36]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=42\nPages: 42,43\n7 Foucault, pp. 30-94.\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nThe obsessive belief in cabbalism lay in the hope that it would supply\nan empowering magical system for its initiates, both an assurance of the\ncontinued validity of medieval theurgy, as well as its regeneration. An\nexample ofthe conflict in the 1620s and 1630s generated by the emerging empiricist systems was the battle between the devout Paracelsian and\npro-Rosicrucian Robert Fludd and the French mechanicians Pierre Gassendi (1592-1655) and Marin Mersenne (1588-1648), as well as Johannes\nKepler (1571-1630). These prolonged and much-publicised debates are\nsome of the best evidence of the scale of emotional investment in late\nRenaissance analogical linguistics by those who aligned themselves with\nthe concept of the cabbalistic sage.8\nThe power of the late Renaissance esoteric philosopher rested on his]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=41\nPages: 41,42\nJohannes Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico; De Arte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart: Frommann,\n1964), facsimiles offirst editions. See Charles Zika, \"Reuchlin's \"De Verbo Mirifico\" \",\nJWCI (1976): 104-38; Pico della Mirandola, Conclusiones Nongentae (1532 ed), pp. 151-64;\nScholem, Major Trends in JewishMysticism (New York: Schocken, 1973), pp. 244\nffGershom\n.\n56\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nparticularly on his esoteric linguistics, came from medieval theurgy since\nhe had copies, for example, of Roger Bacon's work on sigils, as well as\nthat ofPeter ofAbano. Clulee was also inclined to favour Trithemius and\nPantheus as additional Renaissance mentors for Dee's occultist linguistics. Sherman, however, has concentrated on the syncretic aspects of\nDee's learning, tending to view his magical interests as an almost counter-humanistic enterprise which favoured the medieval concept of \"given\" esoteric knowledge, instead of empirical experimentation.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=44\nPages: 44,45\n14 For Dee's sources see R&W Reuchlin 1043, B25; Postel 1619, 1622, 1623, D18;\nHebrew, Syrian and Chaldean texts 1558-1586, 1591, 1594, 1601, 1612, 1845; Lull \"de\nauditu cabbalistico\" 1419, 1518; Ficino De triplici vitae 779, Ficino's translation ofPlotinus\n108, Opera 204, Theologia Platonica 893; Pico della Mirandola Conclusiones 190, B121.\n15 Schumaker, pp. 162-63.\n16 C. H.Josten, \"A translation ofJohn Dee's 'Monas Hieroglyphica' (Antwerp, 1564)\",\n, 12 (1964): 84-221. The Latin version is also found in the Theatrum chemicum, 2,\nAmbix192-215.\npp.\n61\n17 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \" (1979), pp. 55-57, 89-99; Clulee, p. 211.\n18 Clulee, pp. 81-96.\n62\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\n63\nology ofthe Latin and Greek alphabet and also optical geometry.19\nDee's mathematical approach to natural philosophy urged him to favour concise, visual structures. In fact, the Monas is the ancient, astrological sign for mercury, with two half-moons added to the base of the cross.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=64\nPages: 64\nmirror on the earth into a dark cave. Kircher's illustration describes the\nvarious lights of nature, the senses and the intellect.\nIt remains to discuss the specific influences triggering Khunrath's\nideas concerning the use of astral virtue and catoptrics in alchemy. These\nmay have been inspired by the publication of Paracelsus' completeworks\nin the Basle edition of 1589-90, as well as the appearance ofdella Porta's\nsecond Magia Naturalis (1589). Another influence was undoubtedly Dee's\ncabbalistic astrology and catoptrics, as well as the enduring effects of Pico\ndella Mirandola's and Reuchlin's Christian cabbalism. In the context of\nthe political pressures on his pietistic beliefs between circa 1595 and\n1604, these influences led Khunrath to devise a cabbalistic alchemy of\nlight, founded on Paracelsian theosophy and Renaissance optical science.\nIOO\n34 Peuckert and Zeller (eds), Valentin Weigel. Samtliche Schriften (Stuttgart, 1962-78), 2,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=105\nPages: 105\nofthe physical world.\nParacelsian alchemy, thus, muted the distinction between physical and\npsychic chemistry. Amplified by the luministic cosmogenesis of the cabbalah, in Dee's theories in the 1560s an image of the magus began to\nemerge whose intellectual light mirrored, not only that of the stars and\nthe sun, but of God's own radiance . In a separate development, Weigel\nappropriated Paracelsian theosophy to make the same point, phrased in\nChristian terms, in which Christ became the essential light of the soul,\nthe real nature of each human-being, with the consequence that spiritual\nwisdom became an innate human faculty, rather than the gift of the\nLutheran sacraments. Khunrath merged Dee's image ofthe illuminated\nmagus with Weigel's alchemical Christ to create an \"alchemy of light\"\nwhich, henceforward, prioritised the inner transformation of the alchemist above that of his chemicals.\nIn the history of alchemy, perhaps the most important change in its]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=48\nPages: 48,47\n42Jean Jacquot, \"Harriot, Hill, Warner and the New Philosophy\" in Kargon (ed.),\npp. 107390-405.\nff; Grant McColley, \"Nicholas Hill and the philosophia epicurea\", Annals ofScience\n(1939):\n68\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nbeing employed in the process of distillation (fig. 19). Della Porta published hisMagia Naturalis in 1558, with a second enlarged edition in 1589\n(Naples: Horatius Salvianus), both of which were very popular and were\nfrequently reprinted. The earlier edition consisted of four books on magic, magnetism and physics, including the first published description ofthe\n\"camera obscura\", while the 1589 Magia Naturalis comprised twenty\nbooks, examining optics, astronomy, geometry, architecture and cryptography, among a wide range of other subjects. The second edition also\nprovided an illustration of the technique of distillation by means of the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=97\nPages: 97\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD:\nTHE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nIn the cabbalistic theogony ofRobert Fludd (1574-1637), the sun was far\nmore than a power-house for theurgical sigils, as in Dee's system, or an\naid to routine alchemical processes, since he considered it to be no less\nthan the altar of Christ the Messiah in his form as the angel Metattron.\nFludd's Christology in the 1620's is as intense and deeply-felt as that of\nKhunrath, but it is expressed in relatively sober academic prose and\nFludd is more absorbed than Khunrath in the minute specifics of Reuchlin's cabbalism. Basing his alchemical theory on that of Paracelsus, Fludd\ndevised not only a new version ofthe cabbalistic theosophy ofthe previous century, but also a novel system of practical medicine, whose claims\nfor efficacy were due to its reliance on the sacred light emanating from\nthe Creator-God (Christ) through the sun's rays.\nScholars are fortunate in being able to draw on Debus' extensive]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11,12\nXVII\n16 Roland Barthes, Mythologies (Paris: Seuil, 1957), pp. 109-59.\n17 Kubovy, pp. 166-72. See also James S. Ackerman, \"Alberti's Light\" in Irving Lavin\nandJohn Plummer, Studies in Late Medieval and Renaissance Painting in Honour ofMillard Meiss\n(New York, 1978), pp. 1-27.\n18 Peirce, 2, pp. 170-72.\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\napply cabbalism to alchemy, since Joannes Pantheus of Venice had devised a comparable system in his Voarchadumia (1530) and Dee had also\nproduced a cabbalistic alchemy in the Monas Hieroglyphica (1564). Khunrath, however, placed his cabbalism within a Christological framework,\nso much so, that his main concern from 1595 was not alchemical theory,\nbut pietistic Christian theology, anticipating, perhaps, the alchemical\nmysticism of Jacob Boehme.\nKhunrath may have developed his Christological alchemy in the mid1590s, both as a response to anti-Christian tendencies within German\nhermetic circles and also as an expression of a pietistic Lutheranism]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10\npragmatic body of knowledge for more esoteric purposes. Specifically,\nby means ofcatoptrics (the reflection and refraction of light-rays by mirrors and lenses), Dee thought that celestial rays could be manipulated\nmore reliably to enhance all aspects of human affairs. The metaphysical\nrationale for Dee's astronomical and optical magic was provided bythe\ncabbalah, which he integrated into his alchemy in the 1560s. His fully\ndeveloped system of natural philosophy was published in the Monas Hieroglyphica (1564) which combined optics, geometry, magic, alchemy, medicine and cabbalism.8\nDee's last published treatise was the Mathematicall Preface to Henry\nBillingsley's translation of Euclid's Principles of Geometry (1570). Although\nthis essay has not been related to alchemy by Dee's scholars, nonetheless,\nitmay have been an additional influence on Maier, Khunrath and Fludd.\nIn the Mathematicall Preface Dee examined Pythagorean geometry in its]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11\nillustration this discursive visual mode provided a demonstrative proof of\nalchemical claims that matter could be united with its opposite, spirit, in\nthe philosopher's stone. In Khunrath's image, however, there was more\nat stake, as will be discussed, for he employed this spatial rhetoric of the\ndivine presence in order to authenticate his pietistic alchemical theosophy.\nIt was Khunrath, in fact, who produced a fully-developed cabbalistic\n\"alchemy of light\" in three of his works, published as the Amphiteatrum\nSapientiae Aeternae (1595; 1609), Chaos (circa 1598) and De Igne Magorum\n(circa 1602-1604). For his cabbalistic ideas Khunrath relied on Johannes\nReuchlin in De verbo mirifico (1494) and De arte cabbalistica (1517), as well as\non Paracelsian theosophy. The central Jewish cabbalistic text, the Zohar,\nhad derived its metaphysical concepts from neoplatonism, specifically\nfrom Plotinus' account of the manner in which the divine light of the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nthis as being a poetic expression of some vague mystical experience, or a\nflowery literary convention. Debus is one of the few to have discussed this\nParacelsian metaphysics of light in his extensive studies of Fludd's alchemy.3 More recently, Clulee has examined the natural philosophy ofthe\nElizabethan theurgist, John Dee (1527-1609), noting, in particular, Dee's\nuse ofscholastic optical theory in the astronomical magic ofhis Propaedeumata Aphoristica (1558). Clulee, however, did not relate Dee's astral theurgy to alchemy, nor to theosophy, since he did not consider Dee to be a\nParacelsian, although he acknowledged the innovatory significance of\nDee's cabbalism in his later alchemical treatise, the Monas Hieroglyphica\n(1564). Few other scholars have examined critically the references to\ncelestial light in late Renaissance alchemical texts and illustrations and\nmajor alchemists of the period, such as Khunrath and Maier, still await a\ndefinitive study.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=44\nPages: 44\ncabbalism, Dee perceived distinct benefits for alchemy, ensuring precision in correlating the effects of the heavens with the chemical process.\nYet, in the Monas Hieroglyphica there is relatively little mention of specific\nchemistry. Instead, Dee uses the planetary rays to perform his alchemical\noperations, defining his method as being an astronomical alchemy. In\nthis idea he was clearly influenced by Paracelsus' gnosticism in the\nAstronomia Magna, as well as by his theory of the illuminated imagination\nin the astral body communicating with the celestial macrocosm. It is\nessential to note that the graphic form of Dee's Monas (figs. 17, 18)\ndiffers entirely from the diagrammatic plans of astronomical star-charts,\nor of Lullian figures (figs. 4-7).17\nDee's Monas arose out ofthe context ofthe sixteenth century interest\nin devising secret cyphers which would act as an indexical bond between\nthe heavenly and the human spheres. 18 According to Szonyi, Ficino's]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=59\nPages: 59\nto be a theologian in the oratory and an alchemist in the laboratory.\nThrough-out his writings, Khunrath refers to the necessity of prayer and\nwork (f. Aiijr). This axiom is his \"leit-motif\", as it was that ofJohn Dee.23\nIn fact, de Vries' emblem is the summation of Khunrath's alchemy of\nlight.\nThe Chaos is dedicated to Pico della Mirandola and, due partly to his\ninfluence, Khunrath produces the first developed exposition of his cabbalistic alchemy. In particular, he discusses the sephiroth on the Tree of\nLife, specifically, \"RUAH-HHOCHMAH-EL\", which is the second sephiroth ofDivine Wisdom on the right axis of the Tree. Khunrath interprets \"Hochmah\" as the Divine Light of God illuminating both nature\nand the human intellect. He relates it to the alchemical \"celum\" or quintessence, as well as to the cabbalistic \"Schamaim\", which is the material\nused for the creation of the world. This is a topic which he develops\nfurther in the second version of the Amphiteatrum (Hanover, 1609). This]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=47\nPages: 47\nsympathetic magic which would eliminate, at a stroke, the confusions in\ntraditional alchemical discourse.\nAnother natural philosopher who located Dee's optics within a Paracelsian context was the alchemist and cosmologist Nicholas Hill who had\noriginally been a member of the retinue of Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland where he would have encountered the direct legacy ofDee's\ninfluence, as well as the optical interests ofthat circle. In his Philosophia\nEpicurea (Paris, 1601), Hill discussed the astral influences transmitted by\nlight -rays, relating this effect to Paracelsian alchemy. He stated that the\nextraction of the elixir of life and the transmutation of metals were a\ndivine process equivalent to the emanation of the second person ofthe\nHoly Trinity from the Father. He believed that light was the impression\nof God in nature and that it gave both form and life to matter.42]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=44\nPages: 44\nthe heavenly and the human spheres. 18 According to Szonyi, Ficino's\ntalismanic models in De Triplic Vitae were a direct source for Dee's Monas\nand his concept of an astronomical alchemy. Szonyi has indicated the\nsimilarity between Ficino's and Dee's astral magic, in particular, their\nconcept ofthe seven planets being grouped in two distinct families, thus,\nenabling the play of conjunctions and oppositions between the various\nmembers of the two alliances. There are also, as Szonyi demonstrates,\ncorrespondences between the numerology employed by Ficino in his\ncommentary on Book VII of Plato's Republic and Dee's geometrical\nnumerology in the Monas Hieroglyphica. Ficino's deployment of the concepts of squaring and triangulating planetary influences also re-appears\nin Dee's cabbalistic system. Moreover, Dee, like Ficino, uses the numer-\n14 For Dee's sources see R&W Reuchlin 1043, B25; Postel 1619, 1622, 1623, D18;]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=41\nPages: 41\nphilosophical context in the early sixteenth century. The distant ancestor\nof both the Paracelsian chemical cosmogony of the aerial fire and that of\nthe cabbalistic divine light is to be found in late hellenistic esotericism.\nThe present study will analyse the manner in which the cabbalah, specifically the cosmogenical account in the Zohar, provided a theologicaljustification for an \"alchemy of light\" through its vision ofthe world's emanation from God by means of his divine will, \"Kav\", in the form ofa beam\noflight.\nKnowledge of cabbalistic texts was dispersed through-out Europe on\nthe expulsion ofthe Jews from Spain in 1492. A Christian version ofthe\ncabbalah was devised by Giovanni Pico della Mirandola (1463-1494) in\nhis Nine Hundred Theses (1496), which provided the model for the more\ndetailed version ofthe German humanist Johannes Reuchlin (1455-1522)\nin De Verbo Mirifico (1494) and De Arte Cabbalistica (1517). In the early]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* John Dee's work is heavily influenced by the Cabbalah, which he integrated into his alchemical theories. Dee's alchemy of light blends alchemical and astronomical principles with cabbalistic theosophy, utilizing divine light as a central force for both creation and transformation. Key points about Dee's use of the Cabbalah and alchemy of light include: 1. Cabbalistic Origins: Dee drew from the Christianized version of the Cabbalah, which had been introduced into Western philosophy by figures like Pico della Mirandola and Johannes Reuchlin. The Cabbalah's vision of the world emanating from God through divine light provided a theological framework for Dee's alchemical theories: > "The present study will analyse the manner in which the cabbalah, specifically the cosmogenical account in the Zohar, provided a theological justification for an 'alchemy of light' through its vision of the world's emanation from God by means of his divine will, 'Kav,' in the form of a beam of light." [Urszula Szul, page 41](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=41). 2. Dee's Monas Hieroglyphica: Dee's *Monas Hieroglyphica* (1564) combines Cabbalistic, alchemical, and astrological concepts. It emphasizes the relationship between the macrocosm and microcosm, using symbols to represent both the material and spiritual transformation that can be achieved through alchemy. The Monas is an emblematic condensation of Dee's entire alchemical philosophy: > "Dee uses the planetary rays to perform his alchemical operations, defining his method as being an astronomical alchemy." [Urszula Szul, page 44](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=44). 3. Cabbalistic Graphology: Dee applied cabbalistic graphology in his alchemical work, using letters and symbols to represent divine forces. This semiotic approach allowed Dee to demonstrate his pantheistic views on the relationship between the celestial and earthly realms: > "Dee is inferring the use of cabbalistic graphology... his more limited pantheism concerning the relation of microcosm to macrocosm." [Urszula Szul, page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45). For more details on how Dee integrated cabbalistic and alchemical ideas, you can explore further on [pages 41-45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=41).
You
graphology
Tool
{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45\nPages: 45,46\n20 R&W: 1437, D16 (British Library Shelf-mark 1033. h. 1(2)).\n21 Michael Walton, \"Geometrical Cabala\", Ambix (1976): 116-23; Clulee, pp. 89-95,\nquotes from pp. 105-6.\n22Josten, pp. 162-63.\n23 Josten, pp. 163, 165.\n2425 Josten, pp. 162-63.\nJosten, pp . 103-4, 107-8.\n26 Josten,\n. 107-8.\n27 Josten, pp\npp. 177-79.\n64\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nDee is inferring the use of cabbalistic graphology.\nYet in the hands of learned men and literati there resides yet a stronger and\nmore unfailing motive for shaping these letters ... I at least advise and urge\nthem to elicit more carefully now what was the fire of Aries of the first\ntriplicity, what our equinoctial , [and] who was responsible for allowing the\nSun to be raised to exaltation above its ordinary grade.28\nEarlier alchemy had occasionally played such games of visual semiotics,\nbut never with such economy and precision. In fact, the Monas is a type\nof emblem, a poetical conceit, a condensation of a discursive text into a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=109\nPages: 109,110\nand Kegan Paul, 1987.\n192\nBIBLIOGRAPHY\nFrick, Karl R. H, Die Erleuchteten. Gnostische-theosophische und alchemistisch-rosenkeuzerische Geheimgesellschaften, Graz: Akademische Druk, 1973.\nGarin, Eugenio, Lo zodiaco della vita: La polemica sull'astrologia dal Trecento al Cinquecento, Rome; Bari, 1976.\nGarin, Eugenio, Astrology in the Renaissance: the Zodiac ofLife, London, 1983. Translated by Carolyn Jackson et al.\nGeissmar, Christoph, Das Auge Gottes Bilder zu Jakob Boehme (Wolfenbuttler Arbeiten\nzur Barockforschung, 23), Wiesbaden: Herzog August Bibliothek, 23, 1993.\nGibson, Walter S., Hieronymous Bosch, London: Thames and Hudson, 1973.\nGiehlow, Karl, \"Die Hieroglyphenkunde des Humanismus in der Allegorie der\nRenaissance\" in Jahrbuch der Kunsthistorisches Sammlungen der Allerhochsten Kaiserhauses, 32 (1915); 1-232.\nGilly, Carlos, \"Iter Rosicrucianum. Auf der Suche nach unbekkanten Quellen]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=48\nPages: 48,49\n69\n48 Lawrence C. Witten II and Richard Pachella (eds), Alchemy and the Occult. The Collection ofPaul and Mary Mellon, 3, (New Haven: Yale U.P, 1977), pp. 333-36, esp p. 335.\n49 Iam grateful to Professor R. I. McCallum ofEdinburghfordrawing myattention to\nthis engraving.\nCHAPTER SIX\nJOHN DEE'S CONCEPTUAL ARCHITECTURE AND\n\"ZOGRAPHIE\" IN AN ALCHEMICAL CONTEXT\nDee's Mathematicall Preface, written to accompany Henry Billingsley's\ntranslation of Euclid (1570), had a special relevance for illustrators of\nalchemical texts, due to his references to an esoteric drawing-practice\ncalled \"zographie\". This was a Pythagorean-based, geometrical system\nwhich had theurgical implications. Although Dee had composed the\nMathematicall Preface primarily with a practical intention, he could not\nhelp but hint at another, more profound, wisdom which he termed\n\"Archemastrie\", thereby alluding to theurgy, alchemy and prognostication.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52\nthe corresponding planetary influences. In other words , a painting could\nbecome a magical talisman, or a catoptrical mirror, registering and enhancing the celestial virtues. Dee's theory of drawing had revolutionary\nimplications for alchemical illustrators, for example, Michelspacher'sfour\nmirrors in the Cabala (1615-16) may well have originated in Dee's ideas of\na graphic theurgy.\nContextualised within Dee's Euclidean optical and alchemical system,\nthe semiotic function of single-point, spatial geometry is essentially the\nsame as that ofhis Monas Hieroglyphica, since they both have a metonymic\nrelationship with the physical world. As a sign in its own right, the Pythagorean-based system ofdrawing was reified by Dee to become a signifying mode which operated within real physical space, not only in that of\nthe painting. The Pythagorean ratios used in the single-point system were\nregarded by Dee as being capable of attracting celestial influences and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=17\nPages: 17\nmost obvious contrast is the developed graphic repertoire of the late\nsixteenth century with its heightened degree of naturalism. In addition,\nthe increased sensitivity of the late Renaissance artist to the topography\nof the picture-plane enabled him to weave together naturalistic and geometrical elements into a visually and conceptually coherent field. Michelspacher's artist, for example , splits the two-dimensional surface of the\npicture-plane into layers of realistic and abstract form, uniting them by\nmeans of perspectival geometry. This meant that the picture could be\nread simultaneously at both the representational and the abstract level, as\nif the viewer was being presented with a vision of the numinous Being\nimplicated within the gross fabric ofthe natural world. In the Paracelsian\ncontext ofKhunrath's and Fludd's alchemical imagery, this compositional structure expressed the essence of their theosophy in which the physical world was the emanation of the celestial spheres.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=135\nPages: 135\n175-76, 178; music, 158-59, 172-173;\n56, 60- 61, 66-67; perspective drawing,\n73-74, 75-76, 125-25, 135; Propaedeumata optics and catoptrics, 101, 169-71, 173,\n177-78; Paracelsian influences, 41, 46,\nAphoristica, xii, xiv, 6, 29, 35, 37-40, 43,\n49, 60, 76, 126, 135, 158, 164, 172;\n154, 167, 169-72, 177; Medicina Catholica,\nsemiotics of emblems, 1, 4, 6, 9, 60-65,\n31, 93, 94, 178-79; Philosophia Moysaica,\n170, 178; Philosophia Sacra, 34, 59, 93,\n67, 77, see Szonyi; theurgy, 5 , 33, 37-39,\n159; Rosicrucian sympathies, xviii, 58,\n45-46, 49, 53, 55-56, 60, 61-62, 71, 76,\n111, 126, 158, 183, see Clucas, Clulee,\n84, 152, 168, 178; sun, 167, 170-71, 17578; Tractatus de Tritico, 170; Tractatus\nSzonyi164; zographie, xv, 71, 76-78, 126,\nCosmi\n135,\nTheologo-philosophicus, 169; Utriusque\n34, 59, 152, 154, 158-59, 163... Historia,\ndeJong, Helena M. E., 159, 160, 162, 163\n64, 168-78\ndella Francesca, Piero, 72\ndella Porta, Giambattista, 67-68, 99, 101, Fortunatus (of Padua), 67\n119]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=22\nPages: 22,23\n18 Gordon Leff, Paris and Oxford Universities in the 13th-C and 14 th-C (New York, 1968).\n19 Obrist, figs. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 11.\n17\n18\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nwith the sacred visions of the saints. In this manner, the alchemists\nmoved their theories from the ground of scholastic debate to that ofthe\nunquestionable truths of the Christian faith.20\nAnother major development in alchemical visual imagery took place\nin the early fifteenth century when a complex geometry intended as a\npractical device was created by pseudo-Lullian alchemists. These were a\ngroup of anonymous writers working under the name of the Catalan\nmystic Ramon Lull, although he had not accepted the claims of alchemy\nand had never discussed the subject. Regardless of this fact in the late\nfourteenth century the first unillustrated text appeared under his name in\nCatalonia. Transported to Northern Italy, the older texts were translated\nfrom the vernacular into Latin and new ones were produced, with the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=82\nPages: 82\nalso promote the spatial illusionism. Consequently, these various graphic\ndevices seem to indicate that the image should be viewed with the aid of\nan optical lens, such as a magnifying glass, or by means of a double\nreflection in two mirrors, or by a combination of mirrors and lenses.\nWhen it is viewed through a convex lens, the graphic exaggerations drop\nback and cease to intrude on the visual logic of the scene, for the depth\nofthe hall diminishes and the floor appears less raked. In particular, the\nspace around the table and the fire-place becomes \"real\" and the furniture stands-up, away from the background.\nBy the eighteenth-century there existed an apparatus known as the\n\"Vue d'Optique\" consisting of an arrangement of mirrors and lenses\nused to reflect the image of an engraving to a viewer, usually of an\narchitectural scene whose three- dimensional quality was thereby greatly\nenhanced.53Engravings intended to be viewed by means of the \"Vue d']","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=77\nPages: 77\nthe Propaedeumata Aphoristica and to the theurgic cypher of the Monas\nHieroglyphica. Dee's account of \"zographie\" in the Mathematicall Preface\nimplied that a graphic system based on Pythagorean geometry would act\nas a theurgic talisman absorbing the celestial virtues. Dee's theories\nwould resonate with Khunrath's own Agrippan influences, as well as with\nhis Paracelsian theosophy in which Christ-Anthropos operated through\nthe light of\"Hochmah\" to pervade the universe. Khunrath's engravings\nwere, thus, spiritual catoptrical mirrors, reflecting the light of Eternal\nWisdom to the mind of the viewer.\nAccording to Szonyi, architectural motifs in mystical imagery are cosmograms in which the buildings and their ground-plans signify the construction of the cosmos, producing a revelation in the viewer's mind'\nconcerning the fabric of reality. Szonyi has, however, distinguished such\ncosmograms from the use of similar architectural motifs in alchemical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=51\nPages: 51,52\n15 Szonyiillustration.\nalchemical\n74\n75\nCHAPTER SIX\nJOHN DEE'S CONCEPTUAL ARCHITECTURE\naccording to \"the Arte of Perspective\" (f. ciiijr). Dee contextualised this\ntype of graphic design within hermeticism, commending Agrippa's De\nOcculta Philosophia which depicted the human-body as a model of the\nPythagorean cosmic order.\nDee was implying that the application of the single-point perspective\nsystem, whether to the human-figure, or to architectural space, served to\nalign the human-being with the macrocosm. Thus, Pythagorean geometry not only had an intellectual and aesthetic role in the art of drawing,\nbut also a spiritual and magical function. Hence, Dee's account of\"Zographie\" prioritises its conceptual and spiritual aspects (f. dijv), the physical application of paint, in contrast, being demoted to a mechanical artform.\nZographie [is] the Scholemaster of Picture, and chief gouernor\n(f. dijv)\nAmong the true \"Zographers\", Dee included the art-theorists Giorgio]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=64\nPages: 64\nmystical geometry is related to that of Michelspacher's first engraving\nentitled \"Der Spigel der Kunst und Natur\" which shows two geometrical\ndiagrams, the one on the left having the same configuration as thefourth\nengraving, that of circle, square and triangle (fig. 24b). In the first engraving this diagram is stated to be an image of the \"Azoth\", another\nWeigelian and Khunradian allusion to Christ. Thus, Michelspacher's\nadheres to Khunrath's Weigelian polemic in which union with the innate\nChrist as the philosopher's stone was attained through the inspiration of\nthe Holy Spirit. Michelspacher located Khunrath's alchemical Christologywithin a Rosicrucian context, for his treatise is specifically dedicated to\nthe Rosy Cross Fraternity.\nIn Michelspacher's \"Fountain of Life\" the lines of flight ofthe Holy\nSpirit were similar to the catoptrical refraction of light-rays by thesurface\nof a mirror. Comparable imagery of the refraction of light-rays is found]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=19\nPages: 19,20\nII\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY IN LATE MEDIEVAL\nAND EARLY RENAISSANCE ALCHEMY\nAlchemical geometry in the Renaissance can be described as passive or\noperative, either using geometrical structures to organise information\ninto tabulations, circular formats or tree-like structures, or, as in the case\nofpseudo-Lullian alchemy, employing a mobile computational system.\nAnother, more complex, type of alchemical geometry emerged in the late\nsixteenth century, based on optical and perspectival diagrams which inter-related Pythagorean geometry, optical science, Paracelsian alchemy\nand cabbalism.\nBy the fifteenth century, European alchemists had several goals,\nnamely, chemical work on matter to remove its impurities, spiritual work\nto redeem their own souls and, finally, a practical medical purpose.3\nFrom the late fourteenth century they were also attempting to develop a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nresults to regard visual and verbal signs as autonomous dialects of the\nsame language, thus requiring different critical approaches. It was Panofsky who first argued for a new type of analytical tool for the study of\nvisual imagery which would be distinct from that ofliterary scholarship.\nHis iconological method involved an examination of the historical context in which a visual sign had appeared, for it was this which had determined the style of its depiction. As Szonyi has demonstrated in his study\nof Agrippa's and Dee's esoteric emblems, Panofsky's method is one ofthe\nfew able to accomodate the complexity of a visual signing-system. Szonyi\nalso continues to favour the historiographical approach of Gombrich,\nwhich has the added advantage of taking into account the psychological\neffects ofthe rhetoric deployed by a visual sign.\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=85\nPages: 85\nChristly \"gnosis\", informing the monstrous group of Lutherans and demonic black-magicians that, no matter whether they esteem, or disparage, him, he will simply continue to pray. He carries a pair ofgeometrical dividers, such as those which appear in the later portrait of Khunrath\nin 1604, with which he is drawing the diagrammatic icon of Christ. In\nthe 1602 engraving, therefore, the scholar may also be Khunrath, his\ndividers signifying the sacred geometry of his theosophical system. With\nthese he pins a serpent to the ground, demonstrating that the wisdom\ninspired by the Holy Spirit conquers sophistry, symbolised by the snake\nwith its \"lingua venona\", whose spurious reasoning in the Garden of\nEden had originally distanced humanity from God's grace.\nMeanwhile, the other character on the right, pays no attention at all\nto his stressful companions, for he is gazing into the cave in the centre of\nthe picture, which is yet another depiction ofAbraham's mountain ofthe]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10\nIn the Mathematicall Preface Dee examined Pythagorean geometry in its\npractical and mystical aspects, although he did not relate his text to\nalchemy at any length, mentioning only briefly a practice called \"Archemastrie\" which comprised alchemy and other magical arts (Math. Pref.\nf. Aiijr). In addition, another of his concepts in this treatise, that of\"zographie\", could have had a special effect on alchemical illustration (Math.\nPref. f. dijv). \"Zographie\" was a Pythagorean-based method of graphic\ndepiction which Dee regarded as a conceptual art-form with a high philosophical status, since the \"zographer\" drew only the forms ofthe eternal\nIdeas in the mind of God, rather than their base natural copies. Most\nsignificant for the present argument was Dee's inclusion of the singlepoint perspective system within the scope of \"zographie\".]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=82\nPages: 82\nenhanced.53Engravings intended to be viewed by means of the \"Vue d'\nOptique\" depict a long depth-of-field, as well as strong contrasts oflight\nand shadow in the foreground. Thus, by means of catoptrics de Vries\ncould have been attempting to produce an unbroken spatial (indexical)\ncontinuum between the physical world and the illustration. For that very\npurpose Alberti in his De Pictura (1435) had originally introduced the\ndevice of single-point space into painting, in order to blur the division\nbetween imagination and reality. Alberti's spatial geometry was primarily\na rhetorical device designed to slip a message effortlessly pastthe viewer's\nobjective judgement. According to Obrist, the medieval alchemists had\nprovided visual depictions oftheir ideas with the same intention of confusing the viewer's sense of reality.54 Paracelsus had also considered the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=111\nPages: 111\nthe Royal Society ofMedicine, 21 (1928): 41-57.\nStoeffler, F. Erb.\nSzonyi, Gyorgy E., \" O Worke Divine\": The Iconography and Intellectual\nBackground ofAlma's House in The Faerie Queens\", Shakespeare and the Emblem.\nStudies in Renaissance Iconography and Iconology, (Papers in English and American\nStudies, 3), Szeged, 1984, pp. 353-94.\nSzonyi, Gyorgy E., \"The Powerful Image: Towards a Typology of Occult Symbolism\", European Iconography East and West, Leiden: Brill, 1996, pp. 250-63.\nEdited by Gyorgy E. The pseudoLullians, similarly, appropriated the Lullian tabulations which had recorded the computations of the letters of the alphabet and they also\nemployed Lullian tree diagrams. The alphabet performed a symbolic\nfunction representing the various objects of discourse, a device which\nLull had encountered in the cabbalistic alphabets of Abraham Abulafia\nin thirteenth century Spain.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=51\nPages: 51,52\nWherupon, he is neither Smith, nor Builder: nor , separately, any Artificer\n(f. diiijr)\nThe lofty intellectual and spiritual stature awarded by Dee to architecture may have had important consequences for alchemical illustration\nin the early seventeenth century.\"15 In many late sixteenth and early\nseventeenth century alchemical engravings the artists used motifs from\nthe classical canon to signify the higher ontological levels of the cosmos\n(frontispiece and fig. 41).\nDee placed great emphasis on the intellectual status of drawing,\nwhether in relation to architecture, or in the depiction of the human\nfigure. He invented a special name for idealised figure-drawing which he\ncalled \"anthropographie\", involving the depiction of human proportions\n13 F. M. Lund, Ad Quadratum (London, 1921); Kubovy (1986), pp. 17-31.\n14 Yates (1969), pp. 112-35.\n(1998) presents a related argument on the role of architecture in 17th-C\n15 Szonyiillustration.\nalchemical\n74\n75\nCHAPTER SIX]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=22\nPages: 22\nthe \"lingua franca\" of European science and art. This mystical ideology\nwas a major constituent of the liberal arts\ncurriculum, lying uneasily\nalongside Aristotelian natural philosophy.18\nHowever, it was not until the late fourteenth and early fifteenth centuries that the conceptual influence of Pythagorean geometry could be discerned in an alchemical context. It made its first appearance in a novel\ntype of alchemical imagery in the late fourteenth century, far more complex than earlier hellenistic and Arabic graphic cyphers since the new\nillustrations involved a whole sequence of pictorial imagery. In addition\nto figurative and narrative elements, the visual forms also involved geometrical schemes, though they lacked finesse in design and graphic skill.\nSuch crude geometries, accompanying equally rough symbolic figures,\nare first encountered in the untitled alchemical treatise of Gratheus and\nin another work by the alchemist Constantinus, Le livre des secrets de ma]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* John Dees use of graphology is tied closely to his alchemical and mystical practices. Specifically, Dees cabbalistic graphology played a role in his integration of symbols, letters, and geometrical figures into alchemical operations. Key points include: 1. Cabbalistic Graphology in Alchemy: Dee utilized cabbalistic graphology to symbolically represent the cosmic forces at play in alchemical transmutations. His emphasis on letters, signs, and geometrical forms reflected his belief that they were not just representations but held actual power: > Dee is inferring the use of cabbalistic graphology... as signs that act as vehicles for divine power. [Urszula Szul, page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45). 2. The Role of Signs in the Monas Hieroglyphica: Dee's *Monas Hieroglyphica* employed a complex system of graphological symbols and signs, blending cabbalistic and alchemical traditions to form a unified esoteric language. These symbols served not only as illustrations but were meant to be active forces in the alchemical process, influencing both the material world and spiritual realms: > Earlier alchemy had occasionally played such games of visual semiotics, but never with such economy and precision. In fact, the *Monas* is a type of emblem, a poetical conceit, a condensation of a discursive text into a graphical form. [Urszula Szul, page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45). 3. Graphology as a Semiotic Tool: The signs Dee used were not merely illustrations but were understood as semiotic tools that could convey deeper philosophical meanings. Dee's graphical system tied into the cabbalistic belief that letters and symbols were keys to unlocking divine knowledge: > Dee's graphology ties into the belief that letters and symbols can unlock deeper spiritual truths. [Urszula Szul, page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45). You can explore more on the topic by visiting [page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45). Let me know if you would like to continue exploring this concept or need further assistance!

role of signs

{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=14\nPages: 14\nillustration. Since it is not possible to examine all the major alchemists of\nthe late Renaissance, the discussion will be confined to the cabbalistic\nmetaphysics and optical alchemy of four central figures, those of Dee,\nKhunrath, Maier and Fludd.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE\nALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nPrevious studies of Renaissance alchemical imagery have rarely involved\na discussion of its semiotic aspects, yet, without such an analysis it is\ndifficult to establish the exact role ofvisual illustration within a particular\ncontext. In the present case-studies, a variety of analytical tools is used\ndrawn from linguistics, structuralism and post-structuralism, such an eclectic approach being justified in the current state of research. For the\nimmediate objective, the most effective model has proved to be Peirce's\ntaxonomy of three fundamental types of sign, namely, those of symbol,\nicon and index. In addition, other types of analysis have been sampled,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=46\nPages: 46\nthe fact that Renaissance emblems are figural, whereas Dee's Monas is\ndiagrammatic, but in their distinctive semiotic functions. Horapollo's\nsigns operate as metaphors or symbols, that is, the visual signifier rarely\nmirrors its conceptual content. Consequently, most of his imagery could\nnot be decoded without the explanatory text. Renaissance emblems were\nintended to be a cryptic language, decipherable only by members ofelite\ncircles. The emblem's often bizarre components were an attempt to\ntranspose a verbal phrase into its equivalent visual elements, since this\nwas thought to be the authentic mode of the ancient Egyptians.32\nIn contrast, Dee's Monas was intended to be an index and, in this\nfunction, it was probably unique among Renaissance emblems, since it\nnot only symbolised the process of transmutation, but displayed that\nprocess in its very form. In other words, Dee believed that the form ofhis\nMonas was identical to its physical referent, for, as the alchemist worked]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16,15\nsigns, on the model of the Hebrew alphabet, as an essential part oftheir\n3 Peirce, 2, pp. 170, 172-73.\n4 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n5 Carl GustavJung, Psychology and Alchemy (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1993),\npp. 26, 112, 152ff, 158, 196.\n6 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n7 For example, Allison Coudert, Alchemy: the philosopher's stone (London: Wildwood\nHouse, 1980). Otherwise, this is an authoritative general study.\n8 Erwin Panofsky, Studies in Iconology (New York: Harper, 1962).\n9 Szonyi (1996), pp. 250-53.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nmagical rituals.10These experiments with cryptography yielded few convincing results, since the linguistic signs of European languages are arbitrary phonetic symbols and, hence, cannot mirror their conceptual representant in the manner of visual signs. Consequently, it is essential that\nscholars of alchemical imagery distinguish between the literary and the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nappearance of any visual sign change both its meaning and function. In\nfact, Peirce devised a taxonomy of hybrid signs to describe the vacillations of such unstable significatory orders.\nFollowing his general approach, the present author would make only\none proposition which is that many late Renaissance alchemical signs\nincline towards the indexical mode. In other words, alchemical visual\nsemiosis from the late sixteenth century is deliberately \" contaminated\"\nnot, as Jung believed, by the collective unconscious of a society,5 but by\nthe viewer's imminent physical reality. Thus, the alchemical imagery\nunder present consideration does not merely copy, it also restructures the\nphysical world by forcing a continuum between the viewer's space and\nthat of the picture.\nPeirce defined the index as\nA sign, or representation, which refers to its object not so much because of\nany similarity or analogy with it, nor because it is associated with general]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=42\nPages: 42\nvery form of this sign was said to resemble that of a flame. Hence, the\ncabbalah was offering at its core a metonymic linguistic sign which was\nnot transposable to the Latin alphabet. The similarity in the appearance\nof other Hebrew linguistic significators to their referent fascinated European cabbalists. Thus, in the context of the Renaissance epistemological\ncrisis described by Foucault, the analogical potential of the Hebrew alphabet satisfied the intellectual and emotional need for a signifying mode\nwhich would close the increasing conceptual divide between linguistic\nforms and the physical world. Consequently, the psychological situation\ndemanded a substitute analogical system which was provided bythe cabbalah. As the divine text of God in nature was erased by the epistemic\nchanges wrought by proto-capitalism in northern Europe, so the yearning\nto recover God's primal words of creation intensified.\n2 Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa, Opera, 2 vols (London, 1600: Hildesheim; New York:]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nwas that which guaranteed their authenticity. Similitude was judged in\nthe terms of adjacency (\"convenientia\"), analogy (\"aemulatio\") and sympathy (\"concordia\"). This taxonomy was inscribed within the universe in\nthe form of signs, decipherable only by an elite of natural philosophers.\nAs Foucault points out, in the sixteenth century no distinction was made\nbetween the empirical observations ofthe natural philosophers and those\noftheologians, or occultists. All of these systems of knowledge were dependent on their ability to read the inscriptions which already pre-existed\nin the forms of the world. Foucault argues that Renaissance signs were\norganised into a conceptual structure consisting of three qualities which\nwere the marks of the sign, the things designated by those marks and the\nsimilitude between them. Since it was \"aemulatio\" which constituted\nboth the form and the content of the sign, these three elements operated]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",\nwhereby it delivers all of its information to the interpretant synchronically. Hence, it requires a broader range of semiotic strategies to correlate\nthe various paradigmatic levels of meaning. The written text, in contrast,\nis deciphered by the reader in a diachronic sequence and, hence, it is far\nmore dictatorial towards its interpretant than the visual artefact. Consequently, alchemical illustrators , like other Renaissance artists, capitalised\non thefactthat the synchronic reading of a visual text caused ambiguities\nto arise in the reception of its meaning. An additional semiotic difference\nbetween visual and literary texts is that visual imagery may be symbolic,\niconic or indexical, but most literary texts can only be symbolic. It is rare,\nin fact, to encounter a linguistic metonymic or indexical structure, although the compilers ofRenaissance grimoires struggled to produce such]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nboth the form and the content of the sign, these three elements operated\nas a single figure. Foucault's contention is that in the seventeenth century\nthis triple construction of a sign became a binary in which a signifier\n(\"significans\") was connected to a significance (\"significandum\"), abandoning the quality of similitude.26\nFoucault's argument provides one explanation for the intensity ofthe\nlate Renaissance search for the \"lingua Adamica\" through the devices of\nmagical cryptography. The issue of the Adamic language has been discussed by Szonyi in his study of the influence of Paracelsian talismanic\nlinguistics on Dee's theurgy. (Dee had certainly procured two copies of\nParacelsus Expositio magicarum figurarum). In contrast to the characterisa-\n44\n18 Pagel (1982), pp.71-76; Allen G. Debus, \"Mathematics and Nature in the Chemical\nTexts ofthe Renaissance\", Ambix (1968): 1-28; Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \"\n(1979), pp. 59, 65-66]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21\nPages: 21\ninsusceptible to the corrupting effects of natural transmutation.\nAstrology was an essential component of alchemical practice since\nalchemy, as a mirror of nature, was similarly affected by stellar influences. The medieval Jewish cabbalistic text, the Zohar, also stressed the necessity of watching the activity of the heavens in order to understand the\ncourse ofhuman affairs.10 The medieval alchemists, especially the pseudo-Lullians of the fifteenth century, emphasised the need to correlate\ntheir chemical\nwork with the motions of the planets and the signs ofthe\nZodiac.11 By the early sixteenth century, Paracelsus was teaching that the\nefficacy of alchemical medications was totally dependent on their concordance with the healing virtues emanating from the stars.12\nThe inter-dependency and unity between macrocosm and microcosm\nhad been summarised in the late Alexandrian text of the Emerald Table]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=47\nPages: 47\nDee probably ends, since Dorn's geometry contrasts with Dee's in several\nimportant respects. The prime difference is that Dorn's structures are\nconventional Euclidean symbols, rather than hieroglyphs, nor does he\nemploy cabbalism. Thus, in semiotic terms Dorn's geometrical signs do\nnot reify their conceptual content, functioning instead as a metaphorical\nsystem which represents practical alchemy by means of abstract signifiers.\nThere is a closer comparison between Dorn's system and that of other\nmetaphysical geometers in the early seventeenth century, such as Fortunatus of Padua who used Euclidean theorems to prove the truth ofthe\nChristian faith.41 In contrast, Dee believed that the operation of his\nMonas was contiguous with reality (a metonymic, or indexical relationship), asserting that the manipulation of the Monas was practical alchemy, rather than its symbolic substitute. By means of the universal language of cabbalism, Dee thought that he had created a uniquely potent]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=30\nPages: 30,31\nTriplici Vitae libri tres (1978), for example, Bk III, Cap I, similitudes of the sun such as\nheliotrope, myrrh, amber, crocus. Ficino's works are found in Dee's collection see R&W:\n404, 736, 1124, 1282, B83, B120, B132, B141, B157, B177. Dee also had a copy ofFicino\nDe Triplici Vitae R&W 779, his translation ofPlotinus R&W: 108 and his Opera R&W: 204,\nas well as his Theologia Platonica R&W: 893.\n34\nCHAPTER THREE\nsign were regarded as being a physical reality. In the same way, Fludd's\ncabbalistic alchemy and medicine in his Philosophia Sacra (1626) relied for\nits effect on the reification of a metaphorical sequence in which the sun\nwas personified as the demiurge, the eye ofgod, the altar of Christ as the\ncabbalistic Messiah, as well as the primal medicine. Fludd's sun-based\nmedicine, like Ficino's astrological talismanic magic, was based on a semiotic fallacy concerning the ontological status of similitude within a sign.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52\nthe corresponding planetary influences. In other words , a painting could\nbecome a magical talisman, or a catoptrical mirror, registering and enhancing the celestial virtues. Dee's theory of drawing had revolutionary\nimplications for alchemical illustrators, for example, Michelspacher'sfour\nmirrors in the Cabala (1615-16) may well have originated in Dee's ideas of\na graphic theurgy.\nContextualised within Dee's Euclidean optical and alchemical system,\nthe semiotic function of single-point, spatial geometry is essentially the\nsame as that ofhis Monas Hieroglyphica, since they both have a metonymic\nrelationship with the physical world. As a sign in its own right, the Pythagorean-based system ofdrawing was reified by Dee to become a signifying mode which operated within real physical space, not only in that of\nthe painting. The Pythagorean ratios used in the single-point system were\nregarded by Dee as being capable of attracting celestial influences and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nresults to regard visual and verbal signs as autonomous dialects of the\nsame language, thus requiring different critical approaches. It was Panofsky who first argued for a new type of analytical tool for the study of\nvisual imagery which would be distinct from that ofliterary scholarship.\nHis iconological method involved an examination of the historical context in which a visual sign had appeared, for it was this which had determined the style of its depiction. As Szonyi has demonstrated in his study\nof Agrippa's and Dee's esoteric emblems, Panofsky's method is one ofthe\nfew able to accomodate the complexity of a visual signing-system. Szonyi\nalso continues to favour the historiographical approach of Gombrich,\nwhich has the added advantage of taking into account the psychological\neffects ofthe rhetoric deployed by a visual sign.\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45\nPages: 45\nThe four elements are the four straight lines emerging from the point.26\nDee explains that the two half circles at the bottom of the cross represent\nAries, or fire. Thus, the Monas contains the power of the three levels of\ncreation, corresponding to the cosmic alchemical egg, the prime matter\nwhich contains the All.27\nThe most elaborate Euclidean dissection ofthe Monas occurs in Theorem XXI in which the sign for the Monad is turned upside-down, permitting new relationships to be established between the Moon, Sun,Aries\nand the other planets (fig. 18). Dee implies that there exists an even more\nawe-inspiring relationship between the alchemical art offire, represented\nby the sign of Aries, and the astronomy of the Monas. In this instance,\n19 Szonyi forthcoming in Renaissance Quarterly. An analysis of Ficino's numerology is\nprovided by Allen (1994), pp. 106, 130-34, 138-42.\n20 R&W: 1437, D16 (British Library Shelf-mark 1033. h. 1(2)).]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=14\nPages: 14,15\nU. Szulakowska, \"Two Italian alchemical manuscripts: some philosophical problems:\nmonism and dualism\" in Didier Kahn, Sylvain Matton, Alchimie: art, histoire et mythes (Paris;\nMilan, 1995), pp. 249-63.\n2 Goldberg (1976).\n2\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nthe illusionistic world of the picture. In Peirce's semiotic system, he has\ndistinguished an indexical sign from a \"symbol\" , which has an arbitrary\nvisual appearance unrelated to its conceptual content and, therefore, can\nonly convey a meaning within a specific context for a particular interpretant. Peirce also differentiated an indexical sign from an \"icon\" which,\nhe stated, \"would possess the character which renders it significant, even\nthough its object had no existence\". According to this definition , it\nwould initially appear that most alchemical visual signs should be termed]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10,11\nXIV\nXV\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\nmodel can be amplified by taking additional recourse to Peirce's semiotic\ntaxonomy of three types ofsign, namely, those of symbol, icon and index.\nFirst, however, it is necessary to understand the original intentions behind the development of the single-point perspective system during the\nearly Renaissance.11\nThe geometrical theory of this spatial system was first expressed by\nLeone Battista Alberti in his treatise on painting, De Pictura (Florence,\n1435).12 He had explained that the orthogonal lines of any architecture\nillustrated by the artist should be drawn as if they were running into the\npicture to meet in a single vanishing-point. In accordance with this new\npictorial convention, in many fifteenth-century Florentine paintings ofan\ninterior scene the floor would be drawn in a chequer-board pattern to\nreinforce the same illusion of space receding to a vanishing-point. The]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10\nMirandola, like Ficino, integrated these practices with Christianity, butin\naddition he introduced the cabbalah into Renaissance hermeticism.6\nThe German natural philosopher and magus Cornelius Agrippa\n(1486-1533) popularised astral magic through his treatise, De Occulta\nPhilosophia (1533), justifying such practices by claiming the existence of a\nnatural sympathy between the human-being and the universe, an idea\nalready well-known to the middle ages. On the model of Agrippa, this\nvenerable notion of the harmony between celestial and human realms\nwas systematised for medical use by Paracelsus who created an analogical\nstructure known as the \"doctrine of signatures\". He taught that in all\nmaterial entities there existed hidden virtues whose qualities corresponded to those ofthe planetary bodies in the heavens. These occult virtues he\ncalled \"astra\" to designate the \"signatures\" (the impressions) of the stars\non matter. Paracelsus argued that, due to the intimate unity between]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nwould initially appear that most alchemical visual signs should be termed\n\"iconic\", since they signify irrational concepts such as the \"union of opposites\", for example, offire with water. While this identification may be\ncorrect in the case of pre-Renaissance alchemical visual signs which are\nnot particularly \"realistic\" in their style of drawing (figs . 9, 10), this is not\napplicable to alchemical illustration from the late sixteenth century onwards when an irrational idea may be represented by naturalistic human\nfigures, as in examples from Maier's Atalanta Fugiens (figs. 40, 41). In this\ncase, the realistic aesthetic of the Renaissance artist has started to transform an iconic signifier into an index. This issue has never been remarked by the few iconologists who have studied alchemical imagery,\nnonetheless, it is extremely important since stylistic differences in the\nappearance of any visual sign change both its meaning and function. In]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11\nreinforce the same illusion of space receding to a vanishing-point. The\ntechnical term for this pictorial effect was the \"pavimentum diminutionis\" (fig. 1).13\nAlberti had based his perspective system on the model of medieval\noptical diagrams which depicted the operation of light-rays in relation to\nthe human eye (figs . 2, 11). Hence, in the semiotic functioning of the\nsingle -point system, its geneology in medieval optics continues to operate\nas a sub-text. To use Derrida's terms, the original opticalgeometrywhich\nhad provided the structure for single-point space continued to exist within it as a signifying trace. 14 Derrida's \"trace\" (le trait) is the transcendental\nsignifier unifying the disparate (and conflicting) elements of a discourse. 15\nHence, the generic signifier of the single-point perspective system would\nbe the eye ofthe viewer and its discourse that of the struggle between the\nrhetorical devices ofthe picture and the objective judgement ofthe interpretant.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\n\"speculum\", a secondary meaning which the reader was undoubtedly\nintended to retrieve from the original title ofthe treatise. Hence, Khunrath's theatre of images, like a mirror, catoptrically reflects the celestial\nspheres to the human mind, awakening the empathetic faculty of the\nhuman spirit which unites, through the imagination, with the heavenly\nrealms. Thus, the visual imagery of Khunrath's treatises has become the\nalchemical quintessence, the spiritualised matter of the philosopher's\nstone, transmuting both the human soul and the physical world into gold.\nIt is evident that late Renaissance alchemists were involved in a radical semiotic enterprise, intuiting the possibility of devising a visual signing-system which would resolve the dualistic conflict of the European\nlinguistic sign in which signifier and signified were arbitrarily related.22\nAccordingly, John Dee regarded his Monas Hieroglyphica as a graphic\nsystem which was also practical chemistry (figs. 17, 18), a metonymic]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* the role of signs in Renaissance alchemical imagery is examined through the lens of semiotic analysis, particularly influenced by the work of Charles Sanders Peirce. Key points include: 1. Semiotic Structures in Alchemical Imagery: The study emphasizes that alchemical illustrations employed different types of signssymbols, icons, and indicesto convey both mystical and material knowledge. These visual signs did more than represent abstract concepts; they engaged with the viewer's reality, often creating a continuity between the physical and spiritual worlds: > Alchemical visual semiosis from the late sixteenth century is deliberately contaminated... by the viewer's imminent physical reality. Thus, the alchemical imagery... does not merely copy, it also restructures the physical world by forcing a continuum between the viewer's space and that of the picture. [Urszula Szul, page 15](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15). 2. Indexical Signs: In contrast to symbolic signs, indexical signs directly referenced the physical processes of alchemy. Dees *Monas Hieroglyphica*, for example, was not just a symbol of transformation; its form and structure were believed to directly influence the alchemical process itself: > In contrast, Dee's Monas was intended to be an index... it not only symbolised the process of transmutation, but displayed that process in its very form. [Urszula Szul, page 46](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=46). 3. Signs as Fields of Interpretation: Visual signs in alchemical illustrations operated as fields, allowing for multiple layers of interpretation simultaneously. This synchronic nature of visual signs, in contrast to the diachronic reading of texts, contributed to the ambiguity and richness of alchemical imagery: > The visual sign operates as a 'field', whereby it delivers all of its information to the interpretant synchronically... causing ambiguities to arise in the reception of its meaning. [Urszula Szul, page 15](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15). These signs played a crucial role in making alchemical knowledge both esoteric and accessible, reflecting the intersection of material, spiritual, and symbolic processes in Renaissance alchemical thought. For further details, see [page 15](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15) and [page 46](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=46).
You
graphology as semiotic tool
Tool
