I at least advise and urge\nthem to elicit more carefully now what was the fire of Aries of the first\ntriplicity, what our equinoctial , [and] who was responsible for allowing the\nSun to be raised to exaltation above its ordinary grade.28\nEarlier alchemy had occasionally played such games of visual semiotics,\nbut never with such economy and precision. In fact, the Monas is a type\nof emblem, a poetical conceit, a condensation of a discursive text into a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nresults to regard visual and verbal signs as autonomous dialects of the\nsame language, thus requiring different critical approaches. It was Panofsky who first argued for a new type of analytical tool for the study of\nvisual imagery which would be distinct from that ofliterary scholarship.\nHis iconological method involved an examination of the historical context in which a visual sign had appeared, for it was this which had determined the style of its depiction. As Szonyi has demonstrated in his study\nof Agrippa's and Dee's esoteric emblems, Panofsky's method is one ofthe\nfew able to accomodate the complexity of a visual signing-system. Szonyi\nalso continues to favour the historiographical approach of Gombrich,\nwhich has the added advantage of taking into account the psychological\neffects ofthe rhetoric deployed by a visual sign.\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=52\nPages: 52\nthe corresponding planetary influences. In other words , a painting could\nbecome a magical talisman, or a catoptrical mirror, registering and enhancing the celestial virtues. Dee's theory of drawing had revolutionary\nimplications for alchemical illustrators, for example, Michelspacher'sfour\nmirrors in the Cabala (1615-16) may well have originated in Dee's ideas of\na graphic theurgy.\nContextualised within Dee's Euclidean optical and alchemical system,\nthe semiotic function of single-point, spatial geometry is essentially the\nsame as that ofhis Monas Hieroglyphica, since they both have a metonymic\nrelationship with the physical world. As a sign in its own right, the Pythagorean-based system ofdrawing was reified by Dee to become a signifying mode which operated within real physical space, not only in that of\nthe painting. The Pythagorean ratios used in the single-point system were\nregarded by Dee as being capable of attracting celestial influences and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10\nIt should be noted that in 1595 there appeared in Khunrath's Amphiteatrum Sapientiae Aeternae (frontispiece) an illustration which employed exaggerated spatial effects. The peculiarly deep vista of this engraving ofan\nalchemist's Oratory-Laboratory involved far more than naturalistic illusionism, since the spatial geometry functioned as a semiotic system in its\nown right, discoursing on the alchemical significance of light-rays.\nAccording to Goldberg, fifteenth century Florentine painters such as\nMasaccio and Domenico Veneziano had used geometrical infrastructures, such as the one in Khunrath's treatise, both as an organisational\ndevice and as a signifying discourse (fig. 36).10 These graphic scaffoldings\nunderlay the painted scene, operating as a conceptual sub-text which\ndrew the viewer into a parallel metaphysical world. In order to clarify\nthis interpretation of Khunrath's image of the laboratory, Goldberg's]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=14\nPages: 14\nillustration. Since it is not possible to examine all the major alchemists of\nthe late Renaissance, the discussion will be confined to the cabbalistic\nmetaphysics and optical alchemy of four central figures, those of Dee,\nKhunrath, Maier and Fludd.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE\nALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nPrevious studies of Renaissance alchemical imagery have rarely involved\na discussion of its semiotic aspects, yet, without such an analysis it is\ndifficult to establish the exact role ofvisual illustration within a particular\ncontext. In the present case-studies, a variety of analytical tools is used\ndrawn from linguistics, structuralism and post-structuralism, such an eclectic approach being justified in the current state of research. For the\nimmediate objective, the most effective model has proved to be Peirce's\ntaxonomy of three fundamental types of sign, namely, those of symbol,\nicon and index. In addition, other types of analysis have been sampled,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18\n\"speculum\", a secondary meaning which the reader was undoubtedly\nintended to retrieve from the original title ofthe treatise. Hence, Khunrath's theatre of images, like a mirror, catoptrically reflects the celestial\nspheres to the human mind, awakening the empathetic faculty of the\nhuman spirit which unites, through the imagination, with the heavenly\nrealms. Thus, the visual imagery of Khunrath's treatises has become the\nalchemical quintessence, the spiritualised matter of the philosopher's\nstone, transmuting both the human soul and the physical world into gold.\nIt is evident that late Renaissance alchemists were involved in a radical semiotic enterprise, intuiting the possibility of devising a visual signing-system which would resolve the dualistic conflict of the European\nlinguistic sign in which signifier and signified were arbitrarily related.22\nAccordingly, John Dee regarded his Monas Hieroglyphica as a graphic\nsystem which was also practical chemistry (figs. 17, 18), a metonymic]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=47\nPages: 47\nDee probably ends, since Dorn's geometry contrasts with Dee's in several\nimportant respects. The prime difference is that Dorn's structures are\nconventional Euclidean symbols, rather than hieroglyphs, nor does he\nemploy cabbalism. Thus, in semiotic terms Dorn's geometrical signs do\nnot reify their conceptual content, functioning instead as a metaphorical\nsystem which represents practical alchemy by means of abstract signifiers.\nThere is a closer comparison between Dorn's system and that of other\nmetaphysical geometers in the early seventeenth century, such as Fortunatus of Padua who used Euclidean theorems to prove the truth ofthe\nChristian faith.41 In contrast, Dee believed that the operation of his\nMonas was contiguous with reality (a metonymic, or indexical relationship), asserting that the manipulation of the Monas was practical alchemy, rather than its symbolic substitute. By means of the universal language of cabbalism, Dee thought that he had created a uniquely potent]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11\nalchemy may have been related to that ofreligious Christian imagery, as\na sympathetic magic drawing the viewer into the presence of God (frontispiece). Alberti in De Pictura had been interested in the use ofrhetorical\ndevices in painting and he had modelled his pictorial system on the\npersuasive techniques of Cicero and Quintillian. Hence, Alberti's perspectival construction aimed to promote such an effective illusion of reality that the viewer, automatically convinced by the visual text, would\nsurrender his resistance to its implications.17\nTaking the present analysis still deeper into the field ofsemiotics, the\nsignificatory mode of single-point perspective can be defined as that of\nthe metonym, or index, in Peirce's terms.18 As a signifying mode, this\ntype of space was intended to persuade the viewer that physical reality\ncontinued into the picture, progressing, in the case of Khunrath's engraving, to its culmination in the eye of God (frontispiece). In alchemical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",\nwhereby it delivers all of its information to the interpretant synchronically. Hence, it requires a broader range of semiotic strategies to correlate\nthe various paradigmatic levels of meaning. The written text, in contrast,\nis deciphered by the reader in a diachronic sequence and, hence, it is far\nmore dictatorial towards its interpretant than the visual artefact. Consequently, alchemical illustrators , like other Renaissance artists, capitalised\non thefactthat the synchronic reading of a visual text caused ambiguities\nto arise in the reception of its meaning. An additional semiotic difference\nbetween visual and literary texts is that visual imagery may be symbolic,\niconic or indexical, but most literary texts can only be symbolic. It is rare,\nin fact, to encounter a linguistic metonymic or indexical structure, although the compilers ofRenaissance grimoires struggled to produce such]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16,15\nsigns, on the model of the Hebrew alphabet, as an essential part oftheir\n3 Peirce, 2, pp. 170, 172-73.\n4 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n5 Carl GustavJung, Psychology and Alchemy (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1993),\npp. 26, 112, 152ff, 158, 196.\n6 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n7 For example, Allison Coudert, Alchemy: the philosopher's stone (London: Wildwood\nHouse, 1980). Otherwise, this is an authoritative general study.\n8 Erwin Panofsky, Studies in Iconology (New York: Harper, 1962).\n9 Szonyi (1996), pp. 250-53.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nmagical rituals.10These experiments with cryptography yielded few convincing results, since the linguistic signs of European languages are arbitrary phonetic symbols and, hence, cannot mirror their conceptual representant in the manner of visual signs. Consequently, it is essential that\nscholars of alchemical imagery distinguish between the literary and the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=18\nPages: 18,19\nFrancken, 1616), pp. 68-72.\n22 Referto Szonyi, \"Ars Scintrilla\" (1999), passim, and his paper forthcoming in RenaissanceQuarterlyfor a discussion ofthe theurgic linguistics ofFicino, Agrippa and Paracelsus.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nAlchemy has always been a type of \"gnosis\", a non-rational esoteric\nphilosophy, fully explicable only by its initiates. Fundamentally an oral\nsystem of knowledge, the epistemic changes in alchemical theory cannot\nbe recovered in their entirety by contemporary historians, even from the\nconsiderable amount ofphysical evidence available to them. Problems of\ninterpretation are exacerbated by the fact that there are few immutable\nmeanings for the various symbols since they have become amplified in\nthe course of their historical use. In Barthes' terms, they should be considered as \"mythic\" secondary-level signifiers, each alchemical sign bearing with it the history of its use. Thus, although dictionaries ofalchemical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=85\nPages: 85\nChristly \"gnosis\", informing the monstrous group of Lutherans and demonic black-magicians that, no matter whether they esteem, or disparage, him, he will simply continue to pray. He carries a pair ofgeometrical dividers, such as those which appear in the later portrait of Khunrath\nin 1604, with which he is drawing the diagrammatic icon of Christ. In\nthe 1602 engraving, therefore, the scholar may also be Khunrath, his\ndividers signifying the sacred geometry of his theosophical system. With\nthese he pins a serpent to the ground, demonstrating that the wisdom\ninspired by the Holy Spirit conquers sophistry, symbolised by the snake\nwith its \"lingua venona\", whose spurious reasoning in the Garden of\nEden had originally distanced humanity from God's grace.\nMeanwhile, the other character on the right, pays no attention at all\nto his stressful companions, for he is gazing into the cave in the centre of\nthe picture, which is yet another depiction ofAbraham's mountain ofthe]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16\npractical function of a specific visual image. Hence, pseudo-Lullian diagrams, as mobile computers, are indexical (figs. 4-7), whereas Pantheus'\nstatic, neo-Lullian structure is merely symbolic (fig. 8).\nIn this sense,John Dee's mobile cypher of the Monas is the epitome of\nthe visual index (figs. 17, 18), perhaps influencing Khunrath's artist, Jan\nVredeman de Vries, to create a more complex version of its metonymic\nstructure (frontispiece). Some of Fludd's cosmological depictions also\nhave indexical qualities, although his illustrations are difficult to categorise, since an image may involve several different types ofsemiotic mode\n(figs. 44-50). At first glance, Fludd's diagrams appear to be symbolic\n(merely illustrating his text), but, in fact, they also have an iconic aspect,\nsince they can be isolated from their textual context while retaining most\noftheir meaning. In addition, as indexical generators of a contemplative]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=46\nPages: 46\nthe fact that Renaissance emblems are figural, whereas Dee's Monas is\ndiagrammatic, but in their distinctive semiotic functions. Horapollo's\nsigns operate as metaphors or symbols, that is, the visual signifier rarely\nmirrors its conceptual content. Consequently, most of his imagery could\nnot be decoded without the explanatory text. Renaissance emblems were\nintended to be a cryptic language, decipherable only by members ofelite\ncircles. The emblem's often bizarre components were an attempt to\ntranspose a verbal phrase into its equivalent visual elements, since this\nwas thought to be the authentic mode of the ancient Egyptians.32\nIn contrast, Dee's Monas was intended to be an index and, in this\nfunction, it was probably unique among Renaissance emblems, since it\nnot only symbolised the process of transmutation, but displayed that\nprocess in its very form. In other words, Dee believed that the form ofhis\nMonas was identical to its physical referent, for, as the alchemist worked]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=104\nPages: 104\nhave the some of the same quality of devices intended to facilitate public\ninstruction.\nIt is misleading, however, to discuss alchemical illustration without\ncontextualising it within the relevant social and political milieu and since\nthis is not possible within the scope of the present study, these issues will\nnot be pursued at any length. It is relevant, however, to make one further\npoint arising from this brief visual analysis of the semiotic function of\nGichtel's engravings, which is that they demonstrate the popularisation,\nwithin a generation, of alchemical imagery previously associated with\nGerman pietism. In this process, Fludd's illustrations had played a large\nrole, due to his voluminous output in very large print-runs, reusing many\nof the same cosmological diagrams through-out his series of works, as\nwell as seeing them copied by other artists. Moreover, Fludd's pictures\nlent themselves to public instruction, as was his intention, since they]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=37\nPages: 37\nrevolution and the enlightenment, then there may well have been a sense\nof existential panic, a feeling that meaning was becoming ever more\ndifficult to retrieve from the open book of nature. The interest in magical\ncyphers may have been an attempt to close the widening gap arising in\ncultural semiosis in which the signifier was slipping away from its referent.\nThe Renaissance came to a halt before the brute fact that language existed:\nin the density of the world, a graphism mingling with things or flowing\nbeneath them ... the existence oflanguage preceded, as if by a mute stubborness, what one could read in it and the words that gave it sound. From the\nseventeenth century, it is this massive and intriguing existence of language\nthat is eliminated\n... one might say that language in the Classical era does\nnot exist: it functions.28\nFor Paracelsus, the primal language of signatures was inspired by God's]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16\nscholars of alchemical imagery distinguish between the literary and the\nvisual components of an alchemical treatise. Moreover, certain types of\nalchemical illustration are capable of functioning almost entirely as a\nvisual text, that is, as metonymic, or indexical, structures, as in the case of\none of Khunrath's illustrations (frontispiece). In such metonymic visual\nimages there is an implied physical continuity between the world ofthe\nviewer and that of the picture. In these instances, the reception of the\npicture's message does not need to be deferred until it can be decoded in\na linguistic form. In such sophisticated metonymic-indexical images the\nvisual structure is the essence ofthe meaning communicated to the viewer. This indexical quality of an image is not necessarily dependent onthe\nartist's use of naturalistic motifs (as Peirce had pointed out), since diagrammatic structures may also be indexical. It is more a question ofthe]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=136\nPages: 136\nOvide\n, 32\nsemiotics\nofillusmoralisee\n153-55,\n174;\n84, 152,\ntrations, 158, 164-65, 181; Septimana\nPhilosophica, 101, 154, 178; Symbola Aureae Pacioli, Luca, 727\nMensae, 133-34, 153; Themis Aurea, 154; Pagel, Walter,\nTripus Aureus, 21, 155, 163; Viatorium, 21 Panofsky, Erwin, 3,\nManicheans, 31\nPantheus, Joannes, xviii, 4, 20-21, 56, 62\nParacelsians, 48\nManutius, Aldus, 64\nParacelsus, 5, 40, 41-52, 84; alchemy, 13,\nMasaccio, xv\nMattioli, Pierandrea, 68\n41, 43, 47-48, 52; Archidoxa, 47, 48, 50,\nMcLean, Adam, 153, 160\n98; astrology, 15, 42-43, 44-45; astral.\nMederus, David, 84\nbody, 7-8, 42-43, 61, 77; astral virtue,\nmedieval alchemical illustration, 17-18, see xii, xiv, 7-8, 23-24, 42-45, 46, 48; AstronoObrist\nmia magna, 43; azoth (quintessence)55,, xvii,\n23-24, 44, 46-47, 61; cabbalism, 58;\nMelancthon, xii, 150\nMerian, Matthieu, 159, 163\ncosmogony, 41-42; De pestilate, 42; docMersenne, Martin, 58, 174, 178\ntrine of signatures, xiv, 45-46; Expositio]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=10\nPages: 10,11\nXIV\nXV\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\nmodel can be amplified by taking additional recourse to Peirce's semiotic\ntaxonomy of three types ofsign, namely, those of symbol, icon and index.\nFirst, however, it is necessary to understand the original intentions behind the development of the single-point perspective system during the\nearly Renaissance.11\nThe geometrical theory of this spatial system was first expressed by\nLeone Battista Alberti in his treatise on painting, De Pictura (Florence,\n1435).12 He had explained that the orthogonal lines of any architecture\nillustrated by the artist should be drawn as if they were running into the\npicture to meet in a single vanishing-point. In accordance with this new\npictorial convention, in many fifteenth-century Florentine paintings ofan\ninterior scene the floor would be drawn in a chequer-board pattern to\nreinforce the same illusion of space receding to a vanishing-point. The]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11\nreinforce the same illusion of space receding to a vanishing-point. The\ntechnical term for this pictorial effect was the \"pavimentum diminutionis\" (fig. 1).13\nAlberti had based his perspective system on the model of medieval\noptical diagrams which depicted the operation of light-rays in relation to\nthe human eye (figs . 2, 11). Hence, in the semiotic functioning of the\nsingle -point system, its geneology in medieval optics continues to operate\nas a sub-text. To use Derrida's terms, the original opticalgeometrywhich\nhad provided the structure for single-point space continued to exist within it as a signifying trace. 14 Derrida's \"trace\" (le trait) is the transcendental\nsignifier unifying the disparate (and conflicting) elements of a discourse. 15\nHence, the generic signifier of the single-point perspective system would\nbe the eye ofthe viewer and its discourse that of the struggle between the\nrhetorical devices ofthe picture and the objective judgement ofthe interpretant.]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* graphology is discussed as a semiotic tool within alchemical traditions, especially through John Dee's cabbalistic and alchemical works. Dees graphological use of signs, symbols, and letters exemplified a semiotic system that aimed to convey deeper meanings beyond literal interpretations, acting as both linguistic and visual elements. Here are some key points: 1. Graphology as Visual Semiotics: Dee integrated graphological elements, such as cabbalistic letters and symbols, into his alchemical works, like the *Monas Hieroglyphica*. These symbols functioned as semiotic fields, where the form and structure of each sign were meant to influence both spiritual and material realms: > Dee is inferring the use of cabbalistic graphology... Earlier alchemy had occasionally played such games of visual semiotics, but never with such economy and precision. [Urszula Szul, page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45). 2. Graphology and Metonymy: Dees graphology was not just symbolic but metonymic, implying a direct connection between the symbols and their referents. His use of letters and signs in the *Monas* was a form of practical alchemy, where manipulating the signs could lead to real-world transformations: > Dees Monas was intended to be an index... not only symbolising the process of transmutation, but displaying that process in its very form. [Urszula Szul, page 46](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=46). 3. Cabbalistic Roots: Dees graphological system was deeply influenced by the Cabbalah, where letters and words were seen as carrying divine power. His cabbalistic graphology used cabbalistic alphabets to invoke celestial and spiritual influences, blending linguistic signs with visual semiotics: > Dee applied cabbalistic graphology to his alchemical theories, where letters and symbols acted as conduits for divine power. [Urszula Szul, page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45). Dees approach demonstrates how graphology served as a practical and symbolic tool in alchemy, merging visual and linguistic systems to effect spiritual and material transformations. For further details, you can explore [page 45](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45) and [page 46](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=46).
You
signs as fields

{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",\nwhereby it delivers all of its information to the interpretant synchronically. Hence, it requires a broader range of semiotic strategies to correlate\nthe various paradigmatic levels of meaning. The written text, in contrast,\nis deciphered by the reader in a diachronic sequence and, hence, it is far\nmore dictatorial towards its interpretant than the visual artefact. Consequently, alchemical illustrators , like other Renaissance artists, capitalised\non thefactthat the synchronic reading of a visual text caused ambiguities\nto arise in the reception of its meaning. An additional semiotic difference\nbetween visual and literary texts is that visual imagery may be symbolic,\niconic or indexical, but most literary texts can only be symbolic. It is rare,\nin fact, to encounter a linguistic metonymic or indexical structure, although the compilers ofRenaissance grimoires struggled to produce such]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nresults to regard visual and verbal signs as autonomous dialects of the\nsame language, thus requiring different critical approaches. It was Panofsky who first argued for a new type of analytical tool for the study of\nvisual imagery which would be distinct from that ofliterary scholarship.\nHis iconological method involved an examination of the historical context in which a visual sign had appeared, for it was this which had determined the style of its depiction. As Szonyi has demonstrated in his study\nof Agrippa's and Dee's esoteric emblems, Panofsky's method is one ofthe\nfew able to accomodate the complexity of a visual signing-system. Szonyi\nalso continues to favour the historiographical approach of Gombrich,\nwhich has the added advantage of taking into account the psychological\neffects ofthe rhetoric deployed by a visual sign.\nFrom a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a \"field\",]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=16\nPages: 16,15\nsigns, on the model of the Hebrew alphabet, as an essential part oftheir\n3 Peirce, 2, pp. 170, 172-73.\n4 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n5 Carl GustavJung, Psychology and Alchemy (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1993),\npp. 26, 112, 152ff, 158, 196.\n6 Peirce, 2, p. 170.\n7 For example, Allison Coudert, Alchemy: the philosopher's stone (London: Wildwood\nHouse, 1980). In accordance with this new\npictorial convention, in many fifteenth-century Florentine paintings ofan\ninterior scene the floor would be drawn in a chequer-board pattern to\nreinforce the same illusion of space receding to a vanishing-point. The]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nboth the form and the content of the sign, these three elements operated\nas a single figure. Foucault's contention is that in the seventeenth century\nthis triple construction of a sign became a binary in which a signifier\n(\"significans\") was connected to a significance (\"significandum\"), abandoning the quality of similitude.26\nFoucault's argument provides one explanation for the intensity ofthe\nlate Renaissance search for the \"lingua Adamica\" through the devices of\nmagical cryptography. The issue of the Adamic language has been discussed by Szonyi in his study of the influence of Paracelsian talismanic\nlinguistics on Dee's theurgy. (Dee had certainly procured two copies of\nParacelsus Expositio magicarum figurarum). In contrast to the characterisa-\n44\n18 Pagel (1982), pp.71-76; Allen G. Debus, \"Mathematics and Nature in the Chemical\nTexts ofthe Renaissance\", Ambix (1968): 1-28; Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" \"\n(1979), pp. 59, 65-66]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15\nPages: 15\nappearance of any visual sign change both its meaning and function. In\nfact, Peirce devised a taxonomy of hybrid signs to describe the vacillations of such unstable significatory orders.\nFollowing his general approach, the present author would make only\none proposition which is that many late Renaissance alchemical signs\nincline towards the indexical mode. In other words, alchemical visual\nsemiosis from the late sixteenth century is deliberately \" contaminated\"\nnot, as Jung believed, by the collective unconscious of a society,5 but by\nthe viewer's imminent physical reality. Thus, the alchemical imagery\nunder present consideration does not merely copy, it also restructures the\nphysical world by forcing a continuum between the viewer's space and\nthat of the picture.\nPeirce defined the index as\nA sign, or representation, which refers to its object not so much because of\nany similarity or analogy with it, nor because it is associated with general]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=36\nPages: 36\nwas that which guaranteed their authenticity. Similitude was judged in\nthe terms of adjacency (\"convenientia\"), analogy (\"aemulatio\") and sympathy (\"concordia\"). This taxonomy was inscribed within the universe in\nthe form of signs, decipherable only by an elite of natural philosophers.\nAs Foucault points out, in the sixteenth century no distinction was made\nbetween the empirical observations ofthe natural philosophers and those\noftheologians, or occultists. All of these systems of knowledge were dependent on their ability to read the inscriptions which already pre-existed\nin the forms of the world. Foucault argues that Renaissance signs were\norganised into a conceptual structure consisting of three qualities which\nwere the marks of the sign, the things designated by those marks and the\nsimilitude between them. Since it was \"aemulatio\" which constituted\nboth the form and the content of the sign, these three elements operated]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=30\nPages: 30,31\nTriplici Vitae libri tres (1978), for example, Bk III, Cap I, similitudes of the sun such as\nheliotrope, myrrh, amber, crocus. In the same way, Fludd's\ncabbalistic alchemy and medicine in his Philosophia Sacra (1626) relied for\nits effect on the reification of a metaphorical sequence in which the sun\nwas personified as the demiurge, the eye ofgod, the altar of Christ as the\ncabbalistic Messiah, as well as the primal medicine. Horapollo's\nsigns operate as metaphors or symbols, that is, the visual signifier rarely\nmirrors its conceptual content. Consequently, most of his imagery could\nnot be decoded without the explanatory text. Renaissance emblems were\nintended to be a cryptic language, decipherable only by members ofelite\ncircles. Since it is not possible to examine all the major alchemists of\nthe late Renaissance, the discussion will be confined to the cabbalistic\nmetaphysics and optical alchemy of four central figures, those of Dee,\nKhunrath, Maier and Fludd.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE\nALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nPrevious studies of Renaissance alchemical imagery have rarely involved\na discussion of its semiotic aspects, yet, without such an analysis it is\ndifficult to establish the exact role ofvisual illustration within a particular\ncontext. In the present case-studies, a variety of analytical tools is used\ndrawn from linguistics, structuralism and post-structuralism, such an eclectic approach being justified in the current state of research. For the\nimmediate objective, the most effective model has proved to be Peirce's\ntaxonomy of three fundamental types of sign, namely, those of symbol,\nicon and index. In addition, other types of analysis have been sampled,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=21\nPages: 21\n15\n9 Joachim Telle, Sol und Luna (Hurtgenwald: Guido Pressler, 1980), pp. 55-64.\n10 Sherwood-Taylor (1976), pp. 21-22, 51-54.
