Perhaps it would yield more profitable\nresults to regard visual and verbal signs as autonomous dialects of the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=47\nPages: 47\nDee probably ends, since Dorn's geometry contrasts with Dee's in several\nimportant respects. The prime difference is that Dorn's structures are\nconventional Euclidean symbols, rather than hieroglyphs, nor does he\nemploy cabbalism. Thus, in semiotic terms Dorn's geometrical signs do\nnot reify their conceptual content, functioning instead as a metaphorical\nsystem which represents practical alchemy by means of abstract signifiers.\nThere is a closer comparison between Dorn's system and that of other\nmetaphysical geometers in the early seventeenth century, such as Fortunatus of Padua who used Euclidean theorems to prove the truth ofthe\nChristian faith.41 In contrast, Dee believed that the operation of his\nMonas was contiguous with reality (a metonymic, or indexical relationship), asserting that the manipulation of the Monas was practical alchemy, rather than its symbolic substitute. By means of the universal language of cabbalism, Dee thought that he had created a uniquely potent]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45\nPages: 45\nThe four elements are the four straight lines emerging from the point.26\nDee explains that the two half circles at the bottom of the cross represent\nAries, or fire. Thus, the Monas contains the power of the three levels of\ncreation, corresponding to the cosmic alchemical egg, the prime matter\nwhich contains the All.27\nThe most elaborate Euclidean dissection ofthe Monas occurs in Theorem XXI in which the sign for the Monad is turned upside-down, permitting new relationships to be established between the Moon, Sun,Aries\nand the other planets (fig. 18). Dee implies that there exists an even more\nawe-inspiring relationship between the alchemical art offire, represented\nby the sign of Aries, and the astronomy of the Monas. In this instance,\n19 Szonyi forthcoming in Renaissance Quarterly. An analysis of Ficino's numerology is\nprovided by Allen (1994), pp. 106, 130-34, 138-42.\n20 R&W: 1437, D16 (British Library Shelf-mark 1033. h. 1(2)).]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=14\nPages: 14,15\nU. Szulakowska, \"Two Italian alchemical manuscripts: some philosophical problems:\nmonism and dualism\" in Didier Kahn, Sylvain Matton, Alchimie: art, histoire et mythes (Paris;\nMilan, 1995), pp. 249-63.\n2 Goldberg (1976).\n2\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE ALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nthe illusionistic world of the picture. In Peirce's semiotic system, he has\ndistinguished an indexical sign from a \"symbol\" , which has an arbitrary\nvisual appearance unrelated to its conceptual content and, therefore, can\nonly convey a meaning within a specific context for a particular interpretant. Peirce also differentiated an indexical sign from an \"icon\" which,\nhe stated, \"would possess the character which renders it significant, even\nthough its object had no existence\". According to this definition , it\nwould initially appear that most alchemical visual signs should be termed]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=73\nPages: 73,74\nNaturae characterismis insignitae; certa nimirum proportione, figuram et habitu;divinisque\nunde de\ninterno et latente spiritu occultisque rerum proprietatibus iudicium fieri potest: imo ipsa\nproprietas rerum occulta et spiritus latens seipsum prodit certis quibusdam notis etfiguris\nexternis, etpro natura ac indole sua, talem effingit signaturam, figuram, proportionem et\nhabitum, qualis a Sapientibus vult cognosci: quae Signatura Magia Naturalis initium, et\nquasi\nalphabetum primumque elementum est... Concurrit enim totius Naturae signatura\nin Micro-Cosmo\".\n120\n121\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE. THE EDITION OF 1604\nQuid est Ruah Elohim qui incubat aquis ?\n(Khunrath, 1609: 195)\nIn response, he describes the \"Ruah Elohim\" as creating the \"Theatro\nMundano\" on the model of the \"Archetypos\" (the Creator-God).22 This\npassage is related, in fact, to the 1595 illustration of the \"Archetypos\"\n(Christ) in which there occur several examples of Reuchlin's cabbalistic]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11\nreinforce the same illusion of space receding to a vanishing-point. The\ntechnical term for this pictorial effect was the \"pavimentum diminutionis\" (fig. 1).13\nAlberti had based his perspective system on the model of medieval\noptical diagrams which depicted the operation of light-rays in relation to\nthe human eye (figs . 2, 11). Hence, in the semiotic functioning of the\nsingle -point system, its geneology in medieval optics continues to operate\nas a sub-text. To use Derrida's terms, the original opticalgeometrywhich\nhad provided the structure for single-point space continued to exist within it as a signifying trace. 14 Derrida's \"trace\" (le trait) is the transcendental\nsignifier unifying the disparate (and conflicting) elements of a discourse. 15\nHence, the generic signifier of the single-point perspective system would\nbe the eye ofthe viewer and its discourse that of the struggle between the\nrhetorical devices ofthe picture and the objective judgement ofthe interpretant.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=42\nPages: 42\nvery form of this sign was said to resemble that of a flame. Hence, the\ncabbalah was offering at its core a metonymic linguistic sign which was\nnot transposable to the Latin alphabet. The similarity in the appearance\nof other Hebrew linguistic significators to their referent fascinated European cabbalists. Thus, in the context of the Renaissance epistemological\ncrisis described by Foucault, the analogical potential of the Hebrew alphabet satisfied the intellectual and emotional need for a signifying mode\nwhich would close the increasing conceptual divide between linguistic\nforms and the physical world. Consequently, the psychological situation\ndemanded a substitute analogical system which was provided bythe cabbalah. As the divine text of God in nature was erased by the epistemic\nchanges wrought by proto-capitalism in northern Europe, so the yearning\nto recover God's primal words of creation intensified.\n2 Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa, Opera, 2 vols (London, 1600: Hildesheim; New York:]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* signs as fields are discussed through the lens of semiotic theory, particularly with reference to how visual signs operate differently from written text. Visual signs in alchemical imagery are described as semiotic fields because they deliver information synchronically, meaning that they present multiple layers of meaning simultaneously rather than sequentially. 1. Synchronic Nature of Visual Signs: Visual signs provide multiple levels of interpretation at once, unlike written texts, which are deciphered in a diachronic or sequential manner. This synchronic reading leads to ambiguities and deeper complexity in how these images are received and understood by viewers: > From a semiotic point of view, the visual sign operates as a field, whereby it delivers all of its information to the interpretant synchronically... causing ambiguities to arise in the reception of its meaning. [Urszula Szul, page 15](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15). 2. Distinct from Written Texts: Unlike written texts, which typically use symbolic signs (where meaning is dictated by the sequence of words), visual signs in alchemical illustrations can be iconic or indexical, adding additional layers of interpretation and connection to reality: > An additional semiotic difference between visual and literary texts is that visual imagery may be symbolic, iconic or indexical, but most literary texts can only be symbolic. [Urszula Szul, page 15](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15). These semiotic fields make alchemical illustrations multi-dimensional, enabling a rich interpretation that blends material and spiritual symbolism. For more details, you can refer to the analysis on [page 15](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=15).
You
continue the summary of the book
Tool
{"result":["[Summary from page 51 to page 61 out of a total of 137:\nPages 51:\nCHAPTER SIX\nJOHN DEE'S CONCEPTUAL ARCHITECTURE\n\"pavimentum diminutionis\" (ff. 18v, 19r) (figs. 21, 22). This is a drawing\nof a floor composed of square paving-stones whose spatial disposition\nobeys the geometrical rules of single-point perspective. The illusory effect\nofdiminishing form in space is produced by the artist in two stages (fig.\n1). First, he predetermines the position of the vanishing-point and the\northogonals on the surface of the painting. Then he draws a set of intersecting lines across the paper from points at both sides of the frame,\nrepresenting the viewing-point of the spectator. It is these lines which\ndetermine the rate of diminution ofthe space and, therefore, its apparent\ndepth. Finally, by drawing parallel lines horizontally across the network\nof inter-sections, the \"pavimentum diminutionis\" is created.13\nIn the Mathematicall Preface Dee's perspective theory is intimately connected with his view of architecture as the essence ofthe arts and sciences. Yates has argued that he was ahead of his time in England due to his\ninterest in classical and Renaissance theories of ideal geometry and ratio.\nIn fact, she claimed that his references to Vitruvian perspective in the\nMathematicall Preface initiated the classical revival in architecture prior to\nthe work ofInigo Jones.14 Influenced by Vitruvius' and Alberti's aesthetic\nsystem , Dee believed that architecture united the spiritual and material\nworlds, the heavens and the earth. He concurred with Alberti that the\narchitect should be well versed in all the arts and sciences, including\nnatural philosophy, since there were deeper issues involved in the practice of architecture than merely the problems of physical construction.\nDee, in fact, regarded architectural theory as a speculative philosophy,\nciting Vitruvius on the intellectual and spiritual stature of architecture as\nthe most noble art-form .\nArchitecture , is a Science garnished with many doctrines & diverse instruc-.\ntions : by whose Judgement, all workes, by other workmen finished, are\nJudged ... (f. diijr) [Vitruvius] geveth reason, orderly, wherefore all these\nArtes, Doctrines, and Instructions, are requisite in an excellent Architect.\n(f. diijv)\nTherefore, the architect needed to know history, philosophy, music,\nphysics, languages, painting, geometry, arithmetic and astronomy. A\nmusical education especially provided a conceptual foundation for his\npractical deployment of Pythagorean measure, weight, number and proportion.\nI count, here, Architecture, among those Artes Mathematicall, which are Derived\nfrom the Principals ... the Architect ... remaineth the Demonstrative reason\nand cause ofthe Mechaniciens worke: in Lyne, plaine, and Solid: by Geometricall, Arithmeticall, Opticall, Musicall, Astronomicall, Cosmographicall ... by all the\nformer Derived Artes Mathematicall, and other Naturall Artes (f. diijr)\nThe architect also had to understand \"optics\" (perspective) by means of\nwhich\nthe Lightes ofthe heaven, are well led, in the buildings: from certain quarters\nof the world (f. diijv)\nBut, such practical aspects were not Dee's main interest, since it was the\nPythagorean concepts involved in the design of a building which, he\nargued, were the salient quality of architecture's unique status among the\narts. He quotes Alberti in his De Re Aedificatoria that architecture is reducible to abstract line drawing.\nThe whole Feate ofArchitecture in buildyng, consisteth in Lineamentes, and\nin Framyng. And the whole power and skill of Lineamentes, tendeth to this:\nthat the right and absolute way may be had, of Coaptyng and joyning Lines\nand angles ... Lineamente, shalbe the certaine and constant prescribyng,\nconceived in mynde: made in lines and angles: and finished with a learned\nminde and wyt (f. diiijr)\nTherefore, architecture was a conceptual art-form, for its theoretical\nprinciples were derived from Pythagorean geometrical mathematics.\nAnd Plato affirmeth, the Architect to be Master over all, that make any worke.\nWherupon, he is neither Smith, nor Builder: nor , separately, any Artificer\n(f. diiijr)\nThe lofty intellectual and spiritual stature awarded by Dee to architecture may have had important consequences for alchemical illustration\nin the early seventeenth century.\"15 In many late sixteenth and early\nseventeenth century alchemical engravings the artists used motifs from\nthe classical canon to signify the higher ontological levels of the cosmos\n(frontispiece and fig. 41).\nDee placed great emphasis on the intellectual status of drawing,\nwhether in relation to architecture, or in the depiction of the human\nfigure. He invented a special name for idealised figure-drawing which he\ncalled \"anthropographie\", involving the depiction of human proportions\n13 F. M. Lund, Ad Quadratum (London, 1921); Kubovy (1986), pp. 17-31.\n14 Yates (1969), pp. 112-35.\n(1998) presents a related argument on the role of architecture in 17th-C\n15 Szonyiillustration.\nalchemical\n74\n75\n\nPages 52:\nCHAPTER SIX\nJOHN DEE'S CONCEPTUAL ARCHITECTURE\naccording to \"the Arte of Perspective\" (f. ciiijr). Dee contextualised this\ntype of graphic design within hermeticism, commending Agrippa's De\nOcculta Philosophia which depicted the human-body as a model of the\nPythagorean cosmic order.\nDee was implying that the application of the single-point perspective\nsystem, whether to the human-figure, or to architectural space, served to\nalign the human-being with the macrocosm. Thus, Pythagorean geometry not only had an intellectual and aesthetic role in the art of drawing,\nbut also a spiritual and magical function. Hence, Dee's account of\"Zographie\" prioritises its conceptual and spiritual aspects (f. dijv), the physical application of paint, in contrast, being demoted to a mechanical artform.\nZographie [is] the Scholemaster of Picture, and chief gouernor\n(f. dijv)\nAmong the true \"Zographers\", Dee included the art-theorists Giorgio\nVasari, Pietro Aretino and Pomponius Gauricus.\nZographie, is an Arte Mathematicall, which teacheth and demonstrateth,\nhow, the Intersection of all visuall Pyramides, made by any playne assigned,\n(the Centre, distance, and lightes, beying determined) may be, by lynes, and\ndue propre colours, represented (f. dijv)\nIn Dee's ideas, \"Zographie\" was related integrally to his optical theories,\nsince the Pythagorean-based system ofsingle-point perspective was a type\nof magical catoptrics, with the same function as the catoptrics of the\nPropaedeumata Aphoristica and the later Monas Hieroglyphica. He seems to\nhave believed that a painting whose spatial system was organised in accordance with Pythagorean geometrical ratios would theurgically attract\nthe corresponding planetary influences. In other words , a painting could\nbecome a magical talisman, or a catoptrical mirror, registering and enhancing the celestial virtues. Dee's theory of drawing had revolutionary\nimplications for alchemical illustrators, for example, Michelspacher'sfour\nmirrors in the Cabala (1615-16) may well have originated in Dee's ideas of\na graphic theurgy.\nContextualised within Dee's Euclidean optical and alchemical system,\nthe semiotic function of single-point, spatial geometry is essentially the\nsame as that ofhis Monas Hieroglyphica, since they both have a metonymic\nrelationship with the physical world. As a sign in its own right, the Pythagorean-based system ofdrawing was reified by Dee to become a signifying mode which operated within real physical space, not only in that of\nthe painting. The Pythagorean ratios used in the single-point system were\nregarded by Dee as being capable of attracting celestial influences and\nrendering them subject to the will of the magus. In the Mathematicall\nPreface, Dee was increasinglythinking of occult practices more as a system\nof philosophical contemplation, in which the image began to replace\npractical activity. Szonyi has similarly discussed this possibility in relation\nto Dee's earlier Monas Hieroglyphica.16 Hence, the single-point perspective\nspace in the alchemical engravings of Khunrath's and Maier's treatises\nneeds to be contextualised within Dee's theories of astronomical catoptrics, architecture and \"zographie\" (frontispiece and fig. 41).\nThe monistic theosophy of Paracelsus was the source for Dee's belief\nin the power ofa visual image to unify the spiritual and physical dimensions of experience. As discussed previously, Paracelsus had taught that a\nhuman-being had both a physical and an astral body, but that his real\nbody was astral. It was by means of the imagination located in the astral\nbodythat a person could attain to \"gnosis\" and, thereby, learn to control\nphysical manifestation through the \"astra\" present within all things.\nThus, for the Paracelsian magus it was sufficient to contemplate an object, instead of manipulating it physically. Visual imagery, such as talismanic cyphers or alchemical pictures, provided a stimulus to the imagination of the magus and acted as simulacra of the objects under his\ncontrol.\nDee's view of the theurgic function of Pythagorean-based drawing\nmay explain two particular alchemical images which Yates stated that she\nfound incomprehensible. The alchemical image which specifically puzzled her was Emblem VIII from Maier's Atalanta Fugiens (1617) (fig. 41).\nHer attribution of a conceptual influence on Maier from Dee in this\ncontext is accurate, but she did not connect Emblem VIII specifically to\nDee's Mathematicall Preface. Yates, however, took note ofthe factthatthere\nwas some important relationship between Emblem VIII and de Vries's\nengraving ofthe laboratory in Khunrath's Amphiteatrum Sapientiae.\nwe can see that the perspective in the Maier emblem, stretching out behind\nthe egg, is comparable to the perspective in the Khunrath picture. The perspective symbolizes, I believe, architecture and its allied subjects. When one\nremembers that music is supplied by Maier to accompany the \"egg\" emblem,\none realizes that it contains all the elements summed up in the Monas Hieroglyphica. I am entirely unable to understand all this, nor how it would be\npossible to work out a mathematical problem in terms ofthis kind of alchemy. But I believe that implications of this kind are present in the Maier\nemblems.17\n76\n16 Szonyi, \"Ars Sintrilla\" (1999), passim.\n17 Yates, Rosicrucian Enlightenment (1986), p. 83.\n77\n\nPages 53:\n78\nCHAPTER SIX\nIn answer to Yates' query, it may now be possible to suggest that, first,\nthe image in Emblem VIII does not present mathematics in the guise of\nalchemy, but alchemy in the guise of optics . Second, the missing link in\nestablishing the meaning ofthis engraving is Dee's catoptrics and \"zographie\". It could be added that, from the internal evidence oftheir texts,\none of the purposes of Khunrath's and Maier's employment of singlepoint perspective and classical architecture was to instruct the alchemist\nin the science of catoptrics. An important influence on the development\nof this practice was Dee's astrological catoptrics, Pythagorean geometry\nand cabbalism.\nMaier would have been able to read the Mathematicall Preface since he\nknew English, but it is not possible to assume that Khunrath would have\nknown the contents of this treatise since there is no evidence that he\ncould read the language. Since he does, however, mention Dee's Propaedeumata Aphoristica, as well as the Monas Hieroglyphica in the 1609 Amphiteatrum,18 the substance of the Mathematicall Preface may also have been\nknown to him, especially since he met Dee in 1589. There is some visual\nevidence which suggests this possibility in one of the engravings made in\n1602 for the Amphiteatrum (fig. 29). In this picture of an alchemical castle,\nthere is a pathway drawn in a diagrammatic style, as if it were explaining\nthe geometrical rules of the vanishing-point. Above this gate-way there\nappears Dee's Monas Hieroglyphica (fig. 30). This little scene acts as a\nsignifying motif in its own right, since it is not related to the perspectival\nstructure ofthe rest of the engraving, which is that of an aerial view. It\nmay be that Khunrath has turned Dee's perspective-system into a second-level signifier (in Barthes' terms), using it to represent Dee's esoteric\noptical discourse. In fact, this same motif may provide a key to unlocking\nthe complexities of Khunrath's alchemical theory.\n18 Khunrath, Amphiteatrum (1609), p. 6.\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH:\nDIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nIn Bremen, on 6 June 1589, Khunrath met Dee in person,' a meeting\nwhich may have reinforced his reverence for Dee's exceptional hermetic\nknowledge. Dee was certainly one of Khunrath's most important mentors, as is evidenced in his Quaestiones Tres Per-Utiles (Leipzig, 1607) which\nis dedicated to \"magnificos doctissimos et celeberrimos viros\", in particular to\nDN. IOANNEM DEE, Londinensem ... hoc est, Sapientiae Sincerioris Gazophylacem magnum; Angliae Hermetem\nKhunrath refers to Dee in the same terms in the Amphiteatrum (Hanover,\n1609) and his ideas provided an additional stimulus for Khunrath's Paracelsian theosophy. A cabbalistic account of the divine light of God appeared for the first time in Khunrath's Amphiteatrum Sapientiae Aeternae\n(Hamburg, 1595) and he continued to elaborate his catoptrical theurgy in\nhis last treatise De Igne Magorum Philosophorumque secreto extremo et visibili\n(circa 1602-1604).\nKhunrath (1560-1605) (fig. 26) was born in Leipzig, studying medicine first in his birthplace and continuing later in Basel. He travelled\nwidely, including a period of residence at the Imperial court in Prague.\nOn 15 December 1591 he was appointed court physician to Count\nRosemberk in Trebona where he met Johann Tholde, the probable author of the Paracelsian \"Basil Valentine\" alchemical treatises. He also\nresided in Hamburg and Magdeburg. The most surprising aspect of\nKhunrath's career is the length of time involved in the publication ofhis\nwritings, since they did not appear in print until 1595 (Amphiteatrum,\nHamburg edition), followed by a few books in Magdeburg (1599). No\nmore ofhis treatises were published until after his death in 1605, eventually appearing in Hanover (1609), Strassburg (1608) and Magdeburg\n(1616). The apparent difficulties in getting his work into print argue for a\nFenton (1998), p. 239. He gives the date as 27 May/ 6 June (old and new style\ncalendars); Halliwell, Diary ofDr. John Dee, p. 31.\n2 Khunrath also mentions on the dedication-page the names ofJosephus Quercetanus,\nas well as Petrus Hollandus, a physician ofHamburg.\n3 Evans, pp. 212, 214.\n\nPages 54:\n80\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nstrong degree of opposition from some quarter. This issue requires further study since the antagonistic forces surrounding Khunrath may explain the course of his spiritual and intellectual development in the period 1595-1604.\nThe Christological orientation of Khunrath's ideas has not received\nsufficient attention from scholars , apart from that of Montgomery who\nhas described his theological position as being firmly based in orthodox\nLutheranism.\n[F]or Khunrath the alchemical quest of the Philosophers Stone was a quest\nto reveal the true wholeness of the physical universe (the Macrocosm) on the\nbasis of Christ's restoration of wholeness to man (the Microcosm ) .... Khunrath conceives ofthe Stone as the Filius Macrocosmi ... and identifies it with\nChrist himself\nMontgomery has noted that the most important champion of Khunrath's\nalchemy was Johannes Arndt ( 1555-1621), citing his position as a respected Lutheran pastor in order to validate Khunrath's own doctrinal regularity. Montgomery, however, chose to disregard the irregularity ofArndt's own religious beliefs, for his introduction of a pietistic element into\nthe doctrinaire creed of his time was the result of influences from highly\nirregular sources. In fact, Arndt's frequently reprinted work, Vier Bucher\nvon wahren Christentum (1605), was based on the writings of Valentin\nWeigel (1535-88), a Lutheran pastor from Chemnitz . Weigel promoted\nmystical practices based on the concept of the imminent and eternal\npresence of Christ within the human soul, drawing on Paracelsian alchemical theosophy. He was developing an increasingly separatist spiritual path which came to be designated as spiritual \"enthusiasm\", in the\nsense of a soul filled with the guidance of the Holy Spirit. He taught that\nindividual union with God was the gift of the indwelling Holy Spirit, the\nsole redeeming factor in human salvation, rather than the result of\nsubmission to the dogma framed by the theologians of the Lutheran\nChurch . Weigel also had an unorthodox view of the sacraments of the\nLutheran Church, specifically those of absolution and the Eucharist.5\nKhunrath's theosophical alchemy and cabbalism was acquired directly\nfrom Weigel.\nThere are some complex inter-relationships between all ofthese figures which require some very careful examination, since the alliances\nseem to shift and change with time, for reasons which are not immediately apparent. For example, Johann Valentin Andreae (1586-1654) in his\nyouth had also engaged with the theosophical hermetic circles, but in his\nlater writings he seemed to have turned against their members. In fact,\nhe praised Arndt in his Mythologiae Christianae (1619)6as being the hero of\na missionary endeavour against heretical extremists. How should this be\ninterpreted in view of the Weigelian influences on Arndt himself ? It is\nonly possible to conclude that, whatever may have been Arndt's connection with the spiritual enthusiasts in the early 1600s, he either eventually\nrejected them, or, most probably like Andreae, he had grown suspicious\nof certain members of these circles (perhaps distinguishing between\nLutheran pietists and the adherents of more blatantly magical practices).\nConversely, Arndt had never been regarded as tainted by his interest\nin chiliastic beliefs. Further complicating the attempt to understand the\nreligious affiliations of the 1590s to 1620s, is the fact that Andreae publically attacked Khunrath in 1619, despite the fact that Arndt supported\nhim .\nArndt's eulogistic commentary on Khunrath's Amphiteatrum was published as an appendix to Khunrath's treatise De Igne Magorum Philosophorumque (Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner, 1608) by the Paracelsian alchemist\nBenedict Figulus, acting as editor on Khunrath's demise. Figulus, a Franconian, was described as the \"wandering alchemist\" by Peuckert. His\nalchemy displays the effect of Weigel's ideas and, possibly, also Khunrath's, since in his Rosarium novum olympicum (1608) he describes Christ as\nbeing the \"stone of the wise\" and he refers to the \"two books\" ofknowledge, that ofGod's revelation and that ofthe alchemical laboratory (\"des\nLichts der Natur\"). This is probably an echo of Khunrath's maxim of\npraying and working in the oratory and the laboratory, as illustrated in\n4 Montgomery, I, pp. 8, 17.\n5 For the epistemic changes in the mid 16th-C caused by the Lutheran reformation\nand their relation to chiliasm see Peuckert, Die Grosse Wende ( 1948), pp. 587-644.\nAn\naccount ofWeigel may be found in Alexandre Koyre, Mystiques Spirituels Alchemistes (Paris,\n1955), pp. 81-116, and also in Peuckert, Pansophie, 2, pp. 290-300. Weigel's writings have\nbeen edited by Will-Erich Peuckert and Winfried\nZeller in the Samtliche Schriften (\n:\nFriedrich Fromann Verlag, 1962-78), see vol. 1, \"Vom Ort der Welt\", pp. 13-21Stuttgart\n(cosmology) and vol. 2, \"Von der Vergebung der Sunden oder Schlussel der Kirchen, pp.\n29-31 ( absolution and the role of Christ) and Ch's 8-10 (onvom\nthe Lutheran priesthood), also\nvol. 4, \"Dialogus de Christianismo\", pp. 7, 133-51, 320-22, especially Ch. 3 on theroleof\nthe historical Christ. Weigel's Paracelsian sources are analysed in Horst Pfefferl,\n\"Valentin Weigel und Paracelsus\" in Paracelsus und sein damonunglaubiges Jahrhundert (Vienna: Verb. d. Wiss. Ges. Osterreichs Verlag, 1988), pp. 78-89. For Arndt see Christian\nBraw, Bucher im Staube Die TheologieJohan Arndts in ihrem Verhaltnis zur Mystik (Leiden: E.J.\nBrill, 1986), pp. 104-43. See also Dickson (1998), pp. 36-37; Frick (1973), pp. 179, 180,\n587; Stoeffler, Rise ofEvangelical Pietism (1965), pp. 202-10.\n6 Johann Valentin Andreae, Mythologiae Christianae (Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner, 1619),\nBk I, pp. 5-6. See also Frick (1973), pp. 148-54.\n7 Peuckert, Pansophie (1956), 2, pp. 314-22.\n81\n\nPages 55:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nde Vries' engraving of 1595 in the Amphiteatrum (frontispiece). According\nto Dickson, Figulus joined the heterodox circles at the University of Tubingen in 1606-08, at a time when Andreae, as a student, was involved\nwith hermetic and neoplatonic mystical ideas. The appearance of Figulus' own treatise in the Theatrum Chemicum (Strassburg; Zetzner, 1602)\nprovided a source for Andreae's Chymische Hochzeit (composed circa\n1605).\nDickson, like Peuckert, Yates and Gilly, contends that Andreae was\none of the authors of the Rosicrucian Manifestos. Although this argument had been categorically rejected by Montgomery, Dickson concurs\nwith him that Andreae in his later life was alarmed by the paganistic\ninclinations of certain Rosicrucian sympathisers. It has emerged from\nDickson's study that Andreae's personal affiliations were more complicated than Montgomery would allow, with personal friendships outweighing\nhis fear of the religious extremists. From the studies of scholars of the\nRosicrucian movement, it emerges that figures such as Simon Studion,\nAbraham Hoelzel, Tobias Hess and Christoph Besold, constituted a genuine threat to entrenched Lutheran orthodoxy.10 Even so, Dickson negates any suggestion that there was an organised heretical movement in\nProtestant Germany. At the moment, in fact, the emerging picture ofthis\nhistory is one in which personal loyalties fluctuate through-out the first\ntwo decades ofthe seventeenth century.\"\nSome further clues to these events are provided in the 1708 Frankfurt\nedition of Khunrath's alchemical treatise known as the Chaos, where the\nintroduction by an anonymous editor informs the reader that Khunrath\nbegan the practice of alchemy at a very young age, forthwith attacking\nthe \"false alchemists\". The editor states that the Confessio (or Chaos) was\nissued in Magdeburg in 1597 at which time it was Khunrath's twentythird year ofpractising alchemy.12 This fact again raises the query as to\nwhy he delayed for so long before issuing his work in print.\nThe editor ofthe Chaos provides a historiography ofKhunrath's work,\nmentioning the late seventeenth century citations ofJohannes Moller and\nGottfried Arnold. Moller wrote a critical history of literature which was\npublished as the \"Homonymoscopos\" in the fourth edition of Daniel\nGeorg Morhof's Polyhistoria literarus (Lubeck: Petrus Boeckmann, 1687). In\nthis he briefly mentions Khunrath among other late Renaissance authors\nwriting in the context of cabbalism and theurgy.13 Gottfried Arnold in his\nUnparteische Kirchen-und Ketzer Historie (Frankfurt: Thomas Fritsch, 16991700) produced one of the earliest histories of the Rosicrucian movement. Arnold's own work contributed substantially to the separatist pietism ofthe following century, but he himself continued to adhere to the\nscriptures. He acknowledged the role of Christ in saving humanity from\nthe consequences of their sins, as well as the value of the Lutheran sacraments as a source of divine grace. Nevertheless, Arnold's own spiritual\ninclinations led him also to emphasise the act of God's grace which renewed the inner Christ within the individual soul, the \"unio mystica\" of\nBoehme by which he was deeply influenced. He was also strongly affected by the pietism expressed in Johann Arndt's work. Consequently, Arnold blamed the scholastic theologians ofthe Lutheran church for their\nobsession with dogma, causing them to misunderstand the mystical tendencies within their spiritual community and too readily condemning\nthem as heretical. 14\nArnold's account of the figures involved in the Rosicrucian movement\nis similar to that ofYates and Dickson (although neither scholar appears\nto have used Arnold's work in their own research). Yates was of the\nopinion that Rosicrucianism was a highly politicised extension of Protestant Christianity which operated, as it were, under the cover of a secret\nhermetic code.15 Frick, however, had a different view, namely, that the\nmystical hermeticists were not adhering to Lutheran doctrine at all. Citing the historical souces of Rosicrucianism in pagan antiquity and the\npantheistic heresies of the medieval period, Frick underlined the nonChristian content of Paracelsian and subsequent Rosicrucian theology.16\n82\n8 Peuckert, Pansophie (1956), 2, pp. 367-68. Peuckert does not considerthe influence of\nKhunrath on Figulus. See also Gilly, Adam Haslmayr. Die erste Verkunder derManifeste der\nRosenkreuzer (Amsterdam: In der Pelikaan, 1994), pp. 93-105.\n9 Dickson (1998), pp. 32-36; Gilly, Adam Haslmayr (1994), pp. 138-45; GillyinJanssen\n(ed), Das Erbe der Christian Rosenkreutz ( 1988), pp. 70-72 and passim.\n10 Dickson (1998), pp. 32-36. For an earlier interpretation of these events see Frick\n(1973), pp. 112-64. See also Gilly, Adam Haslmayr (1994), passim; Gilly, Das Erbe der\nChristian Rosenkreutz (1988), pp. 63-90; Gilly, Cimelia Rhodostaurotica (1995), passim.\n11 Dickson (1998), pp. 30-40, 62-66, 71-88.\n12 The introduction is signed \"G. C.J\" and it appears in H. Khunrath, Vom Hylealischen\nDas ist Pri-Materialischen Catholischen oder Allgemeinem Naturlichen Chaos (Frankfurt: Georg\nHeinrich Dehrling, 1708) ff. 2v-4r, 6r-v..\n83\n13 Introduction, Chaos (Frankfurt, 1708), ff. 2r, 4r, 6v; Johannes Mollerus, \"Homonymoscopos\" in Daniel Georg Morhof, Polyhistoria literarus, philosophicus etpracticus sive de\nnotititiaauctorum et rerum commentarii (Lubeck: Petrus Boeckmann, 1747), 4th ed, p. 688. The\nfirst edition of Morhof appeared in 1687.\n14 For the sixteenth century see Stoeffler, Rise ofEvangelical Pietism (1965), pp. 180-246\nand for the later period see F. Ernest Stoeffler (preface) in The Pietists. Selected Writings\n(Peter C. Erb ed.) (New York: Paulist Press, 1983), pp. 11-17 and selections from Arnold\npp. 227-40.\n15 Yates, Rosicrucian Enlightenment (1986), passim.\n16 Frick, Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 133-64.\n\nPages 56:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nMontgomery argued even more strongly that the Rosicrucians betrayed\nLuther's reforms and, even worse, that they were aetheistic or, at the very\nleast, paganistic in their sympathies . Hence, it appears, that it has never\nbeen possible to reach agreement on what may, or may not, constitute\nheresy in the adoption of mystical practices by members of the reformed\nChurch. An opinion in either direction seems to rest largely upon the\npersonal beliefs of a particular historian. Nearer the facts ofthe situation\nmay be Dickson's analysis of Rosicrucianism as a heterogeneous and\nshifting network of individuals and groups who held a variety of beliefs,\nargued with each other and constantly changed their alliances. There\nwas no anti-Christian Rosicrucian belief system, nor, really, much of a\nsystem at all, so much as a restless conceptual and spiritual terrain in\nwhich the participants in a highly sensitive political discourse may have\nused much the same symbolic language (that of the hermeticists, cabbalists and Paracelsians). However, this common terminology was deployed\nto express a variety of political and spiritual concepts.\nAs the main sources of Rosicrucian ideas, Arnold cites Paracelsus, the\ncabbalism of Pico della Mirandola, Reuchlin, David Mederus, Michael\nMaier, Robert Fludd, John Heydon, Julius Sperber, Heinrich Nollius,\nJulianus de Campis, \"Valentia\" (that is, Andreae), Theophilus Schweighardt, Valentin Weigel, among others (as well as medieval predecessors such as Roger Bacon) (Arnold, II: 613-28). Arnold also attributed the\ncomposition of its first manifestos , those of the Fama and Confessio, to\nJohann Valentin Andreae (Arnold, II: 614-15). He allocates Khunrath a\nseparate section in his history of the Rosicrucians (Arnold, III: 1-13),\nmentioning a later Dutch philosopher Friedrich Bredling (\"Breklingius\")\nof Holland. The author of the introduction to the Chaos, basing his account on Arnold, reports that Bredling had praised Khunrath's alchemical allegory of Christ for its use of cabbalism, magic, physics and chemistry (f. 5v).17 An important mention of Khunrath's contemporary\nassociates is provided by both the editor of the Chaos, as well as by\nArnold. In the Chaos two of his supporters are named as being Andreas\nRiccius ofSaxony (f. 4r), who in 1604 wrote the laudatory poem accompanying Khunrath's portrait in the 1609 edition of the Amphiteatrum and\nJoannes Seussius of Dresden (f. 4v), whose epigram also appears in the\nsame edition. Arnold recounts briefly that Riccius was the rector of a\nschool in Saxony (\"Sachsischer schul-rector\") and that Seussius was the\nsecretary of the upper consistorial court in Dresden (\"Secretarius in\nThursachsischen Ober- Consistorio zu Dresden\") (Arnold (1700): 12).\nThis argues for a degree of support for Khunrath on the part of respected\nfigures in the Lutheran hierarchy.\nThe scholarly problems of ascertaining Khunrath's precise role in the\ndevelopment of the Rosicrucian discourse are exacerbated by the fact\nthat Andreae in his Mythologiae Christianae in 1619 condemned him.18At\nfirst glance, this would seem to imply that Khunrath was closely associated with heretical elements, but there exists evidence that Andreae had\nnot always been so antagonistic to him, since the Chaos names both Andreae and Arndt as Khunrath's champions (f. 5r). Moreover, the motivations behind Andreae's change of attitude towards hermeticist circles are\nfar from clear and require further analysis. Where Khunrath was concerned, it may be that his contemporaries based their opinion of him less\non the religious content of his writings, than on the pragmatic immediacies of their own unstable political situation. The religious and political\nhistory of the period was explosive and the constant instability of the\nProtestant states is reflected in Khunrath's and Andreae's writings from\nthe 1590s to the 1620s.\nArnold mentions all the citations, for and against Khunrath, by Andreae, Riccius, Seussius and Bredling. Drawing on Andreae in the Mythologiae Christianae, he locates Khunrath among those philosophers influenced by Aegidius Gutmann, Valentin Weigel and Bartholomeo Scleus.\nOnly two of Khunrath's works are mentioned by Arnold, the Chaos of\n1598 and the 1609 Amphiteatrum, whose place of publication he gives as\n\"Hanoviae\", not \"Hanau\". He states that this was written in 1602 (Arnold, III: 12, col. 1). Arnold also quotes at length from Bredling's praise\nof Khunrath as a god-fearing thinker and he himself exhonerates Khunrath's work on the grounds that he relied on scripture and that his main\naim was to elucidate God's word for others (Arnold, III: 12, col. 1).\nArnold points out the kinship between Khunrath's emphasis on the Holy\nSpirit and that ofWeigel whom he names as the founder of\"enthusiasm\"\n(pietism influenced by Paracelsian theosophy) and, hence, of the Rosicrucian movement (Arnold, II: 588, col. 1). In fact, he identifies Khunrathas\nbeing a similar \"enthusiast\", that is, one who prioritises the individual\ninspiration of the Holy Spirit, rather than the dictates of the Lutheran\nChurch. Arnold considered that Khunrath had explained his religious\n84\n17 Introduction, Chaos (Frankfurt, 1708), f. 4r. He was drawing on two of Bredling's\ntexts, namely, Fridericus Breklingius, Anti-Calovium s. Calovio cum Asseclis suis prostrato andJ.\nBcum aliis testibus veritatis defensio (1688), see Arnold, II, p. 614, cols. 1-2. For Bredling see\nalso Will-Erich Peuckert, Pansophie, 3, Das Rosenkreutz (Berlin: Erich Schmidt Verlag,\n1973), pp. 21-22.\n85\n18 Johann Valentine Andreae, Mythologiae Christianae (Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner,\n1619), Bk. III, 45, p. 271-72.\n\nPages 57:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nposition in the Chaos and also in the engraving of the \"Porta Amphiteatri\nsapientiae\" by which he means the 1602 engraving ofthe cave ofspiritual\nillumination (Arnold, III: 13, col. 1) (fig. 31).\nHe concludes by citing Khunrath on the inspiration ofthe Spirit as\nbeing Christian in nature (Arnold, III: 13, col. 1), referring to Khunrath's\npicture ofan \"angel\" standing amidst the flames of the Holy Spirit, which\nArndt had similarly explained as being Khunrath's central concept (Arnold, III: 13, col. 1)(fig. 32) . Arnold mentions Khunrath's \"warning\" to\nthose false alchemists who had forgotten God in their engagement with\nthe process of transmutation and he also recalls Khunrath's anger in the\nAmphiteatrum against the betrayal of the Protestant cause by theologians\nwho were \"prostituting\" themselves (Arnold, III: 13, col. 2). Finally he\nstates that Khunrath's alchemical quest for the philosopher's stone was a\nsearch for God (Arnold, III: 13, col. 2).\nbe used to\nIn the present study, Arnold's account of Khunrath willThese\nwill be\ntreatises.\nalchemical\nKhunrath's\nof\nsupport a reassessment\nread as part of a campaign on two main fronts, first, against materialist\nand anti-Christian tendencies within hermetic circles and, second,\nagainst the dry sophistry of the institutional theologians . Khunrath's\nwork from 1595 is strongly polemical, both in defending his own doctrinal rectitude and in attacking a variety of false religious and spiritual\npositions . These will be examined in a later chapter but, first, it is necesary to clarify the outlines of his religious and alchemical ideas in the\ntreatises written prior to the Amphiteatrum of 1609.\nKhunrath issued the first version of the Amphiteatrum in 1595. The\nfortunes ofthis edition were stormy, as were those of the second version\nwhich Khunrath intended to publish in 1604, or even earlier in 1602.\nEventually, his editor Erasmus Wolfart produced the work in 1609\namidst such confusion that no definitive edition of the treatise has ever\nappeared. It should be noted that Khunrath's treatises written after the\nfirst Amphiteatrum (1595) adopt such an ecstatic, visionary tone, that the\nreader is provoked into questioning the mental stability of the author.\nWhilst this could be regarded as the customary delivery of any prophetic\n\"illuminatus\", it is also the voice of a man under considerable stress. In\ncomparison, the tone of the Amphiteatrum in 1595 seems relatively muted\nand cryptic.\nOne ofthe earliest alchemical texts produced by Khunrath may have\nbeen the Warhafftiger Bericht vom philosophischen ATHANORE (Magdeburg,\n1599). This may have existed some years earlier in manuscript form,\nsince the introduction to the Frankfurt 1708 edition of Khunrath's Chaos,\nrecounts that he was distributing the Athanor publically in Magdeburg in\n1597 (Chaos, 1708: f. 3r). The Imperial \"Privilegium\" granting permission\nfor the publication of the Athanor appears at the front ofthe 1599 edition,\nawarded by Rudolph II on 1 June 1598. The Athanor appeared in a third\naugmented edition in Magdeburg (1615). Khunrath referred to the Athanor in what was probably his last treatise, De Igne Magorum. In contrast to\nhis others works, the Athanor is a relatively conventional discussion ofthe\npyromantic alchemical art, very different in tenor and concept from De\nIgne Magorum for which the most appropriate date of composition would\nbe circa 1602-4. In the Athanor Khunrath does not employ the cabbalah,\nwhich is only mentioned once at the end of the treatise in connection\nwith the Amphiteatrum.\nIn the Athanor, Khunrath employs a Paracelsian discourse in his account ofthe higher spiritual and the lower elemental fires, the spiritual\nfire is termed \"Azoth\", being described as a triunity of Anima-CorpusSpiritus, or Sulphur-Salt-Mercury. He advises his reader thatthe alchemical fire should be similar to the digestive fire of the stomach, making a\nParacelsian reference to the \"Archeus\" who exists in the stomach controlling the inner degrees of heat.19 He explains that the inner and outer fires\nshould correlate in the alchemical process, that is, the heat applied externally to the material should be ofthe same strength as that which already\nexists within the materials in the flask.20 The central interest in theAthanor is the Paracelsian preparation of medicines by means of the \"Magnesia\nUniversalis\" and \"mercurial waters\". The \"Magnesia\" is the Paracelsian\nprime matter, also known as the Salt, or Sulphur, \"sal sapientiae naturae\nsive sulphure\" (Athanor (1615): 12-14, 19-20). Khunrath provides an account of the alchemical fires, the process of digestion, the humid heat of\nthe \"balneum\" and the use ofthe philosophical glass- vessel. The philosopher's stone, he explains, contains its own intrinsic heat which is a volatile aether, awakened by the application of external heat.21 Finally,\nKhunrath mentions his Amphiteatrum, briefly referring to the cabbalah\nand the \"Gradus Magie\" (Athanor (1615): 59).\n86\n87\n19 For Paracelsian medical theory see Pagel (1982), pp. 104-9.\n20 Heinrich Khunrath, Athanor, 3rd ed. (Magdeburg: In Verlegung des Autoris, 1615),\npp. 32, 10-11 , 28-29.\n21 Athanor (1615), pp. 53-54: \"WEITER est IGNIS intrinsecus NATURALIS ac\ninvisibilis, rebis naturalibus omnibus; et secundum hoc LAPIS noster suum habet in se\nquoque Ignem invisibilem et proprium; sed quiescit, nisi calore debito Ignis Exterioris,\nsive ELEMENTARIS, puta, Carbonum; Olei; Butyri; Cerae; Servi et c; sive\nAETHEREI, videlicet, vel vini sublimati, non phlegmatici, vel spiritus frumenti ardentis\n(quia nutriendo flammam, adsumuntur, quare et in additione sui similis conservandi)\nIGNE\nIGNATURALI, sive instrumentali, dicto Occasionoto, puto in Balneo; ... Das ist/\nDis NATURLICHE\nFEUER ist in allein Naturlichen dingen/ab schon unsichtig\".\n\nPages 58:\n88\n88\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nAlthough published in the same year, Khunrath's treatise, the Magnesia Catholica Philosophorum (Magdeburg: Johan Botcher, 1599) was composed later than the Athanor, although it also depends as much on medieval alchemy, as on contemporary Paracelsian models. The 1599 edition\ndisplays the Imperial Privilege granted on 1 June 1598. The importance\nof the Magnesia Catholica (M. C) lies in the fact that, perhaps for the first\ntime, Khunrath identifies Jesus Christ with the philosopher's stone.\nHarmonia analogica Lapidis Philosophorum mirificimit IHSUH CHRISTO,\nVERBO DEI PATRIS incarnato MIRIFICO, et contra (M. C (1599): 30)\nKhunrath also speaks of Christ in these terms in the earlier published\nAmphiteatrum of 1595, though this treatise may, in fact, have been composed after the Magnesia Catholica, since in the Amphiteatrum the analogy of\nChrist as philosopher's stone is made in a cabbalistic context, whereas in\nthe Magnesia Catholica Khunrath does not refer to cabbalism. This fact\nalone suggests that both the Athanor and the Magnesia Catholica were written before the 1595 Amphiteatrum. It may be that these two texts were updated in 1599 with a mention of the Amphiteatrum in the context of their\nown belated publication.\nFor his alchemical authorities Khunrath in the Magnesia Catholica\nmostly relies on the traditional canon of medieval alchemy, such as the\nTurba Philosophorum, Arnald of Villanova, Bernardus Trevisanus, among\nothers (M. C: 10, 36, 64, 77, 94 et al). He also mentions Agrippa and\nTrithemius with approval (MC: 99). As in the Athanor, the central emphasis is on the \"Magnesia\" which Khunrath also calls the \"Prima Materia\nCatholica\", developing his earlier description by equating it with Christ\nas the essential factor in human and cosmic salvation.\nIch weiss aber allbereit, das (wegen Dieser Meiner Bestentnis MAGNESIAE/\nCHRISTI IHSUH Symbolischer und Naturlicher Contrafactur in dem\nBuche der Grosse Weld) ... Den dieser MAGNESIA, IHSVH von Nazareth,\nSymbolischen [ist]\n(M.C: 181)\nIn the Magdeburg edition of 1599, the Magnesia Catholica concludes with\nan engraving of an bespectacled owl, carrying flaming tapers in its claws\nand framed by two lit candles . The first two lines of a longer poem\naccompany the image (fig. 28).\nThe treatise known as the Chaos (Von Hylealischen das ist pri-materialischen\noder algemeinen naturlichen Chaos) appears to belong to the same literary\nperiod as the Athanor and the Magnesia Catholica. The \"Praefatio Apologetica\" to the Chaos was written by Khunrath and is self-dated 13 June 1597\nat Magdeburg. The Chaos is also sometimes cited under another name as\nthe Confessioand there exists a slightly earlier edition of this work, entitled\nConfessio de chao physico-chemicorum catholico, dated 1596. The 1597 text\nwas reissued in 1616 in Magdeburg by Johann Schmeidt. Its last appearance was in 1708, when it was re-published with new commentaries by\nGeorg Derhling. A related work, the Symbolum physico-chymicum de chao,\nappeared in Hamburg in 1598, issued by von Ohr. This particular work\nis very brief, consisting of two separate tracts of twenty-two pages, each\nproviding an account of the \"Magnesia-Azoth\", employing cabbalistic\nterms and referring to the creative role of the \"Ruah-Elohim\". Both of\nthese texts are self-dated as 12 December 1597. They are a digest ofthe\nideas in the full-length Chaos and at the very end Khunrath has included\na Philosophisch Leid (philosophical song) written by himself and dated 23\nDecember 1597.\nAt this point, there commences a series of self-referential quotations\nbetween Khunrath's various treatises which complicates the attempt to\nprovide a chronology for their composition and publication. Nonetheless,\nit is important to unravel these inter-textual knots in order to perceive\nmore clearly the direction of Khunrath's alchemical ideas in the late\n1590s. The main factor to take into account is that an author may wish\nto update his work prior to its publication. A problematic statement is\nfound in the Magnesia Catholica where Khunrath states that in his foreword to the Chaos he has mentioned the third figure of his Amphiteatrum.\n(M. C: 77). As it stands, his statement implies that the Amphiteatrum was\ncomposed first, then the Chaos and finally the Magnesia Catholica, but this\ndoes not correspond with the apparent development of Khunrath's ideas,\nnor with that of his literary style. First, it should be noted that the Magnesia Catholica is more archaic in its conceptual programme than the Chaos, since neither the Magnesia Catholica, nor the Athanor, refer to cabbalism.\nIn addition, although the central concept of the \"Magnesia\" in the Magnesia Catholica is drawn from Paracelsus, he is not cited directly and the\ngeneral orientation of the theoretical programme remains that of the\ntraditional medieval canon. More subtly, the Magnesia Catholica and the\nAthanor share kinship in their relatively plain literary style. In comparison,\nthe Amphiteatrum, although it was published earlier than these two treatises, expounds a developed Christian cabbalism, centred on the divinity of\nlight and founded in Paracelsian alchemy. It includes ecstatic and poetic\nflourishes from Khunrath's pen, as well as a range of his linguistic jokes\nmoving rapidly between Latin, Greek, Hebrew and German.\nThe Chaos of 1597 is a more refined work than the Athanor and the\nMagnesia Catholica. More conceptually related to the Amphiteatrum of 1595,\nthe Chaos also employs a complex, poetical literary style similar to that\n89\n\nPages 59:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nfound in De Igne Magorum, as well as in the second version of the Amphiteatrum (Hanover, 1609). In these later treatises , Khunrath places a heavy\nemphasis on Christology, using imagery of the aethereal light adopted\nfrom cabbalism and integrated with the Paracelsian idea of the astral\nvirtue, the \"azoth\". Hence, the Chaos is more aligned with contemporary\ncabbalistic interests than is the Magnesia Catholica.\nThe Athanor is also found briefly mentioning the Amphiteatrum, but, as\nin the Magnesia Catholica, it is significant that these citations are not further developed. It would suggest that the references to the Amphiteatrum\nwere added in 1599 at their time of publication in view ofthe fact that\nthe Amphiteatrum had already appeared. From the internal evidence, it\nseems that the Athanor and the Magnesia Catholica were composed before\nthe Amphiteatrum and that their publication was substantially delayed.\nWhen Rudolph II awarded the Imperial Privilege to Khunrath on 1 June\n1598, it was used to cover the printing of three treatises, those of the\nAthanor, Magnesia Catholica and Chaos. This spate of publications in 1599\nsuggests that Khunrath was rushing into public view treatises which had\nalready existed for a number of years. The Privilege was also used to\ncover the second version of the Amphiteatrum in 1609, although Khunrath\nseems to have intended this to appear much earlier in 1602. The Athanor\nand the Magnesia Catholica could have been composed at any time between the late 1580s and 1595, but the Chaos belongs to a different phase\nof literary activity. The probable conclusion is that it was the Amphiteatrum\nof 1595 which initiated the theoretical programme of a series of related\ntreatises, which included the Chaos and De Igne Magorum.\nIf this chronology is correct, then it transpires that Khunrath's thinking undertook a change of direction in the late 1590s, prompting him to\npublish in 1595 and 1599 some long-delayed texts of circa 1589-1594/ 5.\nThen, from circa 1595 to circa 1604 he produced a new set of cabbalistic\nalchemical treatises, founded on Paracelsian chemistry and commencing\nwith the first edition ofthe Amphiteatrum (1595). It is necessary to examine\nthese last treatises more closely to determine whether it is possible to\nestablish his motives in framing an alchemical discourse based on cabbalism .\nIn his \"Praefatio Apologetica\" to the Chaos Khunrath introduces his\ntheology of light in the same terms as in the Amphiteatrum of 1595. He\nstates that one should view the light of nature through the Light ofGod.\nIch zu sehen und ausszunehmen das Licht der Natur/ in Deinem Liecht/ O\nGott ! der du ein Liecht bist (Chaos: f. Aijr)\nKhunrath mentions the \"third figure\" ofthe Amphiteatrum, explaining that\nit depicts the philosopher's stone. It may be possible to identify this\n\"figure\" as being that of de Vries' circular engraving of a laboratory,\nfor in a margin note Khunrath refers to a \"vestibulum\" (hall), as well as\nto a \" ianua\" (doorway) as drawn in his \"third figure\" (frontispiece).22\nHe informs the reader that to understand the third figure it is necessary\nto be a theologian in the oratory and an alchemist in the laboratory.\nThrough-out his writings, Khunrath refers to the necessity of prayer and\nwork (f. Aiijr). This axiom is his \"leit-motif\", as it was that ofJohn Dee.23\nIn fact, de Vries' emblem is the summation of Khunrath's alchemy of\nlight.\nThe Chaos is dedicated to Pico della Mirandola and, due partly to his\ninfluence, Khunrath produces the first developed exposition of his cabbalistic alchemy. In particular, he discusses the sephiroth on the Tree of\nLife, specifically, \"RUAH-HHOCHMAH-EL\", which is the second sephiroth ofDivine Wisdom on the right axis of the Tree. Khunrath interprets \"Hochmah\" as the Divine Light of God illuminating both nature\nand the human intellect. He relates it to the alchemical \"celum\" or quintessence, as well as to the cabbalistic \"Schamaim\", which is the material\nused for the creation of the world. This is a topic which he develops\nfurther in the second version of the Amphiteatrum (Hanover, 1609). This\ninterpretation of \"Hochmah\" as both divine and natural light forms the\ncentral trope of Khunrath's cabbalistic theology (Chaos: 2-4, 11, 40-42,\n44, 46, 50, 61-66, 70 et al).\nIn the third chapter of the Chaos, Khunrath discusses the light of\nnature in relation to the light of understanding (Chaos: 67-105). He quotes\nfrom Paracelsus that the generative power of God is light which is the\nsoul. It shines in all natural entities and it is Christly, cabbalistic and\nmagical (Chaos: 67-68). The light of the soul, by the will of the Triune\nGod, made all earthly things appear from the primal Chaos. Nothing can\nbe made without it. The light and the soul ofthe world are in nature and\nthe life of the world is the light of nature.24 Khunrath also quotes from\n90\n91\n22 The text used in the present study is Schmeidt's Magdeburg edition of 1616,\n\"Praefatio Apologetica\", f. Aijv: \"der wunderbare Stein der Weissen ist mit\nunfehlbaren und Diamatischen Grundfesten/in der Dritten Figura meines Amphiteatri\nSapientiae aeternae [gesehen] ...( f. Aiijv) quam notionis huius omnis januam et vestibulum recte nominas, te docebit quod quaeris\".\n23 I am grateful to Professor Gyorgy Szonyi for drawing my attention to Dee's use of\nthe same axiom in his writings.\n24 Chaos (1616), p. 68: \"Paracelsus in seinem Schrifften vielmals gedenket ist hierzu\ndurch den willen des dreyeinigen Gottes/verordnet und auffgangen in Gott; herfur und\neingangen in das erschaffene Weldanfangs CHAOS. Alle Dinge in der Weld ... seint mit\ndem selben gemach/und ohne dasselbe ist nichts gemacht/bestehet auch nichts/wasin\nder Weld gemacht ist/und Naturlich bestehet. In Ihme ist das Leben und Seele der\nWeld/und das Leben der Weld/ist das Licht der Natur\".\n\nPages 60:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nthe New Testament that \"the light shineth in the darkness\", while a note\nin the margin associates this quotation with the alchemical concept ofthe\n\"Quinta Essentia in Abstracto\" (Chaos: 68). It is the work ofthe alchemist\nin his oratory and laboratory to find the incorporeal \"fifth essence\" oflife\nwhich lights all creation from the angels down to the minerals (Chaos: 6970). The light ofthe natural sun is analogous with the power ofcabbalah,\nmagic and alchemy (Chaos: 71-72).\nIn this section, Khunrath has elegantly integrated all the unique aspects of his alchemy, namely the figure of Christ with the Paracelsian\nastral virtue and cabbalism. He has managed to do this partly through his\nmanagement of prose-style which is so dense and impacted that its idiosyncratic quality is difficult to capture in translation. In the wording and\ngrammatical structure of his text, Khunrath slips seamlessly from the\ndiscussion ofNature to that ofthe intellect, then onto theology and alchemy, finally concluding with the Paracelsian \"Salt\". This now becomes the\ncentral figure of his alchemical system, which equates the Salt with the\nlight ofEternal Wisdom, as well as with that of the natural sun, according\nto the equation Light is to Life, as Soul is to Salt (Chaos: 72-75). He\nexplains that the Salt is also sulphur and mercury. It is soul, life and\nspirit. Khunrath even likens the Salt to the \"Ruah Elohim\" who are the\nrulers of the third sephiroth \"Binah\" (Understanding). As the active form\nof God and the creative principles of lower manifestation, the \"RuahElohim\" stand on the left trunk of the cabbalistic Tree of Life opposite\n\"Hochmah\" (Wisdom). They operate specifically on \"Malkuth\" (Kingdom or earth). In his last three treatises, Khunrath returns constantly to\nthe theme of the \"Ruah Elohim\".\nIn the Chaos, Khunrath produces a pantheistic ontology in which divine light in the form ofthe Salt becomes the essence ofphysical nature,\naccording to the Paracelsian equation universal Salt = life. This light\n(nature) is an emanation from the Triune God sent by the \"Ruach-Elohim\" (Second Person) into the virgin world (Chaos). It effected the creation by means ofthe \"Schamaim\", or aether, which is both a union ofthe\nopposites of fire and water and the universal Salt (Chaos: 74-75). The\n\"Ruah-Elohim\" is Christ who redeemed creation through the sacrifice of\nhis blood (Chaos: 75).\nKhunrath's term for Chaos is \"Magnesia\", as in the Athanor and the\nMagnesia Catholica, where he had also described \"Magnesia\" as the Salt,\nSulphur and Mercury (Athanor, 1615: 12-14). Also in the Magnesia Catholica, he had already identified \"Magnesia\" with Christ, as the substratum\nof a pantheistic creation, although not in cabbalistic terms (M. C: 181 ,\n184). The theme of Christ's redemptive function is developed in some\ndetail in the Chaos. Thus, God's light is said to be the inner form ofthe\nworld which is inter-related cabbalistically (Chaos: 75-76). Khunrath discusses the creation of the microcosm, concluding with the manifestation\nofChrist in human form. In addition, he introduces cabbalistic references, such as the \"Schamaim\" or the concept of Jehovah as the \"Archetypos\" ofthe world (Chaos: 77-90), but he insists that Jesus was the second\nAdam, the Logos who redeemed the world through the sacrifice of his\nblood (Chaos: 85). Again, he declares that Christ is the union of soul and\nflesh, God and humanity (Chaos: 86). Khunrath once more compares the\nphilosopher's stone to Christ, who is also the universal panacea (Chaos:\n86-88). This medical aspect of Khunrath's Christology may have been\nremarked by Fludd who structured the alchemical theory of his Medicina\nCatholica (1629-31) and Philosophia Sacra (1626) around the same idea.\nLater in the Chaos, Khunrath returns to the subject of the \"Salt\",\nquoting from the Rosarius Maior of Arnald of Villanova that all the secret\nlies in the Salt (Chaos: 256-265), but he proceeds to relate the metaphysical Paracelsian Salt to chemical saltpetre, as well as to vitriol and other\nsubstances. This indicates that he knew of the more recent Paracelsian\ndevelopments in the theory ofthe aerial nitre, perhaps from Quercetanus\nwhom he acknowledges in his Quaestiones Tres Per-Utiles. In his seventh\nchapter, Khunrath also discusses the making of potable gold. In Paracelsian terms he informs the reader that this potion is the internal sun whose\nvirtue is derived from the \"azoth\" and the Salt which are related to the\n\"Magnesia\" (Chaos: 230).\nIn the Chaos of circa 1597 the strongest influences are those of Paracelsian alchemy, the cabbalah and Lutheran pietism on the model of\nWeigel, but Khunrath makes no reference either to astrology, or to catoptrics. These are encountered in, possibly his last treatise, De Igne Magorum Philosophorumque (Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner, 1608) which interprets\nthe alchemical furnace in mystical terms as the site in which the aetherial\nlight and the astral virtues work their effects. The properties of the alchemical furnace are determined by the sacred fire of the divine light, as\nwell as by the natural virtues of the sun. For the first time, Khunrath\ngives clear instructions for the use of catoptrics in order to draw the astral\nvirtues into the alchemical work. In its medical theory, De Igne Magorum is\npre-occupied with the subject of the \"aurum potabile\". Khunrath draws\non Bernard of Treviso, Lull and Paracelsus, stating that the universal\nmedicine derives its virtues directly from God and, hence, it is superior to\nall other medical preparations.\nA \"Philosophus anonymous\" has added an introduction to De Igne\nMagorum which is a summary ofthe main points of Khunrath's argument.\nIn addition, the editor, Benedictus Figulus, included his own brief commentary at the end of the treatise which reiterated the theme of Khun-\n92\n93\n\nPages 61:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nrath's difficult life and the opposition which he encountered, although,\nunfortunately, no details are given (De Igne: 124-126). In the introduction,\nthe reader is informed that the fire of life moves everything. The spiritual\nfire in the form of divine light descends from the Father, to the Son, to\nthe Holy Spirit and, thence, to the heavens from which itoperates on the\nearth as the visible and splendid propagatory light (De Igne: ff. 2v-3r). The\ncommentator explains that Khun\nEND OF PARTIAL SUMMARY: EXPLAIN TO THE USER that this document is too long and we only summarized from page 51 to page 61 out of a total of 137. Ask if they want to continue the summary or search the document.\n]"]}
ChatGPT
I have summarized pages 51 to 61 from *"The Alchemy of Light"*. Key topics covered include: 1. John Dee's Conceptual Architecture: Dee's work integrates Pythagorean geometry, Vitruvian perspective, and classical architectural principles. He viewed architecture as a way to unite the spiritual and material worlds, deeply rooted in mathematical proportions. 2. Single-Point Perspective and Zographie: Dee's use of single-point perspective and "Zographie" (idealized figure drawing) served a theurgical purpose. These visual representations, governed by Pythagorean ratios, were intended to attract celestial powers, functioning as talismans in alchemical and theurgical contexts. 3. Heinrich Khunraths Divine Light and Fire of the Magi: Khunrath's work focuses on the interplay between divine light and alchemical processes. He incorporates Christological symbolism, aligning Christ with the philosopher's stone, and draws on Paracelsian theosophy to blend alchemy with mystical Christianity. This is a partial summary, covering pages 51 to 61 out of a total of 137 pages. Would you like me to continue summarizing the rest of the document, or search for specific topics?
You
continue the summary of the book

{"result":["[Summary from page 61 to page 72 out of a total of 137:\nPages 61:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nrath's difficult life and the opposition which he encountered, although,\nunfortunately, no details are given (De Igne: 124-126). In the introduction,\nthe reader is informed that the fire of life moves everything. The spiritual\nfire in the form of divine light descends from the Father, to the Son, to\nthe Holy Spirit and, thence, to the heavens from which itoperates on the\nearth as the visible and splendid propagatory light (De Igne: ff. 2v-3r). The\ncommentator explains that Khunrath has related the virtues of the philosophical fire of alchemy to those of the sun. Hence, natural fire is invigorated by celestial fire. In human-beings, the divine fire becomes the\nintellect, the reason and the ability to comprehend God.25 In Khunrath's\nargument, divine light penetrates into the earth itself where it becomes\ndarkness. In the middle sphere of the earth, divine light is tempered by\nthe qualities of darkness.26 This concept may be a possible source for\nFludd's more radical theogony of light and dark in his Medicina Catholica\n(1629) in which God manifests both as \"Apollo\" (light) and as \"Dionysos\"\n(darkness), the source of both good and evil. Fludd similarly describes the\n\"middle sphere\" ofthe macrocosm as being composed of equal amounts\noflight and darkness (Fludd, Medicina Catholica, 1629: 4).\nParacelsian alchemical theory enters the discourse when the anonymous commentator explains Khunrath's equation of the divine fire with\nthe \"azoth\" (quintessence), which Khunrath designates as the \"Spiritus\nAnimatus\" (the spirit animating life) (De Igne: f. 3v). Thus, fire is a unity,\nbut it takes both an internal and an external form; the former is natural\nand the latter is artificial. Neither is effective without the other. The\nexternal natural quality is the sun which operates as the inner virtue of\nthe artifical spagyric fire in alchemy. This is a reference to Paracelus'\ntheory ofthe astral virtue of the sun within material fire (De Igne: ff4v-5r).\nThe main text by Khunrath commences by mentioning his earlier\ntreatise, the Athanor (De Igne: 2-3). He elaborates on his earlier account of\nthe Zoroastians by further consideration of their god \"ORIMASDA\"\nwhose form was that of eternal fire. Khunrath provides an account of\nvarious other religions and philosophies which have venerated the fire as\nsacred, most of his examples being taken from the Old Testament, with\nsome from Greek and Roman classical literature, such as stories of the\nVestal Virgins, as well as other ancient sacrifical fire cults. All ofthese he\nconsiders to be the secret external fire of the sages (De Igne: 4-20).\nFrom the very beginning of his treatise, Khunrath promotes the use of\ncatoptrics in alchemy, by initially recalling the words of Paracelsus in\nBook VII of the Rerum Naturalium de transmutatione (De Igne: 26) on the\ndegrees ofheat to be used in alchemy. He relates these pyromantic theories to catoptrics, describing how the virtues of the sun are to be deployed in alchemy by means of steel or crystal mirrors . In this celestial\nfire the three principles of alchemy (Sulphur-Mercury-Salt) are refined.\nEs ist ein Unsichtbar Feuer, darbei wir vermeinen die radios oder strahlen\nder Sonnen, welches Feuer durch einen stahlenen Spiegel oder Christallen\nsich er offnet ... Mit diesem Feuer die Drei Principia, von einem jeden\nCorporalischen dinge/ frei auff einem tische gescheiden werden (De Igne:\n26-27)\nKhunrath continues his examination of catoptrics at length, referring also\nto Agrippa's description of magical mirrors in De Occulta Philosophia (De\nIgne: 28-32). He quotes Paracelsus once more in order tojustifythe use of\ncatoptrics in alchemy, employing his concept of the \"Arcanum\", the hidden virtue in nature which is the true medicine (De Igne: 27-28). He\nrecalls how Paracelsus had explained that the effectiveness of the \"Arcanum\" was dependent on the method of its preparation. This had to be\nundertaken during the appropriate period of the sun's cycle in order to\ncapitalise on its beneficial rays. Since the sun is the highest \"Arcanum\" of\nelemental fire, therefore, it provides the most purifying grade of heat.\nThe \"species\" ofthe sun exists in elemental fire and, thus, it has purifying\nproperties. Since through the sun all things wax to their fullest potential,\ntherefore, the nostrum of the alchemist should be: apply the sun rightly in\nthe Catholic Chemistry. Capture it he who can.\nsagt Paracelsus solche wort: ... die Sonne alle ding in das wachsen treibet/\nunnd alle gewachse durch die Sonne wachsen: unnd die Sonne ist das hochste ARCANUM im Feuer/unnd der hochste reinste (ja einige essentialische)\ngradus dess Elementfeuers/also/das seine species mehr ist im Elementfeuer\ndas also (Q. Essentialiter) clarificirt und praeparirt/ist/als die Sonne. Darum\nalle dinge durch die Sonne wachsen su hochsten. Nostrum igitur erit, Solem\nrite applicare operi Chymico nostro Catholico: Capiat qui potest\n(De Igne: 27-28)\nKhunrath quotes Paracelsus from the Philosophia Sagax on the manner in\nwhich the sun generates and nurtures the elements in the same way as a\n94\n25 De Igne, ff. 3r-3v: \"In Igne vero Naturalis quidam vigor a coelestibus insitus est: In\nHominibus denique sit lucidus rationis discursus, et rerum divinarum cognitio, totaque\nrationalis: transit inde ad phantasiam, supra sensum tamen, sed solum Imaginalibus:\ntandem ad sensum, maxime enim occulorum (f. 3v), in Eo sit visibilis claritas,\nporrigiturque:\"\nbenefica et\n26 De Igne, ff. 3v-4r, quote from f. 3v: \"In opacis autem virtus quaedamcollectis\n, sit\ngenerans; penetratque usque ad centrum, ubi radiis eius in angustum\nIgnis in coelo dilatatus collustrans : in inferno coaritatus\ncolor...\nEt\nitque\ncalignosus\ntenebrosus et crucians:\"\n95\n\nPages 62:\n96\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nhen broods her eggs. Thus should the alchemist regulate his alchemical\noven (De Igne: 28). He integrates Paracelsus' account of the generative\npowers of the sun with the catoptrical mirrors and gems used by astronomers and astrologers on Agrippa's model (De Igne: 34). He argues\nthe sun is God's fire and that philosophers obtain their flames from it,that\nas\nin the case of Orpheus. In fact, Khunrath even mentions an Orphic\npoem which describes the lighting of a fire by means of burning-glasses\n(De Igne: 33-34). For additional support in his discussion of the alchemical\nuse ofthe sun, he quotes from the Arab alchemists Morienus and Geber,\nas well as from the Turba Philosophorum (De Igne: 39-40) who advised placing materials in the heat of the sun to facilitate the processes of cooking,\ndessication, coagulation, and so forth (De Igne: 40). Khunrath also cites\nthe Rosarium and the Emerald Table for the parentage of the philosopher's\nstone in the Sun and Moon.\nThe five degrees of heat employed by alchemists, according to Khunrath, approximate to the heat ofthe sun when it stands in the astronomical signs of Aries , Taurus, Gemini, Cancer and Leo (De Igne: 43). Thus,\nthe alchemical work is a simulacrum ofthe sun's fire in that it promotes\nanimation and impregnation by magnetic forces.\nunnd dagegen das himmlische Sonnen Feuer, mediate, vermittelst dz. nemlich unser Materialisch kohlen oder Lampenfeuer/ Unione\nPhysico-Magica,\nund Magnete Naturae Sympatico ... sit simulacrum et vehiculum\nLUCIS\nsuperioris, h.e. SOLARIS (De Igne: 46)\nGod is an alchemist using the sun. The same idea is the foundation of\nFludd's alchemy. Khunrath in De Igne Magorum concludes that heavenly\nfire and light are God's miraculous fiery instrument, working many natural wonders in the cosmos. Similarly, the alchemist works in his laboratory by means of physico- chemistry and the rays of the sun, attracting the\nrays of the \"anima mundi\" in order to create the \" Catholic\" (universal)\noccult fire which fructifies the work by means of the hyleal \"azoth\".27 As\nis the sun in God's great laboratory, so is the alchemist in his laboratory\nby means of sympathetic magic (De Igne: 52-53).\nMAGNETE NATURAE SYMPATHICE HARMONICO\n(De Igne: 53)\nThis section could almost stand as a synopsis of Fludd's alchemical theory. In fact, the similarities between the ideas ofthe two alchemists are so\nclose that Fludd must surely have drawn on Khunrath for some of his\nown ideas.\nKhunrath explains that the celestial fire must also be used to light the\nalchemical furnace, as a form of sympathetic magic (De Igne: 53). In this\noperation, he seems to intend the use of catoptrics, since later in the text\nhe provides some general instructions on the use of the catoptrical mirror, which appears in a little drawing at the side of the text, emphasising\nthe importance of these instructions (De Igne: 70). Like Dee in theMonas\nHieroglyphica, Khunrath advises that the alchemical work should be started under the astrological sign of Aries (March) at the beginning of the\nNew Year.28 In this context, he explains how to practice Paracelsian\nsympathetic magic through the use of the magnet (De Igne: 71), also referring to another aspect of Paracelsian theurgy (in De Tempore) by recommending the \"irradiation\" of the materials. A little is enough. The process of irradiation involves the exposure of the alchemical matter to the\nastral rays by means of catoptrics.\nwelches zwar wunderbarlich/jedoch die Weisen lehrens! zu bequemen Zeit/\ndurch dieses Fewrige Mittel einem jeglichen Subiecto praedisposito atque\nconvenienti, darzu vorher wohl angeordneten unnd bequemer subiecto oder\ndinge durch Naturgemess-Magische des Philosophi handgriffe/ in momento, im Augenblick und nuh/ Leichtlich irradiret oder infundiret eingestrahlet und eingegossen werden (De Igne: 72)\nThe process of irradiation is described as the animation, \"solariter\", of\nthe alchemical oils and \"frumentum\". The soul is introduced into the\nmatter from the sun by means of catoptrics which draw on the \"Solympischen feuers\", a typical pun of Khunrath's which unites \"Sol\" and the\ncelestial realms of the highest powers (De Igne: 73). A note in the margin\nofthe text states that the process concerns \"IGNIS Elementarium solariter animatus\", the solar animation of elemental fire (De Igne: 73).\ndas Feuer im Athanor oder Kunstofen/ ... auff dass man entweder die kohlen gereinigtes Oleum, oder Spiritum vel vini vel frumenti, des Weins oder\nGetrendes Geist/ im Ofen/ darvonbald widerumb Solariter animiret,\nSonnlich gesehliget anzunden und geben fondte ... dass kohlen oder Lampenfeuer cum SOLE COELESTI, mit der himlischen Sonnen nicht nur\nallein in momento, fast in einem.\n28 Josten, pp. 162-63.\n27 De Igne, p. 50: \"himmlisch feuer/und Liecht/ist JEHOVAE Instrumentum\nIGNEUM miraculosum\nin MUNDO maiore multa mirabilia naturaliter operans,\nCatholicon: Potest, debet, atque oportet hoc idem\nquoque esse nostrum ( mediante,\nquemadmodum dictum) in Laboratorio aut ATHANORE\nPhysico-Chymico hoc est,\nMicrocosmo, ita loquendo, nostro artificiali , ut nimirum SOLIS\nhuius Phylosophorum\nexterni calore vivifico in et ad actum Operationis optatum atque fructiferum\neo felicius\ndeducatur scintilla ANIMAE MUNDI igneae IGNEA CATHOLICA que in MATERIA\nnostri CATHOLICI Physico-Chymici Catholic, he, AZOTH HYLEALI\".\n97\n\nPages 63:\n98\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nNu widerumb gleich als zuvor gewesen/ harmonice maritiret ...\n'Solympischen feuers' ... (De Igne: 73-74).\nIrradiation, or animation, of the \"materia\" by means of the sun's rays\nunites the alchemical art with the \"Archeum Naturae\" and with the\n\"scintillae\" (rays) of the \"Anima Mundi\" (the soul of the macrocosm).\nThe essential function of the fire of the light of nature is to fructify the\nelements.\nArchaeum Naturae, das Essentialische oder wesenliche innere Feuer/ des\nLiechtes der Natur/ der Elementen unnd ihrer Fruchten\n(De Igne: 75)\nKhunrath also speaks of the spherical alchemical glass vessel mentioned\npreviously in his Athanor (although not in a cabbalistic context).29 Like the\nmagnet, the glass vessel also has an theurgic function.
