Nothing can be\nachieved so effectively as by means of the sun's fire.\nAlso auch in inserer Spagirischen kleinen Kunst welt/ das ist/ im Philosophischen glase unnd Ofen von der Natur (auch dem Azoch) nicht das so man\nverhoffet/ produciret, und herfur bracht wirt/ ohne adhibition oder anwendung des Himmlischen Einfachen der Sonnen Feuer/ vermittelst kohlen oder\nLampen wie bikhero recht gelehret und angehoret (De Igne: 97)\nIn relation to the fecundating power of the elemental fires, Khunrath\nquotes Paracelsus from Book X of the Archidoxa (\" de vita longa\") and also\nfrom his Tract VII on mineral hot-waters (\"de thermis pipernis\"). Another reference is taken from Paracelsus' Paragranum Medicinae (col. 3, \"que\nest Alchymia?\") (De Igne: 79).30\nKhunrath's alchemical process of \"irradiation\" may be usefully compared with Newton's similar method of \"illuminating\" his chemicals, as\nrecorded in his earliest alchemical notes written prior to 1678. Newton,\nin fact, may have gathered this idea from Khunrath's treatise, for he took\nnotes from the Amphiteratrum and may well have read his other works.\nDobbs has contextualised Newton's alchemical procedure within his optical theory, placing considerable emphasis on Newton's process ofilluminating his materials in order to activate them. Perhaps rather romantically, Dobbs regarded this procedure as the \"hidden secret\" of alchemy.\n99\nthe active principle could also be, or was identical with the spirit ofGod that\nmoved upon the face of the waters in Genesis. Activation might be effected\nbyan agent totally imperceptible to the senses. There were perhaps hundreds\nof alchemical names for it, for it was one of the great secrets of alchemy,\ndisguised willy-nilly in the texts.31\nIt is certainly true that this process of vivification was never clearly described bythe alchemists, as in the case ofthe section concerning \"Illuminatio\" in the Rosarium. The illustration plainly shows the sun enteringthe\ntomb ofdead matter (fig. 10), but the accompanying text speaks only of\nperfect circles and the astronomical role of the sun. It is Khunrath's De\nIgne Magorum which had, in fact, provided the first clear instructions for\nthe practice of catoptrics in an alchemical context, on the basis ofJohn\nDee's technique in the Mathematicall Preface and the Monas Hieroglyphica.\nDobbs argued further that\nthe activating agent in illumination was broadly conceived and was related to\nvisible light more metaphorically than literally.32\nIn this conclusion, she was being too cautious since the pseudo-Lullian\ncorpus with its astrology, the Rosarium, Dee's catoptrical theories and\nKhunrath's De Igne Magorum all produce the impression that celestial rays\nwere, indeed, being employed by alchemists to \"animate\" their materials.\nIn De Igne Magorum, as well as citing Paracelsus and the medieval\ncorpus , Khunrath also refers to the \"twelve books\" of Giambattista della\nPorta's Magia Naturalis, referring, thereby, to the enlarged second edition\nof 1589 (De Igne: 94). Other authorities mentioned in his account of the\nastral fires and catoptrics include Hermolaus Barbarus in Corollario super\nDioscorides ubi de Aquis in Commune (De Igne: 90), Trithemius in the Aureum\nvellus (De Igne: 94), Joannes Pontanus and Penotus's letter to Joannes Bartholomeus Burggravius (De Igne: 96, 103).\nThe most immediate influence of Khunrath's alchemical catoptrics\nwas on Stefan Michelspacher's Cabala, Spiegel der Kunst und Natur (Augsburg, 1615-1616), consisting of four engravings which represent mirrors\ndisplaying alchemical visions.33 Apart from this Paracelsian alchemical\ntreatise, Michelspacher also published an Optica (1616), illustrated by\nRaphael Baltens. In the Cabala he explains that his visions appeared to\n29 Athanor (1615), pp. 53-54.\n30 See Paracelsus, De vita longa in Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 221-48 (in German), 249-92 (in\nLatin). The Archidoxis is found in Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 92-200 and Das Buch Paragranum in\nSudhoff, I, 8, pp. 31-126.\n31 BettyJo Teeter Dobbs, TheJanus Faces ofGenius (Cambridge University Press, 1991),\npp. 37-46, quote from p. 40.\n32 Dobbs, p. 45.\n33 This was later republished as Cabala, Speculum Artis et Naturae in Alchymia (Augsburg:\nAndreas Erffurt, 1654).\n\nPages 64:\nCHAPTER SEVEN\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH: DIVINE LIGHT AND THE FIRE OF THE MAGI\nhim through the power of a radiating celestial fire in three distinct forms.\nThe first mirror was a fiery sapphire, displaying the philosophical Mercury and Salt, while the second showed him the philosophical Sulphur. The\nthird mirror was of a divinely rosy colour, all in flames, in the midst of\nwhich there appeared a very great \"arcanum\", which was the philosophical fire through which all things come to maturation. Putting together\nthe three mirrors, he made a fourth in which he saw God perfectly\n(Cabala, 1654: f. Blv).\nMichelspacher's concept of the inter- relationship of the celestial and\nelemental fires recalls Khunrath's account in De Igne Magorum. The fourth\nengraving in the Cabala incorporates a distinctive catoptrical motif in a\nWeigelian allusion to the innate and eternal Eucharistic union ofthe soul\nwith Christ (fig. 23).34 The crowned figure seated in the fountain oflife\nsignifies Christ as the philosopher's stone, administering communion in\ntwo chalices to the Sun and Moon (Sulphur and Mercury), representing\nthe soul and spirit of the communicant. In the top right of the picture,\nthere is a scene from the passion of Christ, set within the walled city of\nJerusalem (fig. 24a). An angel hovers over the city, while stream ofwater\nflows from beneath its walls to feed the fountain in which the resurrected\nChrist is seated. This motif is an allusion to Weigel's concept of the\nhistoric figure of Christ as being the external representant of the imminent Christ. At the top left ofthe image is the Tetragrammaton, standing\nin an aureole of light. The dove of the Holy Spirit flies from the cityto\nthe symbol of God, then down to the fountain, its two lines offlight, with\nthat of the stream of water, producing the shape of an equilateral triangle, whose apex lies in the Tetragrammaton, with the fountain and the\ncity as the corners ofits base.\nThe whole scene is set within the circle of the rainbow, while the\nfountain itself is located within a (nearly) square walled-garden. This\nmystical geometry is related to that of Michelspacher's first engraving\nentitled \"Der Spigel der Kunst und Natur\" which shows two geometrical\ndiagrams, the one on the left having the same configuration as thefourth\nengraving, that of circle, square and triangle (fig. 24b). In the first engraving this diagram is stated to be an image of the \"Azoth\", another\nWeigelian and Khunradian allusion to Christ. Thus, Michelspacher's\nadheres to Khunrath's Weigelian polemic in which union with the innate\nChrist as the philosopher's stone was attained through the inspiration of\nthe Holy Spirit. Michelspacher located Khunrath's alchemical Christologywithin a Rosicrucian context, for his treatise is specifically dedicated to\nthe Rosy Cross Fraternity.\nIn Michelspacher's \"Fountain of Life\" the lines of flight ofthe Holy\nSpirit were similar to the catoptrical refraction of light-rays by thesurface\nof a mirror. Comparable imagery of the refraction of light-rays is found\nin other contemporary alchemical illustrations, such as those of Robert\nFludd in his various treatises (fig. 49), or of Michael Maier in the Septimana Philosophica (fig. 37). Such geometrical structures depicting the catoptrical reflection and refraction of light-rays became a distinctive motif in\nlate Renaissance hermetic illustration. A slightly later example is Athanasius Kircher's frontispiece to his treatise on optics, Ars Magna Lucis (Rome,\n1646) (fig. 25) in which the Tetragrammaton appears within a aureole of\nlight at the top, while an owl is drawn at the top right. The figure of\nApollo on the left shines his light onto the mirror of the moon, which\nrefracts it to the earth. Another of his rays is projected onto the human\nsenses through an optical instrument, while a third ray bounces off a\nmirror on the earth into a dark cave. Kircher's illustration describes the\nvarious lights of nature, the senses and the intellect.\nIt remains to discuss the specific influences triggering Khunrath's\nideas concerning the use of astral virtue and catoptrics in alchemy. These\nmay have been inspired by the publication of Paracelsus' completeworks\nin the Basle edition of 1589-90, as well as the appearance ofdella Porta's\nsecond Magia Naturalis (1589). Another influence was undoubtedly Dee's\ncabbalistic astrology and catoptrics, as well as the enduring effects of Pico\ndella Mirandola's and Reuchlin's Christian cabbalism. In the context of\nthe political pressures on his pietistic beliefs between circa 1595 and\n1604, these influences led Khunrath to devise a cabbalistic alchemy of\nlight, founded on Paracelsian theosophy and Renaissance optical science.\nIOO\n34 Peuckert and Zeller (eds), Valentin Weigel. Samtliche Schriften (Stuttgart, 1962-78), 2,\n\"Von der Vergebung der Sunden oder vom Schlussel der Kirchen, pp. 29-31 (absolution\nand the role ofChrist); 4, \"Dialogus de Christianismo\", pp. 7, 133-51, 320-22.\nIOI\n\nPages 65:\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH'S\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE:\nTHE 1595 AND 1602 EDITIONS\nKhunrath's historical reputation rests largely on his Amphiteatrum Sapientiae\nAeternae, yet this treatise has been surprisingly neglected by modern\nscholarship, despite the frequent appearance of its lavish engravings in\npopularised accounts of alchemy, such as Stanislas Klossowski de Rola's\nThe Golden Game. Apart from the complexity of the text and the illustrations, an additional deterent to research is the difficulty of establishing a\nhistory for the two editions of the Amphiteatrum published in 1595 and\n1609 .\nEco has taken the lead in unravelling the threads of the book's complex history, but many issues remain unresolved. The main problem, as\nEco has concluded, is that there does not exist a definitive 1609 edition of\nthe Amphiteatrum since all the extant versions differ in the number and\npagination of their illustrations. He argues that all available copies are\ncomposites and, even more confusing, they disagree with their description in the scholarly catalogues. Consequently, although many editions\nother than that of 1609 are reported, nevertheless, Eco prefers to follow\nde Bure (1764) in arguing that there never was more than one edition of\nthefinal version and that was the one published in \"Hanau\" in 1609.3 He\nalso considers that \"Hanau\" means that town specifically, rather than\n\"Hanover\" as the name is usually translated. (The present study follows\nArnold in retaining the more usual \"Hanover\" translation, since he was\ncloser in time to the facts of this history).\nAnother controversy surrounds the dating of the visual imagery. It is\ndifficult to reconcile any of the pictures with the content of Khunrath's\ntext. It seems that, variously, among the different versions of the 1609\nedition, there exists a stock of illustrations which have been bound in\nStanislas, Klossowski de Rola, The Golden Game. Alchemical Engravings ofthe 17th-C\n(London:\nand Hudson, 1988), pp. 29-44. He provides reproductions of all of\nKhunrath'sThames\nillustrations.\n2 Umberto Eco, Lo Strano Caso della Hanau 1609 (Milan: Bompiani, 1989), p. 5.\n3 Eco, p. 18.\n4 Eco, p. 11 .\n\nPages 66:\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAEAETERNAE. THE 1595 AND 1602 EDITIONS\ndifferent arrangements. The visual repertoire consists of Khunrath's portrait (fig. 26), four images in a circular format (frontispiece and figs. 32,\n33, 34), as well as five images taking a rectangular form. In addition,\nthere is an elaborate frontispiece and also an emblem of an owl (fig. 28),\nwearing spectacles and carrying flaming tapers. Eco argues that the four\nimages which take a circular format originated in the 1595 edition. The\nrectangular images are self-dated on their frames at 1602, being intended\nfor a version ofthe Amphiteatrum which was prepared to be issued in either\n1602 or 1604. A final edition was prepared posthumously for 1607, but it\ndid not appear until 1609.5\nThe problem of determining Khunrath's intentions for his work is\ncomplicated by the different dates appearing on the various component\ntexts ofthe 1609 edition. There is one epilogue dated at 1602 and another dated at 1604, while the editor's foreword is dated 1607. Thorndike\nhas noted that a sketch ofthe first version of the Amphiteatrum was published in Hamburg in 1595. Following his argument, Eco considers that\nonly two versions of Hamburg 1595 still exist, in both cases containing\nthe four circular images. One of these editions now belongs to the Duveen library at the University of Wisconsin,\" while the other copy is\nlocated in the University Library Basel. The Basel version comprises an\nelaborate frontispiece, the four circular illustrations and fewer pages of\ntext than the final 1609 version, as well as two copies of the epilogue. A\nvery important point which Eco makes is that the Basel Amphiteatrum may\nhave been the edition intended for publication in 1602. In addition, Gilly\nmentions two other extant copies of the 1595 Amphiteatrum, one in Darmstadt, while the other is, most significantly, a hand-written copy by Johannes Friedrich Jung, the first publisher ofAndreae's Chymischen Hochzeit\nvon Christian Rosenkreutz. Jung made his copy of Khunrath's treatise in\n1602 , including his own adapted version of the 1595 illustration ofthe\npraying alchemist by de Vries. Gilly rightly cites this item as being evidence of the substantial influence of Khunrath's treatise on Andreae's\ncircles.8\nThe \"Isagoges\" (commentaries) which accompany the 1609 edition,\ncorrespond to the texts originally located around the edges of the 1595\ncircular engravings. In the Hamburg 1595 edition, the circular engravings are dated and inscribed as having been engraved by Paul van der\nDoort di Anversa in that year, but the dates have been removed from the\nHanover 1609 illustrations (frontispiece and figs. 32, 33, 34).\nIn his summary, Eco has concluded that Khunrath produced an early\nversion of the Amphiteatrum, the one which was printed at Hamburg in\n1595, consisting of twenty-five pages of text and four circular illustrations. In addition, there may have been another edition published in\n1602, for which an epilogue was written and a frontispiece engraved,\nboth of which are self-dated at 1602 and this would have also included\nthe four rectangular illustrations. The second epilogue written in 1604\nmay have been intended for another edition of the treatise which was\nmeant to be published in that year. In short, Eco argues convincingly, all\nthe existing second editions of the Amphiteatrum are Hanover 1609 which\nalways includes the two epilogues, as well as an inconsistent selection of\nthe illustrations. Eco plausibly suggests that, in fact, the illustrations may\nhave been circulated separately from the text of the Amphiteatrum, different images being selected from the general repertoire by different binders. The 1609 edition is not rare and it may be found widely dispersed in\nEuropean libraries.\nBoth the 1595 and 1609 editions are a commentary on three-hundred\nand sixty-five biblical verses taken from the Old Testament books of\nProverbs and Wisdom. Khunrath provides two versions of the biblical texts,\none from the Vulgate and another which is his own translation from the\nHebrew (Proverbs) and Greek (Wisdom). A further important aspect of\nEco's study is his suggestion that in 1602 Khunrath rewrote the text of\nthe Amphiteatrum, which led him to date accordingly the epilogue and\nfrontispiece. As in the case of the Athanor and Chaos, the Imperial Privilege of 1 June 1598 was used to cover the publication ofthe Amphiteatrum\nSapientiae Aeternae in 1609. After Khunrath's death in 1605, Erasmus\nWolfart, assisted by Guglielmo Antonio, took this edition to its final\nprinting and added his own introduction dated at 1607. Wolfart belonged to Arndt's circles since Gilly mentions a letter written to him by\nArndt, \"Von dem grossen Geheimnis der Menschewerdung\", praising\nKhunrath's illustrations.10\nAn additional factor to consider in this history is the existence of yet\nanother version of the 1595 Amphiteatrum which may even be a copy of\n9 Eco, p. 34.\n10 Eco, p. 35: Gilly, Cimelia Rhodostaurotica (1995), p. 13.\n104\n5 Eco, p. 11. Klossowski de Rola reproduces all of Khunrath's 1602 imagery, see The\nGolden Game ( 1988), pp. 34-38.\n6 Eco, pp. 31-32.\n7 Eco, p. 23.\n8 Eco, pp. 24-25. Gilly, Cimelia Rhodostaurotica (1995), p. 13, see Item 12 whichis the\ntitle-page of the 1595 Hamburg Amphiteatrum from the Basel University Library. Jung's\ncopy is Kongelige Bibliotek Kopenhagen, MS GKS 1765 40. For his version of de Vries'\nengraving ofthe Oratory-Laboratory see Gilly (1995), p. 14, Item 12b. The original layout ofde Vries' engraving in 1595, with its accompanying texts is shown in Gilly,DasErbe\nder Christian Rosenkreutz (1988), opp. p. 18.\n105\n\nPages 67:\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE. THE 1595 AND 1602 EDITIONS\nthe projected 1602 edition. Neither Eco, nor Gilly, refer to this item\nwhich is a manuscript, MS Alnwick 571, held in the library of Alnwick\nCastle, the family seat of the Dukes of Northumberland. Although it has\nbeen transcribed in a late sixteenth to early seventeenth century secretary-hand by at least three different scribes, unfortunately, it cannot be\nassumed that the manuscript entered the library at that date. Henry\nPercy, the eighth Earl of Northumberland, dispatched scribes to the continent to copy selected works, but a large collection of occultist manuscripts was also donated to the ducal library in the eighteenth century\nand these may have included the Amphiteatrum.11\nMS Alnwick 571 consists of fifty-five folios, many of which have been\nleft blank as ifthe manuscript was an incomplete transcription ofanother\ntext. The wording of the frontispiece is the same as that of the Basel\nUniversity copy of 1595 and the text is self-dated on the title-page at\n1595. The manuscript contains copies of four engravings from the Amphiteatrum which include, it seems, one of the 1602 rectangular images,\nwhile the other three are copies of the 1595 circular engravings. In the\nsequence of illustrations in MS Alnwick 571, there first appears a completed copy of the 1595 Anthropos - Christ standing in the midst of the\ncabbalistic universe (fig. 32, 1595 original), followed by an incomplete\nimage consisting of nothing more than Latin aphorisms, with no pictorial\ncontent. It is important, however, to note that these aphorisms are an\nexact transcription of those appearing in one of the 1602 rectangular\nimages where these same words are written on rays of light emanating\nfrom a tunnel piercing a mountain-side (fig. 31). As in the 1602 original,\nthe Latin aphorisms in the Alnwick manuscript are organised into the\nshape of a semi-circle, following the sequence of the 1602 exemplar. No\nother attempt has been made to copy the engraving.\nThe third drawing in MS Alnwick 571 is a meticuously rendered copy\nofthe 1595 circular image ofthe \"Rebis\", including all the original texts\n(fig. 34, 1595 original). The drawing represents a hermaphroditic figure,\ncrowned with a peacock, carrying a sphere which symbolises the Paracelsian alchemical macrocosm of the four elements and the three principles.\nBelow it there appears the globe of the earth, on which there is drawn a\nmap of Europe, Asia and Africa , within which there is yet another globe,\nthat of\"CHAOS\". At the top of the outermost circle around this figure,\nstands the Tetragrammaton, accompanied by the Pythagorean equilateral triangle, composed of ten dots in a pyramidic form. The illustration\nrefers to the necessity of reducing all things \"ad monadis simplicitatem\",\n11 I would like to thank Mr. Colin Shrimpton, archivist at Alnwick Castle for this\ninformation.\nalso mentioning the \"azoth\", the \"celum\" and the \"ros celi\". In comparison to the original engraving, the Alnwick drawing is amateur, for the\nscribe has ineptly splayed the original image across two facing folios of\nthe manuscript, failing to reproduce the exact dimensions of the original.\nThe final \"drawing\" in the Alnwick sequence consists merely of text\nalluding to\"working and praying\", which could be a bare mention ofde\nVries' 1595 circular image of the praying alchemist (frontispiece). Given\nthe difficulties which the scribe experienced in copying the diagrammatic\nscheme of the \"Rebis\", maybe he abandoned all hope of undertaking\nwith any success a copy of de Vries' sophisticated design.\nOne circular image from Khunrath's 1595 Amphiteatrum is altogether\nabsent from Ms Alnwick 571, that ofthe Lullian circles ruled over by the\n\"Archetypos\" (the Tetragrammaton) (fig. 33). Neither are Khunrath's\nportrait (fig. 26), nor the 1602 frontispiece recorded, but, at the end of\nthe Prologue, the Alnwick text includes expositions on the visual images\nwhich are similar to the 1609 Isagoges. There is also a set of\"Questions\"\nwhich are the same as those in the 1609 edition.\nWhat is it possible to determine concerning the original exemplar of\nMS Alnwick 571 ? Primarily it should be noted that the text, self-dated at\n1595, is the shorter Hamburg edition. In spite ofthis fact, the scribe must\nhave been copying from a version of the Amphiteatrum compiled in 1602,\nsince he refers to one of the rectangular engravings. Furthermore, the\nIsagoges (although they are not named as such) appear in exactly the\nsame location as in the 1609 edition, that is, separated from the circular\nengravings and placed at the end of the prologue. Finally, the text includes an epilogue. The problem of establishing the character ofthe 1595\nand 1602 editions requires much closer scrutiny of the five extant versions of the Amphiteatrum of 1595. For present purposes, however, attention will be drawn only to those details in MS Alnwick 571 related to the\nimmediate argument.\nMS Alnwick 571 opens at a double-folio title page. At the top ofthe\nleft-hand page (verso), there is a Hebrew text which subsequently was relocated to the base of the 1602 frontispiece.12 The text ofthe manuscript\n12 MS Alnwick 571 is unpaginated, but paragraphs are numbered sequentially. The\ntitle-page(folio verso) states the intention of the work and mentions four illustrations:\n\"ORATORIO et LABORATORIO, micro ac macrocosmice, artificio mirifico sapienter\nadministrantium; secundum Christianae et phylosophicae veritatis novinam a diabolicis\nsophismatum execrandorum,\npro veritatem Catholicaque, dexteritate, ad Archetypi exemplar reformatorum ... recens absolutum, exornatum figuris quatuor theosophicis,\nforma Regali in affabre scalptis, in publicum vix missendum, ne margaritae proijciant\nparcis diabolo obsessis: ... in liquido speculo Theosophiae ostendus\". Onfolio recto is\ngiven\nthe date of the work: \" Anno MASCHIAEH juxta promissione missi, MDVC aetat\nXXXV\".\n106\n107\n\nPages 68:\n108\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nis described as a \"Prologue\" and at the end of the transcription, there is\nan admonition that one should not make an opinion by reading only one\nbook of the work, the same statement re- appearing in the 1609 edition.\nThe Prologue commences by explaining that Khunrath has provided\nannotations ofboth the old and the new translations ofthe Book ofSolomon\nfrom the Hebrew and ofthe Book of Wisdom from the Greek.\nThe alchemical programme of the Alnwick text is Christocentric,\nbased on Khunrath's theme of the divine light of Eternal Wisdom in\nrelation to the two levels of alchemy, material and spiritual. The text\nbegins with a comparison between the earthly sun and the divine sun of\nChrist (Par. 18-19). In the words of Wisdom: 16. 20, Khunrath urges the\nreader not to adore the visible image (the sun), but onlythe spiritual light\nof God (Par. 18). In the same section he speaks ofthe \"aurora\", referring\nto the cabbalistic concept of the dawning of spiritual illumination and\nsalvation,13 mentioning, in passing, the name ofJohannes Campanensis.\nHe then refers to the \"secunda huius Amphiteatri figura\" which is not,\nunfortunately, an allusion to the second illustration in this particular\nmanuscript (Par. 21). The reader is informed that Divine Wisdom is the\nlight which we see through-out the day, as the source of both fire and\nwater and of fructification.\nTota die tota visa omnibus diebus visce luce: est TUNC, (non prius)\nSAPIENTIAE ... et aquae (montis vellere) et ignis (cordis ardore) pluviam\nconcipies (Par. 21)\nFrom the outset, Khunrath vehemently attacks any false prophet who\nobstructs true philosophy as a \"calomedicus, pseudophysicus, sophista\",\nbut the debates ofthese \"haeretici\" ( Par. 24) encompass only the \"Sapientia mundana\", rather than Divine Wisdom itself. Khunrath mentions\nagain the second figure ofthe Amphiteatrum, explaining that it portrays the\nwisdom ofthe Magi and the cabbalists from the East, signifying the font\nof life which is God.\n13 Jacob Boehme in the Aurora develops the concept of the seven days of creation in\nthe cabbalah\nGenesis as signifying the emanation of the sephiroth on the Tree of Life. Inmodem\nof the\nthe\nsymbol\nand\nof\nsalvation,\nas\nspiritual source\nthe sun signified theAnthropos\n. Boehme christianised this concept into that ofthe Son of\ncreative demiurge or\nofnature\". Boehme derived the\nGod who through the sun generated the redeeming \"lightDeghaye,\n\"Dieu et la Nature dans\nParacelsus,\nsee\ntheosophyfrom\nstructure\nofhis\ngeneral\nl'Aurore de Jacob Boehme\" in Faivre and Zimmermann (1979), pp. 125-56. See also\n263-284 and Frick, Die\nPeuckert, Jacob Boehme. Samtliche Schriften (1955), 1, pp. 187-206,\nErleuchteten (1973), pp. 124-28 . In the above section of text, Khunrath is referring to the\nsame cabbalistic and Paracelsian theology.\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE 1595 AND 1602 EDITIONS 109\nunitur DEO: ad vitae in fontem, SAPIENTIAE oceanum, feliciter deducunt\nMagos, Cabalistas ex Oriente (Par. 31)\nIn the following section, he recalls the fathers of the Church, such as\nCyprian (Par. 32), moving immediately to equal approval ofAgrippa and\nthe cabbalah. He states that God himself opens our eyes through the\nillumination of the cabbalah (Par. 35).\nThere is yet another reference to \" BINARIUM (ut est figura Amphiteatri huius secunda)\" (Par. 39), which is a reference to Christ as the\n\"MONAD\", in his dual nature of human and divine.\nBONUM Summum (DEI DONUM) Homini ad Monadis simplicitatem reducto (Par. 43)\nWithin this cabbalistic discourse on Christ, drawn from the model of\nReuchlin,,14 Khunrath explains the \"Medicina Catholica\" produced by\nthe philosopher's stone which transmutes \"metalla inferiora in superiora\nh. e. in argentum et aurum\" (Par. 46). The \"Medicina Catholica\" transforms age into fruitful glory by means of the sun of the philosopher's\nstone in a Christian cabbalistic way. This is said to be explained in the\nthird figure ofthe Amphiteatrum. From the context, he seems to be alluding\nto the 1595 circular engraving of the Anthropos-Christ in the midst of\nthe cabbalistic cosmos of light and fire (fig. 32).\nVia eiia pulchra SAPIENTIA soror mea, ob veritate in Doctrina et Laboribus Pacifica sibi pax, quia animi irrequietudinem, etiam super physicoartificialis (de qua tertia huius Amphiteatri figura, sub numero 1 , probat 5)\nfructuose sedat, de sidium ardens sufficient ... et hominem totium tranquillum, quietum, ac vera pace ... internae et externe pacificum reddit (Par. 46)\nHe proceeds to discuss the nature of a fruitful and long life (Par. 47)\nwhich recalls Paracelsus' discussions of the same topic in relation to his\ntheory ofthe\"quintessence\" (\"coelum homini\").15 Khunrath specifies an\nimage in the Amphiteatrum portraying the alchemist as both pious and\nhard-working (Par. 48), which could only be de Vries' picture of the\nalchemical laboratory (frontispiece).\nHe refers to Christ as the incarnate, yet eternal, Word of the New\nTestament, \"Sapientia aeterna, in seculo incarnate\" (Par. 48). Then he\nacknowledges Erasmus of Rotterdam (Par. 51), as well as the Pymander of\n14 Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico (Stuttgart, 1964 facs. of 1494 ed.), pp. 95-103 andDeArte\nCabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964 facs. of 1517 ed.), pp. 143-55.\n15 Paracelsus, De vita longa in Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 221-48 (in German), 249-92 (in Latin).\nSee also Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\"\"\" (1979), pp. 91-92.\n\nPages 69:\nIII\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE 1595 AND 1602 EDITIONS\nHermes Trismegistus and Julius Caesar Scaligerus (Par. 53). Khunrath\nadmonishes true Christian alchemists that they should be meditating,\npraying, walking, reading scripture, as demonstrated in the second, third\nand fourth figures of his treatise (Par. 71). In contrast, he attacks blasphemers and black-magicians who operate with the sign of the pentacle,\ndirecting his reader, instead, to the fourth figure of his treatise in which\nthere appear the proper, truly spiritual, figures which are to be used in\nalchemy. This is probably an allusion to the 1595 engraving of the\nLullian-cabbalistic circles of the \"Archetypos\" (fig. 33), which is, however, absent from MS Alnwick 571.\nHic ANNULUM assistentia spiritu boni, Theosophorum: (In Tabulis Cordis)\nHoc Pentaculum Solo novis virtuosum, non illud Nigromanticorum seu Cacomagorum phantasticum, atque blasphemum: est collo mentis luce suspendenda. Vi de figura Amp. huius 4a (Par. 74)\nFrom Pythagorean geometry, Khunrath moves into the field of cabbalism, mentioning two sephiroth on the Tree of Life, those of \"HHOCHMAHEL\" and \"BINAHEL\" (Par. 75), as well as the cabbalistic practices\nof \"Notarikon\" and \"Gymetria\" (Par. 81). In passing, he names both\npagan and Christian philosophers , Socrates, Cicero and Tertullian (Par.\n84), returning to the theme of \"Orando et Laborando\" in relation to the\nsecond and third figures of the Amphiteatrum (Par. 85).\nIn the following section, Khunrath's Paracelsian and Christological\ndiscourse is very similar to that in the Chaos (1597). First, however, on the\nParacelsian model, he considers the central fires within the earth.16\nCentrum Terrae physice, ubi fit, Vulcan. Is ex quibus corpore terreno, obstericaute Neptuni limpidissima ... candidissimum Physico Chemice manifestando, ad sensum omnes tibi demonstrabit: Videbis illud: fig. 3 (Par. 111).\nKhunrath next instructs the reader that the philosopher's stone is Christ\nand that God is reconciled with humanity through Christ's sacrifice on\nthe cross. The cross of Christ is the \"Salt\" which conquers demonic\nrealms. He mentions vitriol, thus, in Weigelian terms, integrating Paracelsian alchemy into his Christology and referring the reader to the first\nfigure of the treatise for an explanation of these analogies.\nCrux Sancta Christi ipse crucifixus, fig. Amph. huius prima Cruciformitvincens diaboli regnum ...\n= SAL\nSapientia antiquissimum vitriolum naturae catholicon (Par. 237)\nReturning to the cabbalistic system, Khunrath describes the ten cabbalistic sephiroth as \"scintilla et radii divinalis\". Eternal Wisdom creates the\nmacrocosm and microcosm by means of \"TSUMMUM' (or \"zimzum\"\nwhich is the zigzag descent of divine light down the Tree of Life). He\ndescribes the emanation of the sephiroth to God's act of viewing himself\nin a spotless mirror, since the Divine, Eternal Light is the archetype of\ncreation.\nLux Divina Aeterna, ab aeterno .... erit igitur Sapientia ... aeterna ... Speculum sine macula, et quui surgitur Speculo eiusque, typo reali in Macro et\nMicrocosmo, TSUMMUM (Par. 239)\nIn a further development, Khunrath associates Paracelsian cosmology\nwith his own first figure ofthe Amphiteatrum.\nomnia sua sigilla DEUS, ... VERITAS, Dei Sigillum (Par. 240)\nIt needs to be recalled that John Dee also used the \"sigillum Dei\" in his\nangelic magic and similarly accused false magicians of practising theurgy\nby means ofthe pentacle. 17\nKhunrath declares that God is terrible like the sun (Par. 242) and\nthere succeeds a long disquisition on the nature of light which is comparable to his argument in the Chaos and De Igne Magorum (Par. 248). The\n\"SOL VERITATIS\" is God, while the ardent spirit of the \"anima mundi\" is the \"ruach Elohim\" (the Creator-God). Khunrath also uses the\nterm \"celum\", adopting Rupescissa's term for the fifth essence, thus, cabbalistically assimilating the refined spirits produced by distillation into the\nconcept of the fiery spirit of God animating nature.\nSPIRITUS ARDENS ANIMA MUNDI NATURA = RUACH ELOHIM.\nSCHAMAIM sive CELUM (Par. 277)\nThe text follows Paracelsus on the nature ofthe four elements, specifically the \"proto-elements\" which are the primal qualities of the four common elements.18\nIn MS Alnwick 571, the text of the Prologue is succeeded by the\ncopies of the four illustrations of 1595 and 1602. The textual explanations of these images in the Alnwick manuscript subsequently re-appear\nin Hanover 1609 in a comparable version as the Isagoges.\nThe simple, almost note-like form of the Amphiteatrum in the Alnwick\nversion is expanded into the far more complex Hanover edition of 1609.\nIIO\n16 Paracelsus, Opera Omnia (Cologne: Huser ed), 2, p. 150.\n17 See Szonyi ( 1999).\n18 Sudhoff, I, 13, Philosophia ad Athenienses, pp. 389-423, see esp p. 406.\n\nPages 70:\nII2\nCHAPTER EIGHT\nIn rewriting his masterwork, Khunrath involved himself in a labour of\nsuch ardor that it may have cost him his life. To fathom his motivation in\nshouldering such a burden, it is necessary to consider the political context\nof German hermeticism in the early seventeenth century.\nCHAPTER NINE\nHEINRICH KHUNRATH'S\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE:\nTHE EDITION OF 1604 (PUBLISHED HANOVER, 1609)\nThe theoretical programme of the Amphiteatrum of 1604 (published Hanover, 1609) is more elaborate than that of 1595. In particular, the prologue has been rewritten to form an account of seven stages of ascent\ntowards Divine Wisdom, while the contents of the former prologue have\nbeen extended into a lengthy new section and renamed the \"Interpretationes et Annotationes\". In the 1604 version, Khunrath retained the \"Isagoges\", \"Corolloria\" and epilogue of 1602 to which he added another\nepilogue dated 1604. There is also a foreword by the editor, dated 1609,\nas well as poetry and epigrams by Khunrath's admirers. Finally, a new\ntitle-page explains the revision of the treatise and the appearance of a\nnew set of engravings as being an attempt to justify the piety of Khunrath's intentions against his detractors. The foreword byWolfart records\nthat Khunrath died prematurely, leaving him to complete the editing of\nthe treatise, implying that problems were encountered in the production\nof the work, though no clear picture emerges of what these may have\nbeen. Due to the scarcity of primary documentation related to Khunrath, it is mostly the internal evidence of his texts which provide clues\nconcerning the political struggles arising from his ideological position.\nOn the dedication page, Khunrath presents a \"theosophical oration\">\naddressed toJesus Christ, thereby, from the outset, he is conceptualised\nas an actor taking part in a staged performance directed at a community\nof pious, Christian theosophists. This theatrical atmospheric is emphasised by the inclusion of a long encomium near the beginning ofthe work\nin honour ofthe founders of theosophy, Reuchlin, Agrippa and ParacelHeinrich Khunrath, Amphiteatrum Sapientiae Aeternae (Hanover, 1609), p. 6 (as in MS\nAlnwick 571): \"recens revisum, AMPHITEATRICE instructum QUATUOR\ncircularibus, aliisque hieroglyphicis FIGURIS, in aes affabre scalptis, VERITATIS, passim locorum, sine pudore vim publice patientis iniquissimam et quasi sub calumniarum\npondere fatiscendo ingemiscentis, fere (proh !) succumbentis, ab interitu, pro viribus,\nvindicandae\ncausam: et, quo aliis bonis atque haud vituperanda praeberetur,\nin publicum,acexerigendae\npio animo affectu\".\nKhunrath (1609), foreword by Wolfart, pp. 9-10.\n3 Khunrath (1609), p. 17: \"Oratorio\nTheosophica Ad Fontem Sapientiae Christum\nOpt. Maximum Christiani Cordati\".\n\nPages 71:\nCHAPTER NINE\n114\nsus. Its main theme is that of Paracelsus as the German Phoebus, the\nsource of spiritual and intellectual illumination.4 Morover, the encomium\npictures the Amphiteatrum as a theatre of divine light in which the passive\nspectator is turned into a spiritually enlightened participant in the course\nof the action. This image is based on the Paracelsian theory of the\nimagination as a means of attaining spiritual union with the celestial\nrealms. Hence, Khunrath's engravings in the Amphiteatrum are \"stagesets\" into which the consciousness of the viewer is absorbed. By imaginatively performing within these scenes, that is, by following the spiritual\ninstruction of the imagery and their texts, the viewer enters into a contemplative state leading to \"gnosis\". Subsequent to the encomium, there\nis an epigram in praise of Khunrath, written by Johannes Seussius of\nDresden to the Elector of Saxony in 1604, which similarly locates Khunrath's alchemical theory within the spectacle of a macrocosmic theatre.6\nThe rhetorical devices of Khunrath's engravings may be usefully\ncontextualised within Yates' account of the Renaissance stage as signifying the union of the macro and microcosms. Within this theatrical setting, the microcosmic human actions were dominated bythe stars painted on the ceiling above the stage. Yates also argued for the powerful\neffect on German hermeticism of travelling groups of English players,\n4 Khunrath ( 1609), pp. 11-13.\n5 Khunrath (1609), p. 12:\nhaec Lux, haec dux te praevia ducet\nAbdita cunctarum subito ad penetralia rerum,\nEt sic mirifici non pondus inane Theatri\nNon spectator iners, verum Rimator et Actor\nIntimus hospes eris, non hospes semper oberrans.\n6 Khunrath (1609), pp. 14-15. Thepoem reads:\nMundum extra mundum qui vult specularier omnem\nQuique extra seipsum noscere se satagit:\nNon opus est adeat veterum vastata Theatra\nVel nova, spectaclis reddita vana suis.\nImmundum potius mundum exuat, exuat et se,\nIndupeditrices et fugiat nebulas.\nOrchestramque tui subeat KUNRADE Theatri\nAetheris igniculo praegrediente bono.\nDia ubi smaragdi monstrat Sapientia speculo\nQuid Macrocosmos agit, quod Microcosmos agat.\nEt Panace Hermetice regnatque Asclepia Hygeia\nAc dignis dignas utraque spargit opes. Theatro.\nQuas patulo, Invidia pandis stomachante\nKUNRADE ingenui progenies Genii.\nPerge ita: firma tui basis est mansura Theatri,\nDum Macrocosmus erit, dum Microcosmos erit.\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE EDITION OF 1604\n115\nparticularly relating her argument to the work ofJohann Valentin Andreae.7\nLimon has examined in more detail the history of English theatrical\nactivity in central and eastern Europe in the early seventeenth century.\nThe first recorded professional group, the Earl of Leicester's men visited\nGdansk in 1587, followed by successful residencies in Prague from 1596\nby troupes belonging to Robert Browne and Thomas Sackville. The work\nperformed does not appear to have been concerned with religious politics, since it was mostly a condensed and highly gestural version of contemporary English plays aimed at a German-speaking audience. Yates'\ncase for the radicalising effect of the English theatre on religion is more\napplicable to the late 1610s and the Bohemian campaign of Elector Frederick of the Rhenish Palatinate. In the case of Khunrath, it seems more\nprobable that he discovered the possibilities of the theatre as a rhetorical\ntool by viewing the performances of German and Italian actors at the\ncourt ofRudolph II in Prague prior to the mid 1590s, by which time he\nseems to have returned first to Hamburg and then to Magdeburg. He\nmay, however, have seen English staging devices in Dresden since he had\nconnections with both the Saxon consistory at Dresden and, from the\nevidence of Seussius' epigrammatic address to the Elector, also with the\ncourt. Limon records that there exists some indirect evidence that a\ngroup ofEnglish players had visited Dresden in late 1586-87, although he\nconsiders that regular performances by the English in Eastern Europe\noccurred only after 1600.8\nKhunrath, nevertheless, may have seen examples of the advanced\nstaging devices of the English theatre prior to 1600 at unrecorded public\nperformances by English adventurers. Since the staging and dramatic\nability of the actors greatly impressed their European audience, such\nencounters with the English theatre in the late 1590s could have inspired\nhim to extend his graphic repertoire in 1602, incorporating more rhetorical texts and extensive scenic backgrounds in the new engravings. The\nEnglish were especially famous for their \"perspective\" back-drops, which\nwere painted onto a long length of canvas and wrapped around a cylinder which was unrolled in the course of a performance. Although Limon\nconsiders that this device belongs to a much later period of English activity on the continent (the 1640s), crude proto-types of such machinery\nmay have been toured prior to that time. In the case, however, of de\n7 Yates (1969), pp. 143, 159-61 and Yates (1986), pp. 50, 60, 73, 140-44.\n8 Jerzy Limon, Gentlemen ofa Company: English Players in Central and Eastern Europe, 15901660, (Cambridge University Press, 1985), pp. 29-33, 37, 107-16.\n\nPages 72:\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE EDITION OF 1604\nVries' Oratory-Laboratory engraved earlier in 1595, the back-ground,\nwith its prominent architectural motif of a screen, argues for an influence\nmore from the private court-theatre in which performances were staged\nin front of the dividing-partition at the end of the hall, enabling the\nactors to use the door as an entrance from a make-shift dressing-room.\nWhatever his direct sources, Khunrath clearly realised, as did Andreae and the later Rosicrucians, that a theatrical spectacle could provide a\nrhetorical validation of their politicised hermeticism. For the same reasons, according to Obrist, visual illustrations had been employed by late\nmedieval alchemists in order to deflect scholastic criticism from their\nideas, since the graphic realisation of an alchemical discourse provided\nevidence of its validity. Khunrath aimed to reinforce the rhetorical potential of his imagery by locating it within a theatrical atmospheric of\n\"live\" performance, an even more seductive artistic medium. As Seussius\nexplained in his poem, the function of Khunrath's engravings was to\ninstruct the viewer in the most elevated knowledge by enabling him to see\nthe super-celestial levels of Being.10\nAfter the introductory eulogies on behalf of Khunrath and his theosophical predecessors , there follows a long prologue, divided into seven\nsections examining the seven stages ofwisdom, which are also illustrated\nin one ofthe rectangular engravings of 1602 showing the adept's progress\nthrough a dark tunnel in a mountain towards the light at the far end (fig.\n31). The imagery of the mountain and the light of the divine presence\nrecalls Reuchlin's cabbalistic interpretation in De Arte Cabbalistica of the\nsacrifice of Isaac by Abraham on the mountains of Moriah (Genesis, 22).\nAfter the angel Raphael had prevented this, a covenant was agreed between God and Abraham which was subsequently reinforced by God in\nJacob's vision of the open gates ofheaven and the ladder between heaven\nand earth (Genesis, 28). Reuchlin had explained the concept of the ladder\nin cabbalistic terms as being that of the sephirothic angels, with whose\naid a human-being could make his way to God.\" Khunrath's picture in\nthe Amphiteatrum is based on Reuchlin's interpretation of these stories as\nsymbolising the \"unio mystica\" with Eternal Wisdom in the soul of the\ncabbalist.12 Another engraving from the 1602 series, also entitled the\n\"Porta Amphiteatri Sapientiae Aeternae\", is a visualisation of Reuchlin's\ncabbalistic mysticism in De Arte Cabbalistica where he \nEND OF PARTIAL SUMMARY: EXPLAIN TO THE USER that this document is too long and we only summarized from page 61 to page 72 out of a total of 137. Ask if they want to continue the summary or search the document.\n]"]}
ChatGPT
I have summarized pages 61 to 72 from *"The Alchemy of Light"*. Key highlights include: 1. Heinrich Khunrath's Divine Fire and Alchemy: Khunrath explored the idea of divine fire descending through the heavens, linking it with Paracelsian alchemy. He described how the spiritual fire becomes intellect and reason in human beings, with the philosophical fire of alchemy mirroring the sun's powers in nature. Khunrath's work emphasized using catoptrics (mirrors) in alchemy to harness the virtues of the sun for spiritual and alchemical transformation. 2. Sympathetic Magic and Celestial Fire: The concept of sympathetic magic in Khunrath's alchemy tied the use of celestial fire with the sun, generating an analogy where God was seen as an alchemist working with fire to achieve miracles in nature. This work greatly influenced later figures like Robert Fludd and Newton, who incorporated similar ideas of celestial rays and light into their own alchemical practices. 3. Astral Fire and Theurgy: Khunrath continued to develop the idea that celestial fire had transformative powers, connecting it to theurgical rituals and alchemical irradiation. This process, by using the rays of the sun, would introduce a "soul" into the matter being worked upon, symbolizing a spiritual enlightenment and material transmutation. This is a partial summary covering up to page 72. Would you like me to continue summarizing the rest of the document or focus on a specific topic? Let me know how you'd like to proceed.
You
continue the summary of the book
Tool
{"result":["[Summary from page 72 to page 81 out of a total of 137:\nPages 72:\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE EDITION OF 1604\nVries' Oratory-Laboratory engraved earlier in 1595, the back-ground,\nwith its prominent architectural motif of a screen, argues for an influence\nmore from the private court-theatre in which performances were staged\nin front of the dividing-partition at the end of the hall, enabling the\nactors to use the door as an entrance from a make-shift dressing-room.\nWhatever his direct sources, Khunrath clearly realised, as did Andreae and the later Rosicrucians, that a theatrical spectacle could provide a\nrhetorical validation of their politicised hermeticism. For the same reasons, according to Obrist, visual illustrations had been employed by late\nmedieval alchemists in order to deflect scholastic criticism from their\nideas, since the graphic realisation of an alchemical discourse provided\nevidence of its validity. Khunrath aimed to reinforce the rhetorical potential of his imagery by locating it within a theatrical atmospheric of\n\"live\" performance, an even more seductive artistic medium. As Seussius\nexplained in his poem, the function of Khunrath's engravings was to\ninstruct the viewer in the most elevated knowledge by enabling him to see\nthe super-celestial levels of Being.10\nAfter the introductory eulogies on behalf of Khunrath and his theosophical predecessors , there follows a long prologue, divided into seven\nsections examining the seven stages ofwisdom, which are also illustrated\nin one ofthe rectangular engravings of 1602 showing the adept's progress\nthrough a dark tunnel in a mountain towards the light at the far end (fig.\n31). The imagery of the mountain and the light of the divine presence\nrecalls Reuchlin's cabbalistic interpretation in De Arte Cabbalistica of the\nsacrifice of Isaac by Abraham on the mountains of Moriah (Genesis, 22).\nAfter the angel Raphael had prevented this, a covenant was agreed between God and Abraham which was subsequently reinforced by God in\nJacob's vision of the open gates ofheaven and the ladder between heaven\nand earth (Genesis, 28). Reuchlin had explained the concept of the ladder\nin cabbalistic terms as being that of the sephirothic angels, with whose\naid a human-being could make his way to God.\" Khunrath's picture in\nthe Amphiteatrum is based on Reuchlin's interpretation of these stories as\nsymbolising the \"unio mystica\" with Eternal Wisdom in the soul of the\ncabbalist.12 Another engraving from the 1602 series, also entitled the\n\"Porta Amphiteatri Sapientiae Aeternae\", is a visualisation of Reuchlin's\ncabbalistic mysticism in De Arte Cabbalistica where he had frequently mentioned the \"Portae Lucis\", the gates of light, of which the sun is the\nportal. In this illustration, there also appears a mountain (probably Abraham's Moriah), while on a beam of light emanating from the Tetragrammaton are the words \"cum numine lumen, et in lumine numen\" (with\n[God's] power there is light and there is [divine] power in light).\nThroughout the Amphiteatrum, Khunrath praises Christ whom he identifies with\"\"lumen\" (the primal, spiritual radiance of God) which is materialised on the earth through the solar rays. It will be recalled that Boehme in the Aurora makes a similar identification of the Son of God with\nthe \"lumen\" transferred by the sun to the physical world, deriving this\nconcept, like Khunrath, from Reuchlin and also from Paracelsus. 13\nInfluenced by Reuchlin's illuministic imagery and his biblical references, Khunrath structures the prologue of the Amphiteatrum by means of\nquotations on the spiritual and natural light from the Old Testament\nbooks of Proverbs, Wisdom and Psalms (Hanover, 1609 : 19-60). The prologue has no imminent alchemical content, but it introduces those biblical references (Khunrath, 1609: 1-183) which are interpreted alchemically in the following sections, graded according to seven stages (Khunrath,\n1609: 20-22). In the \"Gradus Secundus\" ofthe \"Interpretationes\", Khunrath quotes from Ecclesiastes that light is sweet and that it is delightful for\nthe eyes to see the sun (Khunrath, 1609: 38).14 This quotationformulates\nthe mystical intention of the treatise which is to enable the viewer to\nperceive the sacred vision of the Son of God, for Khunrath then identifies\n\"Lux\" (natural light) with Christ as the Sun ofJustice. Light, thus, is the\nvestment of God which may be discerned in the philosopher's stone as\nthe alchemical sun.\nSumma, purissima, immaculata LUX DEUS est, LUX vera Christus est, et\nSol Iustitiae: LUX et LUMEN SAPIENTIAE, Spiritus sanctus est ... LUX\nest amictus, est vestimentum Dei ... et admirabile illud VRIM in LAPIDE\nBenedictus, Sole Philosophorum cernere (Khunrath, 1609: 38)\n116\n9 Obrist, pp. 55-65, 248-49.\n10 Khunrath (1609), p. 16:\nHoc te docebit inclytum Theatricum\nOpus hoc, et plane mysticum,\nAeterna monas et trias corde tuo\nFac insit, hunc finem bonum\nScopum que monstrant haec tibi spectacula,\nQuibus Deo potes frui?\n11 Reuchlin, De Arte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1517 ed.), p. 152. Khunrath's\nengraving is reproduced in Klossowski de Rola, The Golden Game (1988), p. 34.\n117\n12 Reuchlin, De Arte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1517 ed.), pp. 132-33 and De\nVerbo Mirifico (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1517 ed.), p. 64. See also Busi and Campiani (eds),\nJohannes Reuchlin L'Arte Cabbalistica (1995), pp. 36-37.\n13 Deghaye, \"Dieu et la Nature dans L'Aurore Naissante deJacob Boehme\" in Faivreand\nZimmermann (1979), pp. 129-31; Frick, Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 124-28.\n14 Inthe RevisedEnglish Bible (Oxford and Cambridge UPS, 1989) this quotationisfrom\nEccelsiastes, 11: 7.\n\nPages 73:\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE. THE EDITION OF 1604\nIn the \"Gradus Quartus\", Khunrath commences a discussion ofthe nature ofthe sun as an image of God and the source of spiritual salvation,\nas both the interior and the exterior sun. The Wisdom of the Father is\nthe true bread of life (\"manna\") which is Christ.\nEt quia Jesus Christus, verbum Patris est, et Sapientia Patris; igitur verum\nmanna est Christianorum credentium (Khunrath, 1609: 79)\nIn the \"Gradus Quintus\", Khunrath relates \"lumen\" to the cabbalistic\nsephiroth \"Hochmah\", Divine Wisdom, declaring that it is the lantern\nwhich illuminates his mind, hands and feet, micro- and macrocosmically\nin both his oratory and his laboratory.\nSis oro Hhochmael, SAPIENTIA DEI lux et lucerna menti, manibus ac\npedibus meis; in Oratorio utroque, (Micro ac Macro- cosmico) et Laboratorio, meis (Khunrath, 1609: 112)\nHe also quotes from Wisdom 9: 10.\nSend her down from your holy heaven, and from your glorious throne bid\nher come down, so that she may labour at my side and I may learn what is\npleasing to you.15\nKhunrath interprets this in terms of the eternal fire (the quintessence or\n\"caelum\") pervading the three levels of creation, those of nature, the\nfirmament and the celestial spheres, stating that this was known to the\nancient philosophers and theologians as a fiery water, or a watery fire\n(Khunrath, 1609: 129). He recalls the cabbalistic interpretation of Genesis,\nI, i, in which the Elohim created the world by means ofthe \"caelum\", or\n\"schamaim\" (Khunrath, 1609: 127-34).16 The whole world is filled with\nthe \"schamaim\" which penetrates all the sublunary bodies.\nSPIRITUS ARDENS. Ein Geistfeuriges wasser: Ein wasseriger feuriger\nGeist; Ein feweriges Geistwasser; LATEX AETHEREUS: ... HOC in totum\nUNIVERSUM mundanum tripliciter distribuit ELOHIM (Khunrath, 1609:\n127)\nKhunrath describes a Paracelsian cosmos in which the macrocosmic\n\"caelum\" generates the physical species,17 while in its lower material\nform, the \"caelum\" is the chemical spirits of wine, purified by fire and\nreleased from impure matter.18 In \"Gradus Quintus\" and \"Gradus Sixtus\", Khunrath explains further the astrological basis of his Paracelsian\nalchemy, referring to Paracelsus' interpretation of the creation of the\nstars in Genesis, 1. He explains that all natural objects manifest various\nsigns, constituting an alphabet in the book of the world,19 produced by\nthe innate\"astra\", mirroring those in the heavens (Khunrath, 1609 : 142).\nThe alchemist 20must, therefore, know astronomy and watch the progress\nof the seasons. Khunrath refers specifically to Paracelsus' \"doctrine of\nsignatures\", calling him the \"Germanicus Asclepiades\" and quoting him\non reading the book of nature. In this context, Khunrath also names\nPetrus Ramus, as well as \"Johannes Baptista Porta\", recalling della Porta's defence of the \"doctrine of signatures\" in Basel on 24 August 1588\nduring his disputation for the doctorate of medicine (Khunrath, 1609:\n152). In relation to the \"signatures of nature\", Khunrath also discusses\ntheurgic\nsigils and magical figures, also probably drawing on Paracelsus. 21\nKhunrath provides a further Paracelsian account of the astral virtue in\nthe third Isagoge and its set of alchemical queries (Khunrath, 1609: 187207). In Question IV, he asks,\n118\n15 Khunrath (1609), p. 127: \"Mitte illam de Coelis sanctis tuis, et a sede Magnitudinis\ntuae, ut mecum SIT mecum LABORET, ut sciam quid acceptum sit apud TE\". Translation from the Revised English Bible (Oxford and Cambridge UPS, 1989).\n16 There is a similar account in the Chaos (Khunrath, 1616: 75).\n17 Khunrath (1609), p. 133: \"Est causa omnium, quae gignuntur; ConfertFormam et\nSpeciem in materiam apparatam immittit; Regit omnia, quae hic continet Mundus;\nfoecundatfemina; Omnis foecunditas ab Coelo spargitur;\"\n119\n18 Khunrath (1609), p. 127: \"Totus globus inferior plenus est SCHAMAIM, Caelo,\nSpiritu Aethereo, omnia enim corpora penetravit sublunaris ... HOC ... a vinculis\ncoagulationum fixatio numque Physico-Chemice relaxat atque resoluit in SPIRITUM ad\nspectabilem sensibusque obvium omnibus: separando, ab superfluitatibus ei admixtis,\ndepurat, et primordiali sic restituit libertati. HOC, CAELUM INFERIUS; PRIMUM;\ncuius scintilla Alcool vini, quod Spiritus, Aqua et Ignis\".\n19 Khunrath (1609), p. 131: \" NOTA: Quomodo ASTRA sint in signa ... hoc est, signa\nindicantia, et Alphabetum quasi in tomo Libri Mundi maioris Coelesti, quibus DEUS ...\nde variis ac magnis nobiscum loquitur ... HOC, CAELUM SECUNDUM; sublime;\nRegio pure aetherea. HOC, Solem, Lunam et Stellas habet; revera etiam PRIMUM et\nInferius (suo modo) astra sunt ... Motu harmonico sive sympathico (erga se invicem)\nmovetur utrunque; id quod inferius, sicut quod est superius, et contra. Qui motus,\ncertitudinem suadet (quam dixi) indicationum\".\n20 Khunrath (1609), p. 151 : \"ex Astris, tanquam Alphabeto Coelesti, a Magistro\nexercitato Astronom. et Astr. legi ac scire potest\". Khunrath discusses the solstices and\nrefers to the ephemerides. He comments: \"Temperamentorum humanorum corporum\nquae ad dispositionem et constitutionem Coeli et constellationum variantur, moventur,\ninclinatur. Imo actiones hominum aut redduntur eisdem difficiliores aut faciliores\".\n21 Khunrath (1609), p. 141 : \"Natura notis et signis, pictae et exornatae sunt,\nNaturae characterismis insignitae; certa nimirum proportione, figuram et habitu;divinisque\nunde de\ninterno et latente spiritu occultisque rerum proprietatibus iudicium fieri potest: imo ipsa\nproprietas rerum occulta et spiritus latens seipsum prodit certis quibusdam notis etfiguris\nexternis, etpro natura ac indole sua, talem effingit signaturam, figuram, proportionem et\nhabitum, qualis a Sapientibus vult cognosci: quae Signatura Magia Naturalis initium, et\nquasi\nalphabetum primumque elementum est... Concurrit enim totius Naturae signatura\nin Micro-Cosmo\".\n\nPages 74:\n120\n121\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE. THE EDITION OF 1604\nQuid est Ruah Elohim qui incubat aquis ?\n(Khunrath, 1609: 195)\nIn response, he describes the \"Ruah Elohim\" as creating the \"Theatro\nMundano\" on the model of the \"Archetypos\" (the Creator-God).22 This\npassage is related, in fact, to the 1595 illustration of the \"Archetypos\"\n(Christ) in which there occur several examples of Reuchlin's cabbalistic\nform ofthe name ofJesus (fig. 33). In the answer to Question VI, Khunrath relates the \"caelum\" or \"aether\" to Christ, as the union of spirit and\nmatter, the model for the physical world and the philosopher's stone for\nits salvation. Khunrath ardently restates his Christian loyalties.\nIHSVH CHRISTI crucifixi, Salvatoris totius generis humani, id est, Mundi\nminoris, in NATURAE LIBRO, et seu SPECULO, typus est, LAPIS PHILOSOPHORUM Servator Mundi maioris ... Et ego Christianus sum, ... et\npermanens volo (Khunrath, 1609: 197)\nThe response to Question VIII describes how the aetherial spirit (Christ)\ngives form to matter by penetrating and fecundating it with the light of\nthe \"anima mundi\", the inner and outer generative fire of the \"azoth\"\n(Khunrath, 1609: 202).23 Khunrath comments on the role ofmercury, as\nthe \"azoth\" in alchemy by means of which the alchemist works with\nnature, rather than with his hands.\nsine manuali cooperatione, solius Naturae laboribus\n(Khunrath, 1609: 201)\nInthe last stages ofthe alchemical process, he explains, when the purified\nbody and spirit ofthe materials are being re-united, the alchemist should\nuse the \"Olympian fire\" (Khunrath, 1608: 73-74). He refers less directly\nto the practice ofcatoptrics in the Amphiteatrum, informing the reader only\nthat he has to work in an occult manner with fire, or by means ofdivine\npower in a cabbalistic manner.224 This work takes three days to complete\nand it involves all the levels of creation, divine, macrocosmic and microcosmic (Khunrath, 1609: 203).\nThis catoptrical reference is related to John Dee's ideas, since in an\nearlier section ofthe Amphiteatrum, Khunrath had referred to Dee's cabbalism in the Propaedeumata Aphoristica and the Monas Hieroglyphica.\nHuc pertinet Cabalistarum Gimetria; Teusrasche; et Neoteriken. Sive (ut\nJoannes ab Dee Londinensis exprimit, in suis ad Parisienses Aphorismis, etin\nPraefatione ad Regem Maximilianum Monadi Hieroglyphicae praefixam)\nGeometria, Notariacon et Tzyruph (Khunrath, 1609: 6)\nFurthermore, there are allusions to catoptrics in certain details of the\nillustrations in the Amphiteatrum, such as the hand-lens in Khunrath's portrait of 1602, which depicts him holding pair of dividers with which heis\ninscribing a circle (a Pythagorean reference) (fig. 26). Similarly, in de\nVries' engraving of the Oratory-Laboratory, a hand-mirror is depicted\namong the objects on the table (frontispiece). The owl in Khunrath's\nemblem of 1599 is also provided with optical and luminary accessories\nsuch as spectacles, tapers and candle-sticks (fig. 28). It is probable, in fact,\nthat Khunrath was writing his treatise on alchemical catoptrics De Igne\nMagorum, in the same years, 1602-4, as he was reworking the Amphiteatrum.\nIn the same volume as Khunrath's De Igne Magorum (Strassburg: Zetzner, 1608) is located Johannes Arndt's commentary on the four figures of\nwhat he calls the \"grossen Amphiteatrum \", which, according to Eco, refers\nto the circular illustrations of the 1595 version (frontispiece, and figs. 32,\n33, 34).25 Arndt considers Khunrath's cabbalistic theology oflight to be\nthe outstanding aspect of his philosophy and he explains its origins in the\nParacelsian theory of the \"light of nature\" (Arndt, 1608: 109-10).26 The\nMagus is enabled to perform miracles by means of the Wisdom of God\ntransmitted to nature in the form of light and when the magus sees all\nthings in this celestial light, then he is a cabbalist. Cabbalism, thus, is of\nhigher spiritual worth than magic (Arndt, 1608: 111) and, even more\nspecifically, the cabbalah is magic in a heavenly light. Under the influence of the natural irradiation (of the sun's light), magic is natural wis-\n22 Khunrath (1609), pp. 195-96: \"Ruah Elohim est SPIRITUS, Spiraculum, ahelitus\nprimi\n[Tetragrammaton] sancti, sanctus; Vapor virtutis DEI ... foecunditatis vitalis,\nsummique motoris, vivifica atque virtuosa, ... IDEARUM ... Exemplarium, Specierum,\nRationum feminariarum ... in ARCHETYPI, opificis summi, mente ... Hhochmah in\nSAPIENTIA ... ESSENTIA ... vere QUINTA ... DEI NUMEN, et Divina Ratio ...\nUNUS\n(essentia\net numero) hic DEI Spiritus est; ... Anima catholica ... unius Animae\nuniversalis\nscintillae\".\n23 Khunrath (1609), p. 197: \"Ruach Elohim (descendendo demittendoque se per\ncircumferentias partesque; abditissimas omnes, et dispergendo in imum vel meditullium,\nScintillas radiosve foecunditas suae) ad Centrum usque penetrabat\".\n24 Khunrath (1609), p. 202: \"Azoth hoc est [sign for mercury] mercurium\nPhilosophorum Catholicon: qui cum Igne interno et Externo, harmonia tamen\nsympathica, cum Igne Olympico, ob necessitatem inevitabilem, Physicomagice unito, ad\nLapidem nostrum consequendum ... Quod, Vulcani, secretum, profundissime, abscosum,\nnisi probe sciveris ... aut ab artifice, aut usu crebro, aut DEIPSO, more Cabalistico,\nfrustra ...laborabis\".\n25Johannes Arndt, \"Judicium uber die vier Figuren des Grossen Amphiteatrum\nHenrici Khunraths\" in Heinrich Khunrath, De Igne Magorum Philosophorumque secreto\n(Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner, 1608), pp. 107-23.\n26 Pagel, \"Paracelsus als \"Naturmystiker\" (1979), pp. 59-60.\n\nPages 75:\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE. THE EDITION OF 1604\ndom, but under the influence of divine irridescence, it becomes Divine\nWisdom (Arndt, 1608: 113).\nThe focus ofArndt's attention is the \"first figure\" ofthe Amphiteatrum.,\nwhich, from his description, is the circular engraving depicting the \"Anthropos\", identifiable with Christ, standing within a cabbalistic cosmos\n(fig. 32). Arndt refers to the 'Hebrew names which stand in the circle\",\nmeaning the seventy-two names of God inscribed on the outer sphere\n(Arndt, 1608: 117-18). He explains that the Hebrew names are those of\nan \"angel\" within the circle , which may indicate that Arndt was referring\nto Reuchlin's description of the cabbalistic angel Metattron who, as the\nempyreal form of the Messiah, was identified with Christ (Arndt, 1608:\n113).27 The Ten Commandments are also inscribed on the circle, while\nat the four axis points appear the names of the four elements. The theme\nof this picture is the descent of Anthropos (Christ) into the inferior world\nin the form oflight, as the \"Ruah-Elohim\", the Creator-God. Klossowski\nde Rola interprets the outer circle of the Ten Commandments as representing the cabbalistic physical world of Asiyyah, the letters of the Hethat of the formative\nbrew alphabet as that of Yetsirah, the sephiroth\nworld of Beriah and the names of God as the divine world of Azilut. The\nfigure of Christ is the \"En Soph\" itself and both he and the phoenix at his\nfeet represent resurrection and immortality. Hence, the image is a discourse on Christ crucified and resurrected as the philosopher's stone,\nprobably in a Weigelian sense as the eternal drama of the spiritual Christ\nwithin the human soul.28\nAnother aspect ofthese four images which Arndt regarded to be highly significant was their depiction of the astral or aethereal fire produced\nby magic which he regarded as the great secret of nature (Arndt, 1608:\n121-23). Arndt mentions Khunrath's citations ofthe heavenly fire ofPrometheus, which was also the secret fire of the oriental magi , such as\nAaron, the Chaldeans and the Persians. Although his description is brief,\nit is likely that it refers to the image of the \"Archetypos\" whose grace\ndescends to the earth in the form of drops of aetherial water, uniting with\nthe aspiring flames ofthe virtuous human soul (fig. 33). However, Arndt's\naccount ofthe secret fire ofthe sages is equally appropriate to his \"first\nfigure\"(fig. 32) in which Christ appears in the midst of a blaze of roaring\nflames, radiating from the dove ofthe Holy Spirit at his feet. (Klossowski\nde Rola had identified this bird as a phoenix). In this image it would be\nChrist who was the \" secret fire of the sages\". Both of these engravings\nvisualise the intense experience of Christ's gift of divine grace to the\nhuman soul which produces the spiritual state of the \"unio mystica\". The\nillumination of the soul, thus, is achieved through the practice ofcabbalistic contemplation which reveals the vision of God.\nKlossowski de Rola considered that the engraving ofthe \"Archteypos\"\n(fig. 33) described \"the entire process of the elaboration of the Philosopher's Stone\". He interprets the figure ofthe \"Rebis\" in the centre ofthe\nimage as exemplifying a \"most excellent and perfect Marriage, whose\nmysterious offspring is likened to the Divine Logos, redeemer of all humanity\". Klossowski de Rola emphasises the Christological discourse of\nthe image, referring especially to Khunrath's concepts ofthe death and\nresurrection of Christ as the \"Divine Stone\",29\nIn the illustration of the \"Archetypos\" the Tetragrammaton creates\nthe world on the model of its own divine qualities which are inscribed on\nthe flames of light shining forth from it. The model for Khunrath's engraving was the computational circles of the Lullian Art which functioned according to categories determined by the eternal qualities of\nGod. The two inner circles of Khunrath's cosmogram are divided into\nten categories which, in Lullian mode, record the spiritual virtues ofthe\nsoul and the taxonomical functions of the human mind. In the outer\ncircle there is a statement that the forms of nature (signified by the quaternary), the duality (of spirit and body) and the ternary (of spirit, soul\nand body) should be reduced to the simplicity of the Monad (God). Lull\nhad adapted to his logical system the neoplatonic-Augustinian concept of\n\"exemplarism\" in which God's qualities were the model for his material\ncreation. Lull's system in the Ars Inventiva Veritatis (1289-90) was based on\nthe circular diagram ofthe \"Figura Animae\" which employed nine ofthe\nneoplatonic dignities of God. It was structured on a trinitarian numerology, since it was computed by three triangles located in the centre, representing the Holy Trinity. Similarly, in the centre of Khunrath's image\nthere is a triangle containing the figure of the \"Rebis\", signifying the\ndualistic constitution of the human-being as body and soul. It also represents Christ whose nature was also binary since he was both God and\nhuman.\nOn the pages of a book, shown at the top-left of the central scene,\nthere appears the cabbalistic name of Christ, \"YHSVH\", recurring also\non a scroll winding around the \"Rebis\", on whose garment are written\n122\n27 Reuchlin, De Arte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964 facsimile of 1517 ed.), pp. 133, 143,\n152.\nand Zeller,\n28 Klossowski de Rola, The Golden Game (1988), pp. 43-44. See Peuckert\n. Samtliche Schriften, 4, pp. 7ff, 133-51, 320-22, esp. Ch. 3 on \"Christus\nWeigel\nValentin\ncrucifixus\".\n29 Klossowski de Rola, The Golden Game (1988), p. 44.\n123\n\nPages 76:\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE. THE EDITION OF 1604\nthe words \"Christo inductus et eum imitans\" (\"led by Christ and imitating him\"). On the outer circle of the diagram there is another reference\nto the resurrected, triunary \"Xptotoo crucifixus\" who sits on the throne\n(of God) and who leads the soul to the Truth.30 It will be recalled that in\nthe manuscript copy of the 1595 Amphiteatrum (MS Alnwick 571) Khunrath had chastised the black magicians for their use of the pentacle,\nstating that the \"annulus\" (Agrippa's term for a magical talisman) is the\nlegitimate cabbalistic cypher. It is probable that by these words Khunrath\nwas indicating the theurgic authority of the circular engraving of the\n\"Archetypos\" which was derived from the risen Christ.31\nThe same Christian intention ofbelittling the practices ofblackmagic\nis encountered in one of the engravings made for the Amphiteatrum in\n1602, that of a circular fortress with twenty-one gates (fig. 29). The concept promoted in this image is that Christ, as the illuminating principle of\nnature in the philosopher's stone, is the only path to the kingdom ofGod.\nThe texts in the centre of the castle refer to the light of nature and the\nhealing powers of Christ as the universal Salt, the philosopher's stone and\nthe water of life. He is to be attained by spagyric and orthodox philosophical principles. Sophistry will not prevail against them.32 In contrast,\nthe texts around the fortress denounce black magical practices, false alchemical principles and sophistry, that is, theurgy without a Christian\nfoundation (basically witchcraft with spirit familiars), materialism and\ndoctrinal rigidity. The other texts in the circle include references to specific alchemical processes, while the section below the castle describes the\n\"Magnesia\" (Christ) as the \"medicina catholica\". It states that the stone\n(\"Elohim sal sapientiae\") is prepared \"vulcanically\" (\"vulcanicam\") and\n\"neptunically\" (\"neptunicam\"), that is, through the action of fire and\nwater.\nHence, there is only one spiritual path, the way of Christ, by which\nthe fortress ofWisdom may be entered and this is indicated by the elaborate gateway. Klossowski de Rola's interpetation of this image stresses\nthe protective nature ofthe fortress in which the secrets ofthe alchemical\nart are hidden. Twenty of the gates lead the false alchemists to ruin, the\nonly way into the castle is by the practice ofmoral virtue and through the\nilluminated knowledge granted by God.33\nAbove the main gateway to the castle, there is an image of Dee's\nMonas Hieroglyphica, while a motto reads \"Laborando Orando\" which\nwas also Dee's axiom (fig. 30). Around the Monas are two dragons, holding each other's tails in the form ofthe Ouroboros. Various other symbols refer to the secrecy ofthe alchemical process, such as a cryptic word,\n\"MYSTERION\" which is inscribed, letter by letter, on each ofthe seven\nsteps proceeding upwards to the classical gate-way. Two obelisks are\nlocated at the foot of the stairs, the sun crowning the one on the left and\nthe moon that on the right, which is also labelled \"TACITURNITAS\".\nBetween the two obelisks is written the phrase \"OPERA BONA\". At the\nfoot ofthe path, the figure of an alchemist gazes out at the viewer, while\ntwo other figures, exotically dressed in the manner of oriental cabbalists,\nappear in the space behind the gate, incanting Hebrew texts. The symbolic triangle of God hovers at the top ofthe scene, while a dragon lurks\nbelow, representing base-matter. The texts around him refer to the alchemical processes of putrefaction, coagulation, fixation and increation,\nwhile other inscriptions speak of multiplication, reiteration, fermentation,\nthe elixir and the red and white tinctures. Below this scene, there is an\nemblem of a heart, out ofwhich are growing barren thorns and a flowering bramble. An alchemical kiln to the right of this device is inscribed\nwith cyphers referring to Christ, \"INRI\" and \"IHS\".\nThe path to the main gate of the fortress is drawn in the form of an\nabstract geometrical structure, so as to present a diagrammatic model of\nthe single-point perspective system. It should be noted that the threedimensional space of the gateway is discordant with the perspectival\nstructure of the rest of the scene, since the castle itself, as well as its\nlandscape setting, are pictured as a map, or an aerial view. Moreover, the\npath is drawn in the form of a diagrammatic \"pavimentum diminutionis\", in the manner of model-books explaining the construction of\n124\n]\npater [\"YHVSH\" in Hebrew\n30 Khunrath, engraving (1595): \"Sic [Tetragrammaton]omnis\nsedebit in throno suo,\nXpiotoo crucifixus, frater: SPIRITUS SANCTUS\nTEMETIPSO, triuno, renato, catholico\". The scroll around the \"rebis\" reads: \"HOMO\nORA/ binarium/ LABORA [\"YHSVH\" in Hebrew] SAPIENTIA [Tetragrammaton]\nincarnata, miserere, nostri et doce nos VERITATEM: amen\".\nTheoso31 MS Alnwick 571, Par. 74: \"Hic ANNULUM assistentia spiritu boni,Nigroman,\nnon\nillud\nPentaculum\nSolo\nnovis\nvirtuosum\nCordis)\nHoc\nphorum:(In Tabulis\natque blasphemum: est collo mentis luce\nticorum seu Cacomagorum phantasticum,\". For\nAgrippa's \"annulus\" (sigils) see his Opera\nsuspendenda. Vi de figura Amp. huius 4a\nChs.\n30\nand\n31, pp. 390-96.\n;\n1970),\nBk.\nIII,\n1600)\n(Hildesheim\n(\nqui Mundi maioris fil32 Khunrath, engraving (1602): \"PETRA PHILOSOPHALIS,\nsapientiae\nfusili et Oleo, salutis\nsuis\nSALE\npraeconsortibus\nNaturae \u041fav\nius, et magnus\nAnimalium,\nMedicinalis incombustibili, hoc est MEDICINAE Hominum vegetabilium,\nMineralium, Metallorum, ac Lapidum; imo Rerum Materialium, omnium Universali,\nunctus; seminarium habens Ignis Naturae; venat habens Aquae vivae et vitae salientis in\nvitambeatam CHRISTIQUE IHSVH effigies, in Natura symbolica supra quam Unam et\nac Orthodoxe\nSolam Numen Luminis Naturae aedificavit Turbam suam spagyricehaec\nPhilosophantium, Catholicam. Nec est in Ente alio Naturali ullo salus : Et portae\nsophistarum non praevalebunt adversus eam\".\n33 Klossowski de Rola, The Golden Game (1988), p. 42..\n125\n\nPages 77:\nCHAPTER NINE\nAMPHITEATRUM SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE: THE EDITION OF 1604\nillusionistic three-dimensional space (figs. 1, 21, 22). The implication of\nKhunrath's perspectival construction is that it is being used as a symbolic\nimage in its own right.\nThe appearance, hence, of Dee's Monas in this perspectival view of\nthe castle-gate is an allusion both to his Euclidean cabbalism and, also,\nperhaps, indirectly to his \" zographie\" in the Mathematicall Preface (1570: ff.\ndijv, diijr), since the classical forms of the castle-gateway and its spatial\nconstruction could have been influenced by Dee's Vitruvian theory in the\nMathematicall Preface. It will be recalled that Dee considered \"zographie\"\nto be a conceptual art-form, whose geometrical principles were related to\noptics . Furthermore, single-point perspective drawing, like any geometrical structure based on Pythagorean mathematical ratios, was a type of\nmagical sigil (Dee, Math. Pref. f. ciiijr), similar to the astral catoptrics of\nthe Propaedeumata Aphoristica and to the theurgic cypher of the Monas\nHieroglyphica. Dee's account of \"zographie\" in the Mathematicall Preface\nimplied that a graphic system based on Pythagorean geometry would act\nas a theurgic talisman absorbing the celestial virtues. Dee's theories\nwould resonate with Khunrath's own Agrippan influences, as well as with\nhis Paracelsian theosophy in which Christ-Anthropos operated through\nthe light of\"Hochmah\" to pervade the universe. Khunrath's engravings\nwere, thus, spiritual catoptrical mirrors, reflecting the light of Eternal\nWisdom to the mind of the viewer.\nAccording to Szonyi, architectural motifs in mystical imagery are cosmograms in which the buildings and their ground-plans signify the construction of the cosmos, producing a revelation in the viewer's mind'\nconcerning the fabric of reality. Szonyi has, however, distinguished such\ncosmograms from the use of similar architectural motifs in alchemical\nimagery, since he regards them as being more scenic elements, included\nwithin a didactic, slowly-unfolding, alchemical story. For his taxonomy of\nrevelatory and didactic images Szonyi has drawn on Gombrich's definition of symbolic types of imagery.34 According to this argument, Khunrath's 1595 illustrations would be revelatory since they are visually structured to illuminate the viewer's understanding through an empathetic\nengagement. In contrast, Khunrath's 1602 engravings are more narrative, both in their formal construction and in their semiotic mode, though\nelements within these images continue to operate with a revelatory intention. On the other hand, many other seventeenth century alchemical\nimages, such as those ofMaier in the Atalanta Fugiens, are primarily didactic in their intention.\nAnother ofthe 1602 illustrations in the Amphiteatrum, as discussed earlier, is both a revelatory and a didactic exposition of Reuchlin's sephirothic ladder. Recalling Reuchlin's frequent references to the cabbalistic\n\"portae lucis\", Khunrath's cave is similarly entitled \"PORTA AMPHITEATRI SAPIENTIAE AETERNAE\" (fig. 31).34 The wording on the\nrays of light emanating from the cave is discussed in the fourth Isagoge\nlater in the treatise (Khunrath, 1609: 208). Initiates into the cabbalistic\nmysteries proceed up a sequence of seven steps, each of which is related\nto a cryptic aphorism appearing in the rays of light, alluding to the need\nfor obedience on the spiritual path since the great mystery is not available to the profane.35\nThe text below the image states that the path to Jehovah is narrow,\nknown only tothe Christian cabbalist and also to those philosophers who\nprofess orthodox doctrines. The incarnation of Christ was a gift from\nGod given to his friends that they might rejoice. Thus, they will not die\nfrom sophistry but will live in theosophical wisdom.
