Hic enim ut nimis dispergit visivam virtutem et ille in arctum contrahit,\nsic Citrinus color oculorum aerem, quemadmodum et viridis, reficit, in mediocritate\nconservat et delectat\"..\n17 Sylvain Matton and Jacques Rebotier, La Musique des Cantilenae Intellectuales (Alencon:\nJ-C Bailly, 1984), passim.\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\n157\n457\nconceptual art-work, rather than as a practical score to be used in a real\nperformance. His musical forms were based on those of the \"cantus firmus\" of Gregorian chants, although he provided only three voice-parts,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=90\nPages: 90\nexpressive, lyrical mode. Maier structured his alchemical theory mainly\nin the form of stories for a courtly audience.\nAlthough Maier was himself a member of the central European aristocracy, he had trained as a physician and was employed at the courtof\nRudolph II in Prague. He subsequently travelled around Germany and\nHolland, arriving in England in early 1612 where he was similarly attached to the highest court circles, until his departure for Bohemia in\n1618. There exists a Christmas card addressed to James I and to Henry,\nPrince of Wales, in which the greeting has been constructed by Maier in\nthe shape of a rose. It has been cited by Adam McLean as evidence of\nMaier's Rosicrucian convictions.2 He was, in fact, among the first to\nFor Maier's biography see J. B. Craven, Count Michael Maier (Kirkwall, 1910).\n2 Adam McLean, \"A Rosicrucian Manuscript of Michael Maier\", The HermeticJournal\n(1979): 1ff. Maier's Rose is found in British Library MS Royal 14B XVI. See also Ron]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=94\nPages: 94\nas being related to the use of catoptrics.\nWithplants and animals reproduction takes place by means ofseed, but with\nsimple bodies or bodies of a simple composition this takes place by introducing force and by means of assimilation.\nThus, the sun, the celestial luminary, sends its beams to the earth and when\nthese beams are bundled in a sun-glass, shapes are seen, which are, as it\nwere, form projections ofthe sun. On these grounds it is established that sunbeams are nothing but flames offire, which are spread out over a wide space;\nwhen, however, they are focused, they burn everything that comes within the\npoint offocus33\nMaier frequently refers to the secret fire of alchemy, the quintessence, as\nin Emblem XXXVII (Maier, 1618: 158-59).34\nThe quintessential fire is the theme also of Emblem VIII, which alludes to alchemical geometry and catoptrics (fig. 41) on the model ofde\nVries' engraving for Khunrath's Amphiteatrum. The illustration displays an]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=25\nPages: 25\nOn the model ofRipley's Duodecim Portae Michael Maier described similar\nalchemical voyages around a Lullian alchemical circle in the Cantilenae\nIntelectuales (1617), Viatorium (1618) and Tripus Aureus (1618).36\nRipley's probable disciple Thomas Norton was similarly influenced by\npseudo-Lullian alchemy,37 producing one of the most important Renaissance alchemical treatises, The Ordinal ofAlchemy (begun in 1477).38 Dee\ntranscribed a copy of this text in his own hand in 1577 and had it bound\nin purple velvet (Bodleian Library MS Ashmole 57).39 According to Ashmole, Maier came to England in 1611 specifically to learn English, so\nthat he could translate Norton's treatise into Latin for his compendium of\nalchemical texts, the Tripus Aureus (Frankfurt, 1618).40 Norton also referred to the importance of geometry in his alchemical theory, but he\ndeveloped this idea much further than either the pseudo-Lullians or Ripley. In fact, although Norton's Ordinal is related conceptually to the work]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96\nPages: 96\nclosely the \"secondary stages\" of his theatre of memory (fig. 43).44 In\nMaier's illustration, the building on the right has an upper storey, as in\nFludd's\"Theatrum Orbi\", but it has been displaced from centre-stage. In\naddition, the two rear openings of Fludd's theatre have been replaced by\nthe diagrammatic tunnel.\nIf one ofthe sources for Maier's image was the Vitruvianism ofDee's\nMathematicall Preface, filtered through Fludd's work, then Maier would also\nhave known Dee's theory of\"zographie\", that is, his theurgical Pythagorean geometry which is described in the same treatise. The perspectival\nstructure ofMaier's Emblem VIII suggests, in fact, that this was the case.\nMoreover, the spatial design is comparable to Khunrath's gateway in the\nalchemical fortress (1602) (fig. 30) as well as de Vries' hall in the OratoryLaboratory (frontispiece). In Emblem VIII, the perspectival cone (the\ndiagrammatic tunnel) points heavenwards with its base above the egg,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=23\nPages: 23\nopposites being laid out across the diagonals (fig. 3). Around the edges of\nthe square the mutations took place in a circular motion.24\nHence, the symbolic picture of the alchemical process was not only\nthat of a circle, but also that of the squaring of the circle. The same idea\nis subsequently encountered in George Ripley's Compound of Alchemy as\nwell as in Michael Maier's Emblem XLVI in the Atalanta Fugiens (fig. 39).\nSince this geometrical feat cannot be accomplished in Euclidean geometry, therefore, the concept of the squaring of the circle came to signify\nany process which could be accomplished only by means of divine intervention. In fact, it became a generic sign for the alchemical process itself\nand Maier produced a treatise based on this idea, De Circulo Physico,\nQuadrato (Oppenheim: Luca Jennis, 1616), which was an account ofthe\nrole of the sun in the making ofpotable gold.\nIn alchemical theory, the squaring of the circle was a monistic concept]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96\nPages: 96\npurified by fire, they will arise in the perfected form of the philosopher's\nstone. Hence, in Emblem VIII, the perspectival grid signifies the divine\nlight of the heavens, the alchemical quintessence which carries the seed\nof gold from the sun. It is placed directly above the egg to denote the\npotential evolution of prime matter to a higher spiritual condition.\nTherefore, the theurgic meaning of Emblem VIII lies within a set of\nassociations inter- relating Vitruvian architecture, perspectival geometry\nand catoptrics, in short, the same themes explored by Dee. Consequently,\nMaier's emblem, like that of Khunrath, explains the theory of an alchemy of light. The diagrammatic tunnel of orthogonal lines, like de Vries'\nhallway, refers to Paracelsian astral influences and Dee's astrological catoptrics. This geometrical structure, with its base on the earth and its\napex in heaven (signified by the vanishing-point), represents the quest for]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96\nPages: 96,97\napex in heaven (signified by the vanishing-point), represents the quest for\nthe philosopher's stone by means of celestial alchemy. Even more significantly, Maier's emblem like that of de Vries in the Amphiteatrum is an\nalchemical sigil, a catoptrical mirror reflecting the light of the quintessence. It is, in itself, a theurgical instrument whose potency is amplified\nbyMaier's Pythagorean musical score whose motif of the diapentic interval as the golden apple ofAtalanta, introduces the power ofthe solar rays\ninto the process of alchemical transmutation.\n45 Shumaker, pp. 136-38, 148-51.\n46 Maier (1618), p. 42: \"Sic foetui humanam vitam vegetabili (qua solam in utero\nmatris fruebatur) defuncto, alia perfectior per transitum in hanc lucem mundanam sive\nper nativitatem accedit. Imo et nobis hac praesenti vitam, quam agimus, alia\nperfectissima et aeterna imminet\".\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD:\nTHE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91\nPages: 91\nconcept ofthe \"rotation\" ofthe chemicals, stating that in order to purify\nsulphur, the \"soul\" of gold, the alchemist needed to apply the perfect\nform ofthe circle, in other words he needed to use the rotational forces of\ndistillation.8\nHe also quotes from the Rosarium concerning the geometrical figures\nof the circle, square and triangle which represent the masculine and\nfeminine qualities (Maier, 1616: 11).9 An illustration ofthis geometrical\nrelationship appears in his later compendium of alchemical treatises, the\nTripus Aureus (Frankfurt, 1618), in which the emblem accompanying the\nseventh key of Basil Valentine's De Lapide Sapientum depicts a circle,\nsquared internally, with a triangle within the square labelled \"Aqua\".\nThe circle represents \"Chaos\", while the square symbolises the four seasons.10The same relationship of circle, square and triangle appears in the\nillustration to Emblem XXI of the Atalanta Fugiens where a geometrical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=92\nPages: 92\n(1617; 1618) were also accompanied by a musical score of fugues for\nthree voices, providing a series of meditations on the spiritual significance\nof alchemy.\nGodwin and Streich have analysed the musical structure of the Atalanta Fugiens, concluding that Maier's composition should be regarded as a\n12 Maier (1616), pp. 15-16: \"Hic est circulus ab natura ipsa circumscriptus, non\nimaginatione mathematica, sed reali et Physico ductu delineatus\".\n13 Maier (1616), pp. 15-17: \"Hoc est lutum splendidum rota et manu maximi illius et\nomnipotentis figuli sub artum foretumque in substantiam pulcherrimam,\nin qua radii\nsolares congregantur et elucent, haud dubii testes illius aetheriae claritatis et lucis, in\nterrestri materia detentae et portatae\".\n14 Maier (1616), p. 23: \"Aurum, quasi Solem terrenum, a quibusdam dictum, esse\ncentrum omnium humanarum actionum, veluti coelestis planetarum\".\n15 Maier (1616), p. 24: \"Ita ab auro res precio et aestimationi subjacentes aequaliter]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=112\nPages: 112,111\n(ed), John Dee: Inter-disciplinary Approaches, Dordrecht; London; New York: Kluwer, 1999.\nSzonyi, Gyorgy E., \"Architectural Symbolism and Fantasy Landscapes in Alchemical and Occult Discourse: Revelatory Images\", Glasgow Emblem Studies, III,\nUniversity of Glasgow, 1998, pp. 49-69.\nSzulakowska, Urszula, \"Material Pantheism in the Pseudo-Lullian \"S\"-Circle of\nthe Powers ofthe Soul\", Ambix, 35 (1988): 127-54.\nSzulakowska, Urszula, \"Geometry and Optics in Renaissance Alchemical Illustration:John Dee, Robert Fludd and Michael Maier\", Cauda Pavonis, n.s. 14,\n1(1995): 1-12.\nSzulakowska, Urszula, \"The Pseudo-Lullian Origins of George Ripley's Maps\nand Routes as developed by Michael Maier\", Cosmos, 9 , (1993): 107-26.\n196\nBIBLIOGRAPHY\nSzulakowska, Urszula, \"Two Italian alchemical manuscripts: some philosophical\nproblems: monism and dualism\" in Didier Kahn and Sylvain Matton (eds),\nAlchimie: art, histoire et mythes. Actes du 1er colloque international de la Societ\u00e9 d'Etude]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91\nPages: 91\ngold, the sun being an image of God himself.5 According to Maier, the\nuniversal panacea resolved the problem of the squaring of the circle\n(Maier, 1616: 4).\nMaier explained that, according to Plato, the perfect form of eternal\nBeing was the circle and this was also the essential form of gold, the most\nperfect substance in the physical world (Maier, 1616: 11), since the circle\nis the form of nature when she has been quieted from her compulsive\nmotion (Maier, 1616: 12). In this idea, he was following the well-known\nargument of Aristotle in De generatione et corruptione that anything which\nmoves is by nature imperfect, since it is prone to corrupting changes.\nConsequently, the static circle is nature perfected,6 manifesting in the\nphysical form of red, coagulated sulphur, or gold. Maier referred to the\nalchemical theories ofthe pseudo-Lullian Testament, in particular, to their\nconcept ofthe \"rotation\" ofthe chemicals, stating that in order to purify]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* Michael Maier's alchemical geometry is explored as a core element of his symbolic system, combining classical and esoteric influences. Key points about Maiers alchemical geometry include: 1. The Squaring of the Circle: Maier utilized the geometrical concept of the squaring of the circle to symbolize the union of opposites, such as the masculine and feminine principles in alchemy. This concept is illustrated in *Atalanta Fugiens* and represents both spiritual and material perfection, with the circle standing for eternal divine order and the square representing the physical world: > "Maier... based his alchemical programme on geometry, which was itself the subject of one of his earliest treatises on the Euclidean problem of squaring the circle." [Urszula Szul, page 91](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91). 2. Pythagorean Musical Ratios: Maier incorporated Pythagorean music theory into his geometric designs, transforming them into theurgical tools capable of capturing celestial powers. He used the fifth musical interval to symbolize the rays of the sun, thus introducing a theurgic charge into the alchemical process. This geometry was not merely symbolic but functioned as a practical mechanism in his alchemical illustrations: > "The effect of adding Pythagorean musical ratios to Maier's alchemical imagery was that it transformed them into theurgical talismans." [Urszula Szul, page 93](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=93). 3. Alchemical Symbols and the Sun: Maier's alchemical emblems frequently depicted the sun as a transformative force, with solar rays acting as metaphors for divine energy descending into material substances. His use of geometric forms like cones of light represented the descent of divine wisdom from the macrocosm to the microcosm: > "In Maier's emblem... the centric axis passing through the egg to the vanishing-point symbolises the transmutatory effects of the celestial influences." [Urszula Szul, page 96](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96). 4. Vitruvian Architecture and Alchemical Transformation: Maier also incorporated Vitruvian principles of architecture and perspective into his works, using geometric structures like tunnels and cones to symbolize the connection between the spiritual and physical realms. His alchemical geometry often mirrored the catoptrics (mirror-based optical effects) used by figures like John Dee: > "The diagrammatic tunnel... refers to Paracelsian astral influences and Dee's astrological catoptrics." [Urszula Szul, page 96](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96). For more details on Maier's alchemical geometry, you can explore [page 91](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91) and [page 96](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=96).
You
continue the summary of the book
Tool
{"result":["[Summary from page 91 to page 101 out of a total of 137:\nPages 91:\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\npublish a supportive commentary on the Rosicrucian Manifestos in his\nThemis Aurea ( 1618).\nThe internal evidence of Maier's treatises indicates that, during his\nstay in England, he had been influenced by the Paracelsian alchemy of\nRobert Fludd. Although there exists no documented evidence of their\ndirect connection, they could have encountered each other in the same\ncourt circles. Yates has even suggested that Maier in 1616 transported\nthe manuscripts of Fludd's Utriusque Cosmi Historia to the publisher,\nJohann Theodore de Bry, in Oppenheim.3 Moreover, the meteorological\ntheory and imagery of Maier's Septimana Philosophica (Frankfurt : Luca Jennis, 1620) is related to that of Fludd in his \"Microcosm\" (UCH, 1619).*\nIn contrast to Dee, Khunrath and Fludd, Maier infrequently referred\nto the cabbalah, occasionally employing some general concepts, but never applying the system methodically. Instead, he based his alchemical\nprogramme on geometry, which was itself the subject of one of his earliest treatises on the Euclidean problem of squaring the circle, De Circulo\nPhysico, Quadrato (Oppenheim : Luca Jennis, 1616). Maier, like Khunrath,\nused the image ofthe squared circle as a theurgical sigil, representing the\nspiritual and alchemical union of opposites in the \"azoth\". A circle appears on the title-page of his treatise, bearing the names of the four\nuniversal qualities, \"calidum siccum frigidum humidum\", while a rectangle lists the four elements. The main subject of this essay is the Paracelsian theory of the universal panacea, the potable gold which ensured\nboth physical and spiritual health, due to its concordance ofthe macroand microcosms . These were signified by the sun, the human heart and\ngold, the sun being an image of God himself.5 According to Maier, the\nuniversal panacea resolved the problem of the squaring of the circle\n(Maier, 1616: 4).\nMaier explained that, according to Plato, the perfect form of eternal\nBeing was the circle and this was also the essential form of gold, the most\nperfect substance in the physical world (Maier, 1616: 11), since the circle\nis the form of nature when she has been quieted from her compulsive\nmotion (Maier, 1616: 12). In this idea, he was following the well-known\nargument of Aristotle in De generatione et corruptione that anything which\nmoves is by nature imperfect, since it is prone to corrupting changes.\nConsequently, the static circle is nature perfected,6 manifesting in the\nphysical form of red, coagulated sulphur, or gold. Maier referred to the\nalchemical theories ofthe pseudo-Lullian Testament, in particular, to their\nconcept ofthe \"rotation\" ofthe chemicals, stating that in order to purify\nsulphur, the \"soul\" of gold, the alchemist needed to apply the perfect\nform ofthe circle, in other words he needed to use the rotational forces of\ndistillation.8\nHe also quotes from the Rosarium concerning the geometrical figures\nof the circle, square and triangle which represent the masculine and\nfeminine qualities (Maier, 1616: 11).9 An illustration ofthis geometrical\nrelationship appears in his later compendium of alchemical treatises, the\nTripus Aureus (Frankfurt, 1618), in which the emblem accompanying the\nseventh key of Basil Valentine's De Lapide Sapientum depicts a circle,\nsquared internally, with a triangle within the square labelled \"Aqua\".\nThe circle represents \"Chaos\", while the square symbolises the four seasons.10The same relationship of circle, square and triangle appears in the\nillustration to Emblem XXI of the Atalanta Fugiens where a geometrical\ndiagram incorporates additional male and female figures (fig. 38).11\n154\n3 Yates (1986), pp. 80-90.\nMichael Maier, Septimana Philosophica (Frankfurt: Luca Jennis, 1620), pp. 34 ff, \"De\nMeteoris\", see frontispiece and illustration on p. 31.\n5 Maier (1616), p. 6:\nUtque Deus Soli, Sol auro, denique cordi\ndat, et hoc verso respicit orbe Deum:\nVim\nOmnia ab hoc et ad hunc mortalia conditatendunt,\nCirculus hic, quicquid constat ubique, replet\nDee uses the same idea see Shumaker, pp. 158-61.\n155\n6 Maier (1616) , p. 13: \"Hic est ille Circulus Physicis, quem si natura circumgyratione\nsui absolverit, merito quiescit: cum post motum quies appetatur ab omnibus\n... De qua\nloquendi ratione si quisquam dubitet, nodum, quod aiunt, Pythagoras ... illud esse\nCirculum, cuius centrum sit circumferentiae innatum, hoc est, homogeneam substantiam.\nexistere, cuius millesima et interior pars sit formalis et agens, reliquae materiales et\nformatus\".\n7 Maier (1616) , p. 14: \"hinc Centrum seu formam (quae est sulfur rubeum et coagulatum)\nCirculo, Auro ... tanquam superficiei, suam essentiam puram et denomidedisse\".\nnationemin hoc\n8 Maier (1616), pp. 14-15: \"Adhaec Circulum Aurum\nquia ut in rotario opere\ntextorum observamus, stamino ex centro duci recta, diximus,\nsuperqua subtegmina circumgyrantur contiguem, donec sphaerica figura ... introducta sit, sic in auro forma ipse\nmateriae ex materiae sinu simul semelque intertexitur\".\n9 See also Szonyi (1984), pp. 373-74, on Edmund Spenser's use ofthe same concept in\nthe Faerie Queene.\n10 Michael Maier, Tripus Aureus (Frankfurt: Luca Jennis, 1618), p. 407.\nMichael Maier, Atalanta Fugiens (1618) pp. 92-95. On p. 93 the text reads: \"Fac ex\nmasculine et foemina circulum, inde quadrangulum, fac circulum et habebis lapis Philosophorum.\nEpigramma XXI\nFoemina masculineque unus fiant tibi circulus, ex que\nSurgat, habens aquum forma quadrata latus.\nHinc Trigonum ducas, omni qui parte rotundam\nIn sphaeram redeat: Tum LAPIS ortus erit.\nSi res tanta tua non mox venit obvia menti,\nDogma Geometria si capis omne scies.\n\nPages 92:\n156\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nIn his De Circulo Physico, Quadrato Maier states that the incorrupt nature\nof gold proves that the circle, as its essential form, is not an abstract\nmathematical concept, but a physical reality.12 For the congregation of\nthe sun's rays creates its beautiful circular shape13 and gold is central to\nhuman activity, as if it were a sun within the earth.14 Thus, on themodel\nofthe relationship of the centre to the circumference ofthe perfect circle,\ngold is the centre of all things .15 Moreover, gold as a colour is the union\nofopposites, those ofthe white female and the red male aspects.16 Hence,\nsince gold is perfection itself, its essential nature must be spiritual (Maier,\n1616 : 28, 46).\nAnother of Maier's fundamental tenets was the traditional idea that\nboth the cosmic order and the human-being as its reflection were governed by the musical ratios of the Pythagorean octave, the sun in the\nmidst of the macrocosm corresponding to the heart in a human-being\n(Maier, 1616: 7). In fact, he appended a lyric verse to De Circulo Physico,\nQuadrato, a \"Cantilena Anacreontia\" eulogising the properties of gold\n(Maier, 1616: 75-79). Slightly later, he composed another alchemical\nsong set to a musical score in the Cantilenae Intelectuales (Oppenheim,\n1617), in which the philosopher's stone was symbolised by the myth of\nthe Phoenix, possibly an allegory of Christ, although this was not specified. Moreover, the fifty alchemical emblems of the Atalanta Fugiens\n(1617; 1618) were also accompanied by a musical score of fugues for\nthree voices, providing a series of meditations on the spiritual significance\nof alchemy.\nGodwin and Streich have analysed the musical structure of the Atalanta Fugiens, concluding that Maier's composition should be regarded as a\n12 Maier (1616), pp. 15-16: \"Hic est circulus ab natura ipsa circumscriptus, non\nimaginatione mathematica, sed reali et Physico ductu delineatus\".\n13 Maier (1616), pp. 15-17: \"Hoc est lutum splendidum rota et manu maximi illius et\nomnipotentis figuli sub artum foretumque in substantiam pulcherrimam,\nin qua radii\nsolares congregantur et elucent, haud dubii testes illius aetheriae claritatis et lucis, in\nterrestri materia detentae et portatae\".\n14 Maier (1616), p. 23: \"Aurum, quasi Solem terrenum, a quibusdam dictum, esse\ncentrum omnium humanarum actionum, veluti coelestis planetarum\".\n15 Maier (1616), p. 24: \"Ita ab auro res precio et aestimationi subjacentes aequaliter\ndistant, hoc est, Geometrica proportione, vel, si movis\nArithmetica omnes ab uno auro determinentur, earumque valor\".\n16 Maier (1616), pp. 26-27: \"Color in auro non pallidus est ... sed Citrinus, qui ex\nrubeo et albo, mixte inter se proportionibiliter generatur, utpote medios inter extremos,\nnigrum et album. Hic enim ut nimis dispergit visivam virtutem et ille in arctum contrahit,\nsic Citrinus color oculorum aerem, quemadmodum et viridis, reficit, in mediocritate\nconservat et delectat\"..\n17 Sylvain Matton and Jacques Rebotier, La Musique des Cantilenae Intellectuales (Alencon:\nJ-C Bailly, 1984), passim.\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\n157\n457\nconceptual art-work, rather than as a practical score to be used in a real\nperformance. His musical forms were based on those of the \"cantus firmus\" of Gregorian chants, although he provided only three voice-parts,\nrather than four or five as was customary.18 The unresolved dissonances\nin the score could have been an intentional aspect of its design as programme music, describing the story of the race between Atalanta and\nHippomenes. The mythological story, however, is only depicted once on\nthe title-page, although it is described by the analogous construction of\nthe musical score.19 There is no direct reference to these protagonists\nwithin the sequence ofillustrations, nor in the textual discourse, the myth\nstanding only as a central trope in which the race for the golden apple\nsignifies the quest for the philosopher's stone and the union ofAtalanta\nand Hippomenes represents that of the female and male principles of\nalchemy. According to Streich, the structure of the musical score reflects\nthe alchemical process, with the three voice-parts referring to the Paracelsian alchemical principles, Sulphur, Mercury, Salt, in their essence as\nspirit, soul and matter.20 The voices also represent the three mythic characters ofAtalanta, Hippomenes and the golden apple. Most significantly,\nStreich has noted that the sequence for the apple voice wanders from the\nhigher to the lower pitch, as if it were describing the process of distillation.21 The fugue also runs as a mirror canon, or canon by inversion, in\nrespect to the voices of Atalanta and Hippomenes.22 Since music in the\nRenaissance represented the intellectual and spiritual spheres of the cosmos, its presence in Maier's alchemical treatise metaphorised the nature\nof alchemy as a process unifying the micro- and the macrocosm.23\nAs in de Vries' engraving for the Amphiteatrum, the musical motif alludes to Boethian musicology in which Pythagorean geometric ratios regulated the cosmic structure. The tonal sequence of Maier's composition\nwas based on the Pythagorean octave in which the third and sixth intervals were not considered to be consonant. Godwin and Streich have not\ndiscussed the philosophical implications of Maier's Pythagorean score,\nalthough Streich made an important point in her brief mention of the\n18 Joscelyn Godwin, Atalanta Fugiens. An Edition of the Fugues, Emblems and Epigrams\n(Phanes Press, 1989), p. 13. See also the less extensive references to Maier's composition\nin H. M. E de Jong, Michael Maier's \"Atalanta Fugiens\" (Leiden: E. J. Brill, 1969), pp. 3ff\nand passim.\n19 Godwin, p. 14.\n20 Streich in Godwin (ed), Atalanta Fugiens , p. 27.\n21 Streich, p. 43.\n22 Streich, p. 61 .\n23 See also the discussion in Christoph Meinel, Alchemie und Musik, (Wiesbaden: Herzog\nAugust Bibliothek, 1986), pp. 201-27.\n\nPages 93:\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\nfact that in certain parts of the fugues the fifth interval defines the structure ofthe composition and that it represents the sun (the golden apple).\nThe effect of adding Pythagorean musical ratios to Maier's alchemical\nimagery was that it transformed them into theurgical talismans . Just as\nDee's and Khunrath's use of Pythagorean geometry was a means ofcapturing the astral forces in their theurgic sigils, in the same way, Maier's\nPythagorean music attracted the celestial powers into his emblems, turning them into magical instruments. In particular, the fifth interval, representing the solar rays and the philosopher's stone, magnetically attracted\nthe sun, introducing a potent theurgic charge into the alchemical procedure. (This motif may have even been a reference to the process of\ndistillation by the heat of the sun). Reinforced by the music, Maier's\nemblems were intended to become transmutatory instruments of the\nsame type as the catoptrical mirrors described by John Dee in the Monas\nHieroglyphica and the \"annuli\" pictured by Khunrath in the Amphiteatrum.\nIn these ideas, Maier could have been influenced by a reference in the\nPropaedeumata Aphoristica (1568) where Dee had compared the harmonic\nstructure ofthe world to that of the chords of a lyre, alluding thus to the\nPythagorean tonal sequence and its cosmological function. Dee may have\nencountered this concept in the eighteenth discourse of the Corpus Hermeticum whose theological system describes the divine forces ofthe stars, the\nplanets and the sun in their effect on the human intellect. In the eighteenth discourse , Asclepius directs King Ammon to \"tune the inward lyre\nand adjust it to the [divine] musician\". Moreover, Ficino had referred to\nthe theurgic force ofthe fifth interval, the \"diapente\", whose relationship\nof 3: 2 he stated to be the ratio ofthe distance from the earth to the sun,\ncompared with that from the sun to the fixed stars. Hence, the perfect\nfifth in Ficino's astral magic was a musical signifier ofthe sun.24\nFludd had already produced an illustration of the cosmic lyre in the\n\"Macrocosm\", a sequence of Pythagorean octaves relating the physical\nworld to God (UCH, 1, 1617, Tract I: 92). In his musicology he ignored\nthe modifications gradually introduced into the Pythagorean harmonic\nscheme by Renaissance polyphony, which in 1599-1607 had forced Kepler to admit an empirically consonant third and sixth into the Pythago-\nrean tonal mode to enable him to rationalise his astronomical system.\nFludd, however, defended his own musicology against Kepler, and other\nopponents, by stating firmly that the Monochord was not simply a theoretical concept since his friends were using it for practical music-making.25 In his argument, Fludd may have been alluding to Maier's alchemical music as a justification for his ideas, but this connection has yetto be\ninvestigated by historians ofmusic. Yates discussed only certain aspects of\nthe relationship between Maier's Atalanta Fugiens (1617; 1618) and Fludd's\nUtriusque Cosmi ... Historia (1617-21) and the musical connection was not\nher main interest.26\nNeither has any musicologist provided a detailed analysis of the specific relationship between Maier's music and the visual imagery ofthe Atalanta Fugiens. Thus, despite the pioneering work of Godwin, Streich and\nde Jong, Maier's illustrations still await a definitive critical study since de\nJong's investigation of the textual sources of the Atalanta Fugiens did not\ninvolve a detailed examination of the illustrations themselves.\nFor the present purpose, only one image from this sequence will be\nconsidered, that of Emblem VIII since this is most closely related to de\nVries' theurgic \"annulus\" in Khunrath's Amphiteatrum.\nYates has shown that there existed a close historical relationship between the Atalanta Fugiens and Fludd's \"Macrocosm\" (UCH, 1617; 1618)\nwhich were published almost simultaneously byJohann Theodore de Bry\nin Oppenheim. The artists who produced the illustrations for Maier have\nnot been securely identified, though it is possible to discern two or three\ndifferent persons at work, one ofwhom was probably Matthieu Merian.27\nFludd's artists, on the whole, are recognisable by their signatures, which\nindicate that Johann Theodore de Bry engraved the first part of the\n\"Macrocosm\" (1617), the work being completed by Merian who also\nsigned the portrait of Fludd in the Philosophia Sacra.28 When the artistic\nstyles of the two treatises are compared, it appears that in the Atalanta\nFugiens the artist was inclined to depict classical architecture, whereas in\nFludd's illustrations the scenes are those ofmedieval northern towns. The\ntechnical style is also more confident in the Atalanta Fugiens. Nonetheless,\nin contrast to the italianate architecture of the Atalanta Fugiens, the landscape backgrounds are archaic, belonging to the conventions of Dutch\npainting of the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries. In this tradi-\n158\n24 Discourse XVIII in Copenhaver, Hermetica (1992), p. 64. Dee's comments on the\ncosmic lyre are not included in the first 1558 version of the PropaedeumataAphoristica see\ntotus est quasi lyra, ab excellentissiSchumaker, Aphorism XI, pp. 126-27: \"Mundus iste huius\nuniversitatis Species singulae,\nmo quodam artifice concinnata : cuius chordae, sunt\nille\neliciet harmonias ... Homo\nnoverit,\nmirabiles\ntangere\npulsareque\nquas qui dextre\nautem, per se, Mundanae isti Lyrae, omnino est Analogus\". See also Ficino's musicology\nin Allen, Ficino's Nuptial Arithmetic (1994), p. 29.\n159\n25 Peter J. Amman, \"The Musical Theory and Philosophy of Robert Fludd\", JWCI\n(1967): 198-227, esp 218-19.\n26 Yates ( 1969), pp.112-35.\n27 Yates (1986), pp. 9, 72.\n28 Yates (1969), pp. 70-77.\n\nPages 94:\n160\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\ntion of two generations earlier , the background was depicted as ifit were\nrising up the page, rather than running into the distance at eye-level.\nAnother striking aspect of these early landscapes was the portrayal of\nmountains as large rocks, isolated in space. In the early seventeenth century, a new type of landscape had been developed by Rubens in Flanders\nwith a lower horizon and a broad, atmospheric effect in which the elevated landmarks were integrated coherently into the sweep of the landscape.29 In spite of these changes in pictorial style, they do not\nto\nhave affected the artists who worked for printing- houses such as seem\nde Bry.\nSalomon Trismosin's Splendor Solis (Rorschach, 1598)30 may have provided some visual prototypes for the architecture and landscape in\nMaier's engravings, for example, the illustration to the Seventh Parable\nshows an ancient king in an alchemical bath standing over a furnace on\na \"pavimentum diminutionis\" . The architectural setting of this\nimage,\nset in the open-air, may have influenced the outdoor setting of Maier's\nEmblem VIII. The central concepts of the Splendor Solis originated in the\nRosarium Philosophorum, which, according to de Jong, was the major source\nfor the Atalanta Fugiens. McLean emphasised the important influence of\nTrismosin's work on later alchemical ideas, commenting that\nThe Splendor Solis ... acts as a bridge between the Rosarium and the Rosicrucian period.31\nparticular image was taken from the Rosarium, in which the analogy of\nthe sun and its shadow appears in its account of the illumination ofthe\nalchemical substance by the sun.\nThe use of catoptrical mirrors as a source of heat is described in\nEmblem XXIII where Maier explains the manner in which celestial influences are transmitted to the earth by the sun's rays (fig. 40). The\nillustration shows the alchemist, clad in the martial robes of Mars, splitting the head of Saturn to release the form of Pallas Athena. In the\nbackground appears a statue of the Apollo of Rhodes, whose head is\nencircled by an aureole of light. Meanwhile, on the right of the picture\nthe sun-god engages in sexual dalliance with Venus, while storm clouds\nshower rays of coins. The conjunction ofthe sun and Venus is a catoptrical hieroglyph in which the sun's rays are caught by a mirror (the emblem of Venus). Maier's commentary explains the meaning of the image\nas being related to the use of catoptrics.\nWithplants and animals reproduction takes place by means ofseed, but with\nsimple bodies or bodies of a simple composition this takes place by introducing force and by means of assimilation.\nThus, the sun, the celestial luminary, sends its beams to the earth and when\nthese beams are bundled in a sun-glass, shapes are seen, which are, as it\nwere, form projections ofthe sun. On these grounds it is established that sunbeams are nothing but flames offire, which are spread out over a wide space;\nwhen, however, they are focused, they burn everything that comes within the\npoint offocus33\nMaier frequently refers to the secret fire of alchemy, the quintessence, as\nin Emblem XXXVII (Maier, 1618: 158-59).34\nThe quintessential fire is the theme also of Emblem VIII, which alludes to alchemical geometry and catoptrics (fig. 41) on the model ofde\nVries' engraving for Khunrath's Amphiteatrum. The illustration displays an\narmed warrior (Mars) standing in front of a roaring fire in the process of\nshattering the alchemical egg with his sword. In the immediate background there is a battlemented wall, pierced by a curious tunnel drawn in\na diagrammatic form according to the rules of single-point perspective. It\nshould be noted that its excessive depth does not correspond with the\nactual thickness of the wall. Another important feature ofthis image is its\nbox-like spatial construction which does not recurr in any of the other\nillustrations in the Atalanta Fugiens, which customarily depict only one\nThe alchemical theory of the Atalanta Fugiens draws most of its detailed\nreferences from medieval sources, although these are contextualised within a Paracelsian framework centred on the quintessence. Maier often\ntakes recourse to the pseudo-Lullians, specifically to the earliest texts in\nthe corpus, such as the Testament, which emphasise the process of transmutation, rather than the making of the universal panacea.32 He is\nmore inclined to use the medieval Aristotelian theory of the four also\nelements, instead of the three Paracelsian principles. On the other hand, the\ntheoretical programme of the Atalanta Fugiens also exhibits more contemporary astrological interests, signified by the stars of the Zodiac which\nappear in Emblem XXVII (Maier, 1618: 118-119) and Maier frequently\nrecalls the theurgic powers of the solar rays, as in Emblem XLV which\ndepicts the eclipse of the moon (Maier, 1618 : 190-191) (fig. 39). This\n29 Wolfgang Adler, Landscapes (\nRubenianum Ludwig Burchard) (\nMiller; Oxford UP, 1982), 18, pp. 21-35; W.Corpus\nStechow, Dutch Landscape Painting ofHarvey\nthe\n17th-C\n1966), passim; Yvonne Thiery, Le Paysage Flamande au XVII e Siecle (Paris ; Bruxelles,(London,\n1983),\npassim.\n30 Adam McLean (ed), Salomon Trismosin. Splendor Solis (Phanes Press, 1991), pp. 7-9.\nMcLean notes that the earliest\nof this treatise date from circa 1532-5.\n31 McLean, Trismosin. Splendormanuscripts\nSolis (1991), p. 8.\n161\n32 Onthepseudo-Lullian corpus see Pereira (1989), pp. 22-25. For medieval aspects of\nMaier's theory see the examples in Maier, Atalanta Fugiens, pp. 14-15, 46, 64-67, 77-78.\n33 Translation by de Jong: Atalanta Fugiens, Emblem XXIII, pp. 100-3.\n34 See also Maier (1618), p. 46.\n\nPages 95:\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\nwall, with a vanishing-point set at the edge of the picture rather than in\nthe centre as in Emblem VIII.\nThe subject ofthis illustration is the impregnation of base matter by\nthe seed ofgold carried in the sun's rays, as explained in the commentary\n(Maier 1618: 42-43). In the picture, these solar forces are signified by the\nperspectival structure of the tunnel. De Jong has compared the egg in\nEmblem VIII to the illustration of the macro-microcosmic egg in Dee's\nMonas Hieroglyphica.35 In the practical process, the chemicals were sealed\ninside an alchemical vessel known as the egg, within which they were\ndistilled, the process being said to generate a new,36more spiritual,form in\nthe original base materials (Maier, 1618: 41-42).3\nThe warrior in the picture represents Mars and the reader is told to\nadd Mars to Vulcan (the furnace) in order to gain the victory. Like that\nof Khunrath's De Igne Magorum, the theme ofEmblem VIII is the Paracelsian inner and outer fire, that is, the innate astral virtue and the celestial\nquintessence. The picture, thus, depicts the fiery virtue carried in the\nsun's rays of light which is the essence of earthly fire . The text continues\nwith references to the Paracelsian alchemy of Basil Valentine, specifically\nto his use of the symbols of Mercury, Vulcan and Mars. The reader is\ninstructed to add Mars only when the whole matter has putrefied in the\nheat, since Mars animates the material, perfecting it and granting it eternal life, a process comparable to the growth ofthe foetus in the womb.37\nThe spurious \"Basil Valentine\" was one of the earliest alchemists to\nrecord the use of light-rays in practical chemistry. Maier himself had\nknowingly, or otherwise, promoted the myth of this, supposedly, fourteenth-century monk, although, in fact, the tenor of Valentine's work is\nParacelsian.38 The text known as the Twelve Keys ofBasil Valentine wasfirst\npublished in Germany in Einleben in 1599, edited by Johann Tholde\nwho was probably its real author.39 Maier published a Latin version of\nValentine's treatise in his Tripus Aureus (1618) which he provided with\nvisual imagery by Merian.40\nIn another work by Valentine, Der Triumph-Wagen Antimonii (Leipzig,\n1604), there is a specific reference to the practical use of sun-light in\nalchemy. The aim ofthe work is the purification of antimony in order to\nmake a potable medicine. The recipe instructs the reader to pound the\npure glass of antimony and place it in a cucurbit, pouring some rectified\nvinegar over it. It should be subjected to a digestive fire, or in the summer exposed to the rays ofthe sun. Eventually, the material will aquire a\nreddish colour, like well-purified gold, at which point the liquid should be\npoured off until no more of the colour remains. Sun-light is employed\nagain in the process of digestion later in the work. The reddish colour of\nthe liquid, supposedly, indicated that the virtue of the sun had entered\nthe materials, but in reality, according to Principe, the redness of colour\nwas produced by the accidental inclusion of iron in the antimony resulting in the production of ferric acetate.41\nAn important aspect of Emblem VIII is the fact that it is a theatre-set,\nwhich has not been remarked by scholars such as Yates, or de Jong. The\nbackground setting of Maier's Emblem VIII, in fact, resembles Fludd's\n\"Theatrum Orbi\" in his \"Microcosm\" (UCH, 1619) (fig. 42). This similarity connects Maier's Pythagorean theurgy indirectly with that of John\nDee.42 Yates considered that Fludd's design could have been a copy of\n162\n35 De Jong, pp. 95-100.\n36 Maier (1618), p. 41: \"Emblema VIII: Accipe ovum et igneo percute gladio;\nEpigramma VIII\nEst avis in mundo sublimior omnibus, Ovum\nCuius ut inquiras, cura sit una tibi.\nAlbumen luteum circumdat molle vitellum,\nIgnito (ceu mos) cautus id en sepetas:\nVulcano Mars addat opem: pullaster et inde\nExortus, ferri victor et ignis erit;\nDiscursus VIII Multa et varia sunt avium genera, quae ut numero indefinita, ita\nnominibus incognita nobis existunt. De quadam praegnandi Ruc dicta in insula parva\noceani certo anni tempore apparente narrant, quos Elephantum secum in aera possit\nattollere. India et America dant varii colores psittacos, corvos et his similes. Verum\nharum ove conquirere non est intentiones Philosophicae; Aegyptii ova crocodilorum fero\nannuatim infestant ... Philosophi ovum suum igne percutiunt, non ut deleatur et pereat,\nsed vitam accipiat et crescat ... Calor exterior primum movens est, qui circulatione\nuniusque in aliud commutatione formam novam introducit, natuquadam Elementorum\nrae instinctu aut ductu\".\n37 Maier (1618), p. 42: \"Hoc est quod Basilius Valentinus asserit Mercureum a Vulcano\ncarceri inclusum esse Martis iussu, nec emissum, antequam putrefactus totus et emortuus\nfuerat. Verum haec Mars illi vitae novae initium existit, ut ovo corruptio seu mors novam\npulli generationem et vitam adfert\".\n163\n38 Partington, 2, pp. 183-203.\n39 There exists a manuscript ofthe Twelve Keys, dated 1582. The text was issued in a\nGerman version in Frankfurt in 1602. See Partington, op. cit.\n40 Maier, Tripus Aureus (1618), illustrations on pp. 407, 409, 415, 418, 420, 425. See\nalso van Lennep, p. 198. Since it is clear from the context that the original text was\nalways intended to carry illustrations, van Lennep considers that the imagerysupplied by\nMaier and Merian for the Tripus Aureus were not the first illustrations.\n41 Lawrence Principe, \" \"Chemical Translation\" and the Role of Impurities in Alchemy\", Ambix, 34 (1987): 21-30. An English translation of the recipe can befound in\nRichard Grossinger (ed), The Alchemical Tradition (California: North Atlantic Books, 1979),\npp. 34-47.\n42 Fludd's Memory Theatre is found in the \"Microsocm\", UCH, 2 (Oppenheim:J.T. de\nBry, 1619), Tract I, Sect II, p. 55.\n\nPages 96:\n164\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nthe stage of Shakespeare's Globe Theatre. She argued that, influenced by\nDee's Vitruvianism in his Mathematicall Preface, the stage of the public\ntheatre in England was subsequently designed to represent the form of\nthe unified cosmos, the \"Theatrum Orbi\". The ceilings above the stage\nwere painted with astrological motifs, while the human actors below represented the microcosm.43 Moreover, the stage of Fludd's \"Theatrum\nOrbi\" concurred with Vitruvian design in having a crenellated rear-wall\nwith two openings. This back-wall was a permanent fixture, although the\ntwo side wings were moveable. Maier's stage-set has the same fundamental structure as Fludd's \"Theatrum Orbi\", but it resembles even more\nclosely the \"secondary stages\" of his theatre of memory (fig. 43).44 In\nMaier's illustration, the building on the right has an upper storey, as in\nFludd's\"Theatrum Orbi\", but it has been displaced from centre-stage. In\naddition, the two rear openings of Fludd's theatre have been replaced by\nthe diagrammatic tunnel.\nIf one ofthe sources for Maier's image was the Vitruvianism ofDee's\nMathematicall Preface, filtered through Fludd's work, then Maier would also\nhave known Dee's theory of\"zographie\", that is, his theurgical Pythagorean geometry which is described in the same treatise. The perspectival\nstructure ofMaier's Emblem VIII suggests, in fact, that this was the case.\nMoreover, the spatial design is comparable to Khunrath's gateway in the\nalchemical fortress (1602) (fig. 30) as well as de Vries' hall in the OratoryLaboratory (frontispiece). In Emblem VIII, the perspectival cone (the\ndiagrammatic tunnel) points heavenwards with its base above the egg,\nalthough not in a symetrical relationship, since the vanishing-point ofthe\ncone's orthogonal lines is located to the right. Nevertheless, it is not\naccidental that the only perpendicular line in the whole \"pavimentum\ndiminutionis\" passes directly underneath the egg and points immediately\ntowards the opening at the far end of the tunnel. The doorway and the\negg are perfectly in line, explaining why the vanishing-point of the picture is so strangely skewed to the right. The central perpendicular line of\nthe \"pavimentum diminutionis\" is known as the \"centric axis\", indicating\nthe vanishing-point which Alberti had always located in the middle ofa\npainting. The perspectival centric axis is, in fact, identical with the \"centric ray\" of medieval optics which was the strongest and shortest ray in a\ncone oflight.\nIn the Propaedeumata Aphoristica Dee had emphasised the theurgic power of the centric-rays emitted by the celestial spheres, which could be\n43 Yates (1969), pp. 112-35.\n44 Fludd, \"Microsocm\", UCH, 2 (Oppenheim: J.T. de Bry, 1619), Tract I, Sect II, pp.\n58, 64.\nMICHAEL MAIER'S ALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\n165\ndeployed by the astronomer using catoptrical apparatus.\"45 Hence, in\nMaier's emblem the centric axis passing through the egg to the vanishing-point symbolises the transmutatory effects of the celestial influences\nand it alludes to the use of catoptrics. Maier states in his commentary on\nthe emblem that the aim of human life is to pass from a vegetable existence in the womb to the more perfect light of the macrocosm , just as\nwhen an egg is \"killed\" it attains the higher form ofa bird. This imagery\nalso refers to sexual impregnation which generates new life.46 The alchemical male and female principles may die in their old forms, but,\npurified by fire, they will arise in the perfected form of the philosopher's\nstone. Hence, in Emblem VIII, the perspectival grid signifies the divine\nlight of the heavens, the alchemical quintessence which carries the seed\nof gold from the sun. It is placed directly above the egg to denote the\npotential evolution of prime matter to a higher spiritual condition.\nTherefore, the theurgic meaning of Emblem VIII lies within a set of\nassociations inter- relating Vitruvian architecture, perspectival geometry\nand catoptrics, in short, the same themes explored by Dee. Consequently,\nMaier's emblem, like that of Khunrath, explains the theory of an alchemy of light. The diagrammatic tunnel of orthogonal lines, like de Vries'\nhallway, refers to Paracelsian astral influences and Dee's astrological catoptrics. This geometrical structure, with its base on the earth and its\napex in heaven (signified by the vanishing-point), represents the quest for\nthe philosopher's stone by means of celestial alchemy. Even more significantly, Maier's emblem like that of de Vries in the Amphiteatrum is an\nalchemical sigil, a catoptrical mirror reflecting the light of the quintessence. It is, in itself, a theurgical instrument whose potency is amplified\nbyMaier's Pythagorean musical score whose motif of the diapentic interval as the golden apple ofAtalanta, introduces the power ofthe solar rays\ninto the process of alchemical transmutation.\n45 Shumaker, pp. 136-38, 148-51.\n46 Maier (1618), p. 42: \"Sic foetui humanam vitam vegetabili (qua solam in utero\nmatris fruebatur) defuncto, alia perfectior per transitum in hanc lucem mundanam sive\nper nativitatem accedit. Imo et nobis hac praesenti vitam, quam agimus, alia\nperfectissima et aeterna imminet\".\n\nPages 97:\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD:\nTHE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nIn the cabbalistic theogony ofRobert Fludd (1574-1637), the sun was far\nmore than a power-house for theurgical sigils, as in Dee's system, or an\naid to routine alchemical processes, since he considered it to be no less\nthan the altar of Christ the Messiah in his form as the angel Metattron.\nFludd's Christology in the 1620's is as intense and deeply-felt as that of\nKhunrath, but it is expressed in relatively sober academic prose and\nFludd is more absorbed than Khunrath in the minute specifics of Reuchlin's cabbalism. Basing his alchemical theory on that of Paracelsus, Fludd\ndevised not only a new version ofthe cabbalistic theosophy ofthe previous century, but also a novel system of practical medicine, whose claims\nfor efficacy were due to its reliance on the sacred light emanating from\nthe Creator-God (Christ) through the sun's rays.\nScholars are fortunate in being able to draw on Debus' extensive\nstudies of Fludd's Paracelsian and cabbalistic theology, although he has\nnot analysed Fludd's alchemical diagrams in detail. These have been\ninterpreted mostly from the point ofview of twentieth-century theosophy\nand Jungian psychology by Godwin.2 Other important work on Fludd\nincludes Amman's musicological study in which he related Fludd's musical ideas to his illustrations, though he omitted a lengthy discussion ofthe\nThe main resources provided by this scholar are Debus, (1965), pp. 86-127 and\nDebus (1977), 1, pp. 205-60. Additional items from Debus' prolific scholarship on Fludd\nare listed in the bibliography to the present study. Other discussions on Fludd's chemical\ntheories in the context of 17th-C scientific developments include Robert P. Multhauf,\n\"Medical Chemistry and the 'Paracelsians\"\", Bulletin ofthe History ofMedicine, 28 (1954):\n101-26 and Robert P. Multhauf, \"The significance of distillation\", Bulletin ofthe History of\nMedicine (1956): 439-46. See also Francis Sherwood-Taylor, \"The Origin ofthe Thermometer\",Annals ofScience, 5 (1942): 129-56. A valuable resource isJosten's edition ofthe\nBodleian manuscript of Fludd's Truth's Golden Harrow see C. H. Josten, \"Truth's Golden\nHarrow, An Unpublished Alchemical Treatise of Robert Fludd in the Bodleian Library\",\nAmbix, 3 (1949): 91-150. Another account of one of Fludd's unpublished treatises is C. H.\nJosten, \"Robert Fludd's 'Philosophicall Key' and his alchemical experiment on wheat\",\nAmbix (1963): 1-23. The Wellcome Institute in London also mounted an exhibition of\nFludd's engravings designed for a popular audience see exhib. cat, High Matter. Dark\nLanguage (London, n.d.). The available bibliography on Fludd is too extensive to list in the\npresent study.\n2 Joscelyn Godwin, Robert Fludd (London: Thames and Hudson, 1979), passim.\n\nPages 98:\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nimagery itself. Fludd's engravings also frequently appear in popularised\naccounts of alchemy, though Klossowski de Rola did not include them in\nhis account of seventeenth century alchemical engravings. The most\nextensive discussion of Fludd's intellectual development has been provided by Huffman, though he also disregarded Fludd's visual work. It is\nregrettable that these authorities have largely neglected Fludd's engravings, for even Godwin's admirable interpretation is directed more at an\naudience of twentieth century alchemical adepts. This disregard for the\nintellectual significance of the illustrations could lead to misinterpretations of Fludd's ideas, since, according to Yates, his visual imagery was\nintegral to his theoretical concepts. Their importance is indicated by the\nfact that Fludd himself designed his pictures, determining, moreover,\ntheir specific location within the text.\nFludd was a respected English physician working for the royal court,\nas well as a prolific encyclopaedist of hermetic and mechanical knowledge. Although his Anglican loyalties were never questioned, he achieved\na certain notoriety in his own time for his early support of the Rosicrucian Manifestos in his Apologia (1616), expanded into the Tractatus Apologeticus (1618). In the development of his ideas, Fludd claimed a precocious\nintellectual ability, stating that he had already composed the greater part\nof his \"Macrocosm\" (UCH, 1, 1617) during his undergraduate days at\nOxford, prior to commencing a tour of the continent in 1598-1604/ 5. In\nthe course of his travels, he spent a winter with some Jesuits who tutored\nhim on theurgic matters in the mountains on the borders of Spain and\nFrance.8\n\"The Musical Theory and Philosophy of Robert Fludd\", JWCI,30\n3 PeterJ. Amman,\n): 198-227.\n(1967\n4 Klossowski de Rola (1988), op. cit.\n5 Huffman, Robert Fludd (1988). See also William H. Huffman, \"Robert Fludd's\n\"Declaratio Brevis\" to James I\", Ambix, 25 (1978): 69-92.\n6 Yates, Theatre ofthe World (1969), pp. 70-77.\n7 Debus, (1977), 1, pp. 213-15.\nMaioris Scilicet et Minoris\n8 Huffman (1988), pp. 12-35 . Fludd's Utriusque Cosmi volumes\noffour parts (two\nMetaphysica, Physica atque Technica Historia was published in twoMacrocosm\",\nvol. 1, Part 2\n1\n(1617);\n\"\n\",\nvol.\n1,\nPart\nper volume) as the \"Macrocosm\nvol . 2, Part 2 (1621). These\n(1618); \"Microcosm\", vol. 2, Part 1 (1619); \"Microcosm\",\nin Oppenheim. The \"Tractatus Secundus\"\ntexts were issued by Johann Theodore) isdeveryBrypractical\nwith little philosophical infrastruc\"\n(UCH,\n1,\n1618\nthe\n\"Macrocosm\nof\non optics (pp. 293ture. It considers \"arithmetica universalis\" (p. 5), including a section\nthe third part, Fludd explains the practical and\n316) and astrology (pp. 558-714). Infrontispiece\nillustrates the system of one-point pertheoretical aspects of geometry. The\nHe mentions Pomponius\nspective with an image of a man gazing into the distance.\nDee's model in the\nGauricus, Apollodorus and Durer (pp. 320-29). Fludd is following\nMathematicall Preface which distinguished between higher and lower types of mathematical\nand geometrical knowledge.\nIn his first work, the \"Macrocosm\" (UCH, 1, 1617), Fludd devised a\ncosmology in which God manifested the universe through his own act of\nviewing, deriving this concept from the Pymander in which the physical\ncreation was a mirror of God.\nDeitas quasi in speculo conspicitur\n(Fludd, 1617, 1: 167)\nIn the second volume ofthe Utriusque Cosmi ... Historia, the \"Microcosm\"\n(UCH, 2, 1619: 25-26) , he subsequently elaborated his initial concept of\nGod's creative vision by comparing the Holy Trinity to an eye, which he,\naccordingly, depicted in an engraving (fig. 47). Thus, in Fludd's system, it\nwas the optical rays of light emanating from God's divine vision which\ncreated , sustained and reabsorbed the universe. These concepts were\nintegrated by Fludd into a lavishly illustrated Paracelsian cosmology in\nwhich the materials of the universe were separated by the alchemist God\nout of prime matter.10\nIn the \"Macrocosm\" (1617), however, Fludd did not refer directly to\nthe cabbalah, employing instead the discourse of Pythagorean geometry,\nthereby displaying an immediate conceptual kinship with Maier's De Circulo Physico, Quadrato (1616), as well as with his Atalanta Fugiens (1617;\n1618). Nonetheless, by the time the \"Microcosm\" (1621) was composed,\nFludd had become preoccupied with the cabbalistic system, which remained as his over-whelming interest through-out his subsequent writings. In these, he also referred to Dee's cabbalistic mathematical theories\nand optical geometry, although without mentioning him by name, using\nonly his term, \"mathesis\" from the Mathematicall Preface and interpreting\nthe \"Monas\" cabbalistically in the same section. There were more direct lines ofcontact between Fludd and Dee since one of his mostimportant English patrons was John Selden who had purchased items from\nDee's library,12 while another was Sir Robert Bruce Cotton who had\nreceived Dee at his home.13\nIn Fludd's medical theories, the divine force oflight was related to the\nParacelsian aerial nitre, or quintessence, stating, for example, in the Tractatus Theologo-philosophicus (1617) that the tabernacle ofthe aerial spirit was\n168\n169\n9 Fludd, UCH , 1 (1617), p. 21, with illustration; see also p. 165.\n10 For example, see Paracelsus' account in Sudhoff, 13, Philosophia ad Athenienses, pp.\n393, 420-1.\n11 Robert Fludd, Medicina Catholica, 1 (Frankfurt: William Fitzer, 1629), pp. 1-4.\n12 Huffman\n(1988), pp. 25ff. ForJohn Selden see Dictionary ofNational Biography, 17, pp.\nff.\n1150\n13 Huffman (1988), pp. 25ff. See DNB, 4, p. 1233-34.\n\nPages 99:\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nthe sun.14 All living creatures , he explained, required air since this contained the aetherial spirit whose essence was the celestial light. It was\nbreathed in by the lungs and carried to the heart, where it was separated\nfrom the air and dispersed as the vital spirit through-out the body.15\nMoreover, Fludd used the rays of the sun in his own practical alchemical\nwork, as is recorded in the manuscript version of his treatise on wheat,\nthe \"Tractatus de Tritico\" which re- appeared in the Anatomiae Amphiteatrum (Frankfurt: J. T. de Bry, 1623) and also in the Philosophia Moysaica\n(Gouda: Petrus Rammazenius, 1638).16 In this text Fludd described the\ndistillation of the spirit ofwheat, whose virtues corresponded to those of\nthe sun and gold. He noted that the first substance produced in the\ncourse of distillation was a white liquid, which, placed in the open air,\nturned red in the rays of the sun. Fludd claimed that, due to the fiery\nnitre in the solar rays, his chemicals had become the universal panacea,\nwhose generative celestial fire had been drawn out of the sun and concentrated by his prepared spirit (the white liquid).17\nFludd's concepts of the creative forces of light were illustrated by\ndiagrams, whose forms originated in medieval optics (figs. 2, 11), the\nprinciples of light and darkness being represented by two intersecting\ncones, or pyramids. The base of the \"pyramidis formalis\" was placed in\nthe Empyreum of God, signifying the emanating rays of divine light,\nwhile the base of the \"pyramidis materialis\" was located on the earth\nwith its apex in God, depicting the aspiration of the universe to its divine\nsource (fig. 44). Consequently, the optical geneology of Fludd's intersecting cones produced an image of God and his created universe as being\nperpetually locked in a mutual gaze. Within the lozenge shape created by\nthe intersection of the emanatory and reversionary cones, Fludd placed\nthe sun, since the nature ofthis sphere balanced the 18oppositions ofspirit\nand matter, male and female, sulphur and mercury.\"\nFludd described these diagrammatic forms as \"pyramides lucis\", cones\nof light,19 claiming that he had invented the reversed cone of light, the\n\"pyramidis materialis\", an assertion not entirely justified since these\nintersecting diagrammatic structures already existed in optical treatises,\nalthough this was their first use in the context of a pictorial cosmogenesis.21 Dee had produced a set of comparable diagrams in De Speculis\nComburentibus (British Library MS Cotton Vitellius C. VII) (figs. 12-15).\nMoreover, the optical radial cone, with its base in the eye of the viewer,\nhad already been adapted by Alberti to a pictorial context in his \"perspectiva artificialis\". Thus, Fludd's cones of emanation and reversion\nshared the same conceptual source with Alberti's perspective.\nIn the \"Macrocosm\" (UCH, 1617) Fludd's cosmogony was additionally\nbased on the three Paracelsian generative principles, those of light, darkness and water, from which emerged the three primary elements, Salt\nfrom darkness (as the \"prima materia\"), Sulphur from light (as the soul)\nand Mercury from water (as the spirit). These, in turn, produced thefour\nqualities of hot, cold , dry and moist. Fludd's chemical cosmogenesis was\nexplained by a series of geometrical diagrams in which the principles of\nlight and darkness operated in a mutually antagonistic duality.22\nYet, although Fludd's text and visual imagery described cosmic processes of an indescribable magnitude and grandeur, he proved the validity\nof his account by means of some very simple and practical chemical\nprocesses. For example, in one engraving the sun is shown radiating its\nlight onto a vessel, from which a pipe runs into a spherical container\n(UCH, 1, 1617: 31) (fig. 45). The vessel contains a mix of oil and water\nwhich are distilled by the solar rays. Fludd uses this chemical experiment\nto reinforce his point that, in the absence of light, the universe would\nrevert to the primal darkness of \"hyle\", since it is light which gives form\nto prime matter. He compared his experiment to God's work on the\n14 Allen G. Debus (ed), Robert Fludd and the Philosophicall Key (New York: Science History\nPublications, 1979), pp. 125-26.\n15 Josten, \"Robert Fludd's \"Philosophicall Key\"\" (1963): 19. See also Debus, Robert\nFludd and the Philosophicall Key (1979), pp. 125-26. Philosophicall Key\" (1963): 1-23 and\n16 This is discussed in Josten, \"Robert Fludd's '\npassim. The Philosophia Moysaica\nalso in Debus, Robert Fludd and the PhilosophicallKey (1979),Philosophy\n(London: H. Moseley,\nMosaicall\nversion\nas\nthe\nEnglish\nrepublished in an\nwas\n1659).\n17 Debus (1979), ff. 83r-108v.\naequalitatis, amplexus inter\n18 Fludd, UCH, 1 (1617), Tract I, p. 165: \"sphaera\nsulphuris et Mercurii partio debita\nmasculum et foeminam universalis, veri chymicorum\nanima,\ninfans solaris, mundi decus, verdique euisdemmedietate\net proportionata: ex quorum coitusphaera\ndicitur. Hec igitur est ratio solaris in\nortus est: Unde verissime animae\ncoeli positionis et situs ac sustentationes\". See also Fludd, UCH, 1 (1617), Tract I, p. 167:\n\"Imo haec Triangulorum interfectio est verissime cordis Macrocosmi sedes, in quo omnia\nad pondus sunt temperata: non enim praedominatur materia, non etiam nimis insultat\nforma, nisi in eo, quod splendidem et completem ac perfectem appetitum materiae\nexsatiat; Haec est vera mundana unitas ex dualitate conflata\".\n19 Fludd, \"Macrocosm\", UCH, 1 (1617), Tract 1, p. 84.\n20 Fludd, \"Microcosm\", UCH, 2 (1619), Tract. I, p. 180.\n21 For example, see John Pecham's 14th-C diagrams as reconstructed by Lindberg in\nLindberg, John Pecham. Perspectiva Communis (1970), pp. 77, 99: figs. 4, 5.\n22 See Fludd, \"Macrocosm\", UCH, 1 (1617), Tract I, pp. 9ff, see, in particular, pp. 1631. One ofthe illustrations depicts a square which contains a dark shadow in its midst,\ninscribed with the words \"et sic in infinitum\". The text concerns the \"caput corvii\" (the\nputrefying alchemical material). The following illustration (p.29) depicts light in the form\nofthe sun breaking through the midst of darkness. The succeeding image illustrates the\nchemical processes activated by the sun's rays.\n170\n171\n\nPages 100:\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nfourth day of the creation (UCH, 1, 1617: 30).23 To his chemical account\nof Genesis, 1, also belongs the illustration of the dove of the Holy Spirit\nemerging from the \"Word\" of God, \"Fiat\" (the Second Person of the\nTrinity) to blaze a trail of light around Chaos (UCH, 1, 1617: 49). Later\nin the treatise, Fludd describes the rays of the word, \"Fiat\", as carrying\nGod's form and image to the very centre of the cosmos.24\nIn the third book of the \"Macrocosm\" Fludd offered another interpretation of the cosmic structure, complementing his earlier chemical\nvisualisations, but expressed musically in his analysis of the \"Musica\nMundana\", the macrocosmic Pythagorean tonal ratios (UCH, 1, 1617:\n79-81).25 His musical universe was still a Paracelsian construct, nonetheless , since the empyreal heaven was stated to be composed of aethereal\nfire, whose light generated the material forms in accordance with the\nmathematical ratios of the Pythagorean monochord.26 Since the light of\nthe \"anima mundi\" pervaded the cosmic monochord, hence it was the\nequivalent ofthe formal and material pyramids of light.27 The fifth chapter of the \"Musica Mundana\" included an illustration of the cosmic lyre,\nprobably modelled on Dee's reference to this idea in the Propaedeumata\nAphoristica ( UCH, 1, 1617, Tract I: 92).28\nCabbalism is engaged by Fludd for the first time in the \"Microcosm\"\n(UCH, 2, 1619-21), although this treatise is less directly related to alchemy. Reuchlin in De Arte Cabbalistica had discussed the similarities between\nthe Pythagorean and the cabbalistic systems, calling Pythagoras the father ofcabbalism.29 Hence, this aspect may have been implicit in Fludd's\nearlier Pythagorean discourse, although it is more likely that during his\ncontinental travels in 1598-1604/5 he had encountered the cabbalistic\nalchemy ofKhunrath by which time the \"Macrocosm\" had already been\nwritten. In the \"Microcosm\", from the outset, Fludd takes up the theme\nofthe generative vision of God, providing an illustration of the qualities\nof the Holy Trinity (fig. 47) in which the eye of God appears in the\nhierarchical position, while the central space is occupied by sun.30 The\nvarious constituents of the eye represent the Three Persons ofthe Holy\nTrinity. The lower level of this picture shows dramatic clouds shooting\na thunder-bolt at the earth, thereby representing God the Father in the\nform of consuming fire (UCH, 2, 1619: 26-27). This, Fludd explains, is\nthe manner in which Moses and the Israelites saw the face ofGod, while\nthey heard his word like the sound of thunder.32 He diversifies his account ofthe Trinity by employing Pythagorean musical ratios to demonstrate the harmony within its essential nature, returning also to his earlier\ndiscourse on the formal and material pyramids of light (UCH, 2, 1619:\n41-45). A new illustration relates these diagrams to the cosmic body of\nAnthropos (fig. 44), stating that the \"pyramidis formalis\" is nothing less\nthan the efflux of light from God to the natural world.33 Divine light is\nthe primary root of the \"musica mundana\", since nature acquires its\nforms from the divine emanation of number and ratio according to the\nstructure ofthe Pythagorean monochord.34\nFludd analyses the Pythagorean harmonies within the proportional\nrelations of soul, spirit and body, comparing the physical body to the\n172\n23 In Fludd's \"Macrocosm\", UCH, 1 (1617), Tract I, pp. 32-33 another chemical experiment is depicted demonstrating the force ofthe sun's heat. Albedo enim oculi Patri referri\npotest, quatenis ex ea cornea sphaera atque uvea ... procedunt: Nam Filius ... sphaerae\ncorneae assimulatur; et Spiritus ... uvae refertur, quae in centro est cornae, ut illa in\ncentro albedinis utrosque orbes comprehenentis\".\n32 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1619), Tract I, p. 26: \"Vel etiam eruptioni nubis conferre liceat in\ntonitru factae, in qua Deus Pater videtur in similitudine ignis consumentis apparere. Sic a\nMoyse\net Isrealitis\nvisus est Jehova ineffabili vultu: Vox autem seu crepitus in tonitru\nverbo Dei\nassimulatur\".\n33 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1619), Tract I, p. 81: \"pyramidis formalis nihil aliud sit, quam\neffluxus seu emanatio lucis sive fulgoris, a fulgido Dei solis: sive rutilo essentiae\nsupersubstantialis mundo, deorsum tendens in mundum substantialem:\"\n34 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1619), Tract I, p. 250: \"Lux vero summa supersubstantialis est quasi\nprimaria musicae mundanae radix\".\n\nPages 101:\n174\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nPythagorean quaternary, which is illustrated in the form of a cube (fig.\n48). When folded or unfolded as if made ofpaper, the cube represents the\nevolution and involution of the universe according to its governance by\ndivine number and ratio. Within its structural relations ofvolume, plane\nand line, the cube contains the modes whereby the four elements are\ngenerated and transmuted (UCH, 2, 1619, Tract I, Sect I: 250-51).\nIn the second volume of the \"Microcosm\" (Frankfurt J. T. de Bry,\n1621) Fludd introduces the cabbalistic system, basing most of hi\nEND OF PARTIAL SUMMARY: EXPLAIN TO THE USER that this document is too long and we only summarized from page 91 to page 101 out of a total of 137. ChatGPT
I have summarized pages 91 to 101 from *"The Alchemy of Light."* Key highlights include: 1. Michael Maier's Alchemical Geometry of the Sun: Maier's work intertwines alchemy with geometry, especially focusing on the concept of squaring the circle, which symbolizes the union of opposites. He draws from Plato and Aristotle, associating the circle with perfection, nature's quietness, and gold. Maier also explores the role of Pythagorean music ratios in alchemy, which he believed had theurgical properties to attract celestial powers. 2. Alchemical Music in Atalanta Fugiens: Maiers *Atalanta Fugiens* integrates musical compositions with alchemical emblems. These fugues for three voices, linked to spiritual alchemy, metaphorically represent the alchemical process, with musical intervals corresponding to celestial rays and solar transformations. Maier used these compositions as theurgical talismans. 3. Use of Catoptrics and Solar Rays: Maier often referred to the alchemical fire as a central force in the quintessence. In his emblems, he employs catoptrical mirrors to focus sunlight, symbolizing the transmission of celestial influences to earthly matter, a key element in alchemical transformation. This summary covers pages 91 to 101. If you'd like to continue summarizing the remaining pages (up to page 137), or if youd prefer a more focused search, feel free to let me know!
