squaring the circle
Tool
{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=23\nPages: 23\nopposites being laid out across the diagonals (fig. 3). Around the edges of\nthe square the mutations took place in a circular motion.24\nHence, the symbolic picture of the alchemical process was not only\nthat of a circle, but also that of the squaring of the circle. The same idea\nis subsequently encountered in George Ripley's Compound of Alchemy as\nwell as in Michael Maier's Emblem XLVI in the Atalanta Fugiens (fig. 39).\nSince this geometrical feat cannot be accomplished in Euclidean geometry, therefore, the concept of the squaring of the circle came to signify\nany process which could be accomplished only by means of divine intervention. In fact, it became a generic sign for the alchemical process itself\nand Maier produced a treatise based on this idea, De Circulo Physico,\nQuadrato (Oppenheim: Luca Jennis, 1616), which was an account ofthe\nrole of the sun in the making ofpotable gold.\nIn alchemical theory, the squaring of the circle was a monistic concept]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=23\nPages: 23\nIn alchemical theory, the squaring of the circle was a monistic concept\nsince it implied that nature (signified by the square of the four elements)\nwas God (signified by the perfect circle). Perhaps unwittingly, the pseudoLullian alchemists introduced a material pantheism into their conceptual\nstructures, thereby transgressing Catholic dogma which abhorred any\nidentification ofnature with God. Lull himself had encountered the same\nheresy in the design of his original geometry in the 1270s based on the\nnumber four, causing him to produce another model in the 1290s based\non a trinitarian structure. Whichever numerology was employed in the\nLullian Art, it radically altered the metaphysical universe conceptualised\nby the system.25\nLull's numerology of three represented the conventional Christian\nimage of the Triune God (Father; Son; Holy Spirit) in his alchemical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91\nPages: 91\nIn contrast to Dee, Khunrath and Fludd, Maier infrequently referred\nto the cabbalah, occasionally employing some general concepts, but never applying the system methodically. Instead, he based his alchemical\nprogramme on geometry, which was itself the subject of one of his earliest treatises on the Euclidean problem of squaring the circle, De Circulo\nPhysico, Quadrato (Oppenheim : Luca Jennis, 1616). Maier, like Khunrath,\nused the image ofthe squared circle as a theurgical sigil, representing the\nspiritual and alchemical union of opposites in the \"azoth\". A circle appears on the title-page of his treatise, bearing the names of the four\nuniversal qualities, \"calidum siccum frigidum humidum\", while a rectangle lists the four elements. The main subject of this essay is the Paracelsian theory of the universal panacea, the potable gold which ensured\nboth physical and spiritual health, due to its concordance ofthe macroand microcosms . These were signified by the sun, the human heart and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=80\nPages: 80\nwithin the individual soul, for the geometrical cypher ofthe square and\nthe circle represents the \"unio mystica\" ofthe Weigelians. On the dividers in the portrait is written the word \"hieroglyphica\", signifying that the\nsquaring of the circle, like the upright pentacle, is also an \"annulus\" (a\nhieroglyphic sigil).\nIn the 1595 engraving of the Oratory, Khunrath's name is inscribed\non the tabernacle-tent in the context of those who are enlightened, since\nthe main text appearing within the tent admonishes the viewer not to\nspeak about God without the light of illumination (\"ne loquaris de deo\nabsque lumine\"), while another axiom declares that no man can be great\nwithout divine inspiration (\"sine afflatu divino nemo unquam vir magnus\"). Yet another statement proclaims that God himself will come to\n\"our\" aid (\"hoc hoc agentibus nobis aderit ipse deus\").\nThe Oratory- Laboratory is, thus, meant to be read as a sacred \"temenos\" in which God is present in his essence as in the \"sanctum\" ofa]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91\nPages: 91\ngold, the sun being an image of God himself.5 According to Maier, the\nuniversal panacea resolved the problem of the squaring of the circle\n(Maier, 1616: 4).\nMaier explained that, according to Plato, the perfect form of eternal\nBeing was the circle and this was also the essential form of gold, the most\nperfect substance in the physical world (Maier, 1616: 11), since the circle\nis the form of nature when she has been quieted from her compulsive\nmotion (Maier, 1616: 12). In this idea, he was following the well-known\nargument of Aristotle in De generatione et corruptione that anything which\nmoves is by nature imperfect, since it is prone to corrupting changes.\nConsequently, the static circle is nature perfected,6 manifesting in the\nphysical form of red, coagulated sulphur, or gold. Maier referred to the\nalchemical theories ofthe pseudo-Lullian Testament, in particular, to their\nconcept ofthe \"rotation\" ofthe chemicals, stating that in order to purify]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=136\nPages: 136\n115-15, 142\nSeverinus, Peter, 24, 46-47\nSherman, William H., xviii-xix, 46, 56\nShumaker, Wayne, 37\nsingle-point perspective, xvi, 29, 73-74, 7576, 125-25, 129-30, 133-37, 161-62,\n164-65, see Alberti\nSmith, Pamela, 10\nSperber, Julius, xviii, 84, 150\nsquaring the circle, 18-19 , 131, 132, 154-56\nSteganographia, 56\nStoeffler, F. Ernest, xi, 147\nStreich, Hildemaire, 156-59\nStudion, Simon, xviii, xx, 82, 146-47, 149,\n150-51\nsun, ix, xii-xiii, 14, 25-27, 32-34, 40, 47-48,\n50-51, 62, 65-66, 93-94, 96, 108, 111,\n117-17, 154, 156, 158, 160, 162, 165,\n167 , 170-71, 175-78\nSzathmary, George, 133\nSzonyi, Gyorgy, 1, 3, 33, 35, 45-46, 49, 56,\n61 , 66, 77, 126, 129\nmia\nSzydlo, Zbigniew, 47\n18\ntalismanic theurgy, 33-34, 37-38, 42, 49,\n55-56, 61-65, 97, 126, 131-32, 144-45,\n147, 154, 158, 159, 164-65, see Abano,\nAgrippa, Clucas, Clulee, Dee, Studion,\nSzonyi\ntheatre (Renaissance), 113-15, 140, 163-64\nTholde, Johannes (Basil Valentine), 53, 79,\n155, 162-63\nThurneysser, Leonhard, 48, 50]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=79\nPages: 79\ndisplays geometrical symbols, with an upright pentacle in a circle on the\nleft-page and, opposite it, an image ofthe squaring ofthe circle on which\nappears the word \"Time\" and the Tetragrammaton. The appearance of\nthe pentacle is somewhat puzzling in view of Khunrath's diatribe in the\n1595 Amphiteatrum against black magicians who used this sign instead of\nthe truly Christian \"annulus \" (of the \"Archetypos\").\nThis is explained by examining Agrippa's description of theurgical\nsigils in De Occulta Philosophia. Agrippa used the geometrical form of the\npentacle in his account ofthe harmonic relations between the macrocosm\nand the human body.42 This image, nonetheless , was not the only \"pentacle\" desribed by Agrippa who also published the work of Peter ofAbano on magical sigils and the rituals associated with them. In the fourth\nbook ofthis treatise, Abano describes the rites associated with the \"pentacle\". Agrippa illustrates this device which, it turns out, does not have]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=80\nPages: 80\nAbano's rituals and entering the grounds of superstition and demonology.\nThe critical factor for Khunrath would always have been the presence or\nabsence ofChrist in a theurgy whose purpose was to intensify the Christian experience of the Holy Spirit, thus healing both the soul and the\nbody. For his own pentacle, or \"annulus\", Khunrath was using the form\nof Agrippa's cosmically-harmonised man, which Khunrath expanded\ninto the image of cosmic \"Anthropos\", or Christ as the \"anima mundi\",\nthe soul pervading the universe. The pentacle in this case would refer by\nits numerology to the alchemical \"azoth\", which in Khunrath's Weigelian theosophy is also Christ.\nThe pentacle is placed opposite another geometrical image expressing\nthe same pietistic Christology, that ofthe squaring ofthe circle. Since the\nresolution ofthis Pythagorean problem could only be a superhuman feat,\nhence in the context of Khunrath's theosophy it becomes an icon ofthe]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91\nPages: 91\nconcept ofthe \"rotation\" ofthe chemicals, stating that in order to purify\nsulphur, the \"soul\" of gold, the alchemist needed to apply the perfect\nform ofthe circle, in other words he needed to use the rotational forces of\ndistillation.8\nHe also quotes from the Rosarium concerning the geometrical figures\nof the circle, square and triangle which represent the masculine and\nfeminine qualities (Maier, 1616: 11).9 An illustration ofthis geometrical\nrelationship appears in his later compendium of alchemical treatises, the\nTripus Aureus (Frankfurt, 1618), in which the emblem accompanying the\nseventh key of Basil Valentine's De Lapide Sapientum depicts a circle,\nsquared internally, with a triangle within the square labelled \"Aqua\".\nThe circle represents \"Chaos\", while the square symbolises the four seasons.10The same relationship of circle, square and triangle appears in the\nillustration to Emblem XXI of the Atalanta Fugiens where a geometrical]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=80\nPages: 80\nhence in the context of Khunrath's theosophy it becomes an icon ofthe\nincarnation of Christ, in whom were reconciled spirit (the circle) and\nmatter (the square). The nature of Christ was the the quintessential union\nof the macro- and microcosms, of God and the individual soul. The motif\nofthe circle and the square in this picture also explains the symbol of the\ngeometrical dividers in the later portrait of Khunrath (1604), with which\nhe is inscribing a circle and the words \"Deo duce\" (led by God), another\nWeigelian reference to Christ as the \"typos\" for a pious life and to the\nguiding words of God written on the human soul (fig. 27).44 Since this\npreliminary drawing ofthe circle may involve the same Euclidean conundrum, thereby Khunrath is pictured contemplating Christ's incarnation\nwithin the individual soul, for the geometrical cypher ofthe square and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=64\nPages: 64\nthere is a scene from the passion of Christ, set within the walled city of\nJerusalem (fig. 24a). An angel hovers over the city, while stream ofwater\nflows from beneath its walls to feed the fountain in which the resurrected\nChrist is seated. This motif is an allusion to Weigel's concept of the\nhistoric figure of Christ as being the external representant of the imminent Christ. At the top left ofthe image is the Tetragrammaton, standing\nin an aureole of light. The dove of the Holy Spirit flies from the cityto\nthe symbol of God, then down to the fountain, its two lines offlight, with\nthat of the stream of water, producing the shape of an equilateral triangle, whose apex lies in the Tetragrammaton, with the fountain and the\ncity as the corners ofits base.\nThe whole scene is set within the circle of the rainbow, while the\nfountain itself is located within a (nearly) square walled-garden. This\nmystical geometry is related to that of Michelspacher's first engraving]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=64\nPages: 64\nmystical geometry is related to that of Michelspacher's first engraving\nentitled \"Der Spigel der Kunst und Natur\" which shows two geometrical\ndiagrams, the one on the left having the same configuration as thefourth\nengraving, that of circle, square and triangle (fig. 24b). In the first engraving this diagram is stated to be an image of the \"Azoth\", another\nWeigelian and Khunradian allusion to Christ. Thus, Michelspacher's\nadheres to Khunrath's Weigelian polemic in which union with the innate\nChrist as the philosopher's stone was attained through the inspiration of\nthe Holy Spirit. Michelspacher located Khunrath's alchemical Christologywithin a Rosicrucian context, for his treatise is specifically dedicated to\nthe Rosy Cross Fraternity.\nIn Michelspacher's \"Fountain of Life\" the lines of flight ofthe Holy\nSpirit were similar to the catoptrical refraction of light-rays by thesurface\nof a mirror. Comparable imagery of the refraction of light-rays is found]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=119\nPages: 119\nILLUSTRATIONS\n210\nILLUSTRATIONS\nnonexisthitd\nbasma,perpendienians\nabc. coms rectus\ndef. con scales.\nab Catnscome\nagaxie.\nit Sit\nitautveingparte\nCips& mempont .\nJe 19H\narrator seconds\nita\nappellamy,qma\n?\nsotsial\nuccoping),\nit H it got promo\n1\n37\ndie\nam ,\n\u4a06\nIme j bestmine\noddeter\na darati fran\nM\nC\nHN\n4B\n211\n7. In the Ars Compendiosa of the 1270s the\nfirst Lullian scheme consisted of a series of diagrams based on the \"Figura Animae A\"\", representing the soul. They took the form ofa numberof\nconcentric circles, around whose circumference Lull placed the names of\nthe dignities of God such as \"Magnitudo\", or \"Bonitas\", as established by\nneoplatonic Christian doctrine (fig. 4). In the middle of each circle there\nwere located four over-lapping squares, signifying the physical elements.\nGod was then allocated sixteen dignities (4 x 4) at the edges of the circle\nto accord with the inner squares. The conceptual outcome was that God\nwas given the form of matter (fig. 5, pseudo-Lullian version).\n20 Obrist, pp. 55-65, 248-49.\n21 Michela Pereira, The Alchemical Corpus Attributed to Raymond Lull (London: Warburg]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=23\nPages: 23\nLull had encountered in the cabbalistic alphabets of Abraham Abulafia\nin thirteenth century Spain.\nThere are three main ideas in pseudo-Lullian theory, those of circularity, motion and of the medium between opposites, all of which originate in Aristotle's theory ofthe four elements. In his text On Coming-to-be\nand Passing Away Aristotle had demonstrated that the changing nature of\nthe world was the result of the constant transmutation of the elements\ninto one other.23 Since each element had two qualities (fire had heat and\ndryness), therefore, opposites united by moving through their common\nquality, for example, fire turning into water by passing through the quality of dryness shared with earth and then through the quality of coldness\nwhich earth shared with water. In the medieval period, Aristotle's theory\nwas pictured as a square with the elements placed at the four corners, the\nopposites being laid out across the diagonals (fig. 3). Around the edges of]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=67\nPages: 67\nthat of\"CHAOS\". At the top of the outermost circle around this figure,\nstands the Tetragrammaton, accompanied by the Pythagorean equilateral triangle, composed of ten dots in a pyramidic form. The illustration\nrefers to the necessity of reducing all things \"ad monadis simplicitatem\",\n11 I would like to thank Mr. Colin Shrimpton, archivist at Alnwick Castle for this\ninformation.\nalso mentioning the \"azoth\", the \"celum\" and the \"ros celi\". In comparison to the original engraving, the Alnwick drawing is amateur, for the\nscribe has ineptly splayed the original image across two facing folios of\nthe manuscript, failing to reproduce the exact dimensions of the original.\nThe final \"drawing\" in the Alnwick sequence consists merely of text\nalluding to\"working and praying\", which could be a bare mention ofde\nVries' 1595 circular image of the praying alchemist (frontispiece). Given\nthe difficulties which the scribe experienced in copying the diagrammatic]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91\nPages: 91,92\nEpigramma XXI\nFoemina masculineque unus fiant tibi circulus, ex que\nSurgat, habens aquum forma quadrata latus.\nHinc Trigonum ducas, omni qui parte rotundam\nIn sphaeram redeat: Tum LAPIS ortus erit.\nSi res tanta tua non mox venit obvia menti,\nDogma Geometria si capis omne scies.\n156\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nIn his De Circulo Physico, Quadrato Maier states that the incorrupt nature\nof gold proves that the circle, as its essential form, is not an abstract\nmathematical concept, but a physical reality.12 For the congregation of\nthe sun's rays creates its beautiful circular shape13 and gold is central to\nhuman activity, as if it were a sun within the earth.14 Thus, on themodel\nofthe relationship of the centre to the circumference ofthe perfect circle,\ngold is the centre of all things .15 Moreover, gold as a colour is the union\nofopposites, those ofthe white female and the red male aspects.16 Hence,\nsince gold is perfection itself, its essential nature must be spiritual (Maier,\n1616 : 28, 46).]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=45\nPages: 45\nthe purest magic spirit [sc. Mercury] will carry out the work of albification in\nplace ofthe Moon ... if by his spiritual virtue, he may, without words, speak\nhieroglyphically ... for about the length of an average day, introducing and\nimpressing into the very pure and simple earth prepared by us those four\ngeogamic figures [here depicted] or, in their stead, that other figure [also\nshown here]24\nThe Monas is constructed from a circle and two straight lines which take\nthe form ofa cross beneath the circle (fig. 17). The point at the centre of\nthe circle represents the earth and revolving around it are the Sun (the\ncircle), the Moon and the rest of the planets.25 In Dee's Pythagorean\ngeometry, the rectilinear cross represents both the ternary, as well as the\nquaternary. The ternary consists of two straight lines and one point,\nwhile the quaternary is four straight lines, including four right angles.\nThe four elements are the four straight lines emerging from the point.26]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=22\nPages: 22,23\n18 Gordon Leff, Paris and Oxford Universities in the 13th-C and 14 th-C (New York, 1968).\n19 Obrist, figs. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 11.\n17\n18\nCHAPTER TWO\nGEOMETRY AND ASTROLOGY\nwith the sacred visions of the saints. In this manner, the alchemists\nmoved their theories from the ground of scholastic debate to that ofthe\nunquestionable truths of the Christian faith.20\nAnother major development in alchemical visual imagery took place\nin the early fifteenth century when a complex geometry intended as a\npractical device was created by pseudo-Lullian alchemists. These were a\ngroup of anonymous writers working under the name of the Catalan\nmystic Ramon Lull, although he had not accepted the claims of alchemy\nand had never discussed the subject. Regardless of this fact in the late\nfourteenth century the first unillustrated text appeared under his name in\nCatalonia. Transported to Northern Italy, the older texts were translated\nfrom the vernacular into Latin and new ones were produced, with the]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* the squaring of the circle is an essential concept in alchemical geometry, symbolizing the union of opposites and the perfection of nature through divine intervention. Key points include: 1. Symbolism in Alchemical Process: The squaring of the circle, which cannot be accomplished in Euclidean geometry, came to represent any process achievable only by divine intervention. This concept became a generic symbol for the entire alchemical process itself. Michael Maier, in his work *De Circulo Physico, Quadrato* (1616), explored this idea in detail, linking it to the role of the sun in creating potable gold, an alchemical panacea: > "The concept of the squaring of the circle came to signify any process which could be accomplished only by means of divine intervention. In fact, it became a generic sign for the alchemical process itself." [Urszula Szul, page 23](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=23). 2. Monistic Concept: In alchemical theory, the squaring of the circle is seen as a monistic concept. The square, representing the four elements (earth, air, fire, water), is combined with the circle, symbolizing divine perfection. This union suggests that nature (the material world) is God: > "In alchemical theory, the squaring of the circle was a monistic concept since it implied that nature (signified by the square) was God (signified by the perfect circle)." [Urszula Szul, page 23](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=23). 3. Spiritual and Alchemical Union: Maier also used the squaring of the circle as a theurgical sigil representing the spiritual and alchemical union of opposites in the "azoth," which is the universal agent of transformation in alchemy. This emblem symbolized the concordance of the macrocosm and microcosm, represented by the sun, the human heart, and the divine soul: > "Maier used the image of the squared circle as a theurgical sigil, representing the spiritual and alchemical union of opposites in the 'azoth'." [Urszula Szul, page 91](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91). The squaring of the circle is a metaphorical and symbolic centerpiece in alchemical geometry, reflecting deeper spiritual truths and the aspiration for both material and spiritual perfection. You can explore more details on [pages 23](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=23) and [91](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91).
You

{"result":["[Summary from page 101 to page 111 out of a total of 137:\nPages 101:\n174\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nPythagorean quaternary, which is illustrated in the form of a cube (fig.\n48). When folded or unfolded as if made ofpaper, the cube represents the\nevolution and involution of the universe according to its governance by\ndivine number and ratio. Within its structural relations ofvolume, plane\nand line, the cube contains the modes whereby the four elements are\ngenerated and transmuted (UCH, 2, 1619, Tract I, Sect I: 250-51).\nIn the second volume of the \"Microcosm\" (Frankfurt J. T. de Bry,\n1621) Fludd introduces the cabbalistic system, basing most of his argument on Reuchlin,35 but occasionally revealing the additional influence\nof Khunrath. The frontispiece to this volume was clearly inspired by de\nVries' praying alchemist in the Amphiteatrum, since Fludd's magus also\nprays before an emblem ofthe Tetragrammaton, borne within the divine\neye ofGod and bedecked with wings. It is enveloped by a cloud, forming\nan enclosure conceptually related to de Vries' depiction of the tabernacle-tent. Fludd seemed to empathise with this image since he returned to\nthe motif of the praying alchemist on several other occasions. A motto,\nostensibly attributed to Psalm 63, is inscribed on Fludd's frontispiece,\nreferring to the protective wings of God, \"In alarum tuarum umbra caram\", recalling the concluding line of the Rosicrucian Fama Fraternitatis,\n\"sub umbra alarum tuarum Jehova\".\nIt is well-known that a similar axiom was used in the heraldic emblem\nof the Andreae family, derived from Psalm 17: 8, \"sub umbra alarum\ntuarum protege me\". 36 The family insignia consisted of a cross and a rose\nwhich had also been one of Luther's emblems. While Khunrath never\nused such a symbol in his illustrations, Maier employed the image of\nthe rose on at least one occasion37 and Fludd similarly depicted a rose,\nwith honey-bees, on the title-page of his Clavis Philosophiae (1633) which\nwas his response to Mersenne. Thus, it seems, that by 1621 Khunrath's\nAmphiteatrum was thoroughly established within the Rosicrucian canon,\nwith de Vries' image of the praying alchemist being used as a common\nRosicrucian emblem. For example, there are references to the original\npicture in Johann Daniel Mylius' Opus Medico-Chymicum (Frankfurt: Luca\nJennis, 1618) in an image representing Oswald Croll, as well as in one\ndepicting Mylius himself, both shown kneeling before the light of God in\ntheir studies. These tiny images also contain a table and a musical instru35 Specifically the sections in Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico (Stuttgart, 1964 facs. of 1494\n95-103 and Reuchlin, De Arte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964 facs. of 1517 ed.), pp.\ned.),, pp.\n133 143-55.\n36 Montgomery, pp. 173-74.\n37 See McLean (1979), passim.\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\n175\nment, as well as alchemical vessels and shelves of books, as in de Vries'\nengraving. A less obvious reference to the original picture occurs on the\nfrontispiece ofTheophilus Schweighardt's Speculum Sophicum Rhodo-Stauroticum(1618) in which both an alchemist and a forge-smith kneel beforethe\nwinged Tetragrammaton, above whom is placed the motto \"sub umbra\nalarum tuarum\".38\nFludd explains the descent of the Tetragrammaton in the form of\ndivine light to create the material light of nature in a cabbalistic exegesis\nofthe Book ofGenesis (UCH, 2, 1621: 2-74). Although the discourse is not\nimmediately related to alchemy, this is implicit in his subsequent discussion of medical issues and meteorology. Fludd commences his cabbalistic\naccount with an examination of the principles of\"gematria\", mentioning\nReuchlin in this context.39 He also begins to employ the name ofChrist,\nas the Second Person of the Trinity (UCH, 2 1621: 2-5), relating him to\nthe angel Metattron who is stated to be the \"anima mundi\", or Anthropos (UCH, 2 1621, Tract II, Sect I: 8-9).40 Fludd equates the First Person\n(God the Father) with the first Hebrew letter of the Tetragrammaton,\n\"Jod\" (UCH, 2 1621: 8), the different levels of creation arising from the\nconstituent letters of the Tetragrammaton, \"Jod He Vau He\". Fludd\nassociates the New Testament \"Word\" (as in the gospel account ofJohn\nthe Evangelist) with the \"Son\" of God who is both the Messiah and the\narchangel Metattron, an indentification said to be proved by Fludd's\nanalysis of the name of Jesus which appears as \"J. H. U. H\" in his\ntranscription of the Tetrgrammaton.41 According to Fludd, the face42of\nMetattron is composed of the rays of the sun (UCH, 2 1621 : 36-47).\nFludd states that \"Hochmah\" (Wisdom ) is the \"Verbum\" (Word),\nwho is the Second Person ofthe Trinity (Christ) and also the first letter of\nthe Hebrew alphabet, \"Aleph\". In his statement that the Messiah is the\nmost potent medicine for all human ills, both spiritual and corporeal,\nFludd may be relying on Khunrath's account of Christ as the universal\n38 Yates (1986), p. 55, fig. 15a.\n39\nwith Reuchlin, De Arte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1517 ed.), pp.\n.\n193ffCompare\n40 See Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1494 ed.), pp. 95-103 andDe\nArte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964 facs. of 1517 ed.), pp. 143-55.\n41 Compare with Reuchlin's version, op. cit.\n42 Pico della Mirandola had been the first to identify the sun with the Messiah in a\ncabbalistic context, in his Conclusiones Nongentae, based on the account ofthe tabernacle of\nMetattron in the Zohar. See Pico della Mirandola, ConclusionesNongentae (1532 ed), No. 51,\np. 160: \"Sicutfuit luna plena in Salomone, ita fuit plenus Sol in vero messia, quifuit Iesus\net de correspondentia ad diminutionem in Sedechia potest quis coniectare si profunduit\ncabala\" and also Lachower and Tisby, Zohar (1989), pp. 643-45.\n\nPages 102:\n176\nCHAPTER TWELVE\n46\npanacea, the \"Magnesia\".43 In fact, much of Fludd's theosophy recalls\nKhunrath's identification of \"Hochmah\" with Christ, based on Reuchlin's account. The \"Verbum\", or Metattron, is the first emanation of\nGod, descending sequentially through the letters comprising the Tetragrammaton\nto reside in the middle sphere of the heavens, that of the\nsun .45 Fludd, like Khunrath in De Igne Magorum, compares \"Hochmah\"\nwith the light and fire of the Zoroastrians and also with that of Hermes\nTrismegistus and other \"prisca theologians\".46 Quoting from the scriptures, he explains that God has placed his tabernacle in the sun.47\nThrough the rays of the angel Metattron (the Spirit of Wisdom created\nprior to all others) the world is illuminated. Therefore, the Word is the\npurest fire and most beautiful light, the source of all generation, without\nqualities but mixing with the elements to provide them with their different qualities. This highest light is, moreover, also associated with the\narchangel Michael, \"Sacerdote Magno Michaele\", and the primal word\n43 Later in the treatise, he expounds a medical theory based on the concept of the\nMessiah Christ as the universal panacea in his forms ofthe quintessence and AnthroposMicrocosm , see Fludd, UCH, 2 (1621), Tract I,\np. 21: \"Unde scriptum est; venit hominis flius salvare, quod perierat Matth. 18. Quod\nquidem de Messia exaudiendum est, non quoad ejus corpus, sed respectu virtutis spiritus\nbenignitate pleni; qui est emanatio essentialis et primaria aJehovah: Hinc Christus, non\nherbis nec medicamentis Pharmacopaeorum, sed mirifica Tetragrammati virtute non\nmodo per solum contactum, verumetjam et Spiritus sui divini afflatun, ac vocis solius\nprolatione\nomnia\nmorborum\ngenera sanavit, hoc est benigna Jehovae virtute et divino\nmisericordiae\nafflatu,\nquo abundabat;\nimo vero et homines emortuos in vitam, ac\npristinum integritatis et sanitatis statum ineffabili suavi et virtute revocavit ac restituit, uti\nin novo testamentum possim ejus rei documenta et testimonia extant\".\nSee Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1494 ed.), pp. 95-103 and De\nArte Cabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1517 ed.), pp. 143-55.\n45 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1621), Tract. 1, pp. 22-28: \"haec omnia dona a summa illa\nsapientia, seu angelo Metattron, seu universali mundi anima, seu prima emanatione a\nJod, in mundum influere solent ... [p. 23]... Ut ergo deus, Aleph tenebrosum, fuit prima\nunitas extia mundum creatum, et ante ejus creationem, ita etjam prima lucis eius\nemanatio, per quam Verbum; Messias, seu Virtus Tetragrammati in mundum ingressa\nest, imo vero quae est ipsium Verbum, quod est ejusdem essentiae cum Aleph,Jod, Jah,\nEhieh et Tetragrammato, loquitur: ut itaque Aleph erat prima unitas in mundo\nArchetypo et ideali, mundi fabricandi figuram delineans\".\n46 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1621), Tract I, p. 24: \"quod verbum sit in medio, tanquam inter\nignem et Spiritum ... hoc Verbum sacrosanctum a centro Jod Patris ... ita etfrequenter\nambulare solet in sphaera aequalitatis, ubi Spiritus et lux aequali pondere et mensura\npermiscentur, seu in ipsius animae centro, quod in centro firmamenti delineatur\". Onthe\nZoroastrians\nand the \"prisca theologia\" compare with Khunrath, De Igne Magorum, pp. 420.\n47 The original cabbalistic version of this idea may be found in Lachower and Tisby,\nZohar (1989), pp. 643-45.\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\n177\nof creation, \"FIAT\", is yet another form of Metattron. The \"Word\"\n(Christ), Fludd concludes, is \"Vau\", the third letter of the Tetragrammaton who is the clearest and most lucid Spirit (\"Spiritus limpidissimus ac\nlucidissimus\") (UCH, 2 1621: 26).48\nOn this cabbalistic foundation Fludd accounts for the qualities ofthe\nsun which is unique in being the father of light, the tabernacle of Christ,\nthe Word and Apollo. It takes care of the mortal sphere and heals all\nearthly sorrows and ills, although the ultimate medicine is God himself,\nthe prince ofphysicians, who can heal solely through the Word.49 Fludd,\nthus, fervently\naccepts the visible sun as being the mystic body of\nChrist, 50\nHe also provides an analysis of the Hebrew letter \"Shin\", signifying\nfire, the \"azoth\", as well as the Holy Spirit (UCH, 2 1621: 28-33). This\nhad been the central trope in Reuchlin's transposition of the cabbalah\ninto a Christian context.51 In the second book of the treatise, Fludd\nspecifically mentions Reuchlin in his account ofthe incarnation ofChrist\nas the second Adam, stating that the regeneration of the inner man is\nthrough Christ (\"hominis interni per Christum regeneratio\") (UCH, 2\n1621: 46-50). His account may be drawn from Khunrath's pietism, since\nhe uses the image of the resurrection of Christ as a metaphor of individual spiritual rebirth.\nFludd also explores the cabbalah in another treatise, the Philosophia\nSacra et vere Christiana seu Meteorologica Cosmica (Frankfurt: J. T de Bry,\n1626) whose frontispiece displays the archangel Michael in the act of\nslaying a dragon. The angel's head takes the form of the glowing orb of\nthe sun, while another three suns (the Paracelsian principles) and a rainbow (God's covenant with mankind) are illustrated in the background.\nThe treatise employs Paracelsian elemental theory and Pythagorean geometry, as well as the cabbalistic thesis of Christ as Metattron. One ofthe\n48 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1621), Tract I, p. 25: \"hoc Verbum sit ignis purissima, seu lux\npulcherrima ... Physici Ethnici [dixerunt] ... hanc ipsam naturam esselucem seu ignem\ninvisibilem, a quo cuncta sint genita\". Fludd's source for these concepts is found in\nReuchlin's De Arte Cabbalistica, where he had associated the Messiah with the pure light of\nGod, as well as with the letter \"Vau\". For Reuchlin see Busi and Campanini (eds and\ntrans), Reuchlin. L'Arte Cabbalistica (1995), pp. 39, 212-13.\n49 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1621), Tract I, p. 27: \"nonne medicinae Deus, atque medicorum\nprinceps, cum ipse per se solum, absque herbis aut aliis pharmacis, solo suo sermone, et\nSpiritus sui divinitate, omnes credentes ... curaverit ... Atque hinc est, quod Christus, et\nVerbum, et Apollo, quamvis sit in hac mundo, similiterque eius tabernaculum\".\n50 Fludd, UCH, 2 (1621), Tract I, p. 27: \"me solem visibilem pro ipso corpore Christi\nmystico accipere\".\n51 Reuchlin, De Verbo Mirifico (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1494 ed.), pp. 95-103 andDe Arte\nCabbalistica (Stuttgart, 1964, facs. of 1517 ed.), pp. 143-55.\n\nPages 103:\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nnew images is a somewhat novel and ungainly catoptrical conceit, incorporating a radiant sun, drawn with a face whose nose consists of the\nequilateral triangle of the Holy Trinity. It directs the rays of its solar\nvirtues onto a star, which reflects them to a wind-god, who, in turn,\nblows them down to the earth (Fludd, 1626: 189) (fig. 49). This picture\nmay have originated in Balthasar Schwan's engraving for Maier's Septimana Philosophica in which the rays ofthe sun are catoptrically reflected by\nthe mirror of the moon (fig. 37).\nFludd also employed the cabbalah extensively in his Philosophia Moysaica (1638) whose complete title states that Christ is the philosopher's\nstone. Since this treatise was a reply to Mersenne's attacks on his scientific ideas, Fludd may have been taking recourse to a more developed\nChristology, on the model of Khunrath, as a way of placing his ideas in\na religious context out of the reach of such empiricist objections. The\nequating of Christ with the philosopher's stone had first appeared in\nFludd's Clavis Philosophiae (Frankfurt: William Fitzer, 1633) in which he\nexplained, in Rosicrucian terminology, that the rose holds the secret to\nthe philosopher's stone which is Christ.\nA work, located between the composition of the Utriusque Cosmi\nHistoria and the late, more Christological , treatises are the two volumes of\nthe Medicina Catholica ( 1629-31) which translate Fludd's cabbalistic alchemy of light into a practical medical context.52 Fludd's ontology in this\ntreatise hovers on the edge of heresy, very nearly transgressing the Augustinian doctrine of God as the absolute good.53 One of Fludd's engravings (appearing in both volumes of the Medicina Catholica) depicts God in\nthe aspects of both light and darkness, good and evil (fig. 50). Initially,\nFludd mitigates the irregularity of this concept by recourse to classical\nmythology, referring to the apollonian and dionysian aspects of God, but\nthen he proceeds to reinforce his unconventional position by stating that,\nsince \"volunty\" and \"nolunty\" (will and negation) are both in God, therefore, both must be \"good\".\nNonetheless, Fludd wisely reduces the impact of this statement by\nciting the biblical texts of Job and Deuteronomy in which God is described\nas the giver of both health and sickness. Fludd explains that God has a\nsingle nature which is able to mutate into the dispositions of both light\nand darkness.54 In the Zohar there is a similar account of the manner in\nwhich the principles of light and darkness emerge from the left and right\nbranches of the Tree of Life, entwined togther in a mutually generative\nact.\nOne came out of the other, for from goodness evil emerged, and from Mercy\nJudgement emerged, and one was entirely contained in the other: the good\ninclination and the evil inclination, right and left ... white and black.55\nMoreover, in an earlier section, Fludd had already explained the nature\nof the divine Monad (Fludd, 1629: 1-2) as being the most sacrosanct\nlight, God in his purest nature prior to manifestation, in whom there was\nno trace of darkness. The Monad cannot be grasped by human consciousness, he states, since it is \"non-Ens\" when its rays are folded around\nitself. Cabbalists identify the primal Monas with the darkness of\"Aleph\",\nbut when it opens its rays it becomes \"Aleph lucidum\", the \"Excellentia\nSol luculentius\".56\nBoth Maier and Fludd generated a succession of disciples, but their\nclosest follower was a contemporary, Johann Daniel Mylius, who appropriated the design of Fludd's illustrations in the \"Macrocosm\" (1617) for\nhis Opus Medico-Chymicum (1618), while in his Philosophia Reformata (Frankfurt: Luca Jennis, 1622) he produced almost exact reproductions of\nMaier's emblems in the Atalanta Fugiens.\nAn extraordinary development of Fludd's cosmology ofthe divine eye\nof God was produced by the illustrator to Jacob Boehme's collected\nworks in the Amsterdam edition of 1682 published by Gichtel nearly\nsixty years after his death. The date ofthese images falls outside the limits\n178\n52 For a sample of Fludd's chemistry in a practical context see Debus, \"Renaissance\nChemistry and the Work of Robert Fludd\", Ambix (1967): 42-59 and also Sherwood-as\nTaylor, \"The Origin of the Thermometer\", Annals of Science (1942): 129-56, as well\nAllen G. Debus, \"Key to Two Worlds : Robert Fludd's Weather- Glass\", Annali dell'Instituto\n& Museo di Storia della Scienza di Firenze VII (1982): 109-44.\n53 For an outline of this issue see Copleston, pp. 52ff.\n54 Fludd, Medicina Catholica, 1 (1629), p. 4: \"Deus scilicet, et Noctem, Lucem et\nTenebras, Bonum et Malum. Denique eos varia vitae et mortius statuimus mundi unius\n179\nTabernacula. Quorum unum, Deum se de unica natura in aliam secundum Lucis et\nTenebrarum dispositionem mutatum, Principem, cum dictis Partis effinximus\". In the\n1631 volume of the Integrum Morborum sive Medicina Catholica much the same argumentis\nfound on pp. 17-32.\n55 Lachower and Tisby, Zohar (1989), 2, p. 490.\n56 Fludd, Medicina Catholica, pp. 1-2: \"Haec ergo duo invenuerunt in Mathesi\nsapientiores tam Numerorum quam Dimensionum omnium Principia, ordine dignissima\net diuturnitate antiquissima, ad imitationem sive imaginem interni et centralissimi\nDivinitatis pureti, seu Monadi Sancrosanctae lucidae, inqua non sunt tenebrae ullae, in\nseipsam ante Mundi creationem contractae atque occultatae, et in absoluta sua Unitate et\nSimplicitate permanentis ut Monas ista Imperatoria omnem existentiam sua\nmanifestatione, seu dilatatione ac radiorum emissione, amplectitur, detegit, creat, et\nefformat: ita quidem extra istam existentiam nihil, ut et extra nihil syncera est haec\nUnitas. Quare ex istis incomprehensibilis et infinita Naturae istius declarari videtur, quae\nExcellentia Sole luculentiuscum sit Unum, omnia tamen potest... viri Cabalae peritiores,\nmonadem\nsine unitatem istam primordialem in abstrusa et occulta sua dispositione Aleph\ndixerunt tenebrosum\".\n\nPages 104:\n181\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nof the present study, but they cannot entirely be omitted since their\noriginal qualities merit due recognition on the part of the scholar. In\nBoehme's pietism, the cabbalistic Christ was a metaphor for his own\nspiritual experience and he adapted alchemical motifs to his deeply individual monistic \"gnosis\".57 His maxim was adopted from the Paracelsian\nprecept, \"solve et coagula\" and, like Fludd, he considered light and darkness to be two aspects of the one God. Both theosophists probably drew\non the original account of this concept in the Zohar, but Boehme's account was also influenced by Lurianic cabbalism.58 For him, the purpose\nof cosmic and human existence was to balance the oppositions within\ninternal and external nature and to unite them with the Eternal Light.59\nGichtels' mystical emblems signify the spiritual alchemy initiated by\nthe inner inspiration of the Word, Christ and the dawning of the light\nbrought by his incarnation within the individual soul. A frequent symbol\nin these images is that of the eye of God, sometimes profusely inscribed\non the \"wheels\" of the Ezekiel's Chariot (the cabbalistic \"Merkebah\").60\nGichtel inter-related Ezekiel's symbols into those of Christian iconography, such as the dove of the Holy Spirit, the sacred name and form of\nChrist, the emblem of the sacred heart, the equilateral triangle of the\nHoly Trinity and a profusion of the eyes of God, often containing the\nTetragrammaton. These are set within the aurora of the divine light of\nthe Son of God who in Boehme's Aurora (1612) replenished the world\nafter its corruption by the fall of Lucifer from grace.\nThe emblems take the significatory form of hieroglyphs, similar to the\ndevices employed in Renaissance emblem-books of the sixteenth century,\nwhich were a visual translation of a literary maxim.61 Gichtel, however,\nwent beyond the succinct models of the previous century by engaging a\nbroader topographic spread in his design, as well as a more dramatic and\nexpressionistic style of drawing. According to Geissmar, who has investi-\ngated the sources of these illustrations, some of Fludd's cosmological diagrams had a significant import for the development of these illustrations,\nbut Geissmar has not analysed the reasons for the formal differences\nbetween the 1682 emblems and their historical predecessors.62 Gichtel's\ncycle of imagery, in fact, for all its powerful emotional impact, is more\nlike a catalogue of icons, rather than a theatrical scene in the manner of\nKhunrath's, Michelspacher's, or Maier's illustrations. In several respects,\nthe 1682 illustrations are moving away from their original sources in the\npietistic alchemical imagery of the late sixteenth and early seventeenth\ncenturies, anticipating instead the far less sophisticated masonic \"tracing\nboards\" of the eighteenth century.63 These masonic pictures were used\nfor training a group of initiates in the principles of the craft, being designed for communal use rather than for private contemplation. In\nSzonyi's terms, they were didactic, rather than revelatoryimages. Consequently, the individual items in the picture needed to be clearly delineated in order to facilitate the process of instruction by the teacher, who\nwould provide an accompanying oral explanation. Gichtel's engravings\nhave the some of the same quality of devices intended to facilitate public\ninstruction.\nIt is misleading, however, to discuss alchemical illustration without\ncontextualising it within the relevant social and political milieu and since\nthis is not possible within the scope of the present study, these issues will\nnot be pursued at any length. It is relevant, however, to make one further\npoint arising from this brief visual analysis of the semiotic function of\nGichtel's engravings, which is that they demonstrate the popularisation,\nwithin a generation, of alchemical imagery previously associated with\nGerman pietism. In this process, Fludd's illustrations had played a large\nrole, due to his voluminous output in very large print-runs, reusing many\nof the same cosmological diagrams through-out his series of works, as\nwell as seeing them copied by other artists. Moreover, Fludd's pictures\nlent themselves to public instruction, as was his intention, since they\ncould operate at several different semiotic levels, not only as revelatory\nicons, but also as succinct metaphors which could be subjected to oral\ndiscussion. In contrast, Khunrath's 1595 visionary imagery almost over-\n180\nAuge Gottes Bilder zu Jakob Boehme (Wolfenbuttler Arbeiten\n57 Christoph Geissmar, Das\nWiesbaden\n, 23) (\n: Herzog August Bibliothek, 1993), see figs. 179,\nzur Barockforschung\n182 , 187, 188.\n58 Frick, Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 124-28; Weeks, Jacob Boehme (1991), pp. 93-126;\nEberhard H. Paltz , \"Zum Verstandnis von Jacob Boehmes Autorschaft\" in Pietismus und\nNeuzeit (1975): 9-21.\n59 Peuckert (ed), Jacob Boehme. Samtliche Schriften (1955), 1, pp. 187-206, 263-84;\nAlexandre Koyre, La Philosophie de Jacob Boehme (Paris: Vrin , 1979), pp. 281 ff; Victor\npassim.\nWeiss , Die Gnosis Jakob Boehmes (Zurich: Origo,the1955),\n60 See the account of the \"Merkebah\" in Zohar in Lachower and Tisby, Zohar\n(1989), pp. 587-621. Hieroglyphenkunde des Humanismus in der Allegorie der Renais61 Giehlow, \"Die\nKunsthistorisches Sammlungen der Allerhochsten Kaiserhauses, 32 (1915); 1sance\n232. \" in Jahrbuch der\n62 Geissmar, Das Auge Gottes Bilder zu Jakob Boehme (Wolfenbuttler Arbeiten zur\nBarockforschung, 23) (Wiesbaden: Herzog August Bibliothek, 1993), see figs. 179, 182,\n187, 188.\n63 Some excellent examples of masonic boards are illustrated in W. Kirk MacNulty,\nFreemasonry (London: Thames and Hudson, 1991), pp. 48-49. See also Arthur Edward\nWaite, Emblematic Freemasonry (London: W. Rider, 1925), passim and Colin Dyer, Symbolism in Craft Freemasonry (London, 1976), passim. An authoritative account offreemasonryis\nFrick, Die Erleuchteten (1973), pp. 164 ff.\n\nPages 105:\n182\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nwhelms the viewer, being intended to by-pass the discursive intellect in\norder to project him directly into the spiritual presence of God within his\nown soul. Although Khunrath's subsequent engravings in 1602 were intended to be a public polemic, they employed the rhetorical devices of\nthe theatre which similarly aimed to elude the discriminating faculties of\nthe mind. In comparison with Khunrath's visual strategies, those of the\nmasonic teaching boards were a list of the constituent parts of a creed\nthat had to be memorised in order to gain acceptance into a social elite,\nrather than being a visual account of a deeply-intuited spiritual experience . In these historical developments of the use of pietistic imagey,\nGichtel's have reached a mid-point in which, although he is describinga\npersonal spiritual evolution under Boehme's influence, his pictorial symbols by this date already belonged to a public stock of theosophical emblems.\nCONCLUSION\nIn the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries, the alchemical references to the celestial spheres and the light ofthe sun as the agents ofGod's\nwill involved one fundamental issue. Where was divinity located, within,\nor without, the human soul and in what manner could the alchemist\nalign himself with that infinite source of power in order to command\nhuman affairs? Paracelsus had offered, what appeared to be, the surest\nresolution to the conflict between an authoritarian external deity and the\nindividual impulses of its subject by positing a cosmic order in which\neach unit formed a part ofthe astral body ofthe demi- urge Anthropos. In\nthis theosophical model, the alchemist through his empathetic understanding ofthe heavenly spheres could, simultaneously, affect the course\nofthe physical world.\nParacelsian alchemy, thus, muted the distinction between physical and\npsychic chemistry. Amplified by the luministic cosmogenesis of the cabbalah, in Dee's theories in the 1560s an image of the magus began to\nemerge whose intellectual light mirrored, not only that of the stars and\nthe sun, but of God's own radiance . In a separate development, Weigel\nappropriated Paracelsian theosophy to make the same point, phrased in\nChristian terms, in which Christ became the essential light of the soul,\nthe real nature of each human-being, with the consequence that spiritual\nwisdom became an innate human faculty, rather than the gift of the\nLutheran sacraments. Khunrath merged Dee's image ofthe illuminated\nmagus with Weigel's alchemical Christ to create an \"alchemy of light\"\nwhich, henceforward, prioritised the inner transformation of the alchemist above that of his chemicals.\nIn the history of alchemy, perhaps the most important change in its\ncentral concepts occurs in the period from the late 1550s to the early\n1600s in which appeared Dee's and Khunrath's Paracelsian treatises on\nthe use of astral magic and light-rays in the alchemical process. The\ninteresting aspect oftheir work is that they were still advocating practical\nwork, as well as contemplative practices involving visual imagery. This is\nan important point which modern scholarship, influenced by nineteenth\ncentury theosophy and Jungian psychology, tends to under-estimate.\nMost ofthe authors who have written popularised interpretations ofRenaissance alchemical illustration have rarely bothered to read the dense\naccompanying texts, still less have they attempted to place the visual\nimages in any historical context. Whereas it is true, as previously de-\n\nPages 106:\n184\nCONCLUSION\nscribed, that the pictures were becoming transmuting philosopher's\nstones in their own right, nevertheless, alchemists such as Dee, Khunrath,\nMaier and Fludd still involved themselves in practical work. In this, they\nwere, admittedly, seeking a short-cut, setting-up their mirrors and lenses\nin order to trap God's own divine virtues in their chemicals, through the\nrays from the stars, a task more suited to their refined image of themselves as philosophers, than the grimy baking and boiling ofthe medieval\nalchemists. Even so , their texts reveal that they knew their chemistry and\nthat each specific symbol and phrase represented, as in Fludd's writings,\nnot only a \"spiritual\" process, but, usually, a practical equivalent.\nHistorians of chemistry are well-aware of the continuation ofpractical\nalchemy into the eighteenth century, the example of Newton's work being only the most famous, but, on the other hand, they have tended to\ndisregard the visual imagery as if this were mere decoration. Hence,\nbetween the extremes of the twentieth century theosophists who will not\nread the texts and the historians of science who will not read the visual\nimagery, the \"alchemy of light\" has diminished in significance, since only\nthe study of both the visual and the literary documentation, as well as\nknowledge of its political context, can reveal the considerable importance\nof this alchemical concept in the late Renaissance.\nThe present work has taken an extended historical view of the evolution of Paracelsian astral and solar theurgy and its deployment by German theosophists in the late sixteenth century, as well as by some of their\nRosicrucian followers. Such a lengthy over-view has necessitated too brief\na mention of much important contextual history, nor has it been possible\nto provide an extensive analysis of specific theories. Further study is required to validate many of the suggestions concerning cross-influences\nand contradictions between the circles of the sixteenth century pietists\nand hermeticists . Some of this will be possible only when the substantial\nwritings of alchemists, such as Khunrath and Fludd, are provided with a\ndefinitive study, followed by modern editions of their works. Moreover,\nthere remains archival work to be undertaken in the hope that manuscript sources will emerge supplying more conclusive evidence about the\npolitical affiliations of these alchemists. Above all, it is hoped that future\nscholars will be prepared to undertake a detailed analysis of the visual\nillustrations which merit considerably more scrutiny than has been possible in the present study.\nBIBLIOGRAPHY\nPRIMARY MATERIALS\nAgrippa von Nettesheim, Heinrich Cornelius, Opera, 2 vols, London, 1600; Hildesheim; New York: Georg Olms, 1970.\nAlberti, Leone Battista, De re aedificatoria L' architettura, Milan: Il Polifilo, 1966.\nLatin text edited and translated by Giovanni Orlandi. ChatGPT
I have summarized pages 101 to 111 from *"The Alchemy of Light"*. Key points include: 1. Cabbalistic and Alchemical Traditions: The connection between cabbalistic mysticism and alchemy is highlighted through figures like Robert Fludd and Heinrich Khunrath. Fludd incorporates the Tetragrammaton (the Hebrew name of God) and Christological imagery into his alchemical writings, viewing Christ as the philosopher's stone and divine light. 2. The Divine Light and Solar Imagery: Fludd extensively uses solar symbolism in his alchemical and theological works, associating Christ with the sun, representing both spiritual and material light. The sun is the source of healing and cosmic regeneration. 3. Rosicrucian Influence: Rosicrucian symbols, such as the rose and cross, are intertwined with alchemical emblems, signifying spiritual transformation and enlightenment. This summary covers pages 101 to 111. If you'd like to continue summarizing the remaining pages or search specific topics, let me know!

{"result":["[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11,12\nXVII\n16 Roland Barthes, Mythologies (Paris: Seuil, 1957), pp. 109-59.\n17 Kubovy, pp. 166-72. See also James S. Ackerman, \"Alberti's Light\" in Irving Lavin\nandJohn Plummer, Studies in Late Medieval and Renaissance Painting in Honour ofMillard Meiss\n(New York, 1978), pp. 1-27.\n18 Peirce, 2, pp. 170-72.\nINTRODUCTION\nINTRODUCTION\napply cabbalism to alchemy, since Joannes Pantheus of Venice had devised a comparable system in his Voarchadumia (1530) and Dee had also\nproduced a cabbalistic alchemy in the Monas Hieroglyphica (1564). Khunrath, however, placed his cabbalism within a Christological framework,\nso much so, that his main concern from 1595 was not alchemical theory,\nbut pietistic Christian theology, anticipating, perhaps, the alchemical\nmysticism of Jacob Boehme.\nKhunrath may have developed his Christological alchemy in the mid1590s, both as a response to anti-Christian tendencies within German\nhermetic circles and also as an expression of a pietistic Lutheranism]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11\nPages: 11\nillustration this discursive visual mode provided a demonstrative proof of\nalchemical claims that matter could be united with its opposite, spirit, in\nthe philosopher's stone. In Khunrath's image, however, there was more\nat stake, as will be discussed, for he employed this spatial rhetoric of the\ndivine presence in order to authenticate his pietistic alchemical theosophy.\nIt was Khunrath, in fact, who produced a fully-developed cabbalistic\n\"alchemy of light\" in three of his works, published as the Amphiteatrum\nSapientiae Aeternae (1595; 1609), Chaos (circa 1598) and De Igne Magorum\n(circa 1602-1604). For his cabbalistic ideas Khunrath relied on Johannes\nReuchlin in De verbo mirifico (1494) and De arte cabbalistica (1517), as well as\non Paracelsian theosophy. The central Jewish cabbalistic text, the Zohar,\nhad derived its metaphysical concepts from neoplatonism, specifically\nfrom Plotinus' account of the manner in which the divine light of the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=78\nPages: 78\n(fig. 35).\nThe discourse of the enlightened mage, however, commences earlier\nthan the 1602 series, appearing first in the 1595 engraving of the Oratory-Laboratory. Its main thesis, nonetheless, is still that ofthe divine light\nofChrist as the cabbalistic and alchemical \"azoth\". The artist, Jan Vredeman de Vries (1527-1604) trained as a painter in Antwerp, but he fled\nthe Netherlands with his son Pauwels at the time of the Duke of Alba's\ndecree against the Protestants, working instead as an architect for Rudolph II in Prague. He eventually returned to Holland and from 1568 he\nissued a series of architectural model-books, depicting classical buildings\nset in deep perspective settings. He also published instructions for the\nconstruction of single-point perspective.40 None of his treatises are concerned with hermeticism, nor have any records survived which would\nexplain the history of the illustration in the Amphiteatrum and de Vries'\nrelationship with Khunrath.]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=104\nPages: 104,103\nUnitas. Quare ex istis incomprehensibilis et infinita Naturae istius declarari videtur, quae\nExcellentia Sole luculentiuscum sit Unum, omnia tamen potest... viri Cabalae peritiores,\nmonadem\nsine unitatem istam primordialem in abstrusa et occulta sua dispositione Aleph\ndixerunt tenebrosum\".\n181\nCHAPTER TWELVE\nROBERT FLUDD: THE DIVINE ALCHEMY OF THE EYE OF GOD\nof the present study, but they cannot entirely be omitted since their\noriginal qualities merit due recognition on the part of the scholar. In\nBoehme's pietism, the cabbalistic Christ was a metaphor for his own\nspiritual experience and he adapted alchemical motifs to his deeply individual monistic \"gnosis\".57 His maxim was adopted from the Paracelsian\nprecept, \"solve et coagula\" and, like Fludd, he considered light and darkness to be two aspects of the one God. Both theosophists probably drew\non the original account of this concept in the Zohar, but Boehme's account was also influenced by Lurianic cabbalism.58 For him, the purpose]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=90\nPages: 90\ncabbalism. In contrast, Fludd's discovery of Reuchlin's cabbalism and\nKhunrath's pietistic discourse revolutionised the Paracelsian system ofhis\nUtriusque Cosmi ... Historia in its last volume, the \" Microcosm\" (1621). Its\nfervent cabbalistic Christology, and its transposition into a medical context, recalls Khunrath's embattled polemic twenty years earlier.\nCHAPTER ELEVEN\nMICHAEL MAIER'S\nALCHEMICAL GEOMETRY OF THE SUN\nThe classical erudition of Michael Maier's alchemical treatises are a\nworld apart from the passionate intensity of Khunrath's embattled theosophy. Maier's main source for his alchemical symbolism was classical\nlegend, while his impeccable literary style is modelled on the best ancient\nauthorities. His work, in fact, emerges from the context of courtly humanism, rather than out of the academic discourses of the Protestant\nuniversities. In contrast, Khunrath's work was written primarily for a]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=41\nPages: 41\nphilosophical context in the early sixteenth century. The distant ancestor\nof both the Paracelsian chemical cosmogony of the aerial fire and that of\nthe cabbalistic divine light is to be found in late hellenistic esotericism.\nThe present study will analyse the manner in which the cabbalah, specifically the cosmogenical account in the Zohar, provided a theologicaljustification for an \"alchemy of light\" through its vision ofthe world's emanation from God by means of his divine will, \"Kav\", in the form ofa beam\noflight.\nKnowledge of cabbalistic texts was dispersed through-out Europe on\nthe expulsion ofthe Jews from Spain in 1492. A Christian version ofthe\ncabbalah was devised by Giovanni Pico della Mirandola (1463-1494) in\nhis Nine Hundred Theses (1496), which provided the model for the more\ndetailed version ofthe German humanist Johannes Reuchlin (1455-1522)\nin De Verbo Mirifico (1494) and De Arte Cabbalistica (1517). In the early]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=44\nPages: 44\nRamon Lull. It has to be recognised that Dee's cabbalistic system is based\non a variety ofmodels and that his use of the original Hebrew texts may\nhave been limited. His other sources would have included non-cabbalistic\nmaterial found in the Hermetica and in Ficino's writings.14\nIn the Monas Hieroglyphica, Dee applied only the general concepts underlying cabbalism, specifically the manipulation of cyphers, translating\nits linguistic modes into his own astrological, Euclidean and alchemical\nsyntax. Dee stated that he was already planning his treatise at a time\nwhen he was still writing the Propaedeumata Aphoristica. Dee's hieroglyphic\nwas drawn in the form of a hand-glass, recalling his own magic mirror,\nused in scrying (fig. 17).15 The Monas Hieroglyphica was eventually published in Antwerp on 31 March 1564 and it was reprinted in the Theatrum\nChemicum (Strassburg: Lazarus Zetzner, 1609) which ensured a wide dispersal ofits influence in the early seventeenth century.16]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=42\nPages: 42,43\n7 Foucault, pp. 30-94.\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nThe obsessive belief in cabbalism lay in the hope that it would supply\nan empowering magical system for its initiates, both an assurance of the\ncontinued validity of medieval theurgy, as well as its regeneration. An\nexample ofthe conflict in the 1620s and 1630s generated by the emerging empiricist systems was the battle between the devout Paracelsian and\npro-Rosicrucian Robert Fludd and the French mechanicians Pierre Gassendi (1592-1655) and Marin Mersenne (1588-1648), as well as Johannes\nKepler (1571-1630). These prolonged and much-publicised debates are\nsome of the best evidence of the scale of emotional investment in late\nRenaissance analogical linguistics by those who aligned themselves with\nthe concept of the cabbalistic sage.8\nThe power of the late Renaissance esoteric philosopher rested on his]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=14\nPages: 14\nillustration. Since it is not possible to examine all the major alchemists of\nthe late Renaissance, the discussion will be confined to the cabbalistic\nmetaphysics and optical alchemy of four central figures, those of Dee,\nKhunrath, Maier and Fludd.\nCHAPTER ONE\nTHE SEMIOTIC STRUCTURES OF RENAISSANCE\nALCHEMICAL IMAGERY\nPrevious studies of Renaissance alchemical imagery have rarely involved\na discussion of its semiotic aspects, yet, without such an analysis it is\ndifficult to establish the exact role ofvisual illustration within a particular\ncontext. In the present case-studies, a variety of analytical tools is used\ndrawn from linguistics, structuralism and post-structuralism, such an eclectic approach being justified in the current state of research. For the\nimmediate objective, the most effective model has proved to be Peirce's\ntaxonomy of three fundamental types of sign, namely, those of symbol,\nicon and index. In addition, other types of analysis have been sampled,]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=43\nPages: 43,44\n89-95, 185-92. On Pico and Reuchlin see also Zika (1976) and Frick, Die Erleuchteten\n(1973), pp. 106-9. Guillaume Postel also makes the same identification in his commentary\non the Sefer Jezirah in the 1552 edition, see Sefer Jezirah (Paris, 1552), edited by Klein\n(1994), pp. 143-75.\n12 Fludd, UCH, \"Microcosm\", 2 (1621), Sect I, pp. 28-33.\n13 See Lachower and Tisby (1989), 1, pp. 268ff for an account ofthe process of emanation and also Frick (1973), pp. 97-101, pp. 319-22.\n60\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT\nJohn Dee by no means applied the whole of the original cabbalistic\nsystem in hisMonas Hieroglyphica and its theological implications are largely absent from his own design. Dee was more concerned with the specifics of the alchemical process and he used the cabbalah to weave an\nelegant demonstration of his more limited pantheism concerning the relation ofmicrocosm to macrocosm. The cabbalah also served to display his]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=9\nPages: 9\nmajor alchemists of the period, such as Khunrath and Maier, still await a\ndefinitive study.\nIn view of the fact that scholarly research into the alchemical discourse oflight is relatively little developed, the present study will attempt\nto redress this absence byfocusing on Renaissance ideas ofthe generative\npower ofthe light of the sun, stars and planets. Renaissance alchemists,\nsuch as Khunrath and Fludd, conceptualised the astral rays of light as\nbeing the agents ofthe \"anima Mundi\", the cosmic soul or \"Anthropos\",\nout of whose primeval substance, the quintessence or \"azoth\", the universe was generated. Cabbalistic alchemists, moreover, identified the cosmic Anthropos with Christ, whose sacred presence within the alchemical\nprocess transformed it into a sacramental act, paralleling that of the\nLutheran Eucharist.\nAlchemists, since hellenistic times, had relied on the effects of the\nstars, but a coherent theory ofthe astral virtues began to develop only in]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=74\nPages: 74\nnature, rather than with his hands.\nsine manuali cooperatione, solius Naturae laboribus\n(Khunrath, 1609: 201)\nInthe last stages ofthe alchemical process, he explains, when the purified\nbody and spirit ofthe materials are being re-united, the alchemist should\nuse the \"Olympian fire\" (Khunrath, 1608: 73-74). He refers less directly\nto the practice ofcatoptrics in the Amphiteatrum, informing the reader only\nthat he has to work in an occult manner with fire, or by means ofdivine\npower in a cabbalistic manner.224 This work takes three days to complete\nand it involves all the levels of creation, divine, macrocosmic and microcosmic (Khunrath, 1609: 203).\nThis catoptrical reference is related to John Dee's ideas, since in an\nearlier section ofthe Amphiteatrum, Khunrath had referred to Dee's cabbalism in the Propaedeumata Aphoristica and the Monas Hieroglyphica.\nHuc pertinet Cabalistarum Gimetria; Teusrasche; et Neoteriken. Sive (ut]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=8\nPages: 8\npietism, scholars, such as Peuckert and Stoeffler, have acknowledged that\nan important contribution was made by radical theologians of the late\nsixteenth century, such as Valentin Weigel and Johannes Arndt, who\nwere influenced by Paracelsian cabbalism.2 Weigel and his followers began to produce their own interpretations of scripture in which the sacramental rituals of the Lutheran Church and its demands for political authority increasingly appeared superfluous and objectionable.\nMost historians have neglected the contribution of the alchemists to\nthese distinctive and revolutionary theological movements, at best mentioning in passing figures such as Heinrich Khunrath (1560-1605),\nMichael Maier (1568-1622) and Robert Fludd (1574-1637). Yet, their\nParacelsian- cabbalistic metaphysics of light revolutionised contemporary\nalchemical theory, even prompting its adepts to deploy the rays of the]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=101\nPages: 101\nIn the second volume of the \"Microcosm\" (Frankfurt J. T. de Bry,\n1621) Fludd introduces the cabbalistic system, basing most of his argument on Reuchlin,35 but occasionally revealing the additional influence\nof Khunrath. The frontispiece to this volume was clearly inspired by de\nVries' praying alchemist in the Amphiteatrum, since Fludd's magus also\nprays before an emblem ofthe Tetragrammaton, borne within the divine\neye ofGod and bedecked with wings. It is enveloped by a cloud, forming\nan enclosure conceptually related to de Vries' depiction of the tabernacle-tent. Fludd seemed to empathise with this image since he returned to\nthe motif of the praying alchemist on several other occasions. A motto,\nostensibly attributed to Psalm 63, is inscribed on Fludd's frontispiece,\nreferring to the protective wings of God, \"In alarum tuarum umbra caram\", recalling the concluding line of the Rosicrucian Fama Fraternitatis,\n\"sub umbra alarum tuarum Jehova\".]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=40\nPages: 40,41\nscribbles written in haste, and they cannot provide a full picture ofDee's\nalchemy. They have to be read against the broader record of his intellectual life.\n52\n52 Halliwell, p. 50; Fenton, p. 267.\n53 Pagel (1982), p. 276.\n53\n54 For example, Paracelsus on antimony in Sudhoff, I, 3, pp. 275-76. See also J. R.\nPartington, A History ofChemistry (London : Macmillan, 1961), pp. 146-51 and BasilValentine, Der Triumph-WagenAntimonii (Leipzig, 1604). Suchten issued an influentialtexton\nantimony see Sudhoff, Bibliographia Paracelsica (1894), pp. 280-81.\n55 Pagel (1982), pp. 87: n. 230, 276-77.\n56 See Clulee, pp. 203-30; Clucas, \"Non est legendum sed inspicendum solum\" (1998),\nPP. pp. 109-32.\nCHAPTER FIVE\nJOHN DEE'S ALCHEMY OF LIGHT:\nTHE MONAS HIEROGLYPHICA AND THE CABBALAH\nParacelsian theosophy was related conceptually to other neoplatonised\nmetaphysical structures, such as the cabbalah, which entered the western\nphilosophical context in the early sixteenth century. The distant ancestor]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=47\nPages: 47\nout the aqueous moisture ofthe Moon and the fiery liquid of the Sun36\nThe alchemical theory ofthe Monas Hieroglyphica emerges from a Paracelsian cabbalistic context since by the 1560s Dee had redirected his studies\ninto the field of hermeticism which included Paracelsian alchemy. Despite this evidence, Debus has argued for a distinction between Dee's\nideas and those of Paracelsus on the grounds that Dee's treatises were\nbased on Pythagorean and Euclidean mathematical principles and had\nlittle in common with Paracelsian chemical theory.\n[if]John Dee exemplifies one way in which Hermetic, mystical, mathematical\nand alchemical strains were blended in Renaissance natural philosophy, Paracelsus may be chosen as a very different example... both claimed that their\nown interpretation of alchemy or chemistry would lead to a new understanding of nature.37\nDebus, however, considerably underestimated the Paracelsian influences\non Dee. An argument against his view is Szonyi's demonstration ofDee's]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=44\nPages: 44\ncabbalism, Dee perceived distinct benefits for alchemy, ensuring precision in correlating the effects of the heavens with the chemical process.\nYet, in the Monas Hieroglyphica there is relatively little mention of specific\nchemistry. Instead, Dee uses the planetary rays to perform his alchemical\noperations, defining his method as being an astronomical alchemy. In\nthis idea he was clearly influenced by Paracelsus' gnosticism in the\nAstronomia Magna, as well as by his theory of the illuminated imagination\nin the astral body communicating with the celestial macrocosm. It is\nessential to note that the graphic form of Dee's Monas (figs. 17, 18)\ndiffers entirely from the diagrammatic plans of astronomical star-charts,\nor of Lullian figures (figs. 4-7).17\nDee's Monas arose out ofthe context ofthe sixteenth century interest\nin devising secret cyphers which would act as an indexical bond between\nthe heavenly and the human spheres. 18 According to Szonyi, Ficino's]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=91\nPages: 91\nIn contrast to Dee, Khunrath and Fludd, Maier infrequently referred\nto the cabbalah, occasionally employing some general concepts, but never applying the system methodically. Instead, he based his alchemical\nprogramme on geometry, which was itself the subject of one of his earliest treatises on the Euclidean problem of squaring the circle, De Circulo\nPhysico, Quadrato (Oppenheim : Luca Jennis, 1616). Maier, like Khunrath,\nused the image ofthe squared circle as a theurgical sigil, representing the\nspiritual and alchemical union of opposites in the \"azoth\". A circle appears on the title-page of his treatise, bearing the names of the four\nuniversal qualities, \"calidum siccum frigidum humidum\", while a rectangle lists the four elements. The main subject of this essay is the Paracelsian theory of the universal panacea, the potable gold which ensured\nboth physical and spiritual health, due to its concordance ofthe macroand microcosms . These were signified by the sun, the human heart and]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=101\nPages: 101\nalarum tuarum\".38\nFludd explains the descent of the Tetragrammaton in the form of\ndivine light to create the material light of nature in a cabbalistic exegesis\nofthe Book ofGenesis (UCH, 2, 1621: 2-74). Although the discourse is not\nimmediately related to alchemy, this is implicit in his subsequent discussion of medical issues and meteorology. Fludd commences his cabbalistic\naccount with an examination of the principles of\"gematria\", mentioning\nReuchlin in this context.39 He also begins to employ the name ofChrist,\nas the Second Person of the Trinity (UCH, 2 1621: 2-5), relating him to\nthe angel Metattron who is stated to be the \"anima mundi\", or Anthropos (UCH, 2 1621, Tract II, Sect I: 8-9).40 Fludd equates the First Person\n(God the Father) with the first Hebrew letter of the Tetragrammaton,\n\"Jod\" (UCH, 2 1621: 8), the different levels of creation arising from the\nconstituent letters of the Tetragrammaton, \"Jod He Vau He\". Fludd]","[url_for_citation: https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=59\nPages: 59\nthese last treatises more closely to determine whether it is possible to\nestablish his motives in framing an alchemical discourse based on cabbalism .\nIn his \"Praefatio Apologetica\" to the Chaos Khunrath introduces his\ntheology of light in the same terms as in the Amphiteatrum of 1595. He\nstates that one should view the light of nature through the Light ofGod.\nIch zu sehen und ausszunehmen das Licht der Natur/ in Deinem Liecht/ O\nGott ! der du ein Liecht bist (Chaos: f. Aijr)\nKhunrath mentions the \"third figure\" ofthe Amphiteatrum, explaining that\nit depicts the philosopher's stone. It may be possible to identify this\n\"figure\" as being that of de Vries' circular engraving of a laboratory,\nfor in a margin note Khunrath refers to a \"vestibulum\" (hall), as well as\nto a \" ianua\" (doorway) as drawn in his \"third figure\" (frontispiece).22\nHe informs the reader that to understand the third figure it is necessary\nto be a theologian in the oratory and an alchemist in the laboratory.]"]}
ChatGPT
In *"The Alchemy of Light,"* the relationship between Cabbalism and alchemy is explored in several contexts, focusing on how cabbalistic metaphysics influenced alchemical practices during the Renaissance. Key points include: 1. Cabbalistic Alchemy in Khunrath's Work: Heinrich Khunrath's alchemy was deeply rooted in cabbalistic and Christian theosophy. He relied on the works of Johannes Reuchlin, incorporating cabbalistic ideas into his own alchemical system. Khunraths vision of alchemy as a spiritual and mystical process was informed by the Zohar, a key text in Jewish cabbalah, which linked the divine light to the creation of the world. Khunraths alchemical process mirrored this divine light, aiming to unite matter and spirit through the philosopher's stone: > "Khunrath... produced a fully-developed cabbalistic 'alchemy of light' in three of his works, published as the Amphiteatrum Sapientiae Aeternae (1595; 1609), Chaos (circa 1598), and De Igne Magorum (circa 1602-1604)." [Urszula Szul, page 11](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11). 2. Christological Influence in Cabbalistic Alchemy: Khunrath's alchemical approach placed Christ at the center of his cabbalistic philosophy. He associated Christ with the light of divine wisdom and considered him to be the source of both spiritual and material transformation. This Christological framework was essential in Khunrath's theosophical alchemy, as he developed it in response to anti-Christian tendencies within the hermetic circles of his time: > "Khunrath... placed his cabbalism within a Christological framework, so much so that his main concern... was not alchemical theory, but pietistic Christian theology." [Urszula Szul, page 11](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11). 3. Robert Fludd and Cabbalistic Alchemy: Robert Fludd continued this tradition, using cabbalistic symbols and ideas in his alchemical writings. He equated the Tetragrammaton (the Hebrew name of God) with the creation of material light, positioning it as a divine force that permeated the cosmos. Fludds work also reflects an integration of cabbalistic gematria (numerology) with alchemical principles, emphasizing the mystical unity of God and creation through the descent of divine light: > "Fludd introduces the cabbalistic system... explaining the descent of the Tetragrammaton in the form of divine light to create the material light of nature in a cabbalistic exegesis of the Book of Genesis." [Urszula Szul, page 101](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=101). This cabbalistic-alchemical synthesis is a key feature in Renaissance alchemy, intertwining mystical, religious, and scientific elements. For further reading, you can refer to [page 11](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=11) and [page 101](https://myaidrive.com/hs65vjuNRbfJrJRj9xCPd3/Urszula-Szul.pdf?pdfPage=101).
You
continue the summary of the book

Rider, 1925.\nWalker, Daniel Pickering, Spiritual and Demonic Magic from Ficino to Campanella,\nLondon: Warburg Institute, 1958.\nWalton, Michael, \"Geometrical Cabala\", Ambix (1976): 116-23.\nWarburg, Aby, Italienische Kunst und internazionale Astrologie im Palazzo Schifanoia zu\nFerrara, Rome, 1922.\nWarburg, Aby, Orientalisierende Astrologie, Leipzig, 1927.\nWarburg, Aby, \"La Rinascita del Paganesimo Antico\" in Gesammelte Schrifte, London: Warburg Institute, 1966.
